PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Leaded Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
(1)Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
(2)Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

(3)Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
(4)Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the House take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 73 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 76 citizens) and Mr Sinclair (from six citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Western Australians are opposed to any form of title based on a High Court decision and based on eligibility being determined by racial origin.
2.The majority of Australians acknowledge the specific rights granted by the Mabo decision.

3.The issue of whether potential claims for native title should be allowed in any other place, or whether all Australians should have equal right to acquire land under the established laws of the States and Territories—as applied pre-Mabo—should be decided by a referendum of all the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cameron (from 16 citizens), Mr Filing (from 91 citizens) and Mr Prosser (from 50 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
(1)discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
(2)increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
(3)adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
(4)breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 142 citizens) and Mr Bruce Scott (from 81 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 21 citizens) and Mr Hawker (from 99 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Playgroup: Mudgee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, mainly being the electors of the Division of Gwydir, respectfully draws to the attention of the House that a new facility is needed for the continued service of Playgroup in Mudgee. Continuing fund raising ventures have been undertaken over a period of years by a small but dedicated group of volunteers, and will continue to be organised but Government assistance in the form of funding is now being requested.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House is forthcoming with its decision to grant financial funding so the new Playgroup Hall may be completed on the corner of Maderia Road and Aitkenson Street, Mudgee.

PETITION.TITLE: Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia calls upon the House to:
1.Ensure its members cease promoting Australia to become a Republic and to firmly uphold and maintain the existing Australian Constitution 1901 in its entirety and
2.Oppose any move to remove the Queen of Australia as the Head of State.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that certain persons wish to change the National Flag of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request that no change to the National Flag of Australia be made without a full referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Bears
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears, for these purposes, to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Screening
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Overwhelming evidence is now available in Australia to indicate breast cancer can be treated and many deaths can be avoided if screening takes place early enough.
2.Many Australian women are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to be able to undertake mammography screening.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House requests the Federal Government to undertake an urgent review of the present policies with a view to introducing expanded mammography screening services and including them in the schedules to attract medical benefits.

PETITION.TITLE: Mr Nguyen Ly Tuong
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the City of Melbourne draws to the attention of the House that Mr. Nguyen Ly Tuong of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam was arrested on 4 June 1992 after attending a Catholic Mass in Thanh Da church in Ho Chi Minh City.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to express concern to the Government Authorities in the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam that Mr. Nguyen Ly Tuong may be a prisoner of conscience detained for the peaceful expression of his religious and political beliefs, a right guaranteed under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) to which Viet Nam acceded in 1982 and recognised in Articles 50 and 60 of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam Constitution.

PETITION.TITLE: Sky-Rail Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth.

"We believe the grave decision to support the Sky-Rail project between Cairns and Kuranda through the Barron Gorge National Park and World Heritage listed area was based on a narrow set of criteria, incorrect information, and information that has since been discredited."

PETITION.PARA: Your petitions therefore Humbly Pray that the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia will

PARA.TAB: "Review the procedure under which the Sky-Rail proposal has been approved and if not reject the development outright, at least require that an E.I.A. be conducted on this proposal."

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will every Pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note that our Constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society
Your Petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Child-Care Guidelines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.We are opposed to the childcare guidelines issued by the National Childcare Accreditation Council and the Keating Government, and

2.In particular we find offensive the guidelines relating to Christmas Carols and the misconceived gender statements relating to children's toys. We believe that childcare should first and foremost reflect the values of parents and not trendy childcare theorists.
We therefore call upon the House to reject the guidelines as they are currently drafted.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: 1. We believe that our current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of our Nation's history.
2. Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note that our Constitution based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners therefore request that:

PARA.TAB: a. There be no change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag
b. Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Youth Homeless Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1. We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2. We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3. With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a great commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: Off-Road Diesel Fuel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

1. Users of off road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel
2. We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an administration fee, to have that money returned to us as a rebate
3. This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: St Stephen's House
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of South Australia draws to the attention of the House the impending closure of St. Stephen's House in Adelaide because of the withdrawal of Government funding through a restructuring of the Supported Accommodation assistance program in this state. This service has provided accommodation and support for a particularly disadvantaged group of homeless young people, many of whom have mental health problems. The need for such a service has recently been highlighted by the Human Rights Commission Inquiry into Human Rights and Mental Illness.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to make available the resources needed to ensure that this valuable service is able to continue.
Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Mr Snow:
That:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)Australia is over-governed with three levels of government in a nation which is geographically, demographically and socially one;
(b)since Federation there has been a continuing transfer of power from State to federal government;
(c)local government is an essential level of government and natural base for distribution of many services now being provided by State and federal governments; and
(d)State governments hinder rather than provide good government, increase the opportunity for corruption, confuse responsibility and accountability and reduce the sovereignty of the people; and
(2)this House calls on the Executive to:
(a)develop a strategy and a plan to continue the process of transfer of power from State governments but to both federal and local governments;

(b)initiate action to phase out State governments, to base reformed local government on less than a hundred population centres throughout Australia and to provide constitutional recognition and Senate representation for local government; and
(c)thoroughly examine all options for reforming the structure of local government to ensure that it provides democratic, efficient and accountable representation to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Speaker, I thank my colleagues for enabling me to continue on this matter and speak a second time. There are two or three issues which I want to raise but, predominantly, I wish to deal with a possible structure, as I see it, with two tiers of government in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken at length on the inconsistencies and the problems that people have. For instance, a plumber who came to New South Wales from Victoria could not practise in his trade for at least one year because he could not obtain registration. There are many inconsistencies and problems. I have spoken about the huge mice plague in Victoria and South Australia, which was extremely costly, with one state enabling a poison to be used but another state not permitting the poison to be used; and I pointed out that mice do not know boundaries and that this created huge problems in both states.

Since that time, the Business Council of Australia has drawn attention to a number of inconsistencies. I instance the maritime industry in New South Wales. It has been pointed out that there has been a huge increase to the New South Wales government in funds obtained from the maritime industry, so that microeconomic reform has been wiped out by state taxes. Costs have gone up from $15 million in 1989 to $64 million in 1993 because the state has ripped off benefits from the maritime industry where there was supposed to be coordinated action for microeconomic reform.

Similarly, in regard to electricity, New South Wales has been reluctant to cooperate with an eastern grid between Tasmania and Queensland—reluctant to cooperate because it is ripping off about $300 on average from each household through an electricity tax on industry and households through New South Wales; that is, $300 each being ripped off to keep the state going. I said that at least $10 billion could be saved by rationalising government in Australia.

While we are talking about reform, at least the Business Council of Australia is showing less hypocrisy than a number of other industry organisations and less hypocrisy than a lot of people in government. The Business Council has pointed out how the Special Premiers Conference in 1990-91 tried to see movement towards international policy making in the reaction of states to decisions made in that conference. The council pointed out that the South Australian Liberal Party rejected the mutual recognition package negotiated in the forum. Western Australia has yet to pass legislation ratifying the Commonwealth act involved in those reforms, according to the January-February 1994 issue of the Business Council Bulletin. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the States had agreed on a national scheme whereby all legal challenges. . . be commenced in the Supreme Court of Queensland.

Then we have the Western Australian Supreme Court warning of `substantial impairment of the rule of law as a foundation of democracy'—as if democracy is dependent on a government in each state and a court that is separate in each state. The Business Council says:
Where Australia's international competitiveness is at stake, the call for `national' solutions comes from industry.
I am quoting from an address by Gary L. Sturgess, the former Director-General of the Cabinet Office of the New South Wales government, reported in that Business Council Bulletin.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, it is possible for us to get more democracy—in fact, it is likely that we will get more democracy—by the sort of rationalisation of government that I am talking about. We could have one court system, a national court system, including environmental, family support, and a wide range of important issues, with the local courts as we have now. We certainly need to have, and could have, local assemblies. In fact, the Australian assistance plan developed by the present Governor-General showed just how local assemblies, local groups of people, could be involved in important democratic reform.

We could have precinct committees with local council committees that may be elected. But the basis ought to be county councils or, as someone called them, regional assemblies. Those assemblies or county councils could appoint people to meet with the local council committees. They could ensure that local resident assemblies were convened and that the county members, or electorate members in the case of the national parliament, could meet with them. These groups could have the right to initiate referenda with signed petitions of minimum numbers of residents.

These county councils or regional assemblies could administer not only local policies but many of the national policies on a local level. I am not advocating a particular structure but suggesting a possible structure to show that it could be democratic and it could be effective and efficient. I am suggesting a minimum of 65,000 electors in an area with natural boundaries based on a city—a fairly large city—because in that way it will work and we will have a natural regional centre. For instance, Melbourne and Sydney could be one county or region each. Maybe the whole of the state of Tasmania could be one county. Those counties could vary in full-time members from five to 50. The mayor and the deputy could be directly elected by the people or by the council, and the council would monitor all departments, which must respond to questions from council when they are operating in a local area. The council could decide local emphases and approve development and other appropriate activities, including present federal, state and local responsibilities if they are appropriate. The members could be rostered to local council committees and they could delegate appropriate responsibilities to those local council committees. But those local council committees are part of the county or regional structure and must link into it and, as I said, the full-time members would be rostered to meet with those local committees so it is all knitted together.

Those councils, depending on their population, could appoint from their members between one and 10 full-time senators, and we could have a national senate, as we do now, with fewer than 100 members from those councils, and that senate could coordinate local policies. It would disburse funds, as I see it; it could prepare budgets and submit them to the House of Representatives; or the councils could, as the Business Council of Australia suggested one or two years ago, raise their own funds on a national basis, but the amount would need to be agreed to by the House of Representatives, which ought to be able to check, for instance, for approved borrowing levels in international borrowing, and maybe check as well to ensure equity.

We would continue with national electorates, although I believe there ought to be more flexibility so that the electorates could have between 65,000 and 75,000 people and boundaries could approximate as closely as possible local boundaries. There might be more federal members in some local council areas than others. We would have the House of Representatives continuing as now, formulating national policies and endorsing national budgets both from the executive and from the Senate. When budgets are not agreed to, there could be a joint parliamentary sitting of both the parliaments, the Senate and the House of Representatives, and that joint sitting may well be involved in the appointment of a head of state.

These suggestions have no relationship whatsoever to whether we are republic or not; they could happen equally if we were a republic or if we are a monarchy. But it could be a responsibility of the joint parliament to appoint a head of state; to endorse budget expenditure, especially where there is dispute; and to allocate funds to councils if there is a dispute between the two parliaments. It could be chaired by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, with the casting vote available to the Speaker.

This whole suggestion, I believe, merits consideration. The Business Council of Australia a year or so ago stated that we ought to be able to get all this together, and Gary Sturgess, formerly of the New South Wales Premier's Department, is saying that it seems as if the Australian people want the states—although when I go round I find they do not—and therefore we have to try to get more cooperation. We can certainly compete better if we compete on the basis of natural geographic boundaries. That is what we ought to be doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is certainly something refreshingly honest about the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). He has no hidden agenda and he certainly says what he believes. Indeed, on many occasions in this place he has very clearly put forward a point of view which is highly unpopular. I oppose the motion on reforming the structure of government which has been moved by my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. What the honourable member is suggesting in his motion is that the constitutional structures as we know them today, the constitutional structures which have guaranteed this nation the stability it has, should be torn up. In particular, the motion is a revamp of Whitlam's much discredited policy which sought to set up regions controlled by Canberra to replace the sovereign states which, of course, as we all know, derive their authority from the Australian constitution.

PARA.TAB: This approach is not new to the Australian Labor Party, and many people on the government benches hold a similar attitude. I recall a particular interjection by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), who seconded the motion supporting the abolition of the states. Ben Chifley, a Labor icon in this country, also supported the centralisation of power in Canberra. Many years ago he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I favour abolition of state parliaments and greatly extended powers given to locally governing authorities.

Canberra, of course, would have controlled the purse strings. So much for `greatly extended powers given to local authorities'. Those people who advocate the abolition of the federal system as we know it today really mean that we should scrap the states, and all the constitutional protection and constitutional authority given to them, and transfer the powers that they have to Canberra. Some of those powers would then be allocated to regions but, of course, the overall controlling force would be the government in Canberra. Regions would merely be local agents for the implementation of centrally imposed policies.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Eden-Monaro is taking the centralist agenda of the Australian Labor Party to the extreme. He is introducing a radical plan to abolish all state and territory governments. He wants to scrap the more than 900 local government authorities in Australia and replace them with about 100 regional authorities. Of course, as I said a moment ago, ultimate power would reside in the federal government, and in the hands of a group of unrepresentative and out of touch Labor politicians.
The honourable member does, however, deserve full credit for persistence and for consistency in relation to this matter. In 1990, the honourable member moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian federal system is costly and inefficient, impedes social justice and fairness and should be replaced by a two-tier system consisting of reformed and strengthened national and local government structures.
The honourable member then cited some major problems that he saw with our federal system. They included that:

a plumber registered in Victoria cannot practise or operate in New South Wales . . . a person can be fined for turning right in front of someone turning left in New South Wales and fined for doing the opposite in Victoria.
I suspect he is not referring to politics. The member said that he moved the motion because:
people do not have power over their governments; they do not have sovereignty.

I know the honourable member mentioned in his address just a moment ago that perhaps a better system would be to have a provision for citizen initiated referenda at all levels of government. This would certainly return sovereignty to the people.

PARA.TAB: One could not dispute that the federal government is running amuck and out of control and that people do not have any power over it. Honourable members only have to look at the letters to the editor columns in the newspapers, listen to talkback radio programs, or look at the commentary in newspapers and in other media outlets to know that people are frustrated. People do not believe that they have any say at all in how we, as a nation, are governed.

I think that both people who vote for the government and those who vote for us will all agree that the federal government is remote, it is unrepresentative and it is out of touch. State governments and local authorities are, however, closer to their people and more likely to represent their views than is their federal counterpart. It should not, of course, be forgotten that almost half of the members of the House of Representatives come from the Sydney and Melbourne areas.

Obviously there are problems in relation to interstate registrations of plumbers, and we obviously need more uniform road rules, but these sorts of matters can be addressed, and indeed are being addressed, by cooperation among levels of government. I think it is a fairly sad commentary on Australian society that the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) used as one of his vehicles for running over the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, his opposition to Hawke's new federalism policy. That policy sought to have a very sensible approach among all levels of government so that the kinds of difficulties outlined by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro could be harmoniously addressed.

Already in most portfolio areas we have standing committees of various state and territory ministers. For instance, we have the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and much progress has been made in standardising laws and procedures within our federal system. More needs to be done. For instance, Australia really requires a national curriculum for schools but I understand that this matter is now being addressed. We can solve these problems within our system without tearing up the constitution which has served us so well.

There is no point in throwing the baby out with the bathwater. Australia is a vast country and our existing state, territory and local governments are more likely to represent the views and aspirations of their constituencies than a remote, centralised, monolithic structure based in Canberra and controlled by the people of Sydney and Melbourne through the very large number of representatives they have in this place.

It is always interesting to hear government members talk about sovereignty and independence. We all know what a sham the Prime Minister's republican push is. He talks about our becoming an independent nation whereas every day of the week we find the executive in this country entering into more and more international treaties, many of which subvert Australia's international independence. We find that there can now be appeals from the courts of this country to United Nations committees.

In effect, what they are doing in many cases is subverting our independence and eroding our sovereignty, and yet we find government members coming into this place and saying that Australia should be independent, that we should give more sovereignty to the people. I wish they would be upfront and honest. I wish they would admit that many of the steps taken by the executive in this country, by the government of this country, in effect are taking away the sovereignty and independence of Australia as a nation.

Our current system of government may not be perfect—there is always room for improvement—but as yet no-one, to my knowledge, has suggested that there is a system which is any better. Over the last few years we have seen a trend globally, but particularly in central and eastern European, towards decentralisation of authority. People in those countries are rejecting systems of centralised government because they have utterly failed. Despite that we find the honourable member for Eden-Monaro marching into this place and suggesting that we should have more centralisation and not less centralisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I know he is saying that we are going to have a federal parliament and we are going to have regions, but he has to admit that the ultimate governmental authority will reside in the federal parliament. If it wants to dictate some aspect of governmental activity, some aspect of policy, then the dictate will come down from the top and the local regions will become administrative units of the central government. I think that that is not what the people of Australia want. In fact, if the government sought to put that to a referendum then that idea would certainly very strongly be rejected.

PARA.TAB: Our form of government is not perfect and could be improved. I am not an apologist for the current system in the sense that I say it is perfect in all respects. But no-one has devised a better system. Our system has an effective series of checks and balances. It denies any individual, including the Prime Minister of this nation, too much power. What the Prime Minister wants, with his republican push, is to centralise all power in Canberra, all power in his own hands. I think that we should go forward as a nation and see how we can improve things, but quite frankly the proposals of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro would be an unmitigated disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech we have just heard from the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) was the sort of speech I would expect from honourable members on the other side when we talk about macro-economic reform. They are more than happy to impose that kind of reform on workers and ordinary people, but they run away from the reform which will improve efficiency in this country and save billions of dollars for business.

PARA.TAB: What are we talking about in this debate? Let me give the House an example, for which I will use the island state of Tasmania. In doing that, let me clearly say that I am not drawing any conclusions by using Tasmania. It is a wonderful part of Australia, but Tasmania can very easily provide the summary for what is wrong with government in Australia. It might interest honourable gentlemen opposite to know that in 1988 there were 302,333 voters enrolled by the Electoral Commission in Tasmania. Tasmania has a Legislative Assembly of 35 members and a Legislative Council of 19 members, and in 1988 each member of the Tasmania state parliament represented 5,598 enrolled voters.

As an originating state of the Australian federation, Tasmania is entitled to a minimum of five members of the House of Representatives and representation equal to the other states in the Senate, so that gives it 12 senators—that is, Tasmania has one senator for every 25,194 voters. Each Tasmanian member of the House of Representatives represents some 10,000 voters fewer than the mainland equivalent. The pay is the same, mind you.

If honourable members think that is a little rough, another figure is that in Tasmania there are 49 local government bodies—and that is in 1976 figures. There is a local council for every 8,072 enrolled voters, so honourable members should sit back and work out how many councillors there are in the 49 councils and how many people each councillor represents. That is what is wrong with government in Australia today. The cost of running Tasmania impacts on the mainland states. Tasmania receives Commonwealth grants that per capita are seven times greater than those for my state of Victoria. It is not that I do not support fiscal distributions, but the example I have given shows that we in Victoria are paying for inefficient government in Tasmania. In fact, it can be argued that the largest industry in Tasmania is government—an unproductive industry—and right throughout Australia a similar situation is occurring.

In my home state of Victoria there are now 205 councils. In my electorate, the council of Pyalong represents 625 people; it has a shire hall, a shire engineer and a shire secretary. The Cain government, to its credit, tried to reform government. It went through a consultative program, but it was a mistake because the conservatives objected to it; all those rural councillors with their little patches of dirt objected to it. There was a great furore throughout Victoria, as the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) will well remember, as he was then in the opposition to the Victorian government and probably was opposing such reform.

Now the Kennett government, to its credit, is doing that reform. It is not asking anyone—there is no consultation—but it is just ramming home the reform, which will, hopefully, reduce the number of councils in Victoria. The savings can be huge. Billions of dollars can be saved from the reform of government and the removal of regulations from business. It is the macro-reform that everyone is too frightened to tackle. The opponents of reform are always the conservatives.

I was a member of the intergovernmental committee when it existed. That was a committee which was established by state and federal governments to look at reform of government. It was funded by state and federal governments. Its offices were in Hobart and I was this parliament's representative until 1988 when, because the states refused to give any more funding, it was abolished. As usual, the states wanted the Commonwealth to pick up the entire tab. So I have bit of history on the reform of government.

That committee produced a number of reports identifying areas where savings could be made. I am not talking about mickey mouse savings but big money—big savings for business, big savings for the community at large—through macro reform. The usual snide comments are coming from the other side. Those opposite want macro reform for the wage earner, but they will not look at macro reform—through constitutional reform and government reform—for the country. Through its research the intergovernmental committee has all the evidence we need to establish the case for government reform; it is unarguable.

I will give another example of the need for reform. There are four state seats wholly or partly within the boundaries of my federal electorate of McEwen, an area of roughly 20,000 square kilometres. Each one has a state member of parliament. The Victorian parliament—do not ask me why—still has an upper house. For each lower house seat there is an upper house seat with two representatives. So within the boundaries of my federal seat there are nine state members of parliament, all being paid at the same rate as a federal member, less $500. That was a pretty good trick the state pulled years ago—we cop the blame; they get the pay.

As I said, there are nine state members of parliament within the boundaries of my federal seat. It takes nine state members to do what one federal member does. But what is the reaction when this parliament talks about reforming government? We hear, `No, we will not go down that track and save money for people'. We do not hear of any serious attempt to remove restraints on business. And why is that? The answer is: vested interest, as the Cain government found out when it tried to reform government. The conservatives—the rural National Party councillors there—went off their cotton-picking brains about it; they really did.

The states of Australia are accidents of history—that is all they are. They were six independent colonies that did not like each other or get along with each other and were forced to federate because of the threat of Russian invasion. If honourable members opposite had learned their history, they would understand that the boundaries are artificial and have no relevance whatsoever to the economic needs of Australia today.

For those who do not know, the border between Victoria and South Australia is the southern bank of the Murray River. That is an anachronism. The Murray River, like all big rivers, changes course; the southern bank moves. So is the border the southern bank at flood, the southern bank at low water, or the southern bank plus the bit of land on the other side where the natural watercourse forms a sort of a levee system? What is the border? As a lawyer who formerly practised in the Murray River area, I can tell the House that the question is not a joke; it raises enormous constitutional problems for all the towns along the Murray River. For example, if a body is found somewhere on the Murray, there is a dispute about who retrieves it and which police force handles the investigation.

Do we need this in the 20th century? Do we really need that kind of restraint, that kind of stupidity between the states, when surely we are today a national entity with a national government—a country identified as Australia? Yet every time anyone stands up and says, `Reform of government is a necessity', what do we get? For a start, those opposite will oppose it.

I recall Malcolm Fraser, when he was Prime Minister, supporting reform of section 24 of the constitution, the nexus, which requires Senate representation to be half the number of the House of Representatives. That means we now have 12 senators for each state instead of the original 10. Malcolm Fraser supported reform of section 24 and his party supported reform of section 24 because that made commonsense. When it went to a referendum, what did honourable members on the other side of the House do? Typically, they opposed it. So section 24 still exists and we cannot reform the number of lower house seats because to do so would mean increasing Senate representation—and who needs more senators? It is supposed to be a states house, so why should there be more? Why should Tasmania have 12 senators when it has only 305,000-odd enrolled voters?

Do honourable members opposite support reform like this? Never. Their history is one of constant argument against reform and macro reform of government. It is time all of us in this place fought for it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government speakers today, and in this debate last November, have affirmed the true nature of this motion as they have waffled their way through the issues. Of course, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) is the greatest exponent of that waffling that we find in the House.

PARA.TAB: The motion is a transparent sham and it is an ideological regurgitation for more centralised political and economic control from Canberra. It is certainly not what the motion implies. It is not about reforms, whether those reforms be in terms of efficiency, greater democracy or, importantly, accountability enhancements.

Therefore, the motion has the same function as the sports rorts whiteboard of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) as she revealed last evening. It is philosophically driven. It is full of political bias. It is subjective. It is a figment of someone's imagination. It is ethically bankrupt and, most importantly, it flouts our constitutional foundation and practices. As my colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said, in part, in November:

The honourable member would have us go full circle. He abolishes the state governments and almost all municipalities to satisfy his `overgoverned' complaint, and then he finds that his new structure can work effectively only by creating an administrative system almost identical, but with different names, to the one that he has abolished.

Our constitution relies on splitting legislative power between the States and the Commonwealth. This means that the States and only the states can make laws about certain things . . . and only the Commonwealth can legislate about certain other things . . .

Separating law-making in this way was seen by those who framed the Constitution as a way of checking a central government's power, or reducing the changes of government tyranny. This is the basic premise of federalism and is as relevant today as it was when James Madison advocated this form of government during the debates over the adoption of the American Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: However, arguments can be made to the effect that a constitution framed in the days of the horse and buggy might not be relevant in all its detail in the 1990s. Indeed, the High Court has responded to this argument but only by granting more and more legislative powers to the Commonwealth. This can be seen, of course, in the court's treatment of the external affairs and corporations powers.

PARA.TAB: It is not surprising, therefore, that the overlapping of functions and consequent bickering about divisions between the tiers of government have gone on since federation, coming formally on the public agenda in referendums and the constitutional discussions that have emerged over many years. As Robert Garran, in his book Prosper the Commonwealth, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It ought not to be difficult to express in the text of the Constitution the intention to devolve on the states part of the responsibility for the administration of federal laws. It may be difficult to educate our federal administrators to a self-discipline which will counter their natural inclination to keep all the strings in their own hands. But I do not think that even that need be impossible.
At the academic level, Hugh Emy has said:

When I came from Britain to Australia in 1969, I must confess that my belief in federalism was lukewarm. I was struck more by its inefficiencies or irrationalities. There seemed to be too many politicians, too many demarcation disputes over which government should do what, a good deal of administrative overlap and blurred lines of accountability—
and wait for it—

having now lived in Australia for over twenty years, I am more convinced of the existence of significant socio-cultural and economic differences between the states. While recognising that the efficiency of state administration often leaves much to be desired, I am more sceptical of the kind of `rationality' sometimes exhibited by Canberra bureaucrats . . .
He finished by saying:
. . . twenty years on, I have a greater regard for `old-fashioned' constitutional principles such as separation of powers and [their associated] checks and balances.
At the political level, the then South Australian Labor Premier, John Bannon, said in a 1986 oration:
Garran's statement provides the basis for a fundamental move towards innovative democracy—
note that he said `innovative democracy'—
and offers a real chance to `do it better'.
In his 1990-91 new federalism strategy, the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, also said:
But the experience of the years tell us that there are important services which would be improved if the Federal Government were not directly involved in their delivery.
He said that there were two objectives, and he explained what those objectives were, but he made this point:
It is a national strategy; but the co-operation of the States and local government is essential . . .

Of course, it is now history to note that Bob Hawke was forced to castrate his new federalism initiative by the highly effective intervention of his then leadership rival, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who ensured that any future move to correct the imbalance between the Commonwealth and the states would not enjoy a bipartisan climate. The honourable member for Blaxland warned at the time that a possible substantial increase in state revenue powers under the new federalism and the consequent dismembering of the national government were—to use his words—`one of the gravest dangers we face as a nation'. He went on:

This is an agenda being pushed by federalists who don't believe in a national economy, in a national government, who want to turn back the clock to the 19th century. When I was Treasurer, I made it clear that I would never append my name to an Executive Council minute giving power to the States. This has no chance. It's not on. Not for the Labor Party. Not for the Australian people.

However, only last week, Labor Premier Goss of Queensland, when he warned the federal government that it had failed to reform federal-state financial relations and that the Council of Australian Governments could fold this year, said that the bulk of COAG achievements during the past three years—such as the national electricity grid, the national training authority and the creation of the Australian Financial Institutions Commission—resulted from `the co-operation and leadership of the states'.

PARA.TAB: He went on to say that Commonwealth involvement was not essential, `because the issues related to matters that were state responsibilities'. He said federally created bureaucratic structures designed to `look over the shoulders of the states'—and note that this is one of the government's own mob talking—were ridiculous and needed to be eliminated, and that the federal government collected `far too much in the way of revenue and the states far too little'. He said that to survive COAG would have to `steer a middle course between a tired states rights drum and Canberra's disregard for its promise that the reform of the federal relationship would involve two-way traffic'. He finished by saying this:

SPEECH.PARA: Unless COAG continues to operate in a co-operative spirit, and unless COAG sees two-way traffic in terms of concessions being made—not only by the States but by the Commonwealth as well, particularly in the area of Commonwealth-State financial relations—then I think it simply will not survive . . .

He also said that the problem of vertical fiscal imbalance remained `unresolved'. This motion, therefore, has little to offer other than yet another tired philosophical and ideological whimper. It has the half-hearted support from the government colleagues of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). It is criticised roundly by high profile contemporary Labor leaders such as Wayne Goss. It simply mouths the `make it or break it' push by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as he perpetuates division and diversion. But, most importantly, it does not have the popular support of the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Undoubtedly, we do have too much government. To take up the point made by the honourable member for Fisher, I for one believe that we can use citizens' initiatives and referenda not as a replacement for, but as a strong supplement to, the Westminster system—and I make no apology for saying that publicly. This motion clearly fails its own tests and I firmly oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the speech by the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) only reinforces for me once again that the coalition is just not able to respond to the challenges of the 1990s, or to even countenance the problems that are faced by Australia today and the solutions that are needed to resolve them. Coalition members are simply out of date. It is glib to say that in this case they are still in the 19th century.

PARA.TAB: My electorate is not the most remote, but it is one of the most remote in Australia. It is a long way from Canberra, but the major centre of Cairns in my electorate is also a long way from Brisbane. In fact, people do not realise that Brisbane is closer to Melbourne than Brisbane is to Cairns. That is how far away we are. My electorate goes almost to the Papua New Guinea border—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been there—Cape York.

—Yes, it is further than Cape York. It goes to four kilometres from the Papua New Guinea border and, if there is any argument for regionalisation of Australia, one only has to look at the electorate in my part of the world. If we were to start again, no sensible person would suggest that we have the same boundaries. No-one would suggest that we have the same structures—
—They would.

—I am talking about sensible people; I am not talking about honourable members opposite. No-one would suggest that we have the same divisions of powers. Does the constitution refer to the modern telecommunications system that we have in Australia today? Does it contemplate or countenance national electricity grids? So if we were starting again, what would we do? We would obviously look at the sort of structure that is suggested by the motion of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow).

PARA.TAB: In the short time that I have I might refer to the coalition's shadow minister for local government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is it?

—It is Senator Macdonald, but he is quite a sham. He comes from up my way; he comes from Townsville. His solution to the problem is for a new state in North Queensland. This is his brilliant solution to the problem, which he stated publicly. This shadow minister for local government and the ACT is advocating a devolution of power away from local government to add some sort of antediluvian structure on to North Queensland. We do not want a new state.

PARA.TAB: I see the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) at the table. We do not want the structure they have in the Northern Territory; they have a similar structure. There are some members in the assembly in the Northern Territory who could take all their constituents out to dinner—every one of them. That is how small the electorates are in the Northern Territory. That is what would exist if there were new states throughout Australia. That is just ludicrous.

What is needed is what this motion says: to enhance the power of local government. I have to refer at this stage to the good work that has been done by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) to develop regionalisation in Australia, to get the councils—and in some areas it is a struggle—to talk about regionalisation, about the problems that are faced in the 1990s. That does not say that small communities do not have local problems. That is why we need some form of regional government, some form of government that is close to the people. But quite often the problems are of a regional nature and they are not necessarily—and quite often are not—based on those artificial boundaries that were drafted at the start of this century.

Of course, any change would be a slow process. That is why I congratulate the honourable member for Eden-Monaro on not suggesting that we should change overnight. He is saying that we should start thinking about these issues. But, of course, it seems that honourable members opposite do not even want to think about the issues that are raised in this motion—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a difficult process for them.

—That is right. There are huge problems. Day after day there are reports. The coastal zone inquiry by Mr Justice Stewart raised the very problems that are raised in the motion of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. It raised the problems of having the three levels of government to make decisions about a very precious resource in this country. (Time expired)

—I have only a very short time in which to speak—and I cannot possibly cover all the issues I would like to speak about—but I will do so with great passion and enthusiasm. As a former member of the Victorian parliament and, prior to that, as a legal practitioner in an area separated by the state border of New South Wales and Victoria, I am familiar with the frustrations and problems of unnecessary differences in law. As a former state minister for health, local government and planning and for minerals and energy and mines, and as a shadow minister for some of those areas as well, I can assure members of this House that I have a very passionate and strong belief in reform in this area.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons that I am here in this place is that I believe the systems of government throughout the whole of Australia need reform urgently. I believe that they have not been performing adequately and that, unless they do, the people of Australia will be entitled to demand, and will in fact receive, reform which may well throw the baby out with the bathwater. I can also tell the House—from my experience in life and from my experience of the various levels of government that I have worked with and been part of—that any tendency in Australia to further concentrate power in one large central government will be a grave error and a grave mistake. I cannot for any reason support the continuation of further centralism of government in Australia. I say that not as a member of the Liberal Party necessarily, but as an Australian and a regional Australian—as someone from the bush who knows the tyranny of distance, who knows how people can be disadvantaged because of the difficulties of communication and the extra costs and who also realises that the best form of government and the best outcome of government is one that is a true democracy, one that guarantees people access to their representatives, and one that guarantees accountability and scrutiny.

Very briefly, let us just look at the recent examples of what the continuation of increasing central government is doing to our democracy and to our parliament. Just this week we have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) withdraw from Question Time for two days of the four-day sitting week, under the guise of increasing scrutiny of his other ministers. But the fact is that, in making that claim on behalf of this massive central government that has grown in Australia, he is claiming, and misrepresenting, that the people have adequate scrutiny and opportunities, through their elected representatives, in Question Time to scrutinise the actions of the Prime Minister.

In fact, the number of sitting days of the House of Representatives and, therefore, the number of Question Times in this Commonwealth are dismally few; and the Prime Minister is going to reduce by 50 per cent the opportunity to question the first minister. This is an extraordinary illustration of what naked power can do. From my point of view and from experience, the less power central government has in basic matters, the better.

Furthermore, I would like to say that I do believe that we are overgoverned and I believe—and I have said for many years—that there are far too many state members of parliament. I was one of them and I was able to say that and put that on record while I was a state member of parliament. There is no doubt that each level of government needs a massive shake-up. What we really do need to achieve is cooperative federalism. That ought to be the challenge for all of us in the few years that remain in this century.

There are examples of a growing and encouraging tendency towards more cooperative federalism in Australia. That is coming about, might I add, because of the example of the people from the bush in regional Australia, such as in places in north-east Victoria, in Albury-Wodonga, and in the Riverina, where the communities are forgetting state borders and working together for common good. The outcomes are excellent.

We already have a basic health plan for Albury-Wodonga, virtually disregarding the state boundaries. I might add that that has been done with a lot of difficulty and opposition from some levels of bureaucracy. We already have a model for post-secondary education delivery across the border. We already have an excellent adult education service operating mainly from Wodonga, delivering services into New South Wales. All of those were achieved with great difficulty, I might add.

Can I say, however, that to our great shame for 30 years all the health ministers of Australia have been attempting to come up with uniform mental health law, and they have not been able to deliver. Yet there are grave problems in caring for people with mental illness in Australia. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the date will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House recognises the need for fair and just treatment of shares and investments owned by Australians of pensionable age in the context of social security and veterans' affairs payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the last speaker, the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), I know already that I do not have enough time. I have 10 minutes and, quite frankly, the impact on our pensioners and self-funding retirees is so drastic that I could speak for 10 hours rather than 10 minutes. I say to the House that we should be approaching this issue in a thoroughly bipartisan fashion. My concern in this debate is not to attack the government at all. Rather, I want to expose the frightful situation that is being experienced by so many elderly Australians because of the way the government's policy is impacting on them.

PARA.TAB: We all accept that governments have to raise money. The way these assets and income tests on pensions were worked was to save money for the government. We accept that, but it has gone horribly wrong and I am sure the government did not intend it to go horribly wrong. Because of that, I believe it is a great thing that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) yesterday announced that there would be a review of the income and assets tests relating to age, service, disability and sole parent pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well overdue.

—It is well overdue indeed, as my colleague says. While the terms of reference were agreed on in October, the actual appointment of consultants, Ageing Agendas, to conduct the review was announced only yesterday. I welcome that appointment and the first report is due in July this year. I hope that it also focuses on the extreme need to change the law on this matter so that elderly Australians are not disadvantaged by the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PARA.TAB: The first point I make is a generalisation. It is that pensioners are being hit by a double whammy; they are being hit with the double-dipping of taxation. It does not appear to have registered with the government just precisely what is being done. I will give the House an example. Mr and Mrs X have shares that increase in value. Because the shares have gone up, say, by $5 each, their pension is reduced because the amount of capital gain, or rise in the share value, is deemed as income. This is unjust, because they do not get the money until they sell the shares. Nonetheless, their pension is reduced by 50c in the dollar for the increase in their asset. That is a 50 per cent tax—there is no other way of describing it—because it is 50 per cent of each dollar being taken back from them.

That is the first part of the whammy. The double whammy comes when they eventually sell the shares and then they have to pay capital gains tax on the money on which they have already been taxed 50 per cent by having their pension reduced. I see the next speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), sitting in the chamber and he must agree that this is true, that this is the way it works. I am sure that when he speaks he will agree that this is not appropriate. This is one of the areas that must be changed. No member of this parliament can possibly agree with a situation where pensioners, whether they receive social security or veterans pensions, are chopped twice on their investment, first by having their pension reduced by 50c in the dollar, which is exactly a 50 per cent tax, and then again when they eventually sell the investment.

The number of people who have come to me is quite extraordinary. I cannot begin to tell honourable members how many people in my electorate alone—and I am sure in every other electorate in Australia—have been hurt and damaged financially and caused incredible extra worry and concern by the way this is working. It must be changed.

As an example, a couple from Coffs Harbour, who invested $25,000 in property trusts through MLC and $4,000 in the ANZ Bank, have had their combined pension reduced by $20 a fortnight. They are actually getting four per cent in cash, but Veterans' Affairs say that the dividend is netting them 25 per cent and 27 per cent respectively. This is totally crazy. Another couple at Bonville say in a letter:
In April last year I applied for and received a part pension paying $103 per week. The Government then changed policy on share type investments and my pension was cut to $17 per week.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why the pension was cut from $103 to $17 was that the department valued the investments as bringing in an income of $27,813 for the year. That is not a bad income. However, the reality was that that couple only received $8,900. Where is the justice in that? Where is the equity that we are all so concerned about in this parliament? That couple's pension was reduced from $103 to $17 because, although their actual income was $8,900, they were assessed as getting $27,813.

PARA.TAB: Another instance is of a man from Nambucca Heads who sold a number of good quality shares when the provisions were announced in September 1992. He was, of course, disappointed at the backdown. As he says:

SPEECH.PARA: You can imagine my disappointment when the Government backed away from that a week or two before the implementation of the "unrealised capital gain" thing . . .
I would though like to air my displeasure at the Government's handling of this matter.
The Government waited until September 1993 to reverse its policy, re unrealised capital growth/ Income Testing, on shares purchased prior to August 19 1992 . . .
In my opinion the Government should make amends by allowing those so affected the option to repurchase shares up to equal value of the same kind of shares they sold.
Part of the injustice is that people were forced into a position where they thought they had to sell their shares.
Another couple from Kempsey wrote to me about their situation. They said:
We had the first deduction of $60-00 a week in September, 1993 . . . now they have reduced it again another $30-00 . . . we are Part Pensioners receiving a monthly payment from G.I.O Trust No2 . . .
We find that this is grossly unfair Legislation which discriminates against Pensioners and Superannuants.

It certainly does. Another example is from a lady from Nambucca Heads. Her situation was that in 1992 she was receiving a part pension equivalent to $4,300 a year, plus benefits. In 1993 she received a letter from the Department of Social Security informing her that it had cancelled the entire pension and benefits. She was told that the estimate of what she may receive in income from investments was $61,500. That was what the department said she was going to receive. Her actual taxable income, as per her tax return, was only $23,600.

PARA.TAB: I could go on and on with examples. There are so many people who are in this situation. A gentleman from Coffs Harbour wrote to me. His wife receives a part age pension and an income from managed investments. She had a declining return from investments, and the pension has been reduced. The Department of Social Security estimated their income at $1,800 more than they actually received. And so it goes on.

Another couple from Urunga first received the age pension in August 1992. Their income from a GIO monthly income trust was $778 per month, and from the pension was $249. The income from the trust from August 1992 to January 1994 ranged from $714 to $778 per month. The pension rose from $249 to $262 in July 1993. In September 1993 it was reduced to $205, and in January 1994 it was reduced to $170. And this is just one of the many situations that exist.

Another couple from Coffs Harbour received identical dividends of $50.07 quarterly over the last 12 months, a total of $200.28. That is $7.70 per fortnight. However, the Department of Veterans' Affairs says they are earning at the rate of 17.13 per cent per unit, or $16.49 per fortnight. They actually get $7.70 cash in hand per fortnight, but the department says that they get $16.49.

Unfortunately, I have to finish. I have received many cries for help from the elderly and other people around Australia. We must make sure that the review announced yesterday is effective and that it gets results. We have to restore justice and equity and fairness to the elderly of Australia. In particular, we have to stop the double whammy, whereby we take 50 per cent in tax on pensions, and then charge capital gains tax when they sell their shares. That situation is absolutely unfair, and that is not what Australia is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate and to indicate to the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) that we on this side of the House have no objection to the terms of his motion and agree to the wording of the motion, which is:

PARA.TAB: That this House recognises the need for fair and just treatment of shares and investments owned by Australians of pensionable age in the context of social security and veterans' affairs payments.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a fairly simple and straightforward principle and, of course, it is something that we on this side of the House support. Where we may come into some disagreement is in the process of how one determines what is a fair and just treatment of shares and investments and putting the whole question of shares and investments in the perspective of the total social welfare system, particularly as it applies to older Australians.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make a few points in response to the contribution of the honourable member for Cowper to this debate. I thought we were actually going to be talking about the principles of how a country and a government establish a fair system for retirement incomes and for managing our ageing population and ensuring that as a government we are able to ensure that all Australians get fair access to government support, but bearing in mind that, when people have some of their own resources and have some of their own assets to care for themselves, they have a lesser need for government support. It is those who have not had the opportunity to build up assets who get a greater level of government support.

I did not quite realise that we were going to have a debate about the cases of individual constituents. I could have brought in my file of cases. We all have constituents come to our electorate offices with cases where they feel they have been unjustly treated. In some cases they have been unfairly treated. As a local member, when I have a constituent come to me saying, `The department has assessed my assets in this way or my income in this way, yet here is the real situation', I get on the phone to my regional office of the Department of Social Security and say, `Excuse me, my constituent Mrs whoever or Mr whoever has this problem. You seem to have made this assessment incorrectly', and the department has a full process for reviewing all assessments that it makes. In many cases, yes, there have been errors made. Of course that is going to be the case, because let us not forget that the Department of Social Security makes some eight million payments a fortnight. So of course there are going to be errors made in determinations from time to time. One of our jobs, whatever party we are in, is to look after our constituents and to raise those individual cases where there have been errors.

I want to talk about the principle behind this measure, and I also want to highlight the fact that I agree that there needs to be a review of all of the different processes that the government has utilised in assessing various assets and income levels and determining what is a fair amount of pension that persons should get, dependent upon their assets and incomes. I was one of the people on this side of the House who pushed quite strongly, along with a number of my colleagues, for the review that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) has announced. The very fact that, firstly, the government reviewed its treatment of shares last September in response to the high level of concern about the impact of that and, secondly, the government has now introduced this major review of the whole impact of the income and assets test, is a reflection of the fact that the government does listen and does respond and does act in a sensible way to ensure that the policy mix that it puts in place is achieving its positive aims and is not having those negative unintended consequences.

So I think it is very important to highlight the review that the minister has announced and what will be occurring over the next few months. The objectives of the review will be to examine the rationale of income and assets testing in the context of the government retirement income objectives; to examine the conceptual framework, design principles and the actual operation of the pensions, income and asset tests, including perceptions of their complexity on the part of social security and service pensioners, et cetera. It goes through quite a lot of detail about the scope of the review. What is also important is that there will be a major consultation process engaged in and there is a reference group being established which will involve peak retiree and veterans organisations and the finance and superannuation industry, as well as the departments concerned.

So it is an important review and it is something that we should not just pass over briefly. It is an important opportunity for all people who are affected and for the peak organisations representing people in the aged sector in this country to have a say and to have that impact on that review.

The honourable member for Cowper talked about some individual cases; and he referred to part-pensioners who, because of their shares, have lost some further pension. What the honourable member for Cowper did not highlight was that, when the government first introduced this measure before we then amended it in the subsequent budget, it was going to raise some $80 million. In that same budget we announced a $120 million extension of the fringe benefits process for all part-pensioners. It was because we needed to find some of the money to pay for that that we looked at a further targeting process within the assessment of pensions and assets.

We have decreased considerably the impact of this measure by making it only shares purchased after this decision was first announced, which cuts the impact of this measure down to two per cent of pensioners. Only two per cent of pensioners are affected, yet there are thousands—a much greater percentage—of pensioners who are going to gain real benefits because we have extended the provision of the health care card and other fringe benefits to all part-pensioners.

In this financial year the amount of money that we are providing in direct support to the aged care sector by giving them access to a health care card and giving them access to a whole range of other fringe benefits that the Commonwealth supports is going to be close to $200 million; and we have negotiated with state governments to extend their fringe benefits processes to those other areas as well. A far greater percentage of pensioners are going to benefit from that measure.

I did not hear the honourable member for Cowper talk about the 8,000 to 10,000 pensioners in his electorate—and his electorate is probably pretty similar to mine—who are now going to be eligible for the fringe benefits, which by any measure work out to around a $1,500 benefit per year in access to lower cost pharmaceuticals, free health care, dental services, the telephone concession, railway concessions and a range of other measures.

Let us put this debate into balance. There has not been a lot of balance in the opposition's contribution on this measure. People have got to understand that the government does not have a bottomless pit of money to enable it to introduce new measures. When we see that we have to introduce a measure which is a fair and equitable measure, such as provision of fringe benefits to a whole range of additional people, we have to say, `How do we pay for that?'. The government said, `We will accrue some of the money by looking at the current fairness which operates within the assets and income test'. There was an inequity occurring in the income and assets test regarding the treatment of shares and managed investments compared with other investments. So the government said, `Why should one group of pensioners who have investments in one area not be targeted, whereas pensioners and retirees who have benefits or investments in another area are targeted and their capital growth is measured?'. So the government said, `We are going to introduce both'.

I agree with the honourable member that there were some unintended consequences. Because I disagreed with the retrospectivity of it, and I pushed very hard to have that measure introduced from the date that it was announced—not going back. That is what the government did. When it listened to the complaints from people across this parliament, it did make that change. We now have in place a system which is fairer, but we are going to review the whole lot. I agree with the honourable member for Cowper that it is a very complex system and it does need to be reviewed; it needs to be simplified; and it needs to be better understood by both the veterans and the pensioners and their families.

Let us understand and put this matter into perspective. We, as a government, have made major improvements in the provision of aged care support services and income support across the whole country, both to ordinary pensioners and to service pensioners. There has been a major improvement in the value of the pension and in what we are allowing people to gain in fringe benefits. None of that seems to be taken into account. To do that we have had a massively increasing social security budget over the last decade. We are proud of that and we are happy to do that, but there will always need to be a time to target. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to second the motion moved by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). It was interesting to listen to some of the comments by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson).
