Some members of the government have actually realised the problems and the sleepless nights that they have created across the length and breadth of this country with these measures that they have introduced.

PARA.TAB: That is basically what we are talking about today. It is not so much a matter of whether the measures are correct or not. We disagree with the government attitude on what is income, what is an asset, and whether or not capital gains that are unrealised should be considered as income before they are realised as a liquid capital gain.

TALK.START.PARA: —And taxed again.
—And taxed again. As the honourable member for Cowper so rightly pointed out in his address, they are being taxed twice on these things.

PARA.TAB: I have not been in this place for even 12 months yet, but my concern is that it seems that in excess of 60 per cent of my constituent inquiries are about this matter. I probably have even more pensioners in the electorate of Lyne, in places such as Forster, Tuncurry, Taree and Port Macquarie, than the honourable members for Cowper and Moreton have in their electorates.

It seems that people were not given enough warning. They have spent the latter part of their working lives creating a nest egg and planning for their retirement. They have considered what they are going to be doing for the latter part of their lives, what their income will be, and have taken into account the key elements of the circumstances at the time as far as a pension or a part-pension is concerned. All of a sudden the government moved the goal posts. That is what we are talking about here: not giving these people enough warning to get their houses in order. Maybe they needed to have worked for another five years if they had to live off managed investments as they do now.

This heartless legislative approach by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) is undoubtedly one of the great embarrassments of this government during its current term of office. The honourable member for Moreton has pointed out that he has had just as many constituent inquiries as we have. I have probably sent as many people off for reviews as the honourable member for Moreton has, and I have not struck one success yet where a pension has been reviewed and it has been found that a mistake was made. So we are talking about the policy as much as its implementation.

This government has introduced the most incoherent and impractical formula to test the level of unrealised capital gain that I have ever seen—for both share portfolios and managed investments. It frightens me to see pensioners on both social security and veterans affairs payments coming into my offices in Taree and Port Macquarie totally confused, surprised, frustrated and ultimately outraged by the actions of the government.

They are in such a state, not only because they are unable to work out the connection between the supposed increase in unrealised capital gains and the real cuts in their fortnightly pensions but also because they cannot believe the government could be so callous in its revenue raising measures.

I have said it before and I will continue to say that these people have worked hard all their lives and have done the right thing by the government throughout their lives. The majority of them are not the high-fliers; they are not the silver spoon set; they are simply storing away a small investment for security purposes. The great irony with this legislation is that it is the Minister for Social Security—we hear so much in this place about social security from the government—who has taken away the one thing for which the majority of these people have worked hard all their lives: security in retirement. The government has taken it away. What an inherent contradiction that the Minister for Social Security is the one who takes from the elderly just that: social security.

During the budget debacle that ripped this government apart, some horse-trading was done with this legislation, which saw unrealised capital gains on shares assessed as income only if purchased after August 1992. Therefore, any share portfolios taken out before that date are now exempt. That still caught a lot of people because the people that were assessed on their total share portfolio before that change turned around and sold their shares. They saw no other way of dealing with the problem. They did not want the complication in their lives, so they sold their share portfolio. If they bought back in, they were going to be assessed after the changes.

The haphazard approach by the government over the history of these changes raises several questions. For example, why on earth has the retrospective nature of the legislation been left in the legislation on share portfolios? Why on earth, if the government so desperately wants to continue with these measures, could it not start from this year's budget so that the pensioner community could have had time to get its financial affairs in order and maintain some sort of personal social security? Why on earth was the legislation regarding managed investments left untouched? What is the difference that the government sees that means managed investments should be treated differently from share portfolios?

I think I heard one of the most outrageous defence claims made by this government when it was in the process of introducing the shares legislation. It was arguing at the time that this was not going to be a big deal and it used the case of managed investments as its example. It argued that, since no-one really complained about managed investments, the same will be true on the shares issue.

The sad fact is that no-one within the community knew about any of these changes until they started to see massive cuts in their fortnightly pensions. In many cases, this was not until their pension was cut completely. In a speech on the social security amendment bill the other day, I mentioned Mr Baker of Port Macquarie, who has had his pension completely cut. All he did was move $200,000 from an interest-bearing deposit in a bank into a managed investment. He was allowed to have it sitting in the bank, but he was not allowed to have it sitting in a managed investment. He had $150-something a fortnight in pension whilst he had that money in the bank. As soon as he put it in a managed investment portfolio, he lost his pension completely.

We have seen major changes. By introducing these legislative changes, this government has moved the goal posts, as I said before. The real issue is that people plan for many years for their retirement based on the rules of the day. This government moved the goal posts. It removed that security that the pensioner community had before these changes were introduced. The government cannot try to convince me that it flagged this legislation to the pensioner community because there are still many people within my electorate and right throughout Australia who are only now realising just what the government has actually done to affect their income.
To emphasise my point, I will quote from a media article from the last few weeks which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 19 January. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Financial advisers received an expected flood of phone calls from pensioners last week, following the impact of the latest quarterly review of pensions by the Department of Social Security. The surge in local and overseas equity markets during the past few months has delivered some spectacular returns to investors in direct shares and managed funds. But the assessment of unrealised capital gains under the pension income test had led to big pension cuts for many.

Again, the unrealised capital gain does not put bread and butter on the table each week. It does not put petrol in the car. It does not pay the rates. Let us not kid ourselves, the increase in the equity markets is not being truly reflected in the pension cuts. The formula being used is so overexaggerated that it inflates the capital gain enormously. I just wish the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) was with me every time I interview a pensioner when he says, `If I were earning the money on my investment that the formula says I am, I sure wouldn't be complaining'. They would not be complaining, but they are not earning that money. The money is not in their pockets. Comments such as these emphasise the unrealistic nature of the formula being used.

PARA.TAB: To be fair to the government, I think that it has realised its blunder on this issue, even though it is not for truly compassionate reasons. Instead, as part of a budget backroom deal, it brought forward the exemption date on the shares issue. It has also announced a review of the current income and assets test for pensioners, which is well overdue. It was promised before Christmas. The review is obviously now well behind schedule and the minister only just announced yesterday that Ageing Agendas will conduct the review. Let us hope that it is a truly independent review and not something that we may have witnessed on the Yes, Minister program on TV. I think this review so far has simply been a vehicle to take the heat off the government on this issue, so that when people start complaining about this ridiculous legislation, the minister can pass the buck and say that he is holding a review, so that he looks like he is doing something.

I challenge the government and the minister to take this review seriously and allow it to operate totally independently and away from their intrusive hand. Most importantly, I challenge this government and this minister to get out and meet some of the people being affected by this legislation, and to sit down and talk with them, and to listen to their story to see just what the government is doing to the lives of some of our elderly Australians. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite interesting to listen to those opposite give their views on this matter. What a lot of hype and carry on. What a load of scare tactics there are going around. There is no need for us to go and get every pensioner in Australia on their knees wondering what on earth is happening. A bit of simple explanation will give it to them.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in the statement of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who said that pensioners kept shares and investments for security purposes, and then he went on to blast `security' as in social security. May I advise the previous speaker that security purposes in my book—when I am thinking about investment and my future—are for when I retire. Surely, the nest egg that I am building and that some of these people have built is for retirement, not just for them to hide away and not use, so that they can then sponge on the government for social security.

This morning I would like to explain very carefully and simply what the investment shares review is all about. For the information of honourable members opposite, 95 per cent of supplementary shares data collection forms have now been completed, and this was done by the end of December 1993. Currently, there are about 40,000 clients with post 18 August 1992 shares, and they have been recorded and included in the bulk reassessment. Pre 19 August 1992 share assessments have been updated using the latest dividend data.

As at January 1994, the update had found that 198,600 pensioners were recorded as having managed investments and/or post 18 August 1992 shares. Of these, some pensioners held management investments only, and some held shares only. It needs to be noted that, owing to the offsetting arrangements, only the combined impact of managed investment and share assessment can be measured for bulk assessment.

Thus we find at January 1994 that approximately 103,400 pensioners had no change in their rate of payment. Of the remaining 95,200, 52 per cent recorded an increased pension payment averaging an increase of $3 a week, and 48 per cent recorded a decrease in their pension payment with an average reduction of $6 per week. A further 1,100 clients had their pension cancelled. These increases and decreases resulted from a general fall in interest rates and the associated reduction in crediting rates on life products such as insurance bonds, and also from the relative stability in rates of return on shares and managed investments.

It is to be noted therefore that, while rates of return on these products over the past three months have been quite strong, they have not been all that different from those in the three months to the end of December 1992, which have now dropped out of the 12-month period for calculating rates of return. Pensioners whose payments vary because of the update have been notified of payment changes and have been advised how, if they required further information about their investment assessment, they could contact their local financial information service. It is also noted that, in general, the bulk update proceeded smoothly with very little media comment and no extra volume of calls to FIS or the teleservice centres.

The background to assist with the understanding of those changes and what the new rules are that apply needs to be separated out for comprehension. Changes to managed investments that took place, effective in March 1993, comprised the following: the removal of the artificial distinction between market linked investments and accruing return investments, so that all managed investments are now assessed on their actual rate of return—before that, they had had a capped rate of return of 11 per cent; and the allowing of losses on all managed investments to be offset against gains.

Pre-March 1993 there was no cap on managed investments that were clarified as accruing return investments—for example, friendly society bonds—because since 1988 the capital growth on these investments was assessed as income. Therefore, the only change to accruing return investments was to allow losses on other managed investments to be offset against gains.

As a result, some people gained from the change and others lost. For example, when assessments on managed investments were updated in September, around 48 per cent of pensioners with managed investments had a change in their rate of pension. Of these, 40 per cent had an increase and 60 per cent had a decrease. Most of the increases and decreases were less than $10 per week. Initial information on the January update is that the number of pension increases and decreases are similar to those that occurred in September.

It would be inappropriate to grandfather managed investments made before 18 August 1992, as has occurred with shares, because a savings clause for managed investments would be overly generous for most pensioners, given that they have been assessed already on an accruing rather than a realisation basis for around five years. Some people with losses would be worse off because they could no longer offset these losses during the term of the investment.

The government has initiated an independent review, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) has already explained, of the pension income and assets testing arrangements. The treatment of investments will be covered in that review.

Let us now discuss how the government will implement the new rules for the treatment of shares acquired after 18 August 1992. These changes apply only—`only', I stress—to shares acquired post 18 August 1992 and have been applied progressively since 23 September 1993. New clients—that is, new clients after 23 September—had the new rules applied from the date of the first payment.

To identify existing clients who acquired shares after 18 August 1992 the Department of Social Security sent a supplementary shares review form in October last year to around 25,000 pensioners who were most likely to have acquired shares after 18 August 1992. They were pensioners who had invested in new share floats since that date—for example, Woolworths; pensioners who had indicated that they had incurred brokerage fees over the past 12 months; those who had held shares in companies that have had a rights issue since 18 August 1992; and those pensioners with portfolios valued at $50,000 or more.

The majority of forms have now been returned and each case has been assessed. The new rules have been applied. Each pensioner affected has received advice to make the matter clear. Those pensioners or their nominees who have not returned their form or contacted the department will be contacted shortly.

Recent increases in the value of shares may lead to some pension reductions as the new rules are applied, but pensioners will still be better off overall as only 50c in pension is lost for every dollar in income. In addition, the rate of return at a maximum of 50 per cent ensures that no share can be assessed as having a rate of return in excess of 50 per cent. Therefore, many shares where the rate of return has recently been increased will receive the benefit of the 50 per cent cap.

The new rules will now be applied progressively to other groups of pensioner shareholders who were not sent a supplementary review form because they were considered less likely to have acquired shares previous to 18 August. The government, as I said, has also initiated an independent review of pension income and assets testing arrangements and the treatment of investments will be covered in that.

To explain the contradiction between the Social Security treatment and their tax treatment: the government is supportive of allocated pensions. They can play a valuable role in the retirement income system. In recognition of this, the tax treatment of allocated pension provides substantial concessions that encourage self-provision in the form of these investments. However, added concessions through Social Security will be illogical and result in tilting the balance of government provision away from those in need and consequently increase government pension outlays. The government's proposed change recognises that allocated pensions have a hybrid nature displaying some characteristics of investment in superannuation and characteristics of managed investments. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for moving the motion, that all honourable members in this House should support, that we recognise the need for fair and just treatment of shares and investments owned by Australians of pensionable age in the context of social security and veterans affairs payments. Yet this House has failed, through no fault of honourable members on this side of the House, to be fair and just in the treatment of pensioners who hold shares and investments. I refer in particular to the government's treatment of unrealised capital gains on shares and investments as income for the purposes of calculating a pension.

PARA.TAB: This is the fifth time I have spoken in this place on this issue. I think that reflects fairly badly on the government, which has shown arrogance and unwillingness to be fair and reasonable in its treatment of pensioners. Today we hear the government describe these fine Australians as `spongers'. It is only because of my personal respect for the honourable member opposite that I do not name her, because otherwise her office in Launceston would be deluged with hordes of these so-called spongers. I acknowledge that the government made some concessions on this issue in the last budget, when it took out the retrospectivity provision. However, that response was too little. Pensioners are virtually prohibited from investing in our nation because, if they do and there is even minor rise in the value of their shares or investments, they will have their pensions cut.

I would like to relate to the House the story of one pensioner in my electorate of Stirling who had some shares. She inherited them from her husband. They had held them for quite a number of years. Prior to the announcement in the budget of changes to the rules for assessing pensions, there had been quite a lot of media attention on this issue, and justifiably so. Anyhow, like many other pensioners, this old lady had become frustrated at the government's arrogance. She had waited too long, on a meagre income each week, for the government to show some compassion on this issue. So she consulted her financial advisers.

They told her, `The government does not care about the elderly in society. If you want to survive, you need your pension. So your only option is to sell your shares'. She sold her shares. Twenty-four hours later, the government did another of its backflips. It repealed the retrospectivity. That should have been good for this dear old lady, but it was too late for her. She missed out by 24 hours. She sold the little nest egg which she and her husband had scraped together over a number of years before he died.

This woman's case illustrates the total disregard the government has shown for the elderly of our society—or the spongers, as it calls them. One should look at how the government prioritises things. The former Speaker, now government whip, falls off his bike and collects $65,000 of taxpayers' money. The Australian Labor Party is trailing in the polls, so the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says, `Here's 30 million bucks, Ros. Go and buy some votes in our marginal seats'. What does that tell us? But when pensioners invest in our nation—the country in which they worked so hard to ensure that our generation and generations to come would enjoy a reasonable standard of living—the government says, `Oh, their shares have gone up. They have not earned any extra money, but let us penalise them anyway'.

The government cares little for ordinary Australians. It cares only about its own re-election prospects and lining the pockets of former speakers for their own clumsiness. How does the government fund its self-interest? It rips off ordinary Australians. Following the last budget, there were the changes that I talked about earlier. However, I should point out that many pensioners sold their investments unnecessarily, many making a loss. We also have legislation which penalises pensioners for investing in shares and making other investments. This is prohibition. That is the only word for it. Which pensioners in their right mind would invest their money when they know that they will be penalised for it? It defies logic. That, sadly, is a common characteristic of the government.

I understand that a committee is looking into the treatment of pensioners. It will obviously go further than just discussing the treatment of shares and investments. I suggest to honourable members, with regard to this issue, that the committee will recommend the total repealing of this legislation, and quite rightly so. I have talked about this on numerous occasions but it is important to point it out again. It is absolutely ridiculous to treat an increase in the value of one's shares or investment as income when they have not

SPEECH.PARA: been cashed in. Notional gains do not buy groceries, they do not pay rent and they do not pay bills.

PARA.TAB: It is high time the government treated our elderly citizens with the respect and compassion they deserve. It should not describe them as spongers. This issue has proven that the government lacks any compassion. I think that the government should act now to repeal its unfair legislation, even before the committee reports, because the unfairness of this issue is so blatantly obvious that the government must act now in the interests of our fine, elderly Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that this session of backbenchers' business is normally a useful and worthwhile forum, particularly for new members, to bring to their colleagues in the parliament an awareness and understanding of the problems in their electorates and in the community at large. What we are seeing, in fact, is its misuse in the most hypocritical and mischievous kind of way one can imagine. One really has to go back to the 1970s, to the Fraser government which converted the assets test out of the system, actually changed the means test basis of the Australian pension system to be income only and took assets out of it.

PARA.TAB: What we saw between 1977 and 1982 was this massive shift of capacity from income earning to asset, and the whole pension system was tilted that way. In 1983, when we started to try to correct that, we heard the screams, the shouts and the mass hysteria from those honourable members opposite who were protecting, essentially, those people with substantial assets and wealth who were getting full pensions. We had the hypocrisy of millionaires getting pensions, and those honourable members opposite supported it. The principle was that if one had assets it did not matter; it was only income.

Ever since 1983, there has been an ongoing debate as to how to treat people in Australia fairly. So when people retire, whether they put their money into banks, into shares or into property, it should be treated fairly and equally. There is the idea that notional gain is the same as notional interest. So do not take the interest from the bank; let it sit there. That makes it notional. It is not real money; it is only a paper entry; therefore, it should not affect the pension. The fact is that notional gains are real gains and they are able to be realised. That is what this is about. Quite frankly, what the opposition is looking for here is a new form of assets avoidance, that people should transfer their capacity into shares—put all their assets into shares—because the capital growth on shares will not be tested. People will be able to get a full pension. It is the old assets test revisited. That is what it is about. We know that; the pensioners federation knows that; all the organisations know that. The unfortunate part is that the vast bulk of pensioners—the millions of pensioners who have no shares—do not understand it. What they see—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand it, Allan.

—I understand it, Garry; I understand it very well. I have been here longer than any honourable member in the chamber now, and I understand it very well because I was here in 1983. I heard the same arguments in 1983 about assets—the crocodile tears and pleadings for a small number of people with very large amounts of money who were getting pensions. Who was paying for it? The average working Joe was paying for it. Shares are an asset. The increase in share values is realisable—any day, every day, whenever it is wanted. In the same way as people go to the bank or the building society and draw out interest on their investment, the interest is notional in the opposition's terms; there is no difference at all.

PARA.TAB: So what we would be seeing would be a total shift of all capital owned by pensioners or retired persons—not even pensioners, of retired persons—away from the banks and from the building societies into some form of shareholding, on the basis that only the income would be affected. Any capital gain would be pension free. In other words, asset growth would not be affected. In other words, it is the assets test again. If we are going to have a sense of fairness in the system—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want them to sell all their shares?

—If we were to repeal it and do what the honourable member is suggesting, then the financial advisers would say to their retired clients, `Have a go. Get out of banks. Get out of building societies. Get out of cash investments. Put it into shares. Own the shares, and any capital growth in those shares would be ignored in terms of the pension'. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House calls upon the Government to allow telephone subscribers to indicate their choice not to receive unsolicited telephone calls from telemarketers selling a good or service, by adding an asterisk against their entry in the White Pages telephone directory.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disturbed to read in the parliamentary blue paper today that my motion was described as `Protection from telemarketers'. That is a wrong description of the intent of my motion. I thought I would point that out, because sometimes these things can be misconstrued.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I would like to refer to an editorial in the Australian of Tuesday, 8 February 1994, in relation to a slightly different subject, but nonetheless one which carries with it the gist of what is a fundamental criticism of the government's telecommunications policy. The editorial is about bulletin boards. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The political and bureaucratic response to the challenge of communications technology is too often hamfisted and hostile.
On another subject it comments:
Visiting Australia last week, the chairman of Microsoft, Mr Bill Gates, was justifiably unimpressed with the narrow, official view of pay TV.
Further, in dealing with the question of regulation of this particular activity, it says:
Nor to regulate an activity simply because it is not already regulated.

In other words, the editorial in the Australian was criticising the government's tendency to respond in a ham-fisted way to communications issues and, more often than not, to respond in a way that introduces over-regulation of an important and booming industry.

PARA.TAB: It is the dawn of an age of mass telecommunications. There will be a revolution in telecommunications. There will be all sorts of interactive telecommunications via telecommunication lines and satellite and other such means of communication. There will be some tremendous revolutionary advances in the technology and in the facilities that will be available to the consumer, including householders. So it is important that the government responds in a carefully considered way and, instead of opting to over-regulate, looks to the optimum approach, which is self-regulation by the users and providers.

The motion which I have moved today is to allow all telephone subscribers the opportunity to indicate whether they wish to receive unsolicited telephone calls from telemarketers by having an asterisk added against their entry in Telecom's white pages. The unsolicited calls to which I am referring are those whereby the caller attempts to directly market a good or service. Based on the information I have received on this matter through my electorate office, the practice usually entails selling goods or asking for a donation, and that generally causes the subscribers some angst because they are wary of a voice over the phone requesting money or credit card numbers.

I do not include in this the legitimate and important surveying of opinions of constituents, which is part of the proper representation of constituents in parliament, whether here or in the state parliaments. I believe that is an important part of our democratic process. What I am indicating in this motion is that subscribers, by having an asterisk next to their entry in the white pages, ought to be able to indicate their preference not to receive unsolicited telemarketing calls to their homes.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we have all received such calls. It is obviously a very important part of our economy. It is a legitimate practice which, according to the chief executive officer of the Australian Direct Marketing Association, Mr Rob Edwards, turns over in excess of $4.5 billion per annum. That is just by the 220 telemarketing companies which are voluntary members of that association. Nevertheless, there are a number of people who find unsolicited telemarketing calls offensive, intrusive and sometimes a gross invasion of privacy, particularly when the call is perhaps received in the middle of the evening meal or in the middle of some other activity which people at home are undertaking.

I was recently interviewed on this matter on an ABC morning program and was very heavily supported by listeners who called in with their thoughts on unsolicited calls. Some of their comments were as follows: telemarketing is an invasion of everything; one usually gets the calls at a time when one is most busy during the evening; I regard it as a total invasion of privacy and if I get someone calling me I simply put the phone down and let them gabble on; I agree with the idea of an asterisk; the worst thing is when one is trying to run a business and is with a client and the phone rings and it is one of those organisations trying to get a donation; and it is our right to be annoyed when we get these calls, `Do I want this, do I want that?'. They are just a damn nuisance.

The matter is by no means a new problem, but it does appear to be a problem which the government cannot address. In December 1992, Austel released the final report on its inquiry into the privacy implication of telecommunication services. Among Austel's many recommendations were the following aimed at protecting and promoting consumer interests. One was applying a principle of informed consent; another was a committee of consumers, industry and government agencies developing a voluntary framework for dealing with the issues, funding being made available to Austel to service that committee; industry developing codes of conduct dealing with specific aspects of the issues, for example, telemarketing, for approval by the committee; and measures to control the capture and use of personal data.

As far as unsolicited telecommunications are concerned, the telecommunications privacy report defined these as being telecommunications initiated by a business or other organisation to a resident where the resident does not have a continuing relationship with the business or organisation, or where the telecommunication is to persuade the resident to a course of action, that is, to buy goods or services. One of the principal recommendations by Austel in that report on this matter was that the telecommunications privacy committee should oversee the development of a cost-effective process by which consumers who prefer not to receive unsolicited telecommunications may, as far as possible, indicate that preference. Others included the development of appropriate codes of conduct for approval by the committee to deal with intrusion, control of personal data and fair trading issues in relation to unsolicited telecommunications, and the collection and collation of complaints relating to unsolicited calls by the telecommunications industry ombudsman.

I have a view that in this case we ought not to go for the ham-fisted approach, that in the case of telemarketing it is quite feasible, and I think proper, for the industry as much as possible to be able to regulate itself, to have a voluntary code of standards. I think that a code of conduct is something that is very strongly supported by, for instance, the Australian Direct Marketing Association. But the problem is that not all telemarketers are members of those types of bodies, and those that are not members may from time to time cause the problems which I have alluded to earlier in my speech.

I am aware that ADMA has taken the initiative of providing legal assistance to some consumers who have been wronged by miscreant companies, and that it is as keen as I am to ensure a practical solution to help telephone subscribers to be able to indicate their preference. ADMA claims to have no problem with the concept of marking numbers in the phone directory, although it is keen to see the issue of funding addressed or resolved first. In the interim, however, ADMA is continuing with its telephone preference scheme, whereby people who do not wish to be called can telephone ADMA's head office in Sydney to have their name deleted from the lists of all ADMA's member companies. This is, of course, of some benefit to people who are fearful of unsolicited calls, particularly the elderly, who may live alone and view requests for money with great suspicion. Unfortunately, there are many non-members in the business and names cannot be removed from their lists by this process.

Of course, where they obtained their lists is another issue that causes some debate in this country. List broking is a fast growing business in Australia. However, more often than not, any electronic lists are composed using current or old white pages as a primary source. If an asterisk is placed against particular numbers in this primary source, I envisage that this data could also be transferred to subsequent lists. If a telemarketer observes this code to indicate a subscriber's lack of interest, it is reasonable to assume that they would know that this person is hardly likely to be receptive to their call. I think this is another argument. I mean, we are basically looking for a cheap, efficient and simple way whereby consumers and service providers alike can know what people's preferences are and that they do not wish to be contacted in this way.

But talking about the government's response, in November of last year—notwithstanding the fact that the report was released the year before last—Senator Collins, a former communications minister, was asked when a decision would be made on the formal responsibilities of the telecommunications privacy committee and when it would be up and running. The minister's less than positive response was that the government expected to respond to the report in the near future, at which time it would address the question of an appropriate forum for consideration of telecommunications privacy issues. Of course, that is the old `in due course' or `in the fullness of time' argument that we so often hear from Sir Humphrey Appleby in Yes, Prime Minister. It is more than a year down the track and telecommunications privacy is still on the backburner. It indicates that, as with other policy areas, the government's communications policy is a shambles. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak at a later stage of the debate.

—This is a very complex issue. As the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) said, it is a million dollar industry which is continuing to develop. Questions of privacy, fraud, and abuse come into the paradigm of this particular industry and it is an issue on which the government has still to firm its response.

PARA.TAB: At this stage, I will address the definitional aspects of it. One thing that is happening in this country, and throughout world, is that, with the increase and development of new technologies, many new forms of selling and marketing are developing. It is putting the world into the situation where it is continually having to face new challenges about the processes and regulations that should be used to ensure that consumer's rights, and the responsibilities of those selling, are put into the proper legislative framework.

There are basically two parts to telemarketing—inbound and outbound telemarketing. Inbound telemarketing is about consumers calling marketers for product, for information or for purchase. I do not think anyone has a particular problem with that. We are principally talking about outbound telemarketing—the making of unsolicited telephone calls to consumers by the marketer. Outbound telemarketing could be defined as any deliberate, unsolicited marketing communication activities conducted through telephone lines to the reception facilities—for example, telephone sets, fax machines, computer modems—of new customers. As I said, the call is unsolicited and no prior business relationship exists between the telemarketer and the consumer.

As was said earlier, we have all experienced calls from people whose call we have not asked for regarding particular elements of a sales program or other forms of service delivery. As an issue, when we look at the overseas experience, the potential there is quite frightening. In the United States, telemarketing is a billion dollar business with annual sales amounting to about $430 billion. It is an industry that has had problems in relation to privacy and fraud. Unscrupulous telemarketers can abuse the telephone lines of consumers as much as they like, as long as they pay their telephone bills. The telephone company does not have any liability for the telemarketing behaviour of its customers.

In relation to fraud, without written records it is easy for telemarketers to manipulate orders. The consumer may also forget the deal that the caller offered. Telemarketers can collect information from consumers over the telephone. If the receiver is a minor or an incautious person he may be deceived into releasing personal information or credit card numbers to professional telephone artists. Telemarketing is a genuine means of communication, but it is very easily misused. Telemarketing fraud has cost the US public about $1 billion a year. The federal trade commission receives over 37,000 complaints about telemarketers.

When we turn to actually how to legislate and how to regulate this sort of system, we find that a number of approaches have been used in the various states of the United States. Five particular types of telemarketing laws have been used, with varying degrees of success, across the states of America.

The first, I guess, is the asterisk system, the one in respect of which the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has moved this motion today, whereby telemarketers cannot call individuals or households who mark in the telephone directory their unwillingness to receive telemarketing calls. There are also automatically dialled recorded message players. Telemarketers are either restricted or not allowed to used automatically dialled recorded message players to make their calls to consumers. The principal aspect of that is that, with the new technology that is developed, it is not normally a situation of just having the phone book there and actually going down the list to make those calls. New technology now allows a greater volume of calls and, therefore, a greater volume of sales, but also at the same time a greater volume of nuisance to the general public.

I turn to the monitoring of telephone calls. There are regulations governing the recording of conversations during telemarketing calls. They mainly serve to protect the privacy of the telemarketing employee rather than the consumer. In most states where there is such a statute, telemarketers must obtain the prior consent of their employees before they can monitor conversations.

There are also home solicitation regulations. These are rules that apply to telemarketers soliciting business from consumers at home. Telemarketers are required to disclose their identity and to provide a mandatory cooling off period during which buyers may cancel the transaction and secure the return of their down payment. This law is, I think, a very important aspect of what should be done, simply for the reason that, when one receives a telemarketing call, one is not expecting it, is caught off-guard and is often willing to listen. The person who is speaking has a well-rehearsed routine and superior knowledge of the product and of the object of the call. In those situations the consumer can be put at a disadvantage and that can lead to a purchase which, once the purchaser thought about it, he or she would not have actually gone ahead with.

The other type of law is registration. Before making business solicitation calls, telemarketers have to provide the consumer protection section of the state's department of justice with information on their products and services, employee lists, how they made their calls, price or gift offers, advertising literature and calling scripts. This, I think, is an important part of any system that should be introduced.

The question relating to telemarketing that the honourable member for Moore emphasised was that of privacy—the fact that people should not be disturbed in their own homes, going about their own lives, by unsolicited telephone calls. I think we understand that that quite clearly is a concern; it is a concern we have all faced.

Although I have no figures and no idea of the elements of fraud that exist in the Australian industry, I worry about what has occurred in America and what then may occur in Australia. Something in the region of $3 million to $15 million in tax revenues have been lost, as estimated by the US government, to fraudulent telemarketers. Often telemarketers have a room set up with a bank of phones. The people who are making the calls become expert over time in the detail of what they are required to do. I have also often heard complaints about the working conditions in those situations, about poor wages and about extra pressure being put on employees in a very unfair fashion. It is often part-time work and it is often done on a contract basis in terms of sales. All of that, I think, undermines not only the actual result of those calls, but the actual conditions of the employees doing the work.

That question of privacy abuse and how we deal with it comes down to two basic approaches that can be used—that is, more of a remedial approach than preventive measures. By `remedial', I mean action taken subsequent to the actual event. One of the problems with that relates to the nature of many victims of telemarketing fraud. Figures show that they are mostly less educated and younger consumers who are prone to accept the calls and who, subsequent to the event, feel ashamed to report they have been deceived. The problems that can occur in this sort of industry are often ones that will not be reported and, therefore, it is very hard to get a firm handle on the detail of what has occurred. The vulnerability of that group is something that government has to be concerned about.

When we look at the question of preventative measures, the use of asterisks, of course, is one system which could be used. There are a few problems with that. As the technology grows and develops the situation—and this happens even now—is that the use of purely the white pages is not necessarily how the future of this industry will go. More and more there are other databases being provided and developed which can be utilised. They can be provided by other industries which have developed their own telemarketing databases. They can also use situations where they are concentrating on an area. They work on the question of the actual prefix by going through, number by number, the actual phone numbers in that area. In those circumstances, that will lead to a position where silent numbers will be rung and any asterisk system would be jeopardised.

It is a difficult area and it is an area that requires a long, hard look from government. I note the Austel report. I urge the government to respond to it as soon as possible. We have got a problem here that we only know a little about as yet, but over time it could be quite damaging. It certainly requires a firm, guided response by the government to ensure that matters like the asterisk system and further regulation are investigated and a proper system of regulation put into place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is quite a self-explanatory motion which the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has moved. It is seeking to protect the privacy of individuals who do not wish to be annoyed by telemarketers selling goods and services. This matter was brought to my attention by a gentleman in my electorate who queried the right of businesses and organisations to make unsolicited telephone calls, often at inconvenient times of the day or night, without the recipient of those calls being able to ensure that such calls are not made to them.

PARA.TAB: On another occasion, a different constituent received raffle tickets in the mail from a charity. She was told to send $20 despite not having agreed to purchase any raffle tickets. Upon inquiring about this, the lady was told that her house had been telephoned and someone there had agreed to buy the tickets. That was news for the whole household. That perfectly illustrates that unsolicited telephone calls require some regulation and that people require protection and should be afforded privacy from these so-called cold calls if they so desire.

In other areas of communication, we are able to prevent similar nuisances such as junk mail and doorknocking politicians—or whatever or whomever—from annoying us with a simple sign on the letterbox or door expressing the wish that we do not want to be annoyed. I am sure honourable members would agree that this method of preventing one from being annoyed is better than having the door slammed in their face. However, there is no way at present of protecting people from being disturbed on the telephone by telemarketers other than if that person has a silent number. This is not a preferable way of going about this, given that to take out a silent number one must pay a fee. What is more, one may also want to appear in the telephone book but just not be disturbed by telemarketers.

This motion seeks to allow people who do not wish to be disturbed by such unsolicited telephone calls perhaps to place an asterisk beside their name in the telephone book. That is one option. Prior to telemarketers making telephone calls on potential clientele, they would have to check the book to ensure that person is prepared to accept such telephone calls.

The final report in 1992 of Austel's inquiry into the privacy implications of telecommunications services addressed this particular issue. The report recommended that consumers who did not wish to receive unsolicited telephone calls should have a means of exercising that particular preference. In fact, later on in the report it said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many submitters—
that is, to the inquiry—
perceive unsolicited telecommunications as intrusive. They expressed views to the effect that—
*such telecommunications should not be permitted unless the called party has given prior explicit consent; and that
*there should be a mechanism by which consumers can indicate that they do not wish to receive such calls.

The motion by the honourable member for Moore provides that mechanism. This would appear to be the easiest and most convenient way of coordinating it, both for telemarketers and the general public alike. The report also, among other things, recommended that a code of conduct be developed by relevant groups dealing with unsolicited telephone calls and that the telecommunications industry ombudsman should be the initial person to whom complaints are referred relating to unsolicited telecommunications.

PARA.TAB: These would have to be dealt with if and when the substance of this motion evolves. However, I am also aware that many direct marketing companies conform to a code of conduct, though there are also many, as we have heard, that do not. The Austel report also distinguished between telemarketing—where unsolicited calls were made in an attempt to sell a good or a service—and opinion polling, where it is not intended to sell a good or a service but to seek one's opinion about something. If we adopt a scheme where an asterisk is put next to the names of those who do not want to receive telemarketing calls, it should apply to all unsolicited telephone calls whether they are seeking to sell a good or service or to seek one's opinion.

I cannot deny that prior to the last election I undertook telephone surveys to gauge the opinions of people in my electorate, as I am sure many honourable members also did. As a matter of courtesy, we first asked whether they were willing and prepared to participate in a survey, and my helpers also made it known for whom the calls were being made. However, this is not the same as people having a mark put next to their name to ensure they do not receive unsolicited calls. Had we had this scheme in place prior to the last election, I would have respected the desire of those people who wanted their privacy protected.

While some may disagree with the suggestion that unsolicited telephone calls selling a product are different from those doing opinion polls—political surveys in particular—I should point out that we have secret ballots to protect individuals from being identified as supporting a particular political viewpoint. So I ask why individuals cannot be protected from having unknown people seeking similar information, irrespective of whether that polling be about politics or any other subject. I also point out that the fair trading issue has been mentioned as a matter for the states, so accordingly the states' rights should be paramount on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have concerns about the motion before the House, but not because of its content or intent. In fact, I am very much in favour of a system being put in place whereby the privacy of my constituents can be protected. However, what the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) is doing reminds me of the time when I was a librarian and the association of librarians computerised a subjects heading list according to the technologies of 1922. I suggest that this motion, in asking for an asterisk to be put next to a telephone subscriber's number, is similarly inadequate. Quite honestly, that is like suggesting that we re-invent the ark in this day of modern ships.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that people do not sit down with telephone books any more and start dialling by name from the telephone book. It just does not happen that way. I commend the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) for trying to do something in this area but what he is suggesting is nonsense because it will be totally ineffective—it will do absolutely nothing. With automatic dialling, computer generated numbers do not consult an asterisk. An asterisk in a telephone book is not going to do anything. But if there were a computer register of numbers somewhere within the Telecom system we might get somewhere.

Other honourable members have mentioned sequential dialling. The bottom line with sequential dialling is that silent numbers come up, and computer generated calls prove that. There is no-one at the other end to look at the telephone book; it is being done by a computer. I suggest that it creates great problems for the aged and infirm, for working people and people who may be in a romantic situation, to be disturbed by a phone call because someone wants to sell them a shonky wristwatch or whatever.

My other concern about telemarketing is the use of credit cards and the fraud that has occurred there. I have heard no mention of the style or nature of products that can be sold in this manner. I suggest that there needs to be some rules to govern that.

The next section is the sale of databases. I am involved in organisations, one of which is a limited liability company, a leagues club which I know has sold the databases of the membership. The membership was not consulted. I suggest that there needs to be rules about selling membership lists of an organisation. Does membership of a club give that club the right to sell your name and address and your privacy to an organisation. A club requires a person to fill out a membership application but does it then have the right to resell that information? I would contend that it does not unless it has your express approval.

That is one of the main areas we should be going into. Unfortunately the motion of the honourable member for Moore does not attempt to do that. As I say, I approve of the idea of doing it but I think what we would be doing by passing this motion would be ineffectual and, in fact, it would get nothing done.

I believe that what we need to do is to ask Austel to look at this issue in a very detailed way and make sure that it comes up with some answers which are going to note the technology which is available now. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J. D. M. Dobie)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Mr Sawford:
That this House:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)recognises the need for innovative solutions to reduce unemployment;
(2)in particular, acknowledges the export potential of environmental industries; and
(3)takes note of the preliminary Scan Report of the Green Jobs Unit jointly set up by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Conservation Foundation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak on the motion again without closing the debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment requires new questions and new answers and from the vantage point of the 21st century those nations that have low unemployment levels will be those that have a will to have low levels of unemployment. Unemployment is a global crisis. Employment policies in many countries are in policy gridlock. Chronic and endemic unemployment levels of 10 per cent plus bedevil the developed world. Economic growth by itself will not solve the unemployment problem and there needs to be an examination and a considered analysis of a vast array of alternative strategies. There is no single solution to unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Many other strategies are being seriously considered. The first European jobs summit in October 1993 canvassed a number of strategies including shifting taxation on employment onto carbon emissions; re-engineering social security and employment benefits; increased public infrastructure spending; encouraging wage restraint to promote lower interest rates; motivating investment in transport and communications; tax incentives to encourage the manufacture and consumption of certain goods; and structural measures to stimulate the labour market and vocational training.

In addition to those possible strategies there is the enormous potential for job creation in environmental management and technology. There is also no doubt that the exploration of a number of strategies and ideas put forward to reduce working hours and job sharing is timely.

Patricia Hewitt, the Deputy Director of the Institute of Public Policy Research in London, author of the influential book About Time: The Revolution in Work and Family Time and the author of a memorandum to the House of Commons employment committee, presented a widely commented upon paper at the European jobs summit in 1993 in which she argued that a reduction in working time cannot solve the problem of unemployment on its own but that `no analysis of unemployment and employment will be adequate unless it takes account of the rapid changes in the structure of working time and working lifetimes; and no employment debate will be complete if it omits working time re-organisation'.

In the Australian context, John Moorhouse from the University of South Australia in a submission to the expert committee on employment opportunities preparing the green paper pointed out that according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics 20 million hours of overtime are worked in Australia and that since 1978 overtime for males has increased by 70 per cent and for females by over 100 per cent.

Simplistically, 20 million hours is equivalent to 500,000 40-hour per week jobs. It is understood that not all of those hours are paid overtime but nevertheless serious consideration could lead to the release of perhaps 100,000 to 200,000 jobs.

It appears that the proposition got short shrift from the expert committee and from the National Institute of Labour Studies through Mark Wooden and Professor Judith Sloane. Mark Wooden said the idea had `simple intuition' and Sloane described it as `an idle notion of work-sharing'. Perhaps in this unemployment debate we need a little more intuition and a little less expert opinion that only seems to want to maintain the status quo. Wooden states that far from creating jobs, restrictions on hours—and he does not canvass voluntary reduction of hours—will almost certainly exacerbate the unemployment problem.

However, he does acknowledge that the trend of average hours worked by full-time employees has been moving upward. He also acknowledges the marked increase in full-time employees working very long hours. He states that the proportion of full-time workers working in excess of 40 hours has grown from 30 per cent of all persons working full-time to over 40 per cent, and that 20 per cent of workers now work more than 49 hours per week. He contends that this may be because of multiple job holding representing 4.3 per cent of the work force. That must be about 150,000 persons. Wooden also states that 16.5 per cent of workers work paid overtime. That is 3.8 million paid hours worked by full-time employees. Redistributed, that is almost 100,000 jobs. Probably the truth is that the potential number of jobs from the redistribution of overtime could be as low as 100,000 and up to a theoretical maximum of 500,000.

In his conclusion Wooden states that many Australian workers are working longer hours than ever before and thus it is reasonable to question whether a more equitable redistribution of working hours could not be achieved. He goes on to say that restriction of hours—he does not canvass voluntary reduction—would cause unemployment to rise and output to fall due to the greater inefficiency of unemployed labour. Sloane also argues that job-sharing is unlikely to be welcomed by employers and will be very unpopular.

Essentially the criticisms of Wooden and Sloane are purely economic. They take little or no account of social costs of unemployment, with increased crime and suicide, nor do they mention an inefficient economy with high unemployment levels, occupational health and safety, lost productivity caused by fatigue and boredom, increased compensation claims and redundancy payouts. Despite some experts' comments that reducing working hours and job-sharing are naive, they are in fact happening in Australia and elsewhere. The Commonwealth Bank introduced a job-sharing scheme three years ago and now has more than 900 employees in that scheme. Phillip Levy, the Commonwealth's general manager of personnel, rejected the claims by some academics and employers that job-sharing is complicated and expensive. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Job-sharing in our bank is basically self-administering.

Dr Peter Botsman, the executive director of the Evatt Foundation, in his report on the European job summit cited the examples provided by Patricia Hewitt which `exemplified the problems and possibilities of work sharing and reduced working hours'.

PARA.TAB: In January 1993, a British retail company by the name of Burtons made 1,000 workers redundant and then invited them back again to apply for 3,000 lower paid part-time contract jobs. That confrontational approach used by the company caused, not surprisingly, huge problems. By contrast, just a few months later British Airways sought to reduce its work force by allowing its employees in a variety of different areas to reduce their working hours while retaining their pay rates, pension scheme membership and other job terms and conditions. The British Airways road, Hewitt contends, was the high road to flexibility to meet its labour force reductions and to make redundancy savings.

Botsman and Hewitt acknowledge the criticism of some economists that proposals for reducing working hours suffer from a `lump of output' fallacy: that is, the total amount of work to be done is fixed and therefore the only way to employ more people is to share the work more frequently. Hewitt argues that there is a demand deficit which must be addressed through increased expenditure on public infrastructure and higher standards of care and education. Hewitt also added new evidence to support her case. She argues that the `lump of output' fallacy is indeed fallacious because of the productivity gains throughout the 20th century. Between 1881 and 1981, the lifetime hours worked by British men fell from 154,000 hours over 56 years to 88,000 hours over 48 years. Hewitt also cited studies by the French economist Michel Albert which showed that the high productivity gains in the last decade had turned the economy into a machine for unemployment.

In Germany, the most revolutionary moves have been made to reduce working hours through an accord between employers and unions. The shorter working week has increased the number of mainly full-time jobs by between 250,000 and 300,000. The Volkswagen accord is worthy of comment. After marathon bargaining sessions, workers at Volkswagen plants in Germany will put in 20 per cent fewer hours but will get only a 10 per cent wage cut. The accord took effect on 1 January this year and it cuts the working week from 36 hours to 28.8 hours. Volkswagen management has said it will save 1.8 billion German marks a year, or about 20 per cent of its wage costs, and it was the only alternative to cutting 30,000 of its 100,000 jobs in the next two years.

Schemes for job-sharing and reducing working hours will not on their own solve the unemployment problem. We realise that. However, these schemes can make a significant difference. They must be analysed and seriously considered in the unemployment debate, along with other innovative strategies. Implementing such schemes is not without problems but voluntary reductions or negotiated agreements between employers and unions and workers do work.

Some economists, particularly people such as Judith Sloane and Mark Wooden, who criticise the potential of such schemes, seem to ignore that it is happening. It is happening in this country; it is happening overseas. Perhaps, when the debate comes to job-sharing and reducing working hours, those economists ought to be reminded of the words of Victor Hugo:

SPEECH.PARA: An invasion of armies can be resisted but not an idea whose day has come.
The day has come for this country to seriously consider the alternative strategies of job-sharing and reducing working hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to this motion on solutions for unemployment, I wish to address the first two sections of the motion put by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford). The first of those is that we need innovative solutions to reduce unemployment in Australia. Hear, hear! We certainly do. The most innovative solution that I can think of is to replace the absolutely inefficient, incoherent and untenable Labor government which attempts to run this country.

PARA.TAB: In 1990, as the then Treasurer of Australia, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who has the honour of leading this country, visited my electorate to open a new production facility at Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd, arguably Australia's second largest pharmaceutical manufacturer. That company is growing rapidly in terms of output, export and number of employees. It is an exemplary firm. The then Treasurer gave a speech in a marquee at Glaxo and, in that statement about very high interest rates, he said that we just did not understand. We understood all right.

Those who understand business and industry knew that unemployment was going to go through the roof. Companies were falling over left, right and centre. Small- and medium-sized businesses were keeling over at unprecedented rates. Why? It is because no-one can support paying 23, 24 or 25 per cent interest on outstanding debt. Companies that were highly geared and structured from the very rapid increase in output throughout the 1980s felt that very strongly. So as an innovative solution, let us get rid of this government that never has and never will understand Australian business, industry or commerce.

One thing which we could do to decrease unemployment is to change the culture of the Australian Public Service. Yesterday I visited Telecom Australia, which has a purchasing policy that, in the first instance, it should try to buy Australian goods, products and services, particularly in the major project market as it develops new systems, new exchanges, new interchanges, and so forth. That policy has been highly successful. Telecom Australia manages to achieve in the order of 70 per cent Australian content. That is positive for Australia. It means jobs for Australians. It also feeds on itself because new industry develops from new technology, which leads to new businesses, more employment and new export potential for our country.

What is the ethos in the Australian public sector? It is to buy somebody else's goods and somebody else's services from somebody else's country. Its ethos is that Australian quality must be second class. We must change the culture of the Australian public sector. That would be a very positive initiative.

We should scrap the training guarantee levy. Time and time again in this place I have explained to this House the negative factors which the training guarantee levy induces in the job market, and yet this government continues to prevaricate while we have one more inquiry into the training guarantee levy. Even the government's regional development committee suggests that we should suspend it. Let us not just suspend it; let us suspend it indefinitely.

We need to reduce the level of redundancy payments in order to shift social welfare payments into the public sector where they belong and out of the private sector job market cost scenario. Why is that important? It is important because it creates a mindset in the private sector market. The mindset says, `If I get hit like I did in 1989 or 1990 or 1991 with having a massive downturn in my business and having no option but to reduce my work force, I know that those very high redundancy payments in many cases sent many companies over the wall and into voluntary liquidation'.

In other cases, employers are determined that they will never hire full-time employees again so long as they can hire part-time and casual employees, and those classifications of workers are increasing rapidly. Very high redundancy payments as part of the industrial relation system are a positive deterrent to full-time employment. We really need to actually, rather than theoretically, deregulate the labour market. That has been said over and over again, and those on the other side know it to be true, as do I.

We need to put some real teeth into micro-economic reform—not just talk about it. We need to reduce government taxes on business inputs, not increase them—for example, fuel excise. We are increasing fuel excise, thereby increasing company transport costs. We are increasing the cost of diesel oil to fire the generators for Nabalco at Gove in the Northern Territory, which makes a total nonsense of the $10 million that that company has just spent to reduce pollution and increase efficiency in its powerhouse. And what happens? The increase in the levy, the increase in taxation on diesel fuel oil, totally offsets the $10 million that Nabalco was just going to save in terms of increased efficiency. This government, while it talks about micro-economic reform, actually produces very little. There is a long range of other things which I could mention but I will run out of time.

Part of the honourable member's motion says, in particular, `we acknowledge the export potential of environmental industries'. In this case I will support the honourable member for Port Adelaide very strongly, and I have been a strong supporter, in a national sense, of developing fully a renewable resource energy potential in this country. That is available to us in a number of respects.

The one issue which I have attempted to bring to national attention is the huge tidal range that exists in the Kimberleys on the coast of Western Australia at a number of inlets and bays where we could build barricades and where we could install turbogenerators so that we generate electric power from the rise and fall of the tides. If the tides ever fail us, I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we are gone. There is an energy source which is non-destructible, absolutely renewable and, in a sense, is totally free. The electricity, the power, that we generate from those turbos would cost us only the cost of capital development and some small operating expense.

We need a bit of vision and a bit of political will in order to undertake this kind of an enterprise. It is a long way from the rest of Australia. It is a long way from those centres that use electric power. But there is a solution to that problem. That solution is a thing called hydrogen. At the moment the major energy carrier, outside of copper wire for electric current, is hydrocarbons, in terms of fuel oil, diesel oil and gas in various forms. But hydrocarbons, in terms of their quantity available to us, are a limited resource. We can use those hydrocarbons to produce chemicals, to produce all sorts and manner of things that mankind needs in order to make his lifestyle better. But what do we do? We burn them. We put more carbon into the atmosphere. We choke our lungs and our cities and we think we are doing the world a favour. We are not. But there is a solution.

The solution is to take the electric power that we could generate in the Kimberley from the rise and fall of the tides and, through electrolysis, to split water into its basic elements, hydrogen and oxygen, and convert it. If we put the hydrogen in pipelines and pump that across the nation, we can burn the hydrogen in low-temperature burners and the only pollutant, the only waste product, is water. The hydrogen recombines with oxygen to form water. So we have, as an energy carrier, hydrogen which we can use in power stations and in fuel cells, which we can use in our automobiles and trucks. The engineers around the world who look into energy transmission estimate that clearly by the middle of next century hydrogen will start to become the world's major energy carrier.

We have an opportunity in Australia to be the first. We can show the way. We can start new technology which will feed on itself, which will provide more jobs and which will give us new industries. New ideas would flow out of the technical work, the research work, the scientific work, which we undertake on this massive infrastructure project. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), one of the workhorses of the B team. Up until halfway through his speech, I thought we were hearing the recycled speech he usually gives, but here indeed was a positive, innovative idea. For that I congratulate him. It is encouraging to see this because normally the only focus and commitment of the opposition in terms of jobs is on who is going to get the top job and who is going to get on to the front bench. While the parliamentary Australian Labor Party in its caucus meetings is busy making constructive suggestions to contribute to new ideas on employment generation, the Liberal Party is embroiled in its leadership dispute.

PARA.TAB: However, it is very important to note that, in the matter of public importance on unemployment that the opposition brought on last week, a lot of statistics which are widely known and accepted by the government were raised by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Dr Wooldridge) but very little policy innovation. That goes to the heart of the problem of my colleagues on the other side. I encourage them to join with us in looking for constructive solutions.

It is very important, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) said in response to the MPI on unemployment, that we be reminded that since 1983 there has been a 25 per cent increase in jobs. In fact, 1.6 million jobs have been created. At the same time, we have seen a growth in unemployment of 230,000. This is a major difficulty that has to be faced, given structural changes to the economy.

Obviously, one of the problems has been the increase in the participation rate. I refer to an article by Michael Munford in the Australian of 17 January 1994 in which he looks at these trends, not only in Australia but in the OECD. In fact, he mentions that the OECD figures are fairly typical of the Australian figures in terms of the proportion of people coming into the work force. From 1966 we had 42.8 per cent of the population working or seeking work, as opposed to 41 per cent actually working. That had risen in 1989 to 47 per cent actually seeking work, with only 44 per cent working. The important issue of which we have to remind ourselves is stated in his article. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: All these countries have seen higher unemployment levels in the 70s than in the 60s, higher in the 80s than in the 70s. In all these countries there have also been shorter-term trends, with a decline in unemployment in the late 80s, followed by a steep rise in the early 90s.
He goes on to say:

Unemployment is measured as the percentage of the "labour force" which is unemployed. The "labour force" means all those who have work or seek work. So if more people seek work, unemployment will rise, and it will be difficult to get a job, even if there are just as many jobs available. This on the whole is what has happened in Western countries over the past two decades.

This has affected the Australian situation. Obviously, there have been many factors, but one of the factors Munford reminds us about concerns demographic changes in the population distribution. In fact, we now have a higher proportion of people of work force age and a declining birth rate. So we have got a bulge in the potential work force available and an increase in numbers in those people actively seeking work which, of course, includes women.

PARA.TAB: It is often said, in a number of areas of the community, that if women went back into the kitchen we would not have this problem. But women voted with their feet; they want to work; they want to participate equally; and they have been a success story in terms of increased participation. What we now have to do, across all sectors, is to deal with the mismatch in the skills base, as was mentioned by the minister in his response on the matter of public importance. What we also need to look at is the fact that there has been an improvement in the overall economic picture. I want to cite Terry McCrann in his article in the Daily Telegraph on 18 January. He reminded his readers that he had predicted the recession of 1990 but he now says:
We have the opportunity to build prosperity far more real, far more sustainable and much more solidly based than the speculative and entrepreneur-blown boom of the 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: He further says:
We have already added more than 100,000 jobs and the number could approach 200,000 by the end of the financial year and growth overall in the economy should push 4 per cent.
This is, of course, a result of government policy. He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: For us, we get a supercharger as the rhetoric of the past decade about hitching a ride on Asia's boom increasingly becomes fact. And we will be able to do so precisely because we have become far leaner and more competitive over the past five years—partly through belt-tightening the recession, partly through real structural change.

SPEECH.PARA: It is nice to know that Terry McCrann is supportive of what the government has achieved in that time. I now wish to address my remarks to the innovative solutions.
