Obviously, the green paper on employment and the government's upcoming policy statements want to address these very significant difficulties, particularly with the long-term unemployed. That is where we have a real difficulty. As the economy picks up, the people most likely to get into the work force are going to be those people with skills and flexibility. But we have obviously realised, in the course of this past 10 years, that those workers who have been displaced by structural change and young people without adequate skill based training are going to be the people hardest to place.

PARA.TAB: It is up to government, industry and communities to work together. I want to give some examples from my electorate of just how communities can drive innovative solutions. The first one is the most successful $1 million worth of work campaign launched, just three weeks ago, by the local community of Rockhampton. This was driven by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, local media outlets, the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin and radio station 4R0. They launched a campaign to get $1 million worth of work generated in a 10-week period. What we asked employers to do was to get behind the issue and see the importance of looking to invest in new personnel. The results have been extraordinary. On the first day, $270,572 worth of work was pledged. By the end of the first week, over $500,000 worth of work had been pledged. The target of $1 million worth of work was reached in just three weeks.

This came about because of a number of factors and not just because of the media campaign: there has been an upturn in the positive psychology of the country based on the realistic statistics that have been coming out. People and employers are now seeing that the recovery is happening. Their goods are required; their services are required; so it is now time to put on staff. This innovation shows that if there are governments, communities and people working together and investing in people—that was the point my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) was referring to—then we start to get a pick-up in employment.

The second initiative that I would like to tell honourable members about is the Capricornia Training Co. This is an example, once again, of a state government, DEET and the community working together with the training sector. The particular example that I would like to mention is that of the state government investing $1.2 million in the building of housing commission homes in the Rockhampton region. This has been used to provide employment for young apprentices who are doing carpentry and building trades training.

These young people work on site and build the houses. The TAFE training is on site each day, so that there is a fast tracking in the first 12 months of training. These people are then ready to be apprenticed with other builders. This means they are fast-tracked through the system. It is a win-win situation for the community, for housing, for infrastructure, for young unemployed people and it is cost neutral to government. It has been supported by DEET.
The third initiative I want to talk about is the Capricorn International Resort which pioneered the Aussie host program to provide special training in the hospitality sector. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute to the motion which has been brought forward by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) with, I would suspect, a great sense of shame on the part of the honourable members in the government who have contributed to this debate today. There are many issues and none more important in Australia than unemployment. These honourable members are part of a government that is presiding over 11 per cent unemployment in this nation. In country areas the unemployment levels are much higher—upwards of 18 per cent—and there is also hidden unemployment. Finally, the government has come forward with a motion to deal with what I regard as fundamental issues which could have been addressed during the 11 years of its government.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the report which has been quoted in the honourable member's motion. It was put together by the ACTU and the Australian Conservation Foundation. In the report, they recognise a number of very serious issues where environmental jobs can be created. I do not think there is anything new or innovative about the issues. They refer to pollution abatement with respect to air, water and soils. I want to concentrate on the water aspect of it; that was in point No. 1. Point No. 5 of this report is about water and sewage treatment works.

These are issues that are not only absolutely fundamental to the good health of the community but they also create employment opportunities. They are problems that have been around for many years, in fact, even prior to this government taking office. There has been no recognition whatsoever by the current government of the major problems that we have. In fact, it was highlighted in my local area with the outbreak of further toxic growths in water catchment areas. The season for blue-green algae growth is with us right now and this problem has repeated itself over many years.

In fact, only about 12 months ago, we had an outbreak of blue-green algae in many of the waterways and tributaries leading into that magnificent river system, the Murray-Darling Basin. I am sure that the honourable member for Port Adelaide would understand that water and its quality are vital to the state that he represents. Although the upper reaches and tributaries of the Murray-Darling system are not in South Australia, he would be the first, I am sure, to acknowledge that the quality of the water supply in the state of South Australia is less than desirable. In fact, in many areas, it does not meet world health standards.

I raise this issue particularly because toxic growth shock was reported on Wednesday, 9 February in a number of recreation lakes and holding areas around the electorate of Bendigo which had been affected by this blue-green algal growth. It was not only in recreational areas such as Lake Neangar, Lake Tom Thumb, Lake Weeroona and other small areas, but also in Cairn Curran reservoir, which supplies drinking water to a number of areas. In fact, that water has been revealed to be unfit for drinking.

That is a massive indictment of the present government for not putting money and effort into carrying out the research on the prevalence of toxic growth in waterways and tributaries throughout Australia, and for not dealing with that problem. It requires additional money to be put in by the government into researching that problem throughout Australia. In fact, the whole catchment area of the Murray-Darling Basin needs to have the question of blue-green algal growth addressed. It is of vital importance, and is also linked with water treatment and sewage treatment plants.

The federal government, under both former Prime Minister Hawke and the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), has neglected to provide water and sewage treatment works to many rural township areas in Australia. Ultimately, the outflow or effluent from those systems finds its way into many tributaries which eventually lead into the Murray-Darling system and pollute that watercourse. As I mentioned, it also flows into the Adelaide area and can of course be detrimental to the large population of Adelaide.

I know that the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) has brought this motion forward because of his concern for this area. I have spoken with him on occasions about aspects of environmental issues, and I know he has a deep interest in this. He needs to reflect on it and take the message back to his party in their caucus room and tell them of the years of neglect and lack of funding for research into this major problem—and into the matter of obtaining water treatment for small rural areas and country towns—and of the need for an influx of money to be spent on sewage plants that have been neglected by the federal government for many years.

It is a matter of concern to me and to all country residents. As I indicated to you, the work that is involved and the employment opportunities in that area are nothing new. They may not be terribly innovative, but they do not have to be the latest buzz word. All that the people in those areas require is a good clean water supply; attention to the catchment areas to ensure that those areas are in fact safeguarded against the inflow of chemicals or other external matter that might pollute the water supply; greater care and attention to water catchments; and greater involvement of federal government money in improving the water supply system and sewage treatment plants of many country areas.

The small township of Elmore, in the northern part of my electorate, is situated right alongside the Campaspe River, which ultimately feeds into the Murray River. It is presently facing the problem of water pollution. Both the state and federal governments are putting a proposal to the people of that community to have a sewage system and water treatment works implemented. I trust that the residents of that area will agree to that scheme, because any effluent which has previously been discharged from water and sewage treatment plants has been flowing into the Campaspe River and ultimately into the Murray-Darling system, which dumps it in Adelaide. That must cease, and the government must address this problem.

There are opportunities for employment there and, with the application of additional money to research, particularly to this toxic growth problem with blue-green algae, we must address that question; we must ensure that the quality of water throughout Australia meets the standards of the World Health Organisation. It is one of the most fundamental and basic things required in Australia and it must be addressed by this government.

I commend the honourable member for Port Adelaide for moving his motion and giving us the opportunity to put forward these views. I ask that the honourable member for Port Adelaide impress this matter upon his party, the party of government at the moment, which has neglected these issues. I certainly will raise this matter with my own party, and let us hope that we can approach this in a bipartisan manner so that this problem in our water system is overcome. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's economic policies over the past 10 years have dramatically transformed the Australian economy, and we are now seriously and irrevocably orientated towards the outside world. The cost of this has not been cheap, with unemployment remaining stubbornly high. However, the vast increase in the nation's educational level, especially trade education via TAFE, has enabled us to seriously examine the possibilities of a wide variety of innovative solutions to this unemployment problem.

PARA.TAB: I think it is good for the House to reflect on Austria and what happened at the end of the late 1950s. I was recently talking to Jack Dusseldorf from Workskill and the Dusseldorf Foundation. These are very honourable organisations which have done great work in suggesting to Australia and to industries that we should upgrade the quality of the skills that we have in our work force.

The story goes that, during the late 1950s when Russia was still in charge of Austria, the leaders of the country were locked up together—industrialists, unionists and politicians—and realised what was going to happen after the postwar period. They realised that there was a need to be more competitive if they were to match the resurgence of Germany, so they formed a social accord while they were in prison. They decided that with this policy they would specialise in exceptionally high standards. The social accord they would be lifting the skills of their country; they would concentrate on the best products and the best opportunities. Austria has been very successful in taking this into account, and I think Australia could learn a lot from this.

Of recent times, I have discovered that, for the most part, Australian industry has been very inward looking and concentrating, naturally, on the bottom line but, as a result of this, we have not been concentrating enough on our skills. When we look at unemployment and a long-term future for our country we need to have more emphasis on this.

Australia is most fortunate in being on the doorstep of the Asian region. This gives us an advantage over Europe and the USA. I think that we should capitalise on this proximity and growing familiarity with the region to tackle our unemployment problems. By the year 2000 Asia will have two-thirds of the world population. The number of affluent Asian households with incomes above $US30,000 will be 50 million by the year 2000.

Two areas where Australia actually does very well are health and education. Australian health services are going to be more in demand as the Asian region ages. The two nations to look to are Singapore and Japan. In 1990, 8.7 per cent of the population of Singapore was 60 years of age or over and, by the year 2025, 27 per cent of its population will be 60 years and over. For Japan the figure for 1990 is 17.2 per cent and by 2025 it is estimated that 30 per cent will be in that age group.

It might be a radical concept, but retirement villages in Australia built by Australians and attached to health areas are a likelihood. Physical space in Singapore and Japan is at a premium. (Time expired)

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Lowe will have leave to continue her speech when the debate is resumed.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface today's grievance debate by quoting from the foreword to the book Where Fate Calls written by Dr Tom Frame in 1992. It says in part:

SPEECH.PARA: On the night of 10 February 1964, during naval exercises off the south coast of New South Wales, the destroyer HMAS Voyager inexplicably crossed the bows of the aircraft carrier HMAS Melbourne and was sliced in two. Within a matter of minutes, 82 men perished, making the collision Australia's worst peacetime disaster.

In an unprecedented action, the Australian government broke with established practices and ordered a royal commission into the tragedy. Its findings were controversial and public and parliamentary concern resulted in the appointment of a second commission, again an unprecedented action. Its findings were released four years after the event and the commission has been described as the most spiteful and vindictive in Australia's legal history.

`Where Fate Calls' is a probing and controversial investigation of the four-year Voyager saga and its aftermath, the first fully researched account of one of the most important events in Australia's national history—a veteran Canberra political commentator said recently, "The Voyager story must rate as one of Canberra's three biggest, along with the Petrov defection and the dismissal of the Whitlam Government".

It is an enthralling story containing all of the elements of an epic thriller: a dramatic naval disaster at night, tragic loss of life, exploits of extraordinary bravery, court-room action, political intrigue, public outrage and claims of cover-ups and conspiracies.
It was, as the Sydney Morning Herald said on 6 April 1989:

The longest and sorriest story in our naval—perhaps our parliamentary—history. It is a sad record of evasion, dishonesty and incompetence. Ministers have prevaricated, royal commissions have blundered, naval officers have concealed the truth. Evidence has been destroyed and mislaid.

Today is the 30th anniversary of that national tragedy. As a young duty officer in Canberra that night, and as someone who knew many of those who died or who survived, it remains indelibly etched on my memory.

PARA.TAB: Since I entered this parliament in 1988 I have been heavily involved in compensation cases for survivors of that tragedy, including a precedent-setting High Court action for one of them in 1990, the so-called Verwayen case. Although that claim and some others now have been settled, regrettably many other survivors and their families still bear the indelible scars of psychological trauma, persistent nervous shock, domestic instability, financial strain and, very importantly in this parliamentary setting, misplaced confidence in a government which espouses social justice but which until last year failed to put its money where its mouth is and live up to its compassionate rhetoric. The Brisbane Courier-Mail said, in part, in September 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: The view that the Commonwealth has behaved with despicable bureaucratic self-interest in the Voyager case would result in very little argument in the general community. The High Court ruling paving the way for compensation claims by the survivors of that horrific 1964 naval accident, is a signal victory for social justice. . . the Commonwealth long denied liability for compensation. Mr Hawke's first government lifted the statute of limitations on the case in 1985, then slammed the door in 1986 when it found there might be substantial compensation claims in the offing.

The Verwayen judgment meant that the Commonwealth, as an employer of people paid to defend the country, cannot claim exemption from civil compensation if those people come to harm in the course of their natural or normal duties—the so-called combat defence.

PARA.TAB: Since 1986, ministers have relied on legalistic jingoism in each individual case. Squirm as they might about their rationale, ministers knew that the bottom line for the Commonwealth was a total compensation bill of $30 million to $40 million. Unnecessary and costly legal argument was therefore used as a battering ram to cloud the real issue of this government's reluctance to satisfy such an embarrassingly substantial budgetary outlay. In 1992, Mr Justice Coldrey said in part:

SPEECH.PARA: It would, of course, have been open to the defendant—
in this case the Commonwealth—
if it lost the Verwayen case—
which indeed it did—

to withdraw its defences against all remaining Voyager claimants on the basis of consistency towards an otherwise homogeneous class of persons and in order to prevent any perception of discrimination and injustice.

Early in 1993 the full court of the Victorian Supreme Court dismissed an appeal by the Commonwealth against another of the damages claims, with Mr Justice Ormiston affirming that the Commonwealth could not rely on either the combat defence or the statute of limitations. On 13 May last year we saw a tardy but nonetheless historic turning point from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) when he told the House, in part:

I was asked by the honourable member for Groom about the HMAS Voyager cases. At that time I indicated that negotiations were going on with a view to the Commonwealth and the solicitors for the HMAS Voyager claimants coming to a resolution of the matter by today where the matters would be mentioned again before the Victorian Supreme Court.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to be able to tell the honourable member that in relation to his constituent, Mr Clark, the Commonwealth has told the Supreme Court that we will not be seeking special leave to appeal. Mr Clark will be paid in accordance with earlier court decisions. In relation to other HMAS Voyager claims, there are some 19 which the Commonwealth now regards as having been effectively decided by the decision in Clark.

The Clark decision was on the question of estoppel on a particular date where the Commonwealth changed tack in terms of defending these actions. All cases that commenced prior to February 1986 will be regarded as settled. The Commonwealth will immediately enter into negotiations in relation to these claims with a view to settling them.

In relation to the other HMAS Voyager claims which the Commonwealth does not consider resolved by the decision in Clark, the Commonwealth will not admit liability. However, in accordance with instructions from the Attorney-General and following discussions of the Cabinet, the Commonwealth government solicitors will enter into negotiations with the rest of the claimants with a view to reaching a settlement.

If those negotiations do not succeed, the next step will be a process of mediation. We are hopeful, and I think this is a hope shared by the solicitors for the claimants, that that process should see the remaining cases settled . . .

SPEECH.PARA: His speech concluded with these words:
It has been a long and difficult case but I do believe that now we are at the stage where the Voyager claims can be reasonably settled to the satisfaction of both sides.

I take the opportunity again today to commend the Attorney-General for taking this course of action so early in his portfolio responsibility, albeit after seven years of unnecessary Commonwealth confrontation from the Hawke and Keating governments. I also thank Victorian solicitor Jim Taylor and other legal counsel, without whose persistence and strong sense of equity the claims would still be sitting on very barren ground. The settlement of claims by 89 of the survivors announced in the Victorian Supreme Court on 23 December last year is welcomed. About 25 claims lodged recently remain outstanding.

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding that new legal ground has been broken by the present Attorney-General, the fact that it took 30 years to do so stands as an indefensible indictment of the undue bureaucracy and legal obstructionism by this government, as well as a lack of political will on both sides of the political fence over that long period. That said, I hope that we now have a situation where those who perished in 1964 might rest easier and many of those who survived may be able to pick up the remnants of their shattered lives.

Let us hope that 1994 will see the closing chapter of a long, destructive and divisive struggle. Tom Frame's book should be a salutary reminder to many: to the people of Australia, to the Royal Australian Navy and to federal governments of all party political hues. No-one wants a witch hunt after 30 years, but deep doubt and an inherent mistrust persist.

Mr Deputy Speaker, service at sea is a dangerous calling and every now and again fate extracts a penalty. It would appear that Voyager's motto was appropriate. She went `where fate calls'. However, it remains a national tragedy and scandal that the public at large and the families of the 82 men who died in the waters off Jervis Bay that night will never have the undisputed truth. May Voyager's commanding officer, Captain Stevens, and his shipmates rest in peace on this historic day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minority of voters who made the awful mistake of voting for the Liberal and National parties at the last federal election must now be dumbfounded at the antics of the current leadership of the coalition. For the first time in Australia's political history, the alternative government of this country, by its own admission, does not have a defined set of policies on its philosophy or its vision for Australia. This is an extraordinary situation in the political life of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Australian industry is now engaged in unprecedented challenges to adopt best practice principles to become more export oriented and, above all, to become more competitive, efficient and resilient in the marketplace. Australian industry requires to know not only the policies of government and the policies of opposition, but also that those policies be realistic, and be able to inspire confidence and vigour in Australian industry—qualities that are fundamental to sustained success.

Supporters of the coalition parties must be in despair to learn that the opposition has no existing policy for developing Australian industry and by all accounts is not likely to have one by the next federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear about your concern. You should be worried about your own policies.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! The honourable member for Aston should realise that when he is sitting at the table he should not interject. He should remain silent at the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I expect from people such as the honourable member for Aston. The disgraced policy document known as Fightback—once sneeringly referred to by the opposition shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), as a 500-page suicide note—has been buried in the far corner of the political graveyard. Had the coalition won the last federal election, the Fightback policy of zero tariffs would have decimated the motor vehicle and textile clothing and footwear industries. In those two industries alone, the coalition's Fightback policy would have jeopardised the jobs of 140,000 Australians and put at risk $1.8 billion worth of exports.

PARA.TAB: I can well understand the ongoing campaign by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) in his trenchant condemnation throughout his electorate of all aspects of Fightback policy including zero tariffs, massive cuts in government expenditure, industrial relations anarchy, and the list goes on. The member for Kennedy is right when he says that the National Party should split immediately from the Liberal Party. At least the virtues of honour and self-respect still count with the member for Kennedy.

The authoritative journalist Peter Roberts, in the Australian Financial Review of 30 March 1993, summed up the opposition's former policy on industry development as `dated, rejected and downright damaging to the future national prospects'. The President of the Liberal Party, Mr Tony Staley, has also expressed his concerns about the opposition's former industry policy. Mr Staley recently told the Young Liberals that Fightback `misunderstood the motor vehicle and communications industries and relied too heavily on the economic rationalist doctrine of government non-intervention'.

During a television program on Sunday 6 February 1994, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) announced that he was unilaterally dumping the party's zero tariff policy. The Leader of the Opposition told the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia, as recently as 25 January this year, that:

SPEECH.PARA: 1994 will be a year of policy development . . . trust and honesty will be a sure foundation, I believe, for the policy architecture that we will build.

Within weeks the Leader of the Opposition, who claims to stand for trust and honesty, broke his promise to his colleagues to consult with them on major policy changes. Why has the Leader of the Opposition forsaken the trust of his colleagues? Why has he shunted his colleague Senator Robert Hill out of the shadow ministry for the empty chalice of chairman of his party's policy development committee? Prominent journalist Geoff Kitney suggests that these actions are a result of the de-stabilisation of the Liberal Party leadership.

PARA.TAB: The opposition leader is not the only member of his party to ignore Senator Hill. In his media release of 7 February 1994, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the shadow minister for science, technology and export development, called for a clear and comprehensive export development strategy in the forthcoming industry statement. Does the honourable member for Goldstein support the government's programs to help small and medium sized export businesses? The government already has an export development strategy. Last year the former Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development and the then Minister for Trade jointly announced a $94.5 million package to assist small and medium business access export markets.

When this government came to power in 1983 a major thrust of our economic and industry reform agenda was the creation of a more competitive industry environment. We recognise that the benefits of competition include efficiency in production and distribution, innovation in production and product development, better quality products, and more internationally competitive industries. We acknowledge that a competitive industry environment is essential for the foundation of industry policy through the 1990s.

We recognise that industry policy is evolving and that we will soon enter a new phase in the development of our industry base. The first phase of reform of Australia's industry structure saw industry gradually exposed to international market forces through controlled reduction in tariff levels. This first phase of industry restructure was not just about tariff levels being reduced. The government took on a commitment to micro-economic reform because internationally competitive companies need an internationally competitive infrastructure. The industry policies introduced by the government in the 1980s and the early 1990s have seen the development of a more outward looking and dynamic industry sector. But the job is not yet complete. A second phase in the reform of Australia's industry structure will maintain and extend the move to internationalise the Australian economy.

This government is committed to the reform processes it has initiated since coming to power. We are committed to creating a dynamic and innovative industrial base. In our industry statement we will recognise the role of government in industry development and we will seek to provide policy and institutional stability. We will seek to develop a strong and cooperative relationship between government and industry so that industry concerns can be addressed and new opportunities identified and met. More importantly, we are committed to developing a more dynamic business environment. We believe the move to a post-tariff environment is the first wave of industry reform and that the second wave is to hasten the agenda to create a more competitive business environment.

We will concentrate on a number of areas—not only the processes of micro-economic reform but also a competitive business environment, competitive regulatory processes, and competitive education and training. In short, we are committed to building on Australia's competitive strengths and we recognise the need for government, employers and employees to strive for international best practice in all activities, in contrast to the somewhat stupid and intemperate remarks we received early in my speech from the opposition member at the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the comments made by the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). He raised the question of industry policy. Of course, that evokes the image of the level playing field. And talking of level playing fields, I am reminded of the sports rorts affair. It is amusing to calculate how much whiteboard the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) would have required in order to enter all those thousands of applications. I have calculated that she would have required, if she put them all down at once—
—But she didn't. She did it state by state, region by region.

—I know that she said she did not put them all down at once. I am just saying that, if she had done, she would have required a whiteboard the size of a tennis court. Even to put 100 on there, I have calculated, she would have needed a seven-metre square whiteboard. She would have needed a level tennis court-size whiteboard in order to enter all those thousands of entries.

PARA.TAB: I grieve today on behalf of my constituents and Western Australians generally for a number of reasons. I might start off by commenting on the use of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) for an emergency declaration to stop work for 30 days on the proposed crocodile farm in Broome. All I can say is that this is an example of the minister's quite illogical use of federal powers to override state authority.

You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that he refused to use similar powers to stop work on the old Swan Brewery. One wonders perhaps whether that was because the developer of that particular development was a mate of the ALP, or almost certainly had been a donor to the ALP during the 1980s.

My constituents include a large number of market gardeners and fruit growers who have a particular problem in trying to develop their export industry. During the last 10 years in the industry there have been difficulties in the availability of airfreight space during the peak crayfish season. The cray industry has, I suppose, in the normal operation of its business, standard contracts with freighters and, therefore, a regular supply of product that drives up export prices.

The airlines, in defending their lack of available airfreight space for export vegetables and fruit, have said that air passenger volume out of Perth has increased greatly in the last couple of years and that airfreight capacity has not kept pace. A study on perishable export airfreight is being undertaken for the state government at the present time and a report is due to be released very shortly. I am pleased to see that the inquiry is taking place because my constituents are very concerned about being unable to get space to develop this very fast growing niche export industry.

In the last three years there has been a growth in exports of market garden produce of 25 per cent but an air space capacity increase of less than 10 per cent. The producers determine their exports according to product yield and airfreight capacity, which in turn relates to the volume of passenger traffic and other freight. Because the airlines are saying that they can carry only so many tonnes, producers opt to export the products giving them the best yield—lobsters or crayfish.

The crayfish industry is a very large source of export revenue for Australia while the lobster industry, producing 10 million to 12 million tonnes per annum, is a growing and highly managed industry. In the past, lobsters were mostly sold frozen but the industry has now started to sell lobster as live product. Last year about 2,300 kilos, which represents 19 per cent of the total catch, were shipped live. Over the next few years the intention and hope of the industry is to convert this to 80 per cent of total catch. This in itself will cause a problem which will also affect the lobster industry. Most of the export goes to Japan, Taiwan and Hong Kong. This does not create a problem when the industry can airfreight direct. However, when this is not possible, the freight goes via indirect routes—for example, through Singapore.

Those of us from this side organised a meeting of key players in the industry in my electorate, as well invited an adviser from the office of the state Minister for Finance, representatives from the department of transport and aviation, and one of the consultants who is preparing the report. The purpose of the meeting held on 23 December was to look at the means available to remedy the recurring problem with airfreight availability. We had a very constructive discussion. Background was given to the current problems within the local export industry. Concern was registered at the prospects for a major export industry in the Ord River to service Asian markets that would be likely to be affected by the lack of airfreight capacity.

We understand that there is a large meeting being organised in the area during the early part of this year so that the local growers and exporters can express their concern to the consultants who have been undertaking a review of this area on behalf of the state minister for finance.I will give an example which was raised by one of my constituents who is a grower. He cited the case of a contract he has with Malaysia where he has an order for 2,000 cartons of produce but, because of airfreight inability, he can only supply half this quantity. He went on to explain that a problem for a large number of growers came about, as I mentioned earlier, when the crayfishing season started and they were able to pay higher freight rates—$3 per kilo—because of the obvious high selling cost of their product overseas. Because of these higher rates, the vegetable growers were often left without any airfreight capacity to shift their products overseas.

It was agreed at the meeting that airfreight capability or capacity was the key element and this can be lost if someone else is willing to pay more dollars. The problem is, of course, that in trying to manage the export of vegetables grown in the area often the exporters or the growers are faced with the problem of getting airspace available to them at the last possible minute. Of course, that means they have to take advantage or they lose business and that makes for an obvious problem in organising or managing their vital industry. It was also stated at the meeting that there were limited chill facilities at Perth airport and they needed to be booked in advance if required.

The principal markets for my constituents' products are South-East Asia, Malaysia, Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, with secondary markets in Penang, Thailand, Hong Kong and Indonesia. As I mentioned, the problems occurred when cray marketing commenced. While exports were principally to Japan and Taiwan, a lot of the goods were airfreighted via Singapore and other Asian cities because of the limited air capacity direct to Tokyo. Of course, that mitigates the opportunity for my constituents to get airfreight space out of Perth to their South-East Asian marketplaces. It was also stated that freight out of Melbourne is cheaper than out of Perth. It was agreed that there was a need for a regular supply of airfreight capacity so that regular markets could be set up. This would go a long way towards gaining an increased percentage of the Asian market.

A Boeing 747 aircraft can hold about 100 tonnes of freight. The observation was made whether the overseas markets could handle this amount of produce in such bulk. It was thought that an individual market would not be able to cope with this. It was suggested that, if an airfreight supply could be established, the group should look at using this to export products to three or more markets at a time. It was also suggested that the group try to organise seed money to underwrite a freight-only aircraft to do the run to the Asian markets. David Jull, the shadow minister for aviation who was present at that meeting and who had a very strong participation in it, mentioned that the Russians have excess aircraft which they are willing to put into other markets. There was some concern the markets would not be able to accommodate the 100 tonnes of fresh vegetables arriving at the same time. If the idea for airfreight under those circumstances got off the ground, the cargo would have to be mixed in order for the venture to succeed.

In the dying moments of my speech, I would like to say that our market gardening industry in Wanneroo in my electorate is a very important one. It has a very important developing niche market in South-East Asia, but unfortunately it has been thwarted by a lack of available airfreight space between Perth and the South-East Asian target markets. This is something that is obviously of great concern. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in this grievance debate to express to the parliament my concern at a recent article that appeared in the Australian on Thursday, 3 February, in which unsubstantiated claims by the Executive Director of Athletics Australia were made. He stated in that article that he was very unhappy with the lack of communication, trust and cooperation between the Australian Sports Drug Agency and Athletics Australia.

PARA.TAB: It would appear that these claims made by Athletics Australia are, at best, not an accurate reflection of working relationships between our agency and Athletics Australia and in some cases are completely wrong. In 1992-93, ASDA conducted a total of 336 event and out-of-competition tests on Athletics Australia athletes. This represents almost 16 per cent of the government funded tests that ASDA conducted in that period of time.

To successfully conduct a testing program of this magnitude it is clearly essential that there has to be cooperation between both organisations. This is to ensure that ASDA has the information about athletes and events so that it can conduct sample collections in a manner which is secure and respects the rights and the privacies of our athletes.

Obviously, from time to time, issues of concern are raised in this contentious area of drugs in sport. There have been times when Athletics Australia has raised concerns with ASDA about procedural matters associated with the collection of samples for testing, and certainly about the notification of those results. I am well aware that in 1990, for instance, Athletics Australia identified approximately 20 issues which it wanted to discuss with ASDA with a view to achieving consistency between the sample collection and the testing procedures. To date, because of that close cooperation, all but two of those issues have been resolved to the satisfaction of both organisations and I am proud to say negotiations continue on those other two matters.

The Australian Sports Drug Agency was established by our government as a statutory authority in 1991 with bipartisan political support. Since that time it has established itself as world leader in the fight against drugs in sport. Professor Don Catlin, who successfully coordinated the drug testing program for the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles recently sent the following message to our chief executive at ASDA after the successful bid of Sydney to host the 2000 games. I would like to quote part of that message to our chief executive officer. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I am thoroughly delighted to learn that your fine nation will host the games of 2000. Having experienced the thrill and excitement of being personally involved in '84 I can attest to a wonderful experience coming your way. It will be a marvellous experience. Hurrah for Sydney.
This is the important paragraph:

I am equally excited because your agency and lab will be able to play a major role in developments during this critical phase. I can't imagine a better person to shoulder that responsibility than you, and wish you wisdom and determination as you traverse the terrain.

High praise indeed. It is in such high esteem that our Australian Sports Drug Agency is held by all international sporting bodies. I would add that the Australian Sports Drug Agency has an excellent relationship with Athletics Australia's international body, the International Amateur Athletics Federation. ASDA has already conducted drug tests on behalf of the International Amateur Athletics Foundation in the Oceania region. A contract between ASDA and the International Athletics Federation is currently being negotiated and should be formalised, we hope, during 1994.

PARA.TAB: It is important that ASDA continues to work with international sporting organisations. It is important because we need to establish drug testing programs, particularly in South-East Asia. We need to test the contestants in all world championships held in Australia. Last year the agency was the first independent organisation to be used by the International Weightlifting Federation to conduct drug tests at its world championships.

In addition, our ASDA officers conducted drug testing in China and South Korea on behalf of the International Rowing Federation. This again was a world first. As part of the drive to ensure that there is a level playing field in international competition, two matters are currently under consideration by our government. One is the signing of the anti-doping convention of the Council of Europe, with all of the associated rights of membership that go with this, and the other is the development of links with China and ASDA where we are encouraging an exchange of ideas and programs.

As I am sure all honourable members will agree, sport is about dedication, hard work and the pursuit of excellence. It is a test of an athlete's natural abilities, not those of the chemist. The annual report of the Australian Sports Drug Agency for 1992-93, which was tabled in this parliament on 3 February, shows that nearly 3,000 drug tests were conducted in that period. Of those tests, 2,000 were conducted on athletes involved in our major Olympic and Commonwealth Games sports, including cycling, weight-lifting, swimming and athletics.

Additional tests for professional sports, such as the New South Wales Rugby League, the national soccer league, and the Australian Football League, were conducted on behalf of those organisations on a fee-for-service basis. These sports deserve special recognition for their strong self-initiated anti-drug stance.

Last year, the incidence of positive drug tests in Australia for prohibited drugs was only 0.2 per cent. This clearly demonstrates that ASDA has had a significant deterrent effect. More importantly, nearly 90 per cent of our elite athletes, surveyed on an annual basis, believe that the ASDA drug testing program has produced that effect.

Last Saturday, on the ABC's Grandstand program, elite Australian cyclist Gary Neiwand acknowledged that competition in his sport was now much fairer than it was during the days before the establishment of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. ASDA also remains in close contact with all our elite athletes. Each year an annual survey is conducted to monitor their concerns about drugs in sport issues.

In addition, athlete advisory groups have been established Australia-wide. Over a hundred athletes are involved in this process, which gives them an opportunity to express their concerns about the drugs in sport issue. These athlete advisory groups are also used by our agency to help prepare information resources. Last year, for example, top Australian swimmer Linley Frame launched the drugs in sport handbook. This provides comprehensive information to all our elite athletes about the drug testing procedures and lists the drugs that are banned and, more importantly, the medications that are permitted and those that are not.

It can be seen clearly in the annual report of our Australian Sports Drug Agency that its effectiveness does not solely rely on drug testing. The agency, I am very proud to say, has developed comprehensive education programs for schools and sporting groups. This has been achieved in close association with other sporting organisations, including the Australian Sports Commission, the Australian Coaching Council and the Australian Sports Medicine Federation.

Together with our state governments and sporting organisations, our agency has established sports drug education units in Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. These education programs are supported by the production and distribution of comprehensive information resources, including videos, drugs in sport handbooks, brochures and teaching kits.

A 008 hotline service is also provided to give information to our athletes about those medications that may contain banned drugs and those medications which are safe for them to use. The agency also provides funding to the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories, which are the only drug testing laboratories in the Southern Hemisphere, and that enables them to conduct research into new methods to detect banned drugs.

I have discussed this issue for the information of members of parliament in this grievance debate because I was so concerned by the headlines, which were bad enough, and reports, which were, I repeat, unsubstantiated, that went against an agency that not only has the bipartisan support of this parliament but also has the support of all our athletes—champions and future Olympic champions. I commend the agency for the work that it is doing. I wish it well in its future endeavours. I hope that in future newspapers will look more to promoting and projecting the positives of this agency rather than writing reports to the detriment of the agency. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is with this federal government, which has been in place so long that the stench of death and decay pervades this house of executive government. Really, the greenies ought to be complaining, should they not? The maggots feed on the carcass of this government causing massive pollution in this place. The greenies really ought to complain. The Australian people are sick to death of this government, its prevarication, its inattention to detail, its lack of ability to address the real issues that face this nation and the fact that it is unable to renew itself.

PARA.TAB: The A team is deserting the ship of state, is it not, like the rats deserting the proverbial sinking ship at sea? Who of the A team has gone? John Dawkins is one. He had many portfolios. He absolutely disrupted the tertiary education sector in this country and fatally stuffed up the budget in 1993. Gone.

Where is John Kerin? John Kerin was seen to be a fair and competent minister for primary industries but then he took on the Treasury portfolio and he did not last very long after that. Kerin has gone. Blewett has gone. Sibraa has gone. Tate has gone. The A team has very nearly gone. The few who are left are getting very tired—very tired indeed. But two who are still hanging on, albeit by a very thin thread, are the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly)—the minister for sports rorts and other things—and the former industry minister.

The minister for sports rorts—or the Kellygate affair—visited my electorate of La Trobe in Victoria in 1993 as part of the ALP's election campaign, and it might be interesting to examine the chronology of events surrounding a particular grant that was made in that electorate. Things commenced with a proposal for the development of an environment education resource centre at the Cardinia Reservoir Park, Narre Warren East. On 4 August 1992, draft ideas for the development were put forward by Brian Johnson, who was employed as a ranger 1 with Melbourne Water at the Cardinia Reservoir Park. Brian Johnson is a fine young man who put forward the proposal in a project that he was working on as part of the young achiever award program. As I say, he is a very fine young man, but I know that he was used by the ALP machine and dragged into the net of trying to win votes with sports rorts dollars.

In the outline of his development proposal, a draft was put up and costed at half a million dollars. Remember that figure—half a million dollars—because I will get to the actual amount of the grant later. The estimates—or guesstimates—were made up of the following cost components: labour, $150,000; construction material, $250,000; furnishing, $80,000; and landscaping, $20,000. That comes to half a million dollars. But the proposal actually states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . much more research is needed to be able to prepare a final costing.

On the 28th of that month the application was, theoretically, received by Mrs Kelly's department. We only know that because she should told us so in a supplementary answer to a question I asked her without notice in this place.

PARA.TAB: On 16 November Mrs Kelly came into my electorate, unannounced and without my knowledge, to support the local ALP candidate for La Trobe, Dr Pain. Mrs Kelly met with Dr Pain and the Friends of Cardinia. I might add that the president of the Friends of Cardinia committee—I have forgotten his name—is also the president of the local branch of the ALP. He had also just stood for endorsement—highly unsuccessfully, I might add—as the ALP candidate for the state seat of Pakenham against the Hon. Rob Maclellan.

So this Labor Party group got together and used poor Brian Johnson's research work for the young achiever award program. On the 16th, she met all these people and said, `I will provide $150,000 of federal funding for the construction of an environment education resource centre at the park'. The agreement was on the proviso that the amount offered by the federal government could be matched from other sources on a dollar for dollar basis. On 17 November, the next day, the president of Friends of Cardinia Park Reservoir sent out a letter to people in the community saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The matter is of great urgency, as the Federal grants for environmental projects will be finalised within the next two weeks, and any financial assistance we receive must be agreed to within that period.

So they had two weeks to find $150,000 as their half of a $300,000 grant for a proposal that was going to cost $500,000 to build. There seems to be something wrong here. Not only is there something rotten in the state of Denmark but there is something rotten in the House of Representatives in Canberra, Australia—fair dinkum.

PARA.TAB: On 19 November, the Berwick News published a photo of the minister with the caption `Peter Chapple and Dr Geoff Pain look on as federal environment minister Ros Kelly pledges her support to Brian Johnson for an education centre at Cardinia'. The newspaper article shows a photo of the minister and Dr Pain with his deep, dark black beard. They are going to get Dr Pain elected to federal parliament, no fear, with a bit of sports rorts money, a bit of pork-barrelling.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't do you any harm.

—No, they did not do me any harm. Actually, the combination was successful as I was able to increase my vote. It was terrific stuff. The article went on to say that the minister said that she would match, dollar for dollar, a $300,000 application. The article continued with this statement by the Labor candidate, Dr Pain, referring to the young ranger who prepared the proposal:

SPEECH.PARA: I expect Brian is still rather shocked and probably can't believe he will have the thrill of seeing his dream come true.

Well, his dream did not come true, because it was all a rort. That is exactly what it was. It was an election campaign trick, using federal funds and a federal minister who is supposed to be responsible, in order to induce people to vote for the ALP candidate, Dr Pain.

TALK.START.PARA: —She should resign.

—Of course she should resign. The whole thing was an absolute rip-off, a big con. She used $30 million to try to make sure that this rotten government got re-elected. To that extent she was successful. It did not work in my electorate, but heaven only knows why. The project is still on the drawing board as of today. It did not receive the community's support, and the pork barrel continues. It was cruel to make that announcement and to offer young Johnson the fulfilment of his dream of a new centre when she obviously knew that the grant would never proceed.

PARA.TAB: The only other grant in my electorate that was approved was $45,000 for a well-deserved baseball facility, but we also put up, and I supported them actively because they were well-researched programs, one for a regional performing arts centre in Emerald for a quarter of a million dollars, one for Horatio's Preservation Society in the Dandenong Ranges at $40,000 and one for Puffing Billy for $40,000 to help with a bridge construction. They were all rejected.

The other minister hanging on by a thread, although he is hardly hanging any more, is the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). A sandwich shop with an industry minister is an absolute nonsense. Do we not pay ministers in this place enough? Perhaps we ought to think about raising parliamentarians' salaries if it is necessary for a minister to try to run a sandwich shop in order to eat. What an innovative employment contract that was! There were no wages, no long service leave, no payroll tax, no workers compensation and none of the on-costs that the rest of us experience when we employ people. Why? Because he did not pay any wages. Zero times zero is zero. Bye-bye, Alan Griffiths. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to take this opportunity to talk about the weather but given the last speaker's contribution I think I will say a few words about sports grants. Sports grants were, in effect, a way to return power to the people. In these days of centralised executive government, government becoming more and more centralised and more executive dominated, it was like a breath of fresh air to be able to have an input into the allocation of where funds went in an electorate.

PARA.TAB: What has to be understood is this. The cabinet was aware—and this explanation is entirely my view—of the need for some stimulation of the economy at that time. There was no doubt about that and this $30 million was allocated to those areas where it would have the most stimulating effect. By and large it went to areas of most need. Some people say, `Shock horror, most of it went to Labor electorates'. Of course the majority of it would have gone to Labor electorates as they contain the areas of most need.

We have had people on the opposition side saying that the grants went to marginal seats. Now I have the safest Labor seat in Western Australia and my electorate did very well out of these grants. It did well because I lobbied very hard and followed up the applications. I know that the electorates of some members of the opposition also did well for exactly the same reason.

If one takes my electorate as an example, some of the money in my electorate went to Cundinup an area where, in a good year, I would get 30 per cent of the vote. It is certainly not an area where one would seek to buy votes. I got money for the farmers of Cundinup because they had no other source for the money. Without that money they would not have a centre at Cundinup today, a centre where they can meet and so help to keep the community together. I believe that it was well deserved. I wish it could have been greater and that they could have received it in two consecutive years. I hope the scheme is maintained so that I can get them another grant.

In the north of my electorate in Broome, a very worthwhile project was a swimming pool facility, an aquatic centre. Broome is an area which is very hot in summer but at certain times of the year it is not advisable to swim there and so I thought it was a very worthwhile project. But the representations for that came not from me but from Senator Panizza, a Liberal Party senator from Western Australia. I congratulate him. It was a well deserved project.There are other areas of my electorate which received grants. Not one could be said to be undeserved.

If one goes to the electorate of O'Connor, which is next to my electorate, one comes to what is probably the safest Liberal Party seat in the whole of Australia. The town of Ravensthorpe was apparently told by its member that there was no point in applying since it was a safe Liberal seat and it would not get any funding. As Ravensthorpe used to be in my electorate I was contacted by some of the people. I said, `Send me a copy of your submission. I will have a look at it and see what I can do'. After having read their submission I thought it was good. I then made representations on their behalf and they too received a grant.

A criterion for most of these grants was that the money could be spent quickly. I noticed the comments of John Taylor, the Auditor-General, and I find them strange. I recall John Taylor as Deputy Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. I understand that he is fond of claiming that administrative accountability in the DAA was at its height during this period. I do not recall it that way. I do not recall there has ever been any great accountability there and there is certainly not any in ATSIC, which brings me to another point.

There has been great concern expressed about the operations of Aboriginal legal services. They clearly need auditing. I am aware that Senator Walsh wrote to the Auditor-General who said that he was unable to audit the Aboriginal legal services unless he was asked to by ATSIC. This is not the situation and I suggest that the Auditor-General concentrate on big money matters instead of chasing rabbits down burrows in all directions.

The truth about these grants is that most of them were paid retrospectively and all of them required local input. The scope for fraud was very limited and if fraud occurred at all then because of the nature of the grants it was on a very small scale. If fraud occurred then I am very eager for those people who benefited to be prosecuted. But in the disbursement of government money, fraud occurs all the time. I would say that the level of fraud here as a percentage of the total was far less than the percentage that occurs in something like the Department of Social Security and I will defy anyone to run a department like the Department of Social Security without encountering some fraud.

Of course, what these noble people do is look at these departments without ever taking into consideration the difficulty of dealing with their clientele who are often under stress. They have no idea of conditions that exist in some of these areas.

I think that some of the grants were anomalous. Certainly, had I been making a decision, I would not have given any money to the Hellenic gun club in South Australia. I do not believe in ethnic clubs any more than I believe in ethnic branches in the Labor Party. I believe they are a scandal. However, the Liberal Party endorses multiculturalism, as does the Labor Party—it is a concept which I certainly reject. But, given those criteria, one can hardly blame the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) for making an allocation of money to that club. It should also be borne in mind that this is part of their culture and way of life. There are over 10 million registered shooters in southern France and Italy alone and, pro rata, there would be just as many in Greece.

Regarding this grant, which has been criticised by members of the opposition, the community itself put in a large amount of money and the project development is going ahead at Murray Bridge, I understand. Clearly, while one may not like it, as I do not, one cannot criticise the granting of that amount by the minister.

Something is happening in this parliament that I think is important. The Westminster system of government, of which our system is a loose model, cannot work without an effective opposition. The present opposition has never been effective and that clearly affects the operation of this government. Another thing that detracts from the effective working of a government under the Westminster system is an incompetent, lazy and slothful media. We certainly have that in Canberra. If the media are genuine about this matter, they should be going out to where the grants were delivered and finding examples of where they were not justified. I urge them to come to my electorate and interview the people in my electorate who got grants and see whether any of them feel that their grants were not justified.

I point out that I am no friend of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I have criticised her as the minister for the environment and I believe that, with the clear exception of a certain senator, she is probably the worst minister this party has ever had. There has been no love lost between me and the minister and, if there was going to be any vindictiveness on the part of the minister, it would clearly rebound on my head. I believe that the minister would have more time for most members of the opposition than she has for me, but it is outrageous for the minister to be pilloried in this way by an opposition that simply has no policy, no sense of direction and no sense of proportion.

There are lots of things that need to be criticised in government but this is not one of them. This scheme was set up to provide small amounts of seed capital to people in need who would not have got grants in any other way. As far as I can see, the grants were very beneficial in the community. They were certainly liked by the community and by those members of the government and the opposition who used their initiative and actively sought the grants. As I was saying earlier, the government's aim was to get money out into the economy. The government frankly did not give a damn where it was spent as long as it was spent, because the government was looking for macro-economic benefits and not for some short-term, small electoral benefit.

Members of the opposition have said that we targeted marginal Liberal seats. This was an election the Liberal Party expected to win. In the situation of a possible change of government, the losing government does not win marginal seats; it loses them. In any case, how can one possibly prove it one way or the other? The fact is that many marginal Liberal seats got the grants and many marginal Liberal seats benefited from them. I believe the people who benefited in those seats would welcome those grants and would think that the system was a good one and should be continued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this grievance debate today to raise some very serious concerns that I have about the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), the Health Insurance Commission, the operation of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the problem of generic drug substitution. My motivation for entering into this debate is an extremely worrying series of events that occurred just before Christmas last year. As has been well documented, a pharmacist by the name of Stuart Keen, from my home town of Wingham on the mid-north coast of New South Wales, has allegedly been substituting generic drugs for more expensive brand drugs, where the only effect on patients using the cheaper brand is that it costs them less.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keen has adopted the philosophy that he has a duty of care to his patients which not only involves their obvious physical welfare but also their financial welfare. Mr Keen realised that it could be alleged he was breaking the law, but in this case he believes the law is an ass. Mr Keen strongly believes that, in those instances where the patient may be under financial stress, it is not only appropriate but necessary for the pharmacist to advise about financial options. I can clearly sympathise with Mr Keen on moral grounds and I believe the law needs to be addressed urgently with regard to generic substitution. I think it is high time that Senator Richardson stopped talking about problems in the health industry such as this one and started to act.

To give a quick summary of the problem we face in Australia, the issue focuses on confusion for pharmacists in interpreting the minimum pricing policy, which was introduced by the government to increase price competition by allowing drug manufacturers to set their own prices on multi-branded items listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The government can subsidise a drug to the lowest priced brand but the manufacturer can charge more for a particular brand. Therefore, if the patient is prescribed a brand which is priced higher than the benchmark price, the patient pays the brand premium, that is, the price difference between the lowest priced brand and the brand prescribed. Stuart Keen probably summarised the problem best when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The minimum pricing policy deregulates the price of drugs to allow prices to be set at what the market will bear, yet doctors won't allow their patients to have a choice. What I'm doing is giving them that choice.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the government has brought in a policy about drug pricing, but the National Health Act hasn't been modified to allow that policy to be implemented properly.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson has talked at length on this topic. He has been made fully aware of the circumstance to which I refer and still he has not acted on it. This concerns me greatly, because two days before Christmas last year Stuart Keen had 33 criminal charges laid against him by the Health Insurance Commission—all due to his stance against current government policy on generic substitution. Since then the public prosecutor has taken away five of the charges and added two more, so Mr Keen currently has 30 criminal charges outstanding against him.

PARA.TAB: I am trying to stay as objective on this matter as I possibly can, but when I hear reports that the Health Insurance Commission actually withheld the court summons for several weeks in a vindictive attempt to intimidate Mr Keen, and then ruined his Christmas by delivering it only a few days before—a time when, as we all know, the legal fraternity takes off for a month, so he could not seek any legal advice during that period—I say that we should all become gravely concerned about it. My allegation can be sustained. The summons was issued on 12 November in Sydney, yet the local police at Wingham did not receive it until 22 December. That is a severe time disadvantage to Mr Keen in preparing his case.

That was not the only case of intimidation directed at Mr Keen. For example, last Tuesday Mr Keen was expected in court at 10.00 a.m. to adjourn hearing of the charges to a later date, but at 5.09 p.m. on the Monday five charges were dropped and two more were added. Essentially, the public prosecutor gave Mr Keen one hour's working time to prepare a case for the new charges.

If reports such as this are true, the Health Insurance Commission must be brought into line, because it is its own summons that it should be tracking through the courts. Such scurrilous activities must never become part of our public bureaucracy, be it in this department or in any other. The action taken in this particular case must be answered for by the Minister for Health himself.

I am not advocating the actions of Mr Keen, who has allegedly broken the laws of this country. All I am trying to do is raise this issue in the public forum so that people can be made aware of the situation that is occurring on the mid-north coast of New South Wales: one pharmacist fighting a lone battle against this government in his attempts to change the law. I take my hat off to Mr Keen because it has taken his stance to bring to the attention of this government the obvious inequities in the current system.

I have with me a letter from the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, which kindly was passed on by the shadow minister for health. It clearly shows the Minister for Health is talking about the problem and is considering change. Yet this has been dragging on for too long. The Minister for Health has raised issues in his letter of 20 January 1994, which he was also raising six months ago. He seems to be stalling on this issue under the disguise of minimum pricing policies and loopholes in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

From his letter, the ridiculous thing is that Senator Richardson is obviously in full agreement with the actions of Stuart Keen, despite allowing the Health Insurance Commission to lay 30 charges against him before Christmas. To emphasise my point, I will quote from the letter signed by Senator Richardson. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is currently holding discussions with the pharmaceutical industry, pharmacy and medical groups and the state governments (who regulate the practice of pharmacy). The purpose of these discussions is to gain agreement to allow pharmacists to substitute a cheaper brand which is therapeutically equivalent to the more expensive prescribed brand, at the request of the patient, except where the doctor has endorsed the prescription to the contrary.

By these statements, Senator Richardson obviously sympathises, as I do, with the plight of Stuart Keen. This begs a series of questions. Why did the Minister for Health allow the Health Insurance Commission to lay the original 33 charges against Mr Keen if he is actually in sympathy with him? Why did the Minister for Health allow the Health Insurance Commission to lay charges against Mr Keen when it seems that in the next few months Senator Richardson, by the content of his own letters and articles published, looks likely to drop his own government's policy and adopt the approach taken by Mr Keen? Finally, why did the Minister for Health allow the Health Insurance Commission to delay the delivery of the court summons by several weeks until Christmas Eve in an obvious attempt to intimidate Mr Keen during the Christmas season?

PARA.TAB: I simply cannot believe the bureaucratic heavy-handedness that Mr Keen has had to put up with throughout his solo campaign to improve the health care system in Australia. Mr Keen has been subjected to extraordinary intimidation and abuse by members of the bureaucracy, by members of the Health Insurance Commission. I instance this one story which, only by a strange coincidence, I have been able to hear. On 12 January 1993, two officers from the Health Insurance Commission—one by the name of Owen Moore—stormed into Stuart Keen's pharmacy at Wingham, and began verbally abusing the man they thought to be Mr Stuart Keen. After realising that the man was not Stuart Keen, but the pharmacist in charge of the pharmacy at the time, they stormed out of the pharmacy as quickly as they had arrived.

The strange twist to this story is that Wingham, being a small town and also being my home town, the locum in attendance that day just happened to be my father. He received the verbal abuse from the officers of the Health Insurance Commission. It was he, as I say, who copped the tirade of these officers. They should not be allowed to do this. The taxpayers in this country pay their taxes to pay these people their wages. It does not take much to act in a civilised manner. These officers certainly have not acted in a civilised manner in the way they have dealt with this issue. Such bureaucratic heavy-handedness should never take place in Australia, regardless of the circumstances.

Now I realise perfectly well that Mr Keen has allegedly been breaking the law under the current system. But in a moral sense I admire Mr Keen for his efforts to improve the system by showing the obvious flaws in the current system, and by standing firm in his protest against what is, to him, a ridiculous burden that the people of Australia are faced with when buying their prescription drugs. My interest in this begins and ends with the actions of the Minister for Health and the Health Insurance Commission. However, I simply cannot believe that the minister, about to adopt the approach that Stuart Keen has been using, at the same time thanks Stuart Keen for his initiative by presenting him with a courtroom summons on Christmas Eve, charging him with allegedly dispensing generic drugs.

This issue has been dragging on for too long with no satisfactory outcome or improved policy direction in this country, and it is certainly an unsatisfactory outcome for Stuart Keen with court action about to take place. I therefore call on the Minister for Health to address these questions and allegations and to review the individual circumstances of the Stuart Keen case. For the people of Australia, I call on the Minister for Health to come to a decision about generic substitution and to make the obvious decision to follow the lead of Mr Stuart Keen, so that people buying drugs on prescription are no longer burdened with extra costs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a matter which I know to be as close to your heart as it is to mine. I wish to speak in this grievance debate on the managed investments review currently being conducted by the Department of Social Security, under the aegis of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin).

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) previously spoke on this issue in this House. She said that the opposition and the coalition had forced the government into a review. I have said before in this place, and I will say it again, that that is very far from the truth. What happened was that a number of people from the backbench—I was one of them—had long discussions with the Minister for Social Security. I believe that that is what spurred this review.

The review is needed for a number of reasons. First, it should be said that there has been no attempt by the government to rort or to be dishonest over this whole issue. What has taken place, as the minister quite properly determined, is that there was an area of wealth which was escaping the notice of the taxation department and impacting on social security. It was his responsibility to address that matter and to do something about it.

I disagree with unrealised assets being assessed as income. I say quite categorically that I disagree with that. I favour a system of voluntary retirement at 55, with a package of benefits and a system whereby retirement investment can be placed in a way which is beneficial both to our nation and to the people involved.

We have done a lot for pensioners and for self-funded retired people. Some of the items in the last budget took that even further. What I would like to see is all these moves being repackaged into one easily understood system whereby there is security for our aged, self-funded retirees, superannuants and pensioners. Their main gripe is basically getting access to the pension they feel they are entitled to receive, as well as to medical and fringe benefits cards. The ability to get in and do something about it is there. That is what the review is about.

On the question of how these managed investments are taxed, it may well be that it would be much better to tax those investments through the capital gains tax when they are realised rather than doing it in the way that it is being done at present. One of my constituents had 19 changes made to their pension between March and September. The comment that was made by the department was, `There weren't 19 pay periods, so that's impossible'. The reality is that in a number of instances people had two changes and, in one case, three changes in one week to their pension entitlement. We are talking about people in our community who, according to demographic studies, are more law-abiding than any other section of our community. They are people who want security in their old age and certainty in their income. I believe that this government can deliver those things.

What we need to do, therefore, is to repackage what we have already done in a manner which allows them to have investments.
