I suggest to the members of the National Party of Australia—who, I concede, have been very good in their approach to this matter—that housing funding and the funding that goes to our farming community would make very appropriate investments for the elderly of our community, because they would then be looking after the housing needs of their children and grandchildren as well as the long-term interests of the farming community—which, quite frankly, has been screwed by the banks over the last 10 years. The difference in interest rates in this country at the moment shows that the banks are on the best wicket they have been on for over 20 years, and yet they have no concern for the ordinary Australians they supposedly service.

Honourable members, we should recognise that mature Australians have a right to security. They have a right to be able to make their investments in such a way that they can benefit the country. They have a right not to be required to try to engage in rorts or shonky deals or to hide income or put it away. My submission to that review will be a positive one.

This government has done some very good things for our aged community and we have much to be proud of. However, that does not mean that the game is over. We still need to put in an effort for these people so that they have the security of knowing what their pension is going to be, not only this week, but next week and in four weeks time. Currently, they do not have that security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Rorts!

I can tell him that the people of Australia will reject his republic, because the basis of his republic really means that we revert to having—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, have we not had a lot of hypocrisy about these sports grants? Of course the funding went to the areas of need. My seat—which happens to be marginal—is, like many others, a growth area. Unlike the leafy seats on the North Shore, which benefited from 30 years of patronage by conservative governments, seats such as mine need new facilities. These seats do not have the things that other people take for granted. Plenty of applications in my electorate were funded, but plenty more missed out. There were more applications from areas like mine—from growth areas, from new housing estates—than there were from some of those other areas.

PARA.TAB: The problem with opposition members is that when they were little boys and girls, back in the Rip Van Winkle years of Menzies, their mothers and fathers used to tell them that they were born to rule, and that they would inherit all this one day, and that they would get more and more government funds in their born-to-rule areas. But it did not quite work out that way, did it? We have had five elections in a row in which the people of Australia have rejected the born-to-rule aristocracy of the Liberal and National parties, and that is why these people cannot cop it.

Opposition members cannot bear the fact that for 11 years now they have been in opposition and they still cannot get their hands in the lolly jar. They cannot continue to get patronage for wealthy areas, such as the North Shore of Sydney and the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. That is why these $30 million programs are so important: they fund areas of need and they bring the community—in what is a community program—funding for projects in areas that need sports facilities and activities. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Buses: Sales Tax on Safety Equipment

TALK.START.PARA: —The country school bus is an essential part of Australian rural life, but a sales tax anomaly either threatens the safety of children or puts a number of these services in jeopardy. The Queensland transport department has conducted a steep grade audit survey throughout the state, and it is expected that all buses in declared areas will be required to fit drive line retarders to the braking systems. This is already mandatory in parts of Europe and will probably become so throughout all the Australian states. One of my constituents, Peter Wilson of Gin Gin, operates in the Kalpowar area, a locale of mountainous country near Monto. The audit provision will require Mr Wilson to fit a retarder to his Nissan Civilian omnibus at a cost of $11,000.

PARA.TAB: I therefore use this opportunity to ask the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to consider sales tax exemption for these retardants and other safety equipment on buses. After every crash we hear a lot about the safety of buses—people saying that we should have seat belts or that we should have this or that. Requiring this safety installation is a practical expression of concern for our children. These services, as honourable members will know, are already marginal, and they cannot stand added costs. I appeal to the Treasurer to exempt this vital safety equipment from sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been talking about sports rorts and pork-barrelling. The last time the Liberal government was in power was in 1982-83. I happened to go back to some papers I had then when we had a by-election in Flinders called the Flinders by-election. At that time, in December, one of our local newspapers happened to have in it this ad which I have here. It refers to home loan interest rates, tax rebates, new home deposits and the Commonwealth government of Australia. Who paid for this full-page ad in the local Mornington-Frankston Standard? It was the Liberal party. When we have a look at this small local newspaper, what do we find on the next page? It says, `Commonwealth guaranteed' and it is a half-page ad. How much do honourable members think this sort of thing cost? This is 1982 I am talking about and this is a bit of pork-barrelling at its best. This is just before the Flinders by-election, just before they were trying to win Flinders and shore up Malcolm Fraser and get Peter Reith in.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that Peter Reith was elected and then I beat him and I kept him away from the Australian public for 18 months. I am only sorry I could not have kept him away longer. If people want to have a look at pork-barrelling, go back to the 1982 paper. I will show it to them and they will see it. What these guys did makes us look amateurs. I am only ashamed that we are not as good as them. I hope that we get better and better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will recall the dreadful ranking scored by Ros Kelly—
—Order! The honourable member will refer to honourable members by their correct titles.

—They will recall the dreadful ranking scored by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) in Australian environmental matters as reported in a recent environmental-international study. Clearly, the minister has been too busy sports rorting to bother about this appalling indictment of Labor's environmental management.

PARA.TAB: The key to environmental and economic success on both international and domestic levels is a balance—a recognition of the need to create jobs and also to protect our environment for future generations. The minister is not interested in the environment; she is only interested in sports rorting. She defied the inquiry last night. She is an absolute disgrace to Australia and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should take whatever steps are necessary to throw her back to the back bench because she ought not to be a minister in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) is the ultimate hypocrite. Here he is this morning talking about the Labor party's centralism agenda and not wanting to abolish the states; now he attacks the federal government over environment policies, most of which are governed by state governments. What absolute hypocrisy! It only adds to the sham of the opposition which cannot cop the fact that it is still in opposition after 11 years. Its members are whingeing about the environment of all things now. Everyone knows that most of those environmental decisions like those about waste management are controlled by the state governments, the very state governments that the opposition wants to prop up forever with its usual divisive, conservative, states' rights mentality.

PARA.TAB: Getting back to the sports grants: once again, this program is a valuable program for the people of Australia, the ordinary community that wants to fund its tennis court or basketball court or, in my electorate, a netball court for one of the fastest growing sports amongst children in one of the fastest growing areas with one of the youngest populations. So a netball association has got funding in a marginal seat—so what? What would people rather see happen? Would they rather see it all go to the North Shore or their own electorates? It has just got to be done on a needs basis and that is exactly what happened. That is happening, but there is hypocrisy from the opposition. Now it is talking about the environment. As I said, it is the one that wants states' rights to be paramount and yet now it is blaming the federal government for the environment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it fascinating that honourable members have all of a sudden got onto their high horses about this issue and tried to come back to funding in North Shore and all of these areas. The fact is, all we want on this side of the house is fair and equitable funding. The fact is, $30 million dollars was being allocated to organisations around this country for 2,800 applications. I would have thought that the first thing one would do as a minister would be to sit down and assess the implications of allocating this funding and make sure that the funding could be justified on a fair and equitable basis. I can hardly believe that this minister, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) can come into this place and say that she has allocated it on a whiteboard. How does she believe that we can accept $30 million worth of funding allocated on a whiteboard is a fair and equitable way to provide allocations to organisations around this country? This minister should resign.

Since the sports rorts affair first came to light in mid-November, the minister has been asked over 51 questions; she has participated in two of the four censure motions against her and in two discussions of matters of public importance in this House. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order: I ask you to ask the minister to refer to members by their correct titles, please.
—I did remark to the minister that she might do so. I am sure she will in the future.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the labour force statistics released today. What are the implications of that announcement for job seekers?
—The labour force statistics that have been released today are very good news for job seekers. They show that we now have the highest employment level since August 1990—
—Who was in power in 1990?

—The honourable member should listen to this. They also show that we are on track to exceed the highest ever level of employment, which was recorded in July 1990. In relation to our election promise, which was that we would create 500,000 jobs in the term of this government, we have already created in excess of 147,000. So we are now in a position in which economic growth is translating into jobs growth.

PARA.TAB: On the back of those economic indicators that both the Treasurer and I referred to last week—the skilled vacancy index, the ANZ job advertisements index, the DEET leading indicator and the NAB and the Westpac indexes—together with these figures released today, we are seeing the opportunity for increasing, stronger demand for labour.

The unemployment rate has fallen to 10.6 per cent and, whilst I acknowledge that this is still too high, the trends themselves are very encouraging and create a positive environment against which we can get that figure down. We will get it down through the continued policies to sustain these new growth directions as well as targeting those particular groups in the community that will be disadvantaged and that will not necessarily pick up just from economic growth alone. We will not be ignoring the long-term unemployed in our response through the government's white paper.

I would have thought that was good news and I would have thought the opposition would join with us in welcoming that news. But what do we have from the shadow Treasurer? He believes that we can take little comfort from these figures. He thinks we have the blood of a million unemployed on our hands due to the recession and that we are still a long way from alleviating that problem. How insensitive can you get!

With those on the other side of the House, we saw the episode last week where—because the senator who soon wants to join us in this House has no policies—the leadership aspirants, in trying to hang onto their position, decided they would join her. They too started ditching policies so that they could even up and be on an equal footing with her. That is one approach that the leadership aspirants take. But the others want to talk the economy down. The honourable member for Bennelong is one of those, as was demonstrated by his comments about the Ford closure yesterday. We now have the shadow Treasurer talking the economy down too. Downer by name; Downer by nature.

People have asked me why I had the courage to suggest that the shadow Treasurer might be the next leader of the opposition. I do not think there is any shortage of aspirants for that position. What they lack is the policy and the substance. The reality is that we are on the up and our fortunes are increasing because we are getting the economy up. The reason I have suggested that the shadow Treasurer might be the next leader is that I want to make sure that the Liberal Party remains on a down.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In light of this week's 16th anniversary of the worst act of political violence and terrorism in Australia's history, the Hilton bombing, which occurred in the main street of Australia's largest city, why is the minister continuing to refuse to take part in a joint Commonwealth-New South Wales inquiry, requested unanimously by the New South Wales parliament? Why is the minister continuing to pretend that this tragedy and massive security failure never happened? How can the minister justify spending $17 million on 50-year-old war crimes, yet refuse to properly investigate the death and maiming of five Australians and a multi-million dollar bungle by security agencies in front of the world with no-one held accountable?

—The Hilton bombing, its aftermath and the involvement of a variety of police and security agencies, have obviously been the subject of great scrutiny over many years. Certainly the honourable member has raised the question in this place on a number of occasions. It is true that the parliament of New South Wales has requested that the Commonwealth join with the government of New South Wales in the holding of a joint royal commission into the Hilton bombing.

PARA.TAB: It has been the position of this government, which I have reaffirmed, that the Commonwealth would not agree to be involved in a joint royal commission. However, if the New South Wales government wishes to set up a commission, which it obviously has the full power to do, then I can assure this House—as the government has on many occasions previously indicated—that there would be full cooperation from all Commonwealth agencies and authorities into the conduct of that inquiry.

The detail of the various responsibilities of the agencies involved in the security arrangements for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting is well known. It has been the Commonwealth's position that no Commonwealth agency has acted in an improper way. If that view is not shared by the New South Wales government and it wishes to inquire further, then let it proceed down that path and, I repeat: there will be full cooperation.

The honourable member mentioned the $17 million spent on war crimes. The Commonwealth in that case had very clear evidence in front of it, following on from the Menzies commission of inquiry into the alleged entry into Australia of European war criminals and the subsequent investigation of that by the special war crimes investigations unit, that there were cases to be answered. It was the Commonwealth's decision that such evidence could not be ignored and that cases needed to be determined by Australian courts. In the event, no particular conviction was successful. Nonetheless, given the very clear evidence brought forward during that process, it would have been irresponsible of the government to have walked away from evidence of the involvement of people in this country in what, undoubtedly, was the greatest crime against humanity of this century. I do not think the Commonwealth could have taken any other position than the one it took in that matter. In relation to the Hilton bombing, I believe that the ball is in the court of the New South Wales government if it wishes to proceed with an inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. The Treasurer recently announced revisions to the economic forecasts contained in last year's budget. Can he advise the House whether those revisions mean that the expected budget bottom line has now also been revised?

—The question raised by the honourable member for Perth enables me to advise the House that the government's forecast for the budget outcome for this year is now for a notably lower deficit than that which was forecast in the budget last August. The House will recall that last week I gave revised economic outlook figures for GDP, inflation, employment and the unemployment rate. Honourable members will recall that GDP moved up from 2 3/4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent growth this year. Inflation is down 1 1/2 per cent, from 3 1/2 per cent to two per cent. Employment is up one per cent, from three quarters of a per cent growth to 1 3/4 per cent. The participation rate is up by three quarters of a per cent and the unemployment rate remains much the same, at around 10 3/4 per cent. In the light of today's continued reduction in the unemployment rate, that figure might be starting to look a little bit conservative.

PARA.TAB: The implications of this for the budget outcome are that outlays are expected to be around a quarter of a billion dollars higher than at budget time. The economic improvements reduce outlays by some $300 million, but other factors will swamp that improvement. They include the post-budget decisions to amend or remove some budget measures to reduce outlays and also higher than expected outlays on a number of social security payments. All up, outlays increase by about a quarter of a billion dollars.

On the revenue side, the improved economic parameters mean that gross pay-as-you-earn receipts are now expected to be $1.3 billion higher than was budgeted for. The net effect of the variations to other receipts is to add a further $0.2 billion—$200 million—to revenue. So revenue will increase all up by about $1 1/2 billion dollars. In the overall budget outcome, which has outlays up by a quarter of a billion dollars and revenue up by $1 1/2 billion, the deficit is reduced by $1 1/4 billion, from the $16 billion that we budgeted for to $14 3/4 billion now. As a percentage of GDP, that takes it down from 3.8 per cent at the time of the budget to 3 1/2 per cent now.I stress that these figures are still only estimates; there could be considerable variations when the final results are posted. But there seems little doubt that the end result will be much better than was originally forecast in the budget.

This is clearly very good news for the economy and the nation. It demonstrates quite clearly the capacity of economic recovery to assist the process of restoring the budget outcome. The government is of course very much committed to reducing the deficit to around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97. We have made that our objective over the last couple of years and it remains our objective. These announcements today clearly take us a further step along the way.

However, I do need to sound a note of caution: it does not necessarily follow that the benefits of the budget for 1993-94 from the improved economic growth will automatically flow into 1994-95. Although it is very early days to be making these forecasts, our expectation at the moment would be that we will not receive the same boost to the budget outcome in 1994-95 as we appear likely to receive in 1993-94. This is principally because, although we expect GDP to be growing strongly in 1994-95, low inflation could mean that nominal GDP will be less than had been previously anticipated, so the revenue improvement of 1993-94 may not run through into 1994-95. Nevertheless, it is very early in the piece to be making these judgments and the likely budget outcome for 1994-95 will be much clearer by the time we come to the May budget.

One thing we can be absolutely sure about is that the outlook is for continued economic recovery with low inflation, substantial employment growth and declining unemployment. I can assure the House that in the May budget the government will be making every attempt to further encourage and nurture those very favourable developments.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I hope her babies were all right. By the minister's own admission, the whiteboard used to assess the criteria for the sports grants was the only working document her office, as opposed to her department, used to compile and assess all available data in relation to these applications. By the minister's own evidence to the committee, her whiteboard table would have contained between 12 and 18 different horizontal headings for up to 100 applications listed vertically on the board at any one time, which translates into between 1,200 and 1,800 boxes on the board. Can the minister please detail for the House the headings of all categories used to compile these vast tables; the exact nature of the coding system used for each criterion—was it a numeric system; how it was recorded and tallied on the whiteboard; how the applications were ranked; and whether the highest ranking applications were always the ones chosen?

—I was referring to office equipment, not to a document. As I said to the honourable member last night—in response to the 75 questions she asked me then—there were also 104 drawers-full of documents. On many occasions last night I went through in great detail with her the question that she has just put. She might like to refresh her memory by going through Hansard to see the 75 questions she put to me last night.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Do the recent revisions to budget forecasts indicate that the government's economic policies are working? Does the minister observe the 10-day rule when making presentations to cabinet? Is the government aware of criticisms of these policies and procedures and is the government considering any alternatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As the honourable member would be aware from the answers given by the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the government is well on track with the improvements in the economy suggested by our revised forecasts and the policies that were implemented in the course of the last couple of weeks.

PARA.TAB: As to whether I always observe the 10-day rule, the answer is no. From time to time, a circumstance arises when I and other ministers who have responsibilities in the economy are obliged to put in matters more rapidly either for determination by the cabinet or basically for determination out of the portfolios and by discussion with the Prime Minister.

However, there is a certain amount of alternative advice circulating in the public at the moment as to how we might handle these things. The most recent advice, according to the Australian Financial Review, has been given by the opposition spokesperson on urban and regional affairs—and shadow opposition leader to the opposition leader. She has some fairly interesting methods for handling both these problems. After I have had a chance to elaborate on them, I will suggest whether or not we will adopt them.

Apparently, she made a speech to a group of business leaders in recent times, causing one of them to say, `I went along with a fairly positive view of her; I came away wanting to weep'. I guess the opposition leader would agree with the second of those sentiments. One of the things that caused this individual to weep was an analysis of the actions of the former Treasurer, now Prime Minister, during the floating of the Australian dollar. Her principal criticism of that act was apparently not the floating of the dollar but that the then Treasurer evidently failed to observe the 10-day rule. So, according to Bronwyn Bishop, even when confronted with a currency crisis, the 10-day period of consultation and discussion within the government should have occurred and then at some point an action taken in response to it.

One really wonders what would have occurred in those 10 days if Bronwyn Bishop had been the Treasurer. I suppose day one would have produced a telephone call to Paris to find out whether Trevor Boucher had hedged his salary against downward movements of the Australian dollar. If the answer were yes, immediate recall; if the answer were no, immediate recall on the grounds of stupidity.

Day two would have been spent in a frenetic Commonwealth car trip around Sydney to various points of interest; and day three would have been spent giving the old gold pass a real work-out between Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra and then a discussion with the press about how much stamina she had in the face of the economic turmoil around her.

On day four she would have burst into a press conference for Senator Schacht, who would be opposition science spokesman. She would have said to Senator Schacht that quite clearly he was planning at some point three or four years down the line, after the next election, to organise a golden parachute for someone. On day five—this would probably be the end of the country—there would have been a seance around the cabinet table at which she would have discussed whether or not the 10-day rule would be observed, and they would call up the ghost of Sir Otto Niemeyer.

In case the businessman thought that this was just an offhand remark by Bronwyn Bishop and not a serious strategy, all was revealed later in the course of Bronwyn Bishop's speech. Bronwyn, spokesperson for the opposition, genuinely wants a low Australian dollar. That is the reason why she criticised the then Treasurer for not observing the 10-day rule. An economist said that he got the impression that she thought merchandise trade surpluses with some of the Asian economies were actually a bad thing—`What we need to do is to induce a currency crisis and organise bad merchandise trade deficits with our Asian economies in order to produce in the course of that a 20c dollar'.

She had a few other ideas on how we might deal with the economy. While all this was going on, she evidently proposed that she should take a trip to Germany. She says that during the 1980s she visited the Bundesbank and evidently buttonholed some unfortunate on the front desk and asked the official what would happen if she went around and gave everybody in Germany a credit card with 1,000 marks on it. She then revealed herself to be a dab hand with Colonel Klink accents because she evidently then said to this gathering of economists that she had his assurance that if she were to hand everybody a 1,000 mark credit note the Bundesbank would actually do something about it. With these revelations, she further confused her audience at CEDA.
She shares two things in common with the Leader of the Opposition. On the analysis of one fellow:

ANSWER.PARA: The speech was full of contradictions. Did she want to re-regulate, deregulate? She seems content with motherhood statements.
That certainly applies to the opposition leader's policy backflips in the last little while. Another said:
There was a lot of history, some of it a pretty unusual version, and not much at all about where we are going from here. I'd say the audience was pretty surprised.
There is not a great deal of difference in these areas for policy formulation between the Leader of the Opposition and his would-be shadow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is it the case that the minister kept her working notes for the expenditure of $30 million of taxpayers' money on a whiteboard because it allowed the audit trail to be easily wiped out, which is not possible when decision making is documented?
—Absolutely not. I answered all of those questions last night. Many of them were directed by you through the opposition members of the committee.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of analysis which compares Australia's export performance in recent years with other major economies? Can the Prime Minister tell the House how Australia's performance rates?

—I have talked about, as have other ministers, the transformation that has occurred in the fabric of the Australian economy over the last decade. This is most obvious in the success we have had in the shift to exports and, within exports, the shift to manufacturing and the elaborate transformation of manufactured products. Exports now stand at around 20 per cent of our gross domestic product. A decade ago that figure was around 13 per cent. That is an enormous change in the percentage of the economy's product going to exports—from 13 per cent to 20 per cent.
—Why do we have debt and no jobs?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor does not have a licence to comment on every sentence that every minister utters in this place. I would ask him to just keep quiet.

—We have been among the most efficient and competitive producers of agricultural and mineral products. Today we can also make that claim in relation to manufacturing and services. I am pleased today to be able to inform the House of recent analysis using—
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—I was talking to him!
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—I am pleased today to be able to inform the House of recent analysis using the United Nations trade database. That allows us to compare Australia's performance with other major trading nations and the comparisons are very encouraging.

PARA.TAB: Between 1986 and 1992 our elaborately transformed manufactured exports grew by over 19 per cent a year, whereas the global trade from the UN database of elaborately transformed manufactures over the same period was 11.3 per cent—19 per cent for Australia in the growth of elaborately transformed manufactures and 11 per cent for the world in general. Indeed, Australia's performance was the fastest of all OECD economies. These data also confirm the importance of East Asia as the most dynamic trading area in the world. While our growth in ETMs has outstripped those in the OECD, a number of our Asian neighbours have experienced even more rapid growth, with Indonesia heading the countries surveyed with an annual increase of elaborately transformed exports of 35 per cent. Thailand was next with 32 per cent.

The simple message is that we have been getting things right domestically. That is as a result of our being well placed to take advantage of the burgeoning market in the region and the growth of elaborately transformed manufactures in the Asia-Pacific. This is coming from our 30 per cent improvement in competitiveness, the two per cent inflation rate, the lowest interest rates for 20 years, profit levels approaching record highs, subdued wages, a cooperative and skilled work force and the lowest tax country in the Western world. All of these things have meant that in this area we have seen a tremendous improvement.

That growth is coming through the economy. We are seeing the economy pick up and accelerate. We are seeing that change the budget figuring, as the Treasurer indicated earlier in question time. That is also now flowing into the labour market, as my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training also indicated at question time. Today's labour force figures are an indication of that. They are very encouraging news for the labour market, for its long-term future and for the unemployed—with 145,000 job growths since August over that five-month period, a further 22,000 persons employed in the course of last month and the unemployment rate dropping slightly again to 10.6 per cent.

As the minister said, this puts the government well on the way to meeting its 500,000 job forecast for the three years, a forecast which was derided by the Leader of the Opposition at the time it was announced. In the same forecast of 1983, for 500,000 in the term, we actually surpassed it by 200,000. On this occasion we are well on the way to meeting the 500,000 job figure for the three-year period.

That is very good news on the labour market and good news on jobs. This should be comforting and encouraging to the Australian community. It comes from the massive transformation of the economy being led by exports and, most particularly, by elaborately transformed manufactures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Last night the minister informed the committee that the reason for the acceptance—
—You have got money for your own pool.
—Order! The honourable member for Burke!

—I will start again. Last night the minister informed the committee that the reason for the acceptance and approval of seven late applications for grants under the sports rorts program was that she `made a judgment that they weren't late'. Why did she make a judgment that these seven, including six to marginal Labor electorates, were not late when the application from the Kilkivan Tennis Club was rejected because it was one day late and missed, despite the fact that her department had told it that it was in order to do so?

—The honourable member was there last night when I answered this question in detail. I will formally table my response to that question today. But the details of that were outlined last night in considerable detail at the parliamentary committee. I noticed that the honourable member was there.
—Read the Hansard.
—Read the Hansard!
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is it in order to have a recycling of questions perpetually by the opposition in these matters, particularly by the very low flying shadow minister opposite?
—On the Prime Minister's point of order: stealth bombers are low flying and they drop bombs on him.
—There is no point of order on either occasion.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. What action is the Australian government taking to assist those people affected by the latest tragic upsurge of violence in the former Yugoslavia?

—It is a very great privilege to be called to answer the last question in this place from the retiring member for Bonython, who has espoused the values of tolerance and internationalism in such a way as to leave him, as I think, one of my most distinguished predecessors in this portfolio, and one of the most respected ministers this House has seen. I believe that he will leave the House with those values intact, and one hopes that they will be used to great effect in whatever occupation awaits him in the future. He is not only our most distinguished and longest serving Minister for Health and the father of Medicare but, in my own portfolio of development cooperation, he was one of those who made the Australian aid program well respected around the world. I wish him well.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the substance of the honourable member's question. The House heard from the Prime Minister earlier in the week of the concern which is felt by all Australians at the awful carnage which is being wreaked in the former Yugoslavia and of the intention of the Australian government to add, in so far as it is within its means, to the efforts that we have made of a humanitarian kind to assist the victims of that carnage. I have today agreed to a further increase in Australian humanitarian aid to Bosnia, to the former Yugoslavia, worth an additional $1 million.

As with most of our previous aid to people in the former Yugoslavia, the bulk of this additional assistance will be provided through international agencies. Those agencies have the ability to get aid through to the victims of the conflict, often in the most difficult of circumstances, and they are respected for their impartiality as between the various victims of the conflict and for their efficiency in getting the aid through. It is for those reasons that $650,000 will be provided to continue our support for relief activities which are run by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Committee of the Red Cross. In respect of those, the UNHCR is the lead agency in the former Yugoslavia and it is facing a massive shortfall in the funds available to it. So Australia's additional assistance of $550,000 to that body will help it meet pressing needs for shelter, heating and medical treatment. I have also allocated $100,000 to the ICRC, the International Committee of the Red Cross, particularly to help it trace displaced persons and to treat the civilian casualties of the fighting.

In recognition of the considerable trauma which has been inflicted on women, especially those women who have been sexually assaulted during the conflict, I have allocated $50,000 to Austcare's women's shelter in Zagreb which caters for refugees and rape victims. I am proud to say that this centre is being run by two very dedicated Australians and I am very proud that the government has been able to support the efforts they are making. In addition to that, I have made arrangements for $300,000 from funds which were previously allocated to CARE Australia for relief projects in Africa, which it has proved impossible to utilise fully, to be available to support its trucking operations which deliver relief throughout the former Yugoslavia.

This announcement brings to $3.35 million the total amount of assistance which the Australian government has provided to people in the former Yugoslavia since the conflict began. While it will help to alleviate some of the suffering which has been so graphically illustrated by the slaughter of weekend shoppers in Sarajevo, as the Prime Minister said earlier in the week, that suffering will continue until the warring parties can be prevailed upon to agree and adhere to a lasting peace. Australia will continue to add its efforts to that enterprise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the comments of the Auditor-General in today's Australian Financial Review. In relation to sports grants, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is quite likely that there was fraud, because in the world today where there is easy money, if it is not being followed up and matched, usually fraud will occur.
Where there is relatively easy money that is not followed up, fraud tends to gather like flies around a carcass.

Does the minister now concede that she was grossly negligent in keeping no documentation of her decision making in awarding $30 million—apart from textacolour on a whiteboard which has now been cleaned—and leaving the scheme so prone to fraud, as reported by the Auditor-General?

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no finding of fraud; there was no corruption; there was no wrongdoing; and there was no evidence of political bias. I have answered questions for 5 1/2 hours before a parliamentary committee. I have answered 320 questions from the opposition. I have gone into details on all these matters. I have already said that my department is already acting on the recommendations of administration from the Auditor-General.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Tourism. What benefits are flowing to the tourism industry as a result of Australia's closer economic and cultural ties with Asia, particularly from today, the start of the Chinese new year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is the official start of the Chinese new year in the Year of the Dog. It is a year that promises outstanding success for the tourism industry because an unprecedented number of Asian visitors have decided to celebrate Chinese new year in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The demand for airline seats has meant that Qantas and a number of prominent Asian airlines have had to schedule an extra 40 flights just to cope with the demand of Asians who want to celebrate Chinese new year in Australia. These extra flights will include 22 from Taiwan, 14 from Hong Kong and two each from Singapore and Korea. This means that about 10,000 extra Asian visitors have decided to come to Australia to welcome in the Year of the Dog. This translates to a $25 million boost to the Australian tourism industry—something that I would hope all honourable members would welcome.

The benefits of the additional visitor expenditure will not be concentrated just in Sydney; additional flights are scheduled for Cairns, Brisbane and Melbourne. The good thing is that this influx will help fill a period which has traditionally been quiet, especially in the accommodation sector. This is not just a one-off event; we are getting phenomenal rates of growth from countries such as Taiwan and Korea, with about a 70 per cent increase over the previous year's figures. This will be maintained.

The government's efforts to expand Asian tourism to Australia can be contrasted with some comments which have been made in recent days by people on the other side of this House. Last week the honourable member for Kennedy complained about the Federal Airports Corporation building a modern international passenger terminal at Brisbane to cater for rapid growth in the number of international travellers to Queensland. He complained:

ANSWER.PARA: this is the honourable member for Kennedy; a Queensland National Party member—
for an international airport to cater not for Australians but for very rich foreigners who are visiting Australia.

Forget about the need to provide better terminal facilities for the increasing number of aircraft that will be using Brisbane airport; forget about the extra export earnings for Australia through the tourism industry; forget about the extra investment that will be encouraged; forget about the extra jobs for young Australians—the honourable member for Kennedy says that we have to be worried about foreign visitors using a new terminal at Brisbane. I do not know what the constituents of the electorate of the honourable member for Moncrieff are when they use the international terminal at Brisbane!

PARA.TAB: It goes to show that, at the moment, we have on the record the Queensland Nationals saying that they are opposed to tourism infrastructure spending because rich foreigners benefit. That is the position of the Queensland Nationals. The Queensland Nationals are worried about the extra export earnings, the extra investment, the extra jobs! This is slightly different from the views of some members of the opposition. The shadow minister for tourism and aviation, when visiting a New South Wales Nationals electorate—that of the honourable member for Cowper—had a different view on foreigners visiting and using our airport facilities. In the Coffs Harbour Advocate, which I am sure is a very prominent newspaper on the north coast, there is a story under the headline `Jull supports airport push', which states:

ANSWER.PARA: The federal opposition would seriously consider—
that is a very strong commitment—
funding the upgrading of the Coffs Harbour airport to international standard.

On the one hand, we have the Queensland Nationals saying they are very worried about tourism and transport infrastructure being used for the benefit of the foreign visitors. On the other hand, the New South Wales Nationals and the Queensland Liberals are saying that it is something they are going to encourage and expand. There is no consistency whatsoever; they are all over the place.

PARA.TAB: The period of the Hawke and Keating governments has seen Labor provide an eightfold increase in funding for the Australian Tourist Commission to boost the promotion of the Australian tourism industry overseas. This funding has resulted in a trebling of the number of international visitors to Australia. We could do with perhaps a bit more support from honourable members opposite and a bit more consistency as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a matter for your consideration. In view of the proposal to change the sitting hours of the House of Representatives, the introduction of a main committee, or second chamber, to also handle legislation and the fact that those activities will run concurrently—I recognise there are many issues for you and the government to address on this matter and it will be necessary for honourable members to be kept informed of progress of legislation in both chambers—will you investigate the possibility of the provision of a split or dual television screen showing each chamber simultaneously to enable honourable members to be fully informed of all proceedings of both chambers?

—The honourable member has raised an issue which I think is of concern to all honourable members, given the operation of a second chamber as proposed in the new arrangements for this place. I can say to him that I have had the opportunity to look at one or two matters which are relevant to that and there are a number of options that are available. One option is that each member could be provided with a new television set capable of picture on picture. I understand that they would need to be 82-inch models that would cost about $2,877 each, so I think we might put that aside.
—Ros can get it out of the $30 million.
—Or get it from the sandwich boy.

—Order! A second option is to buy each member a second television receiver for simultaneous monitoring. They would only be $500 each but, fortunately, there is a better option. That is, we could probably allocate two additional House monitoring service channels: one for the main committee, and one for a split screen of the House of Representatives chamber and the main committee through technology which would only cost, we think, around $15,000. That would provide the technical features to which the honourable member refers to give the service to all members. I will further investigate the issue and, as the second chamber gets under way, we will look at ways in which we can provide that service.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—Please proceed.

—The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) implied some improper motives to my representation on behalf of constituents on developing sport in my electorate. May I say, I am proud to represent my constituents and will continue to do so. I look forward to fair consideration, with proper audit of taxpayers' funds.
—I might just say to the honourable member that that is not within the guidelines of a personal explanation. But as he has done it there is not much more I can do.

DEBATE.TITLE: RETIREMENTS: HONOURABLE MEMBER FOR BONYTHON AND HONOURABLE MEMBER FOR WARRINGAH

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am sure all honourable members are aware that today is formally the last day in this place for two longstanding members of the House of Representatives. It is now my intention to give the opportunity for both those honourable members to say a few words to the House with my indulgence.

—On reflecting on my 17 years experience in this House, I recognise that my generation of Labor politicians—that is, those who first entered this House in the 1970s and who are now approaching the sere and yellow leaf of life—has been an extremely fortunate generation. We were not condemned to live long years in the wilderness as were our colleagues under Dr Evatt and Arthur Calwell. Nor did we have only a limited, if rather euphoric, brief period of government like those under Gough Whitlam.

PARA.TAB: We are in fact the most fortunate generation yet of Labor politicians at the national level. Those of us who were ministers—and most of that generation were—have very great reason to be grateful to the Australian people. I, particularly, have reason to be so to my electors in Bonython, who supported me in both the good and bad times, and to my caucus colleagues for the support they gave to me and to those other members of that generation.

We did spend a stint in opposition, which was of value to us. I am not necessarily recommending it, but a short period in opposition does a number of things. It hones one's political steel and it breeds a gritty determination not to let it happen again.

On the other hand, I suspect that a long stint in opposition must be pretty demoralising and disillusioning. In one sense, I regret that Jim Carlton, who came into the House the same day as I did and who became a personal friend, had so little time in his many years in this place to make full use of his undoubted governing and administrative talents. Yet, of course, his disappointment reflected our success, and such are the cruelties of adversarial politics.

Of course, in 1977 when I came in, it was we who were dispirited. We had had the trauma of 1975 and the second crushing electoral defeat of 1977, which had convinced many in the Labor Party that we were doomed again to languish in the wilderness for many long years. That we did not was, above all, due to the first Labor leader under whom I served—Bill Hayden. His achievement in those years was to convince the Labor Party to have faith in itself. Through hard but unspectacular work, he built a new team, developed new policies, reformed the Labor Party and mobilised the opposition. I have long thought that the leadership of the federal opposition is the most demanding and thankless task in federal politics, succoured only by the promise of ultimate reward—and, of course, Bill Hayden did not get that reward.

The foundations of Labor's achievements in the 1980s were built by Bill Hayden. The electoral victory of 1983 was as much Hayden's victory as Hawke's. Hawke's team was very much Hayden's team. Many of the policies, particularly the social policies of the Hawke government, were conceived under Hayden in opposition. Hayden's own blend of tough, realistic economic policies with strong social commitments were characteristic of the social democratic project in this country in the 1980s.

When we came to power, the greatest challenge for the Hawke government was to reach an accommodation with the dominant intellectual climate of the time, of the decade, which very much favoured free and open markets, deregulation and the privatisation of government enterprises. Thus we floated the dollar, opened the Australian system to competition, dismantled protection, embraced the GATT, undertook judicious privatisation and began the erosion of regulation. Given the intellectual climate of the time, no government could have survived without that accommodation. More importantly, I believe that most of these policies, however difficult for many in our own party, were, in the long term, both necessary and desirable for the economic good of this country.

Superficial comparisons were often made with other conservative regimes in the Western world. Often those comparisons admitted subtle distinctions between the economic policies pursued here and those in other countries in the Western world. But those comparisons did ignore entirely two other aspects of what I call the social democratic project in Australia in the 1980s that make that project unique.

First, change was done in this country in cooperation with organised labour, not against it. There has been much talk over time in the Labor Party about the solidarity of the labour movement, the unity of the political and industrial wings of the party. If we look at our national record, more often in the past that has been breached and broken. In a way, it has been more honoured in the breach than in the fact. But under this government the accord has been the sheet anchor of government, the symbol of the solidarity of Labor in facing the difficult policy challenges of the 1980s and 1990s.

The second distinction is that the economic changes we followed through in that period were accompanied by significant social change. One cannot forget the other side of the government's effort in the 1980s. The economic rationalist arguments were turned against some of its own most fervent supporters with the capital gains tax and fringe benefits measures. Medicare, a national health scheme, was at last introduced into this country.

We had a massive transformation of the social security system under Brian Howe. I believe that the family allowance supplement, now the additional family payment, is the most significant single new benefit in this country since the old age pension. I recognise again that it was built on ideas that came originally from the opposition. The most substantial overhaul of services for the aged in the history of the Commonwealth took place in the 1980s.

We had a revolution in school retention rates. In the new areas, there was much pioneering work done in environmental protection, in women's rights and in child care. I think we in this country often do ourselves a disservice by selling the country short, by selling our achievements short. What needs to be said is that the social democratic project in Australia is the most significant and now the most successful in the Western world in the last decades of the 20th century.

The second of the leaders I served under, Bob Hawke, presided over most of this period. As a manager of men and women, Bob Hawke had few peers. I suppose that history will regard his most significant achievement as his ability to shift profoundly the ideology and policies of our party without any serious fracture or disruption. When we consider the fissiparous history of the Labor Party in this country, that is a magnificent achievement.

Looking forward, I spoke of the luck of my generation of Labor politicians. I suspect that the present generation might be equally fortunate, because the structures of electoral behaviour now favour the Labor Party. The peak of the Liberal cycle which saw them victorious in most of the states in the last four years has almost certainly passed and trends are likely now to move in Labor's favour. The congruence of the economic cycle and the electoral cycle in the mid-1990s for the first time since 1984 will work in Labor's favour. The general conservatism of the electorate, allied with the fact that, by 1996, over one-third of the electorate will never as adults have known any other national government but a Labor one will also tend to favour the incumbent government—not, of course, that victory can be determined in this kind of way. Much will depend on luck, accidents, performance and perceptions.

Much too will depend on the third of the leaders under whom I served, Paul Keating. Of course, at this stage we cannot attempt a historic verdict on the present Prime Minister. But to me it is inconceivable that we could have won the last election against the tide if he had not been our leader. Even then, he needed some help from the opposition. He is, as we all know, an extraordinary mixture of a visionary, a masterly persuader and a political street fighter. I think it is the working out of these elements which will do much to determine the fate of this government in the years ahead.

In concluding, I just want to speak of three proposals with which I was particularly associated, the first being Medicare. After 10 years it is now established and popular as the basis of our health system. I believe that, hopefully, we will now finish the debate on principles and both sides can work together to improve the system that exists. No system is immutable and we should be constantly looking at ways in which we can improve it.

We are committed in this country to a mixed private and public system and, therefore, we need to pay attention to the levels of private insurance. But, in doing so, we have to watch that any short-term steps do not endanger the basic principles of Medicare. Moreover, any decent health economist will tell you that the levels of private insurance are a third or fourth order subject.

The central issue for the health system is the working of the public hospital system, and I can be completely bipartisan here. I believe that the hospital reforms introduced by Mrs Tehan in Victoria are the most imaginative set of reforms to deal with the hospital system in this country in the last half a dozen years. I notice that they are now likely to be taken up by other Liberal and Labor governments around the country. Those reforms will do much to sustain the public hospital side of Medicare, provided they are not used simply to save money, and one always has to watch that danger. By using the casemix approach, Mrs Tehan has inaugurated a whole new development in hospital systems in this country. The Commonwealth has always supported that casemix approach and I hope we, as a government, will continue to work with Mrs Tehan and other reforming state health ministers in supporting the casemix approach.

Secondly, I want to refer to another area I was deeply involved with—that is, AIDS. I think we as a community can be rightly proud of our response to the AIDS epidemic and this parliament to its bipartisan approach. But we cannot afford to be complacent in this area. There is a continuing need for community awareness and a constant need to inform each generation of young people of the dangers.

We should also note that Asia, which was the last continent to be affected by the AIDS virus, is now facing a rapidly rising number of cases. Given the whole thrust of our foreign policy, I think we have a responsibility to Asia in that area, particularly as we have much greater experience and expertise in handling this disease.

Finally, we will debate parliamentary reform this afternoon. I do hope that, despite many of the controversies about one or two aspects of that reform, this parliament will see it as a package which I hope will help to restore confidence in and respect for this institution and its members. I hope too that the reformed sitting hours will do something to relieve some of the pressures placed on the families of members who are asked to make many sacrifices. I know too well the impact of such pressures on our families. In this regard, I want to thank my daughter, Susan, and my son, Simon, for their healthy puncturing of all my pomposities and for their love, understanding and support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) on his valedictory speech. Of course, he is only a new boy in the place. He came in 1977. I am glad to see that the other sole remaining member of the class of 69, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), is in the chamber. There were 28 of us who came into parliament in 1969. Unfortunately, there was a predominance on the Labor side—23 of those 28 were from the Labor Party and five were from my side. But it was not a bad class. Of the 28 of us, 11 finished up as ministers, one became Prime Minister and another became deputy leader of my party. Therefore, I think we can be quite proud of the contribution that the sixty-niners have made.

PARA.TAB: I remember that things were very different in those days. These days it seems that people rush in and make their maiden speech on the same day as they arrive. I was a little different. I did not make my maiden speech until 1970. I made it on the Wheat Stabilisation Bill 1970, which caused a bit of controversy because Warringah is not known as a premium wheat growing area. The Country Party, as it was then known, thought that a new junior Liberal Party member leading off the debate in the second reading stage was a little unusual.

The speakers in those days were perhaps a little more assiduous in maintaining the standing orders. One could not use the Wheat Stabilisation Bill 1970 as a vehicle for speaking glowingly about the electorate of Warringah or what I wished to do in a number of other areas in the parliament over the years ahead. So I will take the opportunity to mention a couple of those things here today.

Being in the parliament is an enormous privilege and, as the honourable member for Bonython has said, that is capped, if you are privileged enough, by becoming a minister. Becoming a minister gives you the opportunity, as no other position does, to put into practice some of the things that you would like to see done. I remember my ministerial role in a couple of ministries with very great affection because it gave me the opportunity of proving not only that I could work long hours and hard but also that we as a government could do many things for people which otherwise they would not be able to hope for. I think particularly of the difficulties in the immigration and ethnic affairs area when Australia faced a challenge which it had never faced before—the potential arrival of hundreds of thousands of distressed refugees from Indo-China in small boats. We as a government and I as the minister helped to deal with that situation in a way which, I believe, did Australia great credit.

I think the prime ministership of Malcolm Fraser has been denigrated far too much—not so much by his political opponents, but by those who should be his political supporters. In the sweep of history great achievements were made by the Fraser ministries. His prime ministership will be seen as one when great advances were made. The honourable member for Bonython was kind enough to refer to one of them.

All political careers have some high points and they also seem to have a few low points, as you may have noticed, Mr Speaker. I guess that I have had my share of low points, but then again, as the song says, `Too few to mention'. I am sorry that my colleague and friend the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) is not in the House because, although they might have knocked a few spots off us on the political side of things, we never lost a doubles match against the Senate in 17 years.

There are so many areas I would like to talk about, but I do not think that this is the sort of speech to dwell on the past. I want to talk about the future and what I hope to see coming from members on both sides of this House. I am very concerned that there is a great alienation, particularly amongst the younger people in the community. I think that all political parties should be concentrating very hard on developing policies which will bring back, especially to young people, a sense of personal worth, a feeling that how they live their lives and the contribution their lives can make to the greater good really matters.

At present, I find that a lot of young people see no worth in their lives. They fear the future. They do not know what it holds for them. That is very sad. I come from outside a little country town in the north-west of New South Wales. I remember growing up there, where everybody, no matter what their station in life—whether they were a boundary rider, a rabbiter or owned the biggest property around the place—had a sense of personal worth. Their sense of personal worth was recognised by the other members of the community. Particularly in large cities these days, I find that sense of personal worth missing. I believe that we should be doing something about it.

One of the other areas I would like to mention relates to the environment. We live in the most ecologically sensitive geographic area in the world. The continent of Australia is, ecologically, extremely fragile. We have not always appreciated that. We should pay far more attention to what that fragility means for the future of people living in this country and how they treat it. Our environment is not as forgiving in an ecological sense as other countries around the world. If we do not understand it and if we do not start to adapt our policies to take that fragility very much into consideration, then so much of Australia will be devastated and will not become available for future generations.

I think we should be looking very carefully, for instance, at population size. I do not hear too much discussion about ideal population sizes for Australia. We tried to deal with that in the 1970s. Because Australia is so big some people have put forward the view that we can accept hundreds of millions of people. I do not believe that to be the case. We have to look very carefully at population strategies and land management strategies in the future, particularly in rural areas. Much more consideration at all levels of government has to be devoted to that. I believe that urban and regional planning in Australia leaves an enormous amount to be desired. We really have to look very much more carefully at that.

Today I would also like to mention parliament itself. All of us must remember that we are but part of a continuum. We are here for a little while and then we go away. If we do not understand that, then we can do very great damage to the institution which is absolutely an underpinning of our democracy here in Australia. If we by our actions, and future members by their actions, tear down the public standing of the parliament, then we are tearing down the very future of democracy in this country. Leaders of parties have a very great responsibility in this area.

We are debating changes to the standing orders. I do not think that at this stage of the debate we have addressed the problem of an attitude towards this place. When I came into the parliament—and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) was in the parliament—question time was a vital, active, involved time for the chamber. People were jumping up on both sides of the House. Since that time the chamber has become sterile, there has not been the participation that used to be evident, and its public impact has diminished to an extraordinary degree. That has been brought about by successive leaders of governments and leaders of oppositions.

We must have, in my view, a commitment to an attitude which allows and encourages people to participate. Question time is so structured these days that everybody who has not been given a question to ask is fairly divorced from the proceedings of the House.

We had today a marvellous example of how things can change here in the parliament. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) asked the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) a question without notice. I assume it was without notice because I know there is no collusion between the honourable member for North Sydney and the government—perish the thought. The fact of the matter is that he asked the question and the Attorney-General, to his great credit, came to the dispatch box and answered it without a note. When I was a minister, all those years ago, if we read an answer it showed to our colleagues and to the opposition that we were not in control of our brief; we did not know what we were talking about and had to rely upon the written answer provided by our department.

So often over the last few years we have had these long answers to questions written out to such a degree that members of the opposition have been making comments like `page 1' as the minister at the dispatch box turns over to page 2. That, in my view, has to stop. If question time is going to be effective it really has to be about people asking questions without notice and ministers trying to provide short informative answers.

The other thing that it depends very much upon—and dare I say this—is the role of the Speaker himself or herself. I very much enjoyed my time sitting in the chair as a deputy chairman of committees. I always wanted to umpire a John McEnroe tennis match. I reckon I could have handled a John McEnroe tennis match. The Speaker is in that role at present. I mention John McEnroe particularly because John McEnroe was a magnificent, talented tennis player, but by his actions—his tantrums, his performance, his language—he brought great discredit in many ways to the fine game of tennis.

TALK.START.PARA: —He gave the opposition a serve.

—He gave the opposition a serve and he copped a few serves himself. But the essential point is that, despite his magnificent tennis talent, he will not be remembered for that; he will be remembered for his display contrary to the spirit of the game. I think there is a lesson in that for all members of parliament.

PARA.TAB: That is the end of the reflections and the hopes for the future. You would think it was very remiss of me if I did not mention the challenge of my new job. Probably nothing instantly springs to your mind when I mention the initials PCAI—the Plastics, Chemicals and Allied Industries Association. I hope you will be hearing a lot about the PCAI in the future, and I look forward to very close consultations with members of governments and oppositions at all levels of government in Australia. It is a challenging and very exciting job. It is certainly going to occupy my time and give me another challenge. It just shows all members of parliament that there are people out there who are prepared to look for your talents and to provide you with challenging opportunities in the future.

There are a number of people I would like to thank. I thank all the people who work in Parliament House. I reckon the people who work in Parliament House are simply terrific. It does not matter what role they have. They work in the committees, they work in the chamber, they work as attendants—they work all over the place. In my 24 1/2 years here I have never had any trouble or difficulty with those people. I thank them and place on record how very pleasant they have made my stay in this parliament.

I also thank the loyal and constant members of the Liberal Party. As the honourable member for Bonython said, it gets a bit wearing after a number of years in opposition, and that goes as much for the parliamentarians as for the supporters of the party. I have no doubt that their constancy and they loyalty will be rewarded positively in the near future.

I particularly mention my staff. I have been extremely fortunate with staff. I had very little money in the electoral coffers when I fought the election in 1969. We could only afford secretarial assistance for three days prior to election day in the election campaign of 1969. This experienced person came to me for those three days and she has been with me ever since. Helen Ovens has done an absolutely fantastic job over the years and is now known as the doyen of the electoral secretaries. Lyle Mark, who has been working with me for a number of years now in Parliament House, is another person who demonstrates continuing efficiency and loyalty in a way which I think we, as members of parliament, are extraordinarily fortunate to experience.

I cannot speak strongly enough about my wife and family. They have been terrific. Anybody in this place needs support at the family level. As the honourable member for Bonython says, this job places immense strains on individuals and families. As I say, my family has been fantastic.

As the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) would say, a good field is lining up at the barrier in the seat of Warringah—14 starters at this stage. I do not know what the odds are, but I do know that it is a very good field. I know my successor, whoever he or she is, will make a profound contribution to the parliament.

Finally, to all of you, and for the benefit of Hansard—it is great to see the Chief Hansard Reporter there at the Hansard table; Bernie, you have been around longer than I have—I would like to finish by quoting the words of Catullus when he was taking leave of and paying tribute to his brother. He finished a poem with the words `ave atque vale!'—hail and farewell.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government I extend farewell and best wishes to the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar). I had, of course, an inkling that the honourable member for Bonython may resign his place in the parliament and I had the opportunity to say some things about him at the end of last year, but he dallied and lingered and I again have the opportunity to say a few brief things about both honourable gentlemen.

PARA.TAB: First I mention the honourable member for Bonython. We on this side of the House will miss him greatly. He was part of that enormous energy the government has had right through the 1980s. He came, as he said, in 1977 after probably our most dispiriting defeat. The year 1975 had all sorts of chemistry about it, but 1977 was simply a straight loss on the chin. As the honourable member has said, that hardened us for other things and made it clear to us that opposition was not the place to stay.

At any rate he, as did many others, never wasted the moment. He put as much experience behind him as possible and when he became minister for health in 1983 he was well equipped to establish Australia's first truly universal and deeply comprehensive health system. As a consequence, he and I had the pleasure today of celebrating its 10th anniversary. I think, with much broader political and public support for Medicare now than then, this is a feather in his cap.

It is not just Medicare for which we owe him a debt of gratitude, but also for his corporate role in the government and his role as a cabinet minister. I have often remarked here about the role of a cabinet minister as distinct from a portfolio minister. A cabinet minister has to comprehend all of the responsibilities of government, weigh them in the course of deliberations and interest himself or herself in other colleagues' work because that is important to the corporate work of the government. This Neal Blewett did with great dedication.

Not only was his policy view and his interest in issues quite profound, but his sense of judgment and political judgment was very sound indeed. If we took a straw poll in the parliamentary Labor Party of who the pundits might be, we would turn up a lot of obvious names but we might not turn up Neal Blewett. But he was one of the people I always used to ask when I was seeking to put the dipstick into the electoral water. He would invariably give a sensible and thoughtful analysis.

His sense of politics was very finely honed. He had a commitment to what he saw as the building of a social democracy. The government did stand against the breeze, as he said. Part of the government's strength in those days was, in a sense, to survive against the prevailing wind from the northern hemisphere, which was one of Thatcherism and Reaganism, that markets alone mattered and that there was not the place for a decent social policy or an inclusive policy. This government has now put into place a social democracy framework, along with a great change in economic efficiency and outward orientation, which has made the changes of the 1980s so important, not just in Australia but in world terms.

Neal mentioned the accord with the trade unions. Honourable members have heard me say before—and I will say it again here—that Labor cabinets always govern with more authority, with the authority of the whole labour movement. By the cooperative relationship with organised labour, many great things were done: occupational superannuation; the family allowance supplement, now called additional family payment, which the honourable member for Bonython mentioned earlier; and the Child Support Agency. These kinds of changes were ones in which I think the support of the organised work force has been important—and, of course, training and retraining and the whole shift to productivity, part of the changed culture of the country. I think these are remarkable steps for a country. The government has been very fortunate to have the opportunity of longevity to see much of this go into place step by step. No one thing went into place without it fitting. There was a minimum of mortar between the bricks as each brick was built upon the other.

Neal leaves public life and the parliament with a very great and proud record as Minister for Health, Minister for Social Security, and Minister for Trade through the very important years of the GATT round. As he is leaving, with all the gusto and energy he brought to all the other years, he has left us a substantial parliamentary reform. The parliament just this last week has adopted much of it. The consequence is that the parliament will be better, I think, than it was in the past. On behalf of the government, I say, `Farewell and best wishes. No-one on this side could have ever asked more of you than you have given to us'.
Government members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —To Michael MacKellar, let me repeat some of the same sentiments and come to the point, perhaps one of the last points you mentioned—one of Neal's earliest—about the parliament. It is true that in days gone by backbench members would stand here, as he and I did in 1969, and ask questions of the government. This is less true now with the notion of highlighting particular high points of policy where, if you like, the rank and file interest of the backbench MP is not as to the fore as it used to be.

PARA.TAB: Yet, because members of parliament do have great contact with their electorate, this is a representative chamber. The fact that it is representative, in the sense that members have a close link and affinity with communities, means that they do pick up community concerns. In that kind of parliament, some of the questions which come to the fore are not the obvious ones. They are not the manufactured ones. They are not the ones that are deemed to be asked but ones which come right from left field, which happen to be relevant and often are of great interest in the community at large. I think that character has changed and Michael MacKellar was right in so saying. I am hoping that the changes we have adopted might lead to more opportunity for MPs and that the place is not stylised to the point, as it has become, of focusing simply on the leaders and the front bench of the parliament.

Michael came here in the same year as I did—in 1969—as I remember, with a background in agricultural science. That is what led him to start off on the debate on the Wheat Stabilisation Bill. I can assure him that it was to the chagrin of the members of the Country Party who in those days believed, particularly on the conservative side of public life, that they had a lien over all such rural matters and rural debate. He contributed in this area over a long period and, of course, came into a government. In 1969 Sir John Gorton was returned to office.
