Though a lot of the great strides that the Labor Party made in that period were in 1969, the 1972 election was really won in 1969, giving support to Michael MacKellar's point: 23 of the 28 members who came in in 1969 were Labor Party members.

He came into a government which was run by a very decent man, John Gorton, with a cabinet which had amongst it a lot of verve and a lot of good figures. I remember well some of the figures, like Tom Hughes who fought with John Gorton in the concrete pipes case to extend the corporations power of the Commonwealth. There were many important things. There was the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who was a solid supporter of the then Prime Minister, and who remains one today—as, indeed, a few of us do. It is a lot different from coming into an opposition.

That whole notion of government stuck to Michael in the period and, although the Labor Party won the 1972 election and was here until 1975, he came back fairly fresh as a minister in 1975 and held a number of portfolios, including immigration and ethnic affairs and customs. In the immigration and ethnic affairs area he presided over one of the very large changes to the Australian migration program, particularly during and after the Lebanese war when a very large number of Lebanese people migrated to Australia.

He was a very solid contributor to the government in those days and to the Liberal Party in general and was part of that ballast of experience which all parties need. He has stuck out the 10 or 11 years of opposition which have followed. This has been an unusual period historically for the Labor Party. We have never been in office for this long continuously, and he would have had a reasonable expectation of being returned to office.

He has made a choice, as many members have—as he said, he and I are the last two of the 1969 group of members to be here—to take the opportunity of a life's change. He makes it young enough in his life to be able to succeed in it and, no doubt, we will hear more from the plastics industry as a consequence of his leaving the parliament. His remarks about the parliament bear reflection for all of us.

He commented about Australian youth. We are all very aware of the views of young people in this country. One has to bet on education and say that if we do educate young Australians and the place has a greater level of vitality, that will create its own opportunities. So, while I think it is true that many young Australians are uncertain of the future, part of what will become a more certain future will be their own contribution to it through the education which has been invested in them. I am a great optimist about young people in this country. It is often said that the 1960s generation was the rebellious group, the group that wanted to change the game and open the game up. All that may be true, but, today, wherever you meet a group of young Australians you find an enormous churning of thoughts amongst them and a willingness to change the place and to do things differently.

I take this opportunity of wishing the honourable member for Warringah, Michael MacKellar, well in the future, and of saying how much all of us who have known him have enjoyed his company as a member of parliament, as a parliamentary colleague. I recognise and salute the fact that he has made a very mature decision to have another life after public life, which I think is the way that all straight-thinking parliamentarians should think; that is to say, we are here for a time, you walk on the stage but, as he himself said so eloquently, you cannot do it forever.

On behalf of the government, I wish Michael and his wife, Robyn, and family well. No doubt we will see him again in another incarnation as, indeed, we will probably see the honourable member for Bonython, and think of them well then as now.
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my great pleasure to join the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in recognising the contribution of the two honourable members who in recent days have announced their decision to retire. I will start with the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett).

PARA.TAB: Neal, on our side of the parliament you are known as a substantive and tolerant person and a humanitarian. Focusing on your ministerial career, although I could not agree with some of the things you did and stood for in the health portfolio, I believe you made a substantial contribution in the trade portfolio. We would always judge you as one who was dedicated to improving Australia and Australia's standing in the world. Your fight for freer trade in those international forums in those difficult years will be remembered by this House, and by many on our side of this parliament, as a very significant contribution.

I also recognise the contribution that the honourable member for Bonython tried to make in terms of parliamentary reform. Your chairmanship of the Standing Committee on Procedure was seen by us as a genuine attempt to bring about some significant change in the procedures of this place in a way that would improve its operation and restore to question time the true status that it deserved. We always suspected, of course, that in the end your boss would do whatever he decided to do, but you did put in a very genuine effort and we congratulate you in that regard. I think that will be remembered by many on our side. I was struck by one particular assessment of you by Clyde Cameron in today's press which I think is quite a nice summary:

SPEECH.PARA: I think Blewett wouldn't want to be hurtful, while Paul Keating and Mick Young would lie awake thinking how they can insult.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming from Clyde, that's pretty rich.
—It is an important way of making the point. Neal, we wish you well in your retirement. I am sure that many of us will have an opportunity to visit you in London in the course of the next few years.

PARA.TAB: The second person I want to acknowledge is my very good friend the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar). Michael has made an outstanding contribution to the Liberal Party and to Australia over his time in public life, and we are very sorry to see him go. In recent days a lot of us have taken the opportunity to express that view to Michael, but we understand the nature of the decision that he has had to make. I join with the Prime Minister in that regard. It is never an easy choice, but the opportunity that you have taken is a good one. I am sure we will hear a lot about the plastics industry in the future.

At the time Michael told me of that decision, I could not help thinking of a very famous scene in the movie The Graduate. I think the graduate was at a cocktail party at his parents' home when he was taken aside by one of his father's inebriated friends and told that he should understand just one word in life, and never forget it, and that was plastics. Plastics is what has obviously influenced you in this decision. Although I congratulate you on that decision, it is with some regret that we see you go.

As we look over the years that Mike has served in this place, particularly as a minister, we see a number of significant highlights. I think we should recognise the breadth of his contribution in ministerial portfolios, not only as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, where he served for about four years, but also as Minister for Health, where he served for three years, and as Minister Assisting the Treasurer, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, and Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment, where he served for shorter periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —He used to often act for me in foreign affairs, and he was very good.

—And, of course, he often used to act for the honourable member for Kooyong in foreign affairs. In opposition he has had shadow portfolios in immigration, foreign affairs and science. I think Michael's true success, and the area where he made his greatest contribution, was in the portfolio of immigration and ethnic affairs. Michael was too modest today to focus on the significance of that contribution, so I thought I would put part of it on the record. I picked up a quote from Michael himself in an article where he spoke quite frankly about his experience in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think we did great with immigration and ethnic affairs in the mid- to late-70s. We led the world in many areas and proved to be a model for other countries.

I do not think that is in any sense an exaggeration of the contribution that Michael MacKellar made to the portfolio of immigration and ethnic affairs. Michael's experience in dealing with the Vietnamese boat people has been mentioned, including by Michael himself. It was a very difficult issue, considering the political circumstances and the social pressures of the time. Michael will be remembered for handling that issue both sensitively and sensibly in what were very difficult circumstances. Along with Malcolm Fraser, Michael was instrumental in organising two United Nations conferences on refugees. He really did internationalise an understanding of the problem of refugees. I think that will be long remembered as a very significant contribution.

PARA.TAB: Michael also, in conjunction with Malcolm Fraser, commissioned the Galbally report and subsequently implemented most of its recommendations. I think that this represented the first substantive commitment by any Australian government to a multicultural Australia. As a result of this report, we saw the establishment of SBS, wide-ranging proposals in support of new arrivals, the creation of the Migrant Resource Centre and the establishment of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Studies, which later became the Office of Multicultural Affairs. I think that the contributions Michael made in that one portfolio were very significant and will long be remembered not only by us in this parliament but by many others throughout the width and breadth of this country.

As I looked back over Michael's career, I must say that I was somewhat staggered when I recognised his maiden speech was on wheat quotas. I think this was because he was—as he described himself at the time—a country boy at heart and he came from a Country Party family. He may have made that speech on wheat because of an interest gained from academic studies, but certainly some of those ideas have since moved away from Michael's domain.

Michael has also been known as a prodigious reader. One article stated how he liked to read three different books at the same time. On that particular occasion, he was reading an essay on the principle of population, by Malthus, a book called The Matter Myth, and the other book he was reading was The Good of the Cause by Solzhenitsyn. You cannot deny that Michael was extremely well read but, if you knew Michael, you would know that that breadth of reading always came through in his advice and in the contributions that he made to our party and to the development of its policies.

Mike was of course known as an avid sportsperson. It has already been mentioned that he has not lost a doubles match with the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in 17 years, but he was also a great cricketer and is a pretty good golfer. I do not mind playing golf with Michael but I do not like playing against him because he is a definite burglar on the golf course, as a number of my colleagues would attest.

Michael also founded on our side the wine appreciation society and has therefore brought many good nights—and sometimes some sore heads—to many members on our side of politics and we thank him for that. He has, without doubt, one of the most refined palates in the parliament, and he is a delight to have dinner with not only on those occasions but of course at any other time.

Michael and I also share an interest in cars, and he is a familiar sight in his MG sports car. Mike has been known to like to travel. In fact, I looked up part of his parliamentary record on travel and I was staggered to see the extent of his travel: Noumea, China, Canada, the Seychelles, Europe, North America, Cyprus, Italy, New Zealand, South-East Asia, the USA, the UK, West Germany, France, New Zealand, South Africa, Zimbabwe, Kenya, Mauritius, Fiji and Kiribati—and that was only in one year!

In all seriousness, Mike has been a fantastic contributor to the Liberal Party—as a minister, as a backbencher and as a person. He has made an outstanding contribution to Australia. I personally will miss Mike, not only because of all that experience and all those contributions, but as a person who is a very good friend and a source of very good and sustained advice. Michael, I wish you well in your future career. I am sure we have not seen the end of you. I know we have already organised a series of golf games to make sure that we have not, but I wish you and Robbie every success in this new venture. We congratulate you on what you have done for this country.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself and the National Party of Australia with the remarks made this afternoon, firstly, in relation to Dr Neal Blewett. At the outset, I say to you, Dr Blewett, that the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Tim Fischer—who cannot be here today for reasons that we are all aware of—has asked me to pass on his very best wishes to you on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: Your career here has been a distinguished one from your first election in 1977. You have been an intellectual force within the Labor Party, particularly as a minister covering portfolios such as Health, Community Services and Health, Trade Negotiations, Trade and Overseas Development, and Social Security. From a National Party point of view, your work in the areas of trade and trade negotiations has been of particular note. It is well known that you undertook the grinding work in preparation for the successful conclusion—eventually—of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That sort of work is never particularly glamorous. However, it is, and has been, fundamental to the final outcome that is now before us.

For many years during this process, the country was full of sceptics and those who sought to be cynical about the whole process. We on this side, particularly within the National Party, were constantly having to defend the process against those who said that an agreement such as GATT could never be successfully concluded and that Australia's position was increasing our vulnerability to the very unlevel playing fields which apply so frequently and so often to our disadvantage in the international trade arena.

I pass on to Dr Blewett the very best wishes of the parliamentary National Party for his work as high commissioner in London. We all feel confident that he will fulfil this role in an exemplary fashion. Once again, I pass on the best wishes of Tim Fischer.

I say at the outset to the honourable member for Warringah, Mr Michael MacKellar, that Tim is sorry that he is not here with you. He particularly wanted his thoughts and best wishes passed on to you today.

As has been noted, Michael is a member of the Liberal Party who holds an urban Sydney seat and who, to our great delight and amazement at times over the years, understands agricultural issues. For that reason, he will be missed by the National Party.

There may be those in this place who are not aware that the honourable member for Warringah was born and grew up in Baan Baa. Baan Baa is a thriving metropolis smack in the middle of my electorate of Gwydir. To this day, his father has a property just near Baan Baa. I will return to that point in a moment. Baan Baa was once an active and vital little town. Michael, I have to say that it has entered something of a gentle decline since you left. I trust that that will not happen to this place on your departure.

Michael, Baan Baa was your early home. Your early education was undertaken there. In fact, for the first six years your mother was your teacher. You were able to undertake your early education in the family kitchen care of the Blackfriars correspondence school and the facilities that it operated.

You grew up with your sister Margaret, who is well known to me since she was my first campaign director. To this day, she is the treasurer of the Gwydir electorate council. Margaret is one of those attractive, vivacious, outgoing people to whom people are automatically drawn on first acquaintance. I cannot for the life of me understand why it is that people sometimes say to me that they cannot spot the family resemblance!

Michael, you eventually left correspondence school and went to the Shore school in Sydney. You subsequently gained entry to Sydney University, where you studied agriculture. Graduating with a Bachelor of Agricultural Science, Michael went out to work for a while in the agricultural field before travelling to the United Kingdom, where he gained his Master of Arts at Oxford.

Michael first stood for preselection for the seat of Warringah in 1966, but was narrowly defeated. However, it did not take him long to arrange the necessary secret weapon with which to supplement his already considerable armoury. On 23 March 1969, he married Robbie. As so many of us have discovered in this place, our wives, or husbands as the case may be, are so often our greatest assets, unsung heroes though they may be. Michael, Robbie was soon to prove yours. The day after Michael and Robbie were married, the news broke that the then member for Warringah was to retire. Michael and Robbie were on honeymoon at the time. I trust that this news, if it did reach him, was not too much of a distraction. On your return, you stood for preselection with your wife beside you—you paid her a tribute here today, and I do so too—and won. As they say, the rest is history, and it has been recorded here today.

Michael, I along with so many others will miss you in this place. Along with all your friends and family who belong to, and who have remained loyal to, the National Party, I wish you all the best as you leave this place and begin a new stage in your career. As I do so, I bring you the news from Baan Baa that your old home is being painted. They know now that you will have time to go and help them. While you are there, they are trusting that you will now finally give the answer to the question that you have avoided for so long: why ever did you pass us over in favour of the Liberal Party?

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The failure to disburse grants under the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program in a fair and unbiased way.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to the attendance of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) during this discussion.
—Of course you do, but she will take care of you.

—I also look forward to members of the Australian Labor Party coming in and supporting her, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said they ought to at the recent caucus meeting. In fact, he actually gave them a little lecture. He said that there were not enough members of the caucus turning up to support the embattled minister for sport and that, in particular, it was necessary for ministers to come into the House and show that they had some support for her. I call upon all ministers to come in and to make sure that they show, at least in form, if not in reality, that they are prepared to put their names to what the Prime Minister has asked them to do. The Prime Minister, of course, is hanging on to this minister because of the personal affection in which he holds her.

PARA.TAB: It has taken a long time. It has taken about three months since the Auditor-General reported to this parliament. It has taken about 50 questions, two or three matters of public importance, two or three censure motions and a lot of written questions from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, to which some derelict answers were given by the minister. But, last night, the minister was finally forced to go before the House of Representatives standing committee on the environment. The way she pulled it, to try to minimise the damage and the continuing fallout to the government over the sports rorts affair, was to announce to the media that she was going to go down to the House of Representatives committee inquiry. She had not been prepared to announce it in the House and she had not been prepared to give notice. She went without her staff and without producing the records. By announcing it first to the media she was hoping to catch the House of Representatives committee unawares, as she did last night.

All the time the minister was frightened that, if she did not pull some kind of stunt, the Australian Democrats would—and I hope they still will—set up an independent Senate inquiry backed by judicial officers to get to the bottom of the absolute mismanagement and total incompetence in the way in which she has administered her department and the way in which she has squandered without records $30 million of taxpayers' money. But it took all of that time and it took that little stunt.

Then, last night, out from the woodwork popped the greatest excuse, the greatest joke, the greatest pathetic defence that we have ever heard from the minister in relation to record keeping, audits and account keeping. Out came the revelations as to the whiteboard—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Page 495 of House of Representatives Practice states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Members may not disclose in debate evidence taken by any committee of the House or the proceedings and reports of those committees which have not been reported to the House, unless disclosure or publication has been authorised by the House or, pursuant to the Parliamentary Papers Act, by the committee. Members have thus been prevented from referring to evidence not disclosed to the House or basing statements on matters disclosed to the committee. However, members have, from time to time, made statements on the activities of a committee by leave of the House.

I would submit that, if the honourable member is going to base his speech on references to evidence which has yet to be assessed by the committee—albeit evidence gathered in public but not yet reported to the House in the normal way in which committees report their evidence to the House, which is either within the document of the committee's report or as an attachment to it—that he is, in fact, in breach of quite a fundamental element of parliamentary practice. His remarks ought to be confined to the evidence that is available in the public record outside the context of that committee's presentation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—The Leader of the House has read the appropriate section of House of Representatives Practice. In this case there is a little difficulty because there have been reports in the media about evidence given before the committee, evidence that in some cases has not been through the proper reporting stages. I rule that, in the case of remarks made by the honourable member for Higgins and other members participating in the discussion, if they make reference to those matters reported in the media that are alleged to have been said in the committee hearing, that would be in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It was a pathetic attempt to try to stop something that this government considers extremely damaging.

PARA.TAB: Here we have a minister who doled out $30 million worth of money. She received 2,000 applications and granted 726 of them. She says that, in deciding which ones are given grants and which ones are not, she has to take into account the number of youth in the area, the number of Aborigines in the area, the level of unemployment in the area, the level of migrant populations in the area, the demonstrated community need in the area, the evidence of financial commitments in relation to the application and a whole host of other criteria. But she does not need to produce one single document to assess 726 out of 2,800 applications which were approved because she has the magical whiteboard—a whiteboard on which she put all of the material and rubbed it out before the Auditor-General could come in and audit this program.

On talkback radio today competitions are being held as to who can give the best kind of excuse. They are holding competitions for people to ring in and to comment on the way in which this minister has appropriated $30 million off her whiteboard. People have been ringing in and making suggestions. One example was about children who turn up to school without their homework. When they are asked by their teacher, `Where is your homework?', the answer is, `I left it on the whiteboard at home'. Another example concerned people who have not put in their tax returns. The tax commissioner comes to them and says, `Why haven't you filed your tax returns?' and they reply, `I wrote them up on the whiteboard'. Or they are asked, `Where is the evidence of your deductions; where is the verification?'; and the reply is, `Trevor Boucher, it is all on the whiteboard and it has been rubbed out'. This is the way in which the Keating government administers.

Can honourable members believe it? We have all these wonderful speeches about how the government has internationalised the economy, how it has got sophisticated financial management and all of these things, but what we now know is that a person only needs three things to administer a taxpayer funded program: a whiteboard, a textacolour and a rubber—especially the rubber, because the rubber is very important to take the details off before the auditor comes in. I can just imagine the Treasurer coming in to present his budget. He is asked, `Treasurer, where are the budget papers?'. I suppose he will say, `They're on the whiteboard. There are no budget papers this year. It has all been put up on the whiteboard. It has all been destroyed before the auditor can come in, before the FOI processes can take place, before the parliament can subpoena the documents and before the House of Representatives can call for the documents'. This is a Mr Squiggle method of administration. If people wanted a grant, they sent a squiggle off to the minister. She put the squiggle up on the whiteboard and she could turn it into a $200,000 grant. That is a Mr Squiggle-type application. And the squiggle that really moved an organisation up the whiteboard was if there was a squiggle stating `ALP marginal' somewhere in the application. If it had `ALP marginal' on it, the organisation went right up to the top of the whiteboard and it had a two to one chance of getting money out of this minister. We now have a system where this minister legitimately claims that there is no documentation which shows the decision making in relation to why some applications were granted and others were not because it has all been erased; it has all gone off the whiteboard. How could she deliberate on 2,800 applications, classify them according to 12 columns, put them all up on the whiteboard 100 at a time and make a decision?

The press of this country want to film that whiteboard tonight. It is probably as big as a tennis court to make sure that it can fit all of these entries and applications onto it. But the minister will not even let the press in to look at the whiteboard. She will not let them take a film of the magical mystery whiteboard. When she was asked last night, `How could you possibly do all of this on a whiteboard?'—that is, $30 million worth with 12 entries in relation to yours, mine and every Australian's taxes all rubbed out—she said, `Oh, it was a big whiteboard. It enabled me to have them all up there 100 at a time'. We do not consider that proper administration and neither does the Auditor-General.

This whole affair started when the Auditor-General tried to audit this program to make sure that it was complying with guidelines, that it was being done fairly and that there was no political bias. The finding of the Auditor-General reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The absence of an effective audit trail means ANAO cannot report to Parliament whether or not expenditure on the program represents value for money in achieving the program objectives.

There was no audit trail because this minister had figured out a way of making decisions, having money and not having any records that could be scrutinised by an auditor. If people from a private company make financial decisions and then have to be audited, does the minister think they turn up with a whiteboard? Does the minister think an auditor would say to a private company, `Yes, you've got a clean bill of health, Mr Skase, because we can't find any documents; it was all on a whiteboard that has now been erased.'? Of course he would not. If directors were making decisions and expending shareholders' funds but did not have documents to prove it to an auditor, they would be guilty of an offence. Why should the standard be any less for a minister of the Crown dealing with taxpayers' money than it is for a company director dealing with shareholders' funds? Why should there be one standard for the company directors of Australia and another for the Labor Party ministers?

PARA.TAB: What happens when representatives of the department of labour and industry come to a small business employing people and ask, `Where are your Workcare records'? It is no excuse to say, `It was all on the whiteboard'. What happens if they ask, `Where are your training guarantee levies? Where are your FBT claims? Where are your payroll deductions? Where are the mechanics and the working documents that explain how all of this took place and how the decisions were made'? A person cannot turn around to the tax authorities and say, `I'm sorry. It was all on the whiteboard. There is no documentation. I can't tell you how the decisions were made, who was involved or how much money was spent because it has all been rubbed out'. People are not allowed to do that. The government says that there is a law against it. People are committing an offence if they do that.

Why should it be any different for a minister who has $30 million worth of taxpayers' money? Why should a minister be able to say in an arrogant way to the people of Australia, `I am a friend of the Prime Minister, so I am not required to account; I am a friend of the Prime Minister, who, on political grounds, will vote with me every time. So it does not matter what I do.'? Why should a minister be able to claim, against all the odds, that personal privilege which comes from being in the royal family of the Prime Minister?

The Labor Party backbench knows this. The Australian reported yesterday that most of the backbench concedes that any other minister would have gone before now, but this minister gets special dispensation because she is part of the royal family and part of the rich in crowd in Canberra. She does not have to account for the money. She can have adverse audits. She can fail to explain. She can be pulled through a House of Representatives committee, the parliament, the press and public ridicule in relation to her administration. She has one person standing behind her who is up to his armpits in this—all of the hopeless administration, all of the evasion of responsibility, all of the political corruption and all of the buying of votes. It is the Prime Minister who stands behind this minister and who excuses her on the basis of her personal friendship.

One thing has been absolutely proven throughout this whole affair: the Auditor-General has been entirely vindicated on every point against this minister. The minister has been huffing and puffing with the Auditor-General. We know that the government has been trying to run down his office. We know that the Australian Labor Party has a lease which enables it to rip money out of him and then not reimburse him for the rent. We know that the Australian Labor Party would love to see this Auditor-General run down in relation to his resources and staff. He is one of the few checks and balances that stand between a government that has grown fat, tired, lazy and incompetent and the people of Australia, who deserve public accountability. They give the government the taxes that make it possible for it to delve out money on the basis of calculations done on the back of whiteboards. The Auditor-General is one of the people who stand between this minister getting away with easy money schemes and vote buying exercises such as this and public accountability. We will be supporting the Auditor-General. He has been entirely vindicated in this matter. But there is one person who has been entirely condemned, ridiculed and totally exposed: it is the minister for sport. She is dragging down not only herself; she is also dragging each and every one of the ministry and each and every one of the backbench down with her.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again we have heard a speech delivered with all the style and substance of an Oxford union debater. Behind all the gusto and giggles is a policy and factual vacuum. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) cannot even give a 15-minute factual speech, let alone appear before a committee of opposition members for 5 1/2 hours and answer over 300 questions.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Higgins stood up here and gave a fatuous speech with no substance, yet I was prepared to get up in front of a parliamentary committee, and answer over 300 questions from opposition members, which started at 8.30 last night and finished at 2 o'clock this morning when the committee members had no further questions to ask. I sat there and allowed them the opportunity to ask me any questions about this program. I answered questions for 5 1/2 hours. I answered questions from all the opposition members and I answered them factually. So what has emerged after 5 1/2 hours with the committee, numerous censures and MPIs, questions in this parliament—

TALK.START.PARA: —Auditor's reports.

—An independent audit report outlining recommendations, which I have already said I will adopt. What has emerged at the end of that? There has been no proven political bias, no fraud, no suggestion of any minister personally benefiting from the expenditure, no impropriety and no withholding of documents. I have not misled parliament. I do not think there is any suggestion, except by some members of the opposition, that the projects are not worth while or do not have a huge beneficial or multiplier effect around Australia.

PARA.TAB: All we have now from the opposition is political grandstanding. There is no high moral examination of ministerial responsibility. Those opposite are interested in only one thing, and that is politics. That has been clearly exposed today. We discussed this for 5 1/2 hours last night. I answered all the questions of those opposite, but they still came in today and asked exactly the same questions. They introduced an MPI and gave exactly the same speech as has been delivered in parliament over and over again. It had little factual information and was full of personal abuse. Whenever those opposite cannot find any facts, they reduce to personal abuse. I do not intend to get into that. I intend to stick very much to this subject and go through the points of this program.

The opposition has consistently accused me of fraud. The Auditor-General did not, of course. No-one else in the community has. But those opposite throw their mud around the place and hope some of it will stick. I object to any accusation of fraud in this program. The Auditor-General made it very clear that there was no finding of fraud. The only carcass in this place is that of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). This program is beneficial to the community and, before anyone gets the money, the project must be completed. Documentation proving that the project has been completed or is in the process of being completed must be shown.

Throughout this debate the opposition has vilified so many good, worthwhile community groups around this nation. For any grant over $50,000 community groups have had to make their own contribution. Whether it be from fundraising or local or state government funds, they have made contributions. This opposition has cast a cloud over all of those good Australian citizens who have devoted years of their lives raising these funds.

The Leader of the Opposition has said outside this parliament that this program is squandering taxpayers' money. What absolute hypocrisy on his part. At the same time as the Leader of the Opposition is taking the high moral ground and talking about the squandering of taxpayers' money, he has his own backbench writing me letters saying, `Please, can I have some more money for my programs? Even if that program does not exist, give me some more money from some other pot of money'.

As late as yesterday I had another letter from an opposition member. Every day letters come in from members of the opposition saying, `Please do things to help my electorate; please put money into my electorate'. I bet not one member of the opposition has knocked back an invitation to any of the sod turnings or refused to take part in photographs at the openings. I will have to make sure that none of the opposition actually open any of these facilities around the country.

Members of the opposition should be honest with these community groups. The Leader of the Opposition, at the same time as saying that the government has squandered taxpayers' money and vilifying me personally almost every day in this parliament, what does the hypocrite do? He writes me a letter saying, `Would you please put sunshades on the Bondi bowling club?'. That club may well be a very good club—I am sure it is—but the Leader of the Opposition should have been honest with the club. At the very least he should have written to it and said, `This is my view about this program. This is squandering of public money'. But he was not prepared to do that. On the one hand, opposition members will stand up here and criticise and abuse me personally, and I am prepared to sit there and answer all of their questions in a parliamentary committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha.
—Oh, you laugh. I answered, yesterday and last night—
—You never answered the questions.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The minister will direct her remarks through the chair and the honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night for 5 1/2 hours I answered over 320 questions from the opposition. Those opposite do not like the fact that the answers just do not suit them. The answers do not suit them, not on the question of propriety, and not on the question of ministerial responsibility, but on the question of only one thing—politics, which is what this whole debate comes down to. It is simply about politics. The opposition believes that this program particularly benefited seats that were not theirs. As I have said in this parliament many times, this program has been based on need. It has been based on areas which needed community facilities.

PARA.TAB: Many Liberal seats needed those facilities and they got them. I am sure that the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) knows about some in particular. Many National Party seats received funding because they needed community facilities. Some Labor Party seats received grants because they needed facilities. The grants were based on need. That material was documented. As I explained to the parliamentary committee last night, there are 104 filing cabinets of information on this. I went through the selection criteria in great detail and the needs basis of funding. This program has benefited many Australians. Rather than opposition members getting up here and continually vilifying this program, it would do the community a great deal of good if they tempered some of that by outlining the value of these programs in their own electorates.

After all this debate, which has gone on for months, we have come down to what this is fundamentally all about—politics. The government has always known that. It is about time the rest of the community started to realise that the opposition's pursuit of this matter is purely a political witch-hunt devoted only to making a political point. Opposition members put themselves up on the high moral ground. When I appear before the committee and answer every single one of their questions on this program, what do they do? They bring it on today and ask exactly the same questions, and then they run a matter of public importance, which is exactly the same as it has been every day in this parliament. Those opposite produce no new information. Clearly, I have demonstrated at every opportunity in this debate that there is no fraud in the program. The program is delivering much needed community facilities. Always we see total hypocrisy displayed by opposition members, who send me their begging letters saying, `Please can my constituents have some more of that money?'.

I have also said that I am prepared to accept the recommendations of the Auditor-General regarding this program. I have taken very seriously his comments on the program. I said last night and I will say again that we take his recommendations seriously and we will implement them. The changes that I have discussed with the secretary in relation to this program concern redesigning the application form and information provided to applicants, issuing guidelines to departments on the broad allocation of funds by states and requiring broad geographic coverage, asking my department to analyse applications and provide recommendations, and providing reasons for instances where I depart from the recommendations. This obviously shows that I am very serious about the Auditor-General's comments and I intend to apply them. At the moment, I will be applying to the existing program what recommendations are relevant—as I will to the new program, if there is one.

When we established this program we looked at the balance between administration and program delivery. We spent about one per cent of the program money on bureaucratic and administrative support. On balance, and with the information the Auditor-General gave, that was not enough. My motivation in that regard was purely to give as much money as possible to the community.Obviously, the Auditor-General's view is that we should spend more on administration. When members of the opposition actually get around to outlining their policies they always start by attacking the bureaucracy. The opposition always says that it wants smaller government and fewer bureaucrats. But then the hypocrites stand up and say, `But in this program we want a whole army of bureaucrats'. That would be of great benefit to my electorate here in Canberra. I find it very hypocritical of the opposition to say, `We want smaller government and fewer bureaucrats, but with this program everything is different; we want a much higher percentage of program money devoted to administration'.

During this whole debate I have never heard from the opposition an estimate of what that percentage should be. Currently it is one per cent. Does the opposition want it to be 10 per cent or 20 per cent? Opposition members consistently present a point of view that is critical of programs but never give any constructive views about how programs can be reformed; nor do they ever present any serious alternative policies.

The closest we have come to that is the view of the shadow minister for youth, sport and recreation, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), about how a program such as this could be run. We have heard in this parliament that his idea is to give each member of parliament a certain sum of money to distribute in whatever way they like. I appreciate comments from the Auditor-General on this proposal because we have not heard anything about any guidelines. We have not heard anything about any controls. We have not heard anything about any criteria of assessment. All we have heard is that the bagman for the Liberal Party would hand out a certain amount of money to each electorate in Australia. It will be very interesting to watch the development of that policy and very interesting to hear the Auditor-General's views on that so-called policy.

I revert to the point where I started. This whole debate today is evidence of what this matter is really about: politics. It started as politics and it will finish as politics. It is about time that members of the opposition stopped their pretentious mumblings about ministerial responsibilities and the rights of the Auditor-General and faced up to what this is all about. It is purely politics.

The opposition is very sensitive about corruption and accountability. After all, it was the coalition government of New South Wales that gave us the Eastern Creek racetrack. PARA.TAB: Those opposite use the old conservative trick—we all know it—say something often enough and some people will start to believe it; say it more often and they will believe it themselves. This whole charade is a hypocritical attempt at cheap political point scoring through deliberate deception to deflect attention from having to admit that these programs have been enormously successful; have generated employment for hundreds of people; and have given recognition to the mighty efforts of the dedicated and committed volunteers who give so much to their communities.

Perhaps the best way to demonstrate that political bias did not exist is to talk about the grants that went to my own electorate—the electorate of Paterson that was identified before the 1993 election as `the most marginal electorate in Australia'. That is where one would expect to find pork-barrelling running riot. What do we find? We find that $15,000 went to a girl guide association for renovating a building in a camp that serves the whole of the Hunter region. It does not serve just one little guide troop but the whole region. That is the story of many of these grants and the distorted interpretation that has been placed on them. They are not about individual electorates; they are about serving the needs of the youth of an area.

The Gloucester district tennis club—I get 23 per cent of the vote from that district and it has never had a Labor representative since Federation—got $25,125 for a synthetic surface for its tennis courts. I am pleased to say that the young tennis players of this small rural community now have the same opportunity to learn tennis skills as some of their wealthier city cousins have. I do not know how their parents vote. I do not know how they will continue to vote. The Gloucester Youth Committee got $7,000. It is not a lot of money, but it is all the committee asked for. It is helping to provide a service for the youth of that community. Rural youth have the same needs as city youth do.

Fingal Bay, where the sports and recreation club got $6,590 for sun shades for the bowling green, is in a rapid growth area. The local government is having difficulty providing infrastructure. Fingal Bay has a lot of retirees and a lot of young families. It has a definite need, as was identified in its application.

Port Stephens Council, one of the fastest growth areas in Australia, was successful in getting a grant of $30,000 for wheelchair access for disabled people to the water at Little Beach. How symbolic, in the international year of the disabled, that this minister should support such a grant! It is only a small part of the total cost of that project. Yet, if we listen to those opposite—I notice that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) is suddenly short of supporters, even his seconder has gone—they say that this was politically selective. What nonsense!

I recently had the pleasure of being at the first exhibition held in the Myall Community Arts and Craft Centre. The centre got $26,000. It matched the grant dollar for dollar and its facility has been added on to the local government community centre that was funded under the local government capital works program. This group ran a shop, had street stalls and carried out many fundraising activities to service the need in that community. I have no idea how people in that area vote. I do not want to know that. All I know is that they are industrious and honest and I had the greatest pleasure in supporting the application.

The East Maitland cricket club received $49,000 for practice nets on an oval that was to be built by the New South Wales state government but has not been built. It is in a major growth area where there are lots of young families. That club, afraid it might lose that grant, has approached the Maitland City Council. The Maitland City Council has said that it will support the club; it identified the need, as did the minister.

The last grant that came to my electorate was the biggest one of all—$50,000 went to Dungog Shire Council for a swimming pool at Clarence Town. The state member, a Liberal, got a $60,000 grant.

Perhaps it is exactly as the minister has been stating all along: it is all about needs. That is what today is all about too, is it not, Mr Costello? It is about needs. It is about the opposition's needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to some minor typographical corrections, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following amendments to the standing orders be made with effect from 21 February 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Omit standing orders 13 to 19 and substitute the following standing orders:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Appointment of Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker
Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker appointed

SPEECH.PARA: 13.At the commencement of each Parliament 2 Members shall be appointed by the House, one to be Deputy Speaker and the other to be Second Deputy Speaker.
The Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker shall be appointed in the following manner:
(a)The Speaker shall ask for nominations and call Members in turn to move, without notice, a motion that a Member be appointed a Deputy Speaker of this House, each motion to be seconded.
(b)When there are no further motions the Speaker shall say that the time for motions has expired.

(c)If there is only one nomination the Speaker shall, without question put, declare the Member named to have been appointed Deputy Speaker. The position of Second Deputy Speaker shall remain vacant until the commencement of the next Parliament, a vacancy occurs in the office of Deputy Speaker necessitating a ballot for the position, or the House agrees to a motion that a ballot be conducted for the position of Second Deputy Speaker, whichever occurs first.
(d)If there are 2 or more nominations, when the time for motions has expired, debate may ensue but it shall be relevant to the election.
(e)No Member may speak for more than 5 minutes.

(f)At any time during the debate, a motion without notice may be moved by a Minister, and whether any Member is addressing the Chair or not, "That the question be now put", which question shall be put forthwith and decided without amendment or debate.

Upon the carrying of the question "That the question be now put", or upon the cessation of the debate otherwise, the appointment of the Deputy Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker shall be proceeded with as provided in this standing order.
(g)At the conclusion of the debate the bells shall be rung as in a division and the House shall proceed to a ballot.

Each Member, other than the Speaker, shall deliver to the Clerk a ballot paper, in writing, containing the name of the nominated Member for whom he or she votes to be appointed the Deputy Speaker. The votes shall be counted by the Clerks at the Table and the Member who has the greatest number of votes shall be the Deputy Speaker and the Member who has the next greatest number of votes shall be the Second Deputy Speaker.

(h)If, after any ballot, other than a ballot which takes place in accordance with paragraph (i) of this standing order, in which the names of only 2 Members are submitted, there is an equality of votes, the Speaker shall give a casting vote and the Member for whom the Speaker votes shall be the Deputy Speaker and the other Member shall be the Second Deputy Speaker.

(i)If, after any ballot in which the names of more than 2 Members are submitted, it is impossible by reason of an equality of votes to determine which Member has the greatest number of votes or which Member has the second greatest number of votes—

(1)If there is an equality of votes for 2 Members, the Speaker shall give a casting vote for one of those 2 Members who shall then be declared appointed to the office which the equality of votes had made it impossible to determine; and
(2)If there is an equality of votes for more than 2 Members, a special ballot shall take place in which only the names of the Members who received an equal number of votes are submitted.

If the equality of votes had made it impossible to determine the Member to be appointed as Deputy Speaker, then the ballot shall be conducted in the same manner as provided in paragraph (g) and the Member who receives the greatest number of votes shall be the Deputy Speaker and the Member who receives the next greatest number of votes shall be the Second Deputy Speaker.

If the equality of votes had made it impossible to determine only the position of the Second Deputy Speaker, then each Member shall write on the ballot paper the name of the Member for whom he or she votes to be appointed Second Deputy Speaker and the Member receiving the greatest number of votes shall be the Second Deputy Speaker.

If, by reason of a continued equality of votes, the special ballot is inconclusive, then, unless a name is withdrawn, the sitting shall be suspended for 30 minutes. When the sitting is resumed, the votes shall be taken again unless this is rendered unnecessary by a withdrawal.

(j)At any time after the result of the first ballot is declared, but before the commencement of any subsequent ballot, a Member whose name was submitted in the first ballot may withdraw his or her name and all further proceedings shall take place as if a motion for the appointment of the Member as a Deputy Speaker had not been moved.
13A. The Deputy Speaker shall chair the Main Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Second Deputy Speaker shall assist the Deputy Speaker and, in the absence of the Deputy Speaker, shall act as Deputy Speaker.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Absence of Speaker, Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker

PARA.TAB: Whenever the House is informed by the Clerk of the absence of the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker, or if the Deputy Speaker is also absent the Second Deputy Speaker, shall, subject to any other order of the House, perform the duties of the Speaker, as Acting Speaker, during that absence.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Absence of Speaker, Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker

PARA.TAB: Whenever the House is informed by the Clerk of the absence of the Speaker and both the Deputy Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker, the Members present, if a quorum, may at once proceed to elect one of their number who shall, subject to any other order of the House, perform the duties of the Speaker during that absence. Otherwise the House stands adjourned to the next sitting day.

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this standing order, the Clerk shall act as Chair of the House until a Member is elected to perform the duties of the Speaker.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Speaker relieved by Deputy Speaker or Second Deputy Speaker

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Speaker or the Second Deputy Speaker shall take the Chair whenever requested to do so by the Speaker during a sitting of the House, without any formal communication to the House.

The Speaker shall nominate at the commencement of every Parliament a panel of not less than 4 Members to assist the Chair pursuant to standing order 19, and may, at any time during the Parliament, nominate additional Members or revoke the nomination of any Member.

The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker may call on any one of the members of the Speaker's panel to take the Chair as Deputy Speaker. The Deputy Speaker may also call on any one of the members of the Speaker's panel to take the Chair of the Main Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: (2)After standing order 22 insert the following new standing orders:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Vacancies in both offices of Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker

SPEECH.PARA: 22A. If the offices of Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker become vacant at the same time the House shall appoint 2 Members to be Deputy Speaker and Second Deputy Speaker in the same manner as set out in standing order 13.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Single vacancy in office of Deputy Speaker or Second Deputy Speaker

PARA.TAB: When a single vacancy occurs in the office of Deputy Speaker or the office of Second Deputy Speaker the House shall appoint a Member to fill the vacant office in the following manner:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)A motion shall be moved, without notice, that a Member be appointed Deputy Speaker or Second Deputy Speaker, as the case may be, of this House, which motion shall be seconded. In the case of appointment to the office of Second Deputy Speaker, only a non-government Member may be named in the motion.

(b)The Speaker shall then ask if there is any further motion, and if there is not, shall say that the time for motions has expired. No Member may then address the House or move any motion for the appointment of a Member to the vacant office, and the Speaker shall, without question put, declare the Member named in the motion, to have been appointed to the vacant office.

(c)If more than one motion for the appointment of a Member to the vacant office is moved and seconded, the Speaker shall, after the second motion, and after each subsequent motion (if any), ask if there is any further motion, and if there is not, shall say that the time for motions has expired.
(d)When the time for motions has expired, debate may ensue, but it shall be relevant to the election.
(e)No Member may speak for more than 5 minutes.

(f)At any time during the debate, a motion without notice may be moved by a Minister rising in his or her place, and whether any Member is addressing the Chair or not, "That the question be now put", which question shall be put forthwith and decided without amendment or debate.

Upon the carrying of the question "That the question be now put", or upon the cessation of the debate otherwise, the appointment of the Member to fill the vacant office shall be proceeded with as provided in this standing order.
(g)Before the House proceeds to a ballot the bells shall be rung as in a division.

(h)When only 2 motions for the appointment of a Member to the vacant office are moved and seconded, each Member, other than the Speaker, shall deliver to the Clerk a ballot paper in writing, containing the name of the Member named in one or other of the motions for whom he or she votes, and the votes shall be counted by the Clerks at the Table; and the Member who has the greater number of votes shall be appointed to the vacant office.

(i)When more than 2 motions for the appointment of a Member to the vacant office are moved and seconded, the votes shall be taken in the same manner, and the Member who has the greatest number of votes shall be appointed to the vacant office, provided he or she has also a majority of the votes of the Members present; but if no Member has such majority, the name of the Member having the smallest number of votes shall be excluded from subsequent ballots, and a fresh ballot shall take place; and this shall be done as often as necessary until one Member has such majority when he or she shall be appointed to the vacant office.

(j)If, after any ballot, other than a ballot which takes place in accordance with paragraph (k) of this standing order, in which the names of only 2 Members are submitted, there is an equality of votes, the Speaker shall give a casting vote and the Member for whom he or she votes shall be appointed to the vacant office.
(k)If, after any ballot in which the names of more than 2 Members are submitted, it is impossible by reason of an equality of votes to determine which name shall be excluded from subsequent ballots—
(1)If there is an equality of votes for 2 Members, the Speaker shall give a casting vote and the name of the Member for whom he or she does not vote shall be excluded from subsequent ballots; and

(2)If there is an equality of votes for more than 2 Members, a special ballot shall take place at which there shall be submitted only the names of those Members who have received equal votes and in which each Member shall write on the ballot paper only the names of the Members he or she wishes to retain. The name of the Member who receives the smallest number of votes shall be excluded from subsequent ballots. If, by reason of a continued equality of votes, the special ballot is inconclusive, then, unless a name is withdrawn, the sitting shall be suspended for 30 minutes. When the sitting is resumed, the votes shall be taken again unless this is rendered unnecessary by a withdrawal.

(l)At any time after the result of the first ballot is declared, but before the commencement of any subsequent ballot, a Member whose name was submitted in the first ballot may withdraw his or her name and all further proceedings shall take place as if a motion for the appointment of the Member had not been moved.
(m)Whenever a withdrawal leaves only one Member in respect of whom a motion for appointment to the vacant office is before the House, that Member shall be declared to have been appointed.

(6)Omit standing orders 211 to 242 (chapter XVI) and substitute the following standing orders:

PARA.TAB: (a) A bill (unless received from the Senate) shall be initiated by a motion for leave to bring in a bill specifying its title, by an order of the House, on the calling on of a notice of presentation, or in accordance with the provisions of standing order 291.

SPEECH.PARA: (b)Notice of intention to present a bill shall be given by a Member by either:
(i)delivering a fair copy of its terms to the Clerk at the Table; or
(ii)stating its terms to the House during the period of Members' statements made under standing order 106A and delivering a fair copy of its terms to the Clerk at the Table.
(c)A notice of intention to present a bill shall specify its title and the day for presentation, and shall be signed by the Member and, at least, one other Member.
(d)The standing orders shall, to the necessary extent, be applied and read as if a notice of presentation were a notice of motion.

PARA.TAB: A Member bringing in a bill shall present to the House three fair copies each signed by the Member.
The title shall agree with the order of leave or the notice of presentation, and no clause may be included in any bill not coming within its title.

SPEECH.PARA: 214. Every bill not prepared according to the standing orders of the House shall be ordered to be withdrawn.

215. On the presentation of a bill by a Member, or on the receipt from the Senate of a bill for the concurrence of the House, it shall be read a first time without any question being put. In the case of a bill presented by a Minister, an explanatory memorandum signed by the Minister and including an explanation of the reasons for the bill shall then be presented to the House.
216. On every order for the reading of a bill, the title only shall be read.

PARA.TAB: After the first reading a future day shall be appointed for the Member to move "That this bill be now read a second time" and the bill shall meanwhile be printed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reference to Main or other committee

SPEECH.PARA: 217A. At least 7 days after the first reading and before the motion is moved "That this bill be now read a second time", a motion may be moved without notice "That this bill be referred to the Main Committee for the second reading and consideration in detail stages" or "That the bill be referred to the [here insert title of committee] for consideration and an advisory report". A motion to refer a bill to a committee for an advisory report may specify a date by which the committee is to report to the House.
Provided that, in the case of bills presented by Ministers:

(a)a Minister may present a list of bills proposed to be referred to the Main Committee or other committees and (if at least 7 days have elapsed since the first readings of all of the bills) move without notice either immediately or at a later time "That the bills be referred to committee(s) in accordance with the list"; and
(b)the bills referred to the Main Committee may be considered by it after details of the reference have been published in the Notice Paper.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reference to Main Committee after advisory report presented

SPEECH.PARA: 217B. When a bill has been referred to a committee for an advisory report, and the committee's report has been presented to the House, the bill may be referred to the Main Committee for second reading and consideration in detail stages in accordance with standing order 217A.

217C. After Government bills which are related to one another have been presented and prior to moving for their second reading, a Minister may seek leave to declare that the bills are cognate bills. If the leave of the House is granted, the Minister shall declare the bills to be cognate bills and the Minister, in moving that the first of the bills be read a second time, and Members in speaking in the subsequent debate, may refer to the subject matter of all the bills. In doing so, Members may move an amendment to the motion for the second reading for one or more of the bills: Provided that such amendments shall conform to the provisions of standing order 220. A separate question shall be put in respect of each such second reading amendment at the appropriate stage of each bill and no debate shall be allowed on the motions for the second readings or on any amendments to the second readings of the second and subsequent cognate bills:
Provided that, where a provision of this standing order is inconsistent with a provision of another standing order, this standing order shall prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Subsequent proceedings on bills not referred to Main Committee

SPEECH.PARA: 217D. All stages of bills not referred to the Main Committee shall be considered in the House.

PARA.TAB: An amendment may be moved to the question "That the bill be now read a second time" by omitting "now" and adding "this day 6 months", which, if carried, shall finally dispose of the bill. No amendment may be moved to this amendment.

No other amendment may be moved to such question except in the form of an amendment relevant to the bill, which does not anticipate an amendment which may be moved during consideration in detail and does not propose the addition of words to the question: Provided that an amendment relating to public affairs may be moved to the question for the second reading of an Appropriation or Supply Bill, except an Appropriation or Supply Bill for expenditure that is not expenditure for the ordinary annual services of the Government.
Immediately after the second reading:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)a message recommending an appropriation in connection with the bill may be announced;
(b)a motion "That this bill be referred to a select committee" may be moved, and
(c)an instruction of which notice has been given may be moved. (see S.O.s 299-302)
Consideration in detail unless—

PARA.TAB: After the second reading, or when proceeding under standing order 221, after those proceedings have been disposed of, the House or the Main Committee, as appropriate, shall forthwith consider the bill in detail unless—

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the bill has been referred to a select committee in accordance with standing order 221, or
(b)if the bill is being considered in the House, the House grants leave for the question "That this bill be now read a third time" to be moved forthwith, or
(c)if the bill is being considered in the Main Committee, the Committee grants leave for the question "That this bill be reported to the House without amendment" to be moved forthwith.

PARA.TAB: When a bill has been referred to a select committee and reported, a time shall be fixed on a motion without notice of the Member in charge of the bill for the consideration in detail of the bill as reported. The motion shall specify whether the bill is to be considered by the House or the Main Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Restriction on reference to select committee

PARA.TAB: No motion for referring a bill to a select committee may be moved after consideration in detail of the bill has been completed.

For consideration in detail the title and the preamble stand postponed without question proposed, and the clauses shall be considered in their order, a question being proposed by the Chair on each clause "That the clause be agreed to". The words of enactment at the head of the bill shall not be put to the House or the Main Committee.
The following order shall be observed in considering a bill in detail:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clauses as printed and new clauses, in their numerical order.
2.Schedules as printed and new schedules, in their numerical order.
3.Postponed clauses (not having been specially postponed until after certain other clauses).
4.Preamble.
5.Title.
And in reconsidering the bill the same order shall be followed:
Provided that—

(a)in considering an Appropriation or Supply Bill, any schedule expressing the services for which the appropriation is to be made shall be considered before the clauses and, unless the House otherwise orders, that schedule shall be considered by proposed expenditures in the order in which they are shown, and
(b)in considering a bill to impose taxation, any schedule shall be considered before the clauses.

PARA.TAB: Any amendment may be moved to any part of the bill, provided it is within the title or relevant to the subject matter of the bill, and is otherwise in conformity with the standing orders of the House.
The discussion shall be confined to the clause or amendment before the House or the Main Committee.
If a clause is amended, a further question shall be proposed, "That the clause, as amended, be agreed to".
A clause, or a clause which has been amended, may be postponed.

If any amendment has been made in the bill, necessitating an amendment of the title, the title shall be amended, and a question proposed, "That the title, as amended, be the title of the bill", and the amendment of the title shall be specially reported to the House if the bill has been considered in the Main Committee.
Notwithstanding the provisions of standing orders 172 and 174, a motion moved during consideration in detail need not be seconded.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment inadmissible if contrary to previous decision

PARA.TAB: No amendment or new clause or schedule shall be at any time moved which is substantially the same as one already negatived by the House or the Main Committee, or which is inconsistent with one that has been agreed to already by the House or the Main Committee, unless a reconsideration of the bill has intervened.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report from Main Committee and adoption
Bill ordered to be reported—Bill reported

PARA.TAB: If a bill is being dealt with in the Main Committee, when it has been fully considered, the question shall be put forthwith and determined without amendment or debate, "That this bill (or this bill as amended) be reported to the House", which being agreed to, the Chair shall report the bill at a time when other business is not before the House and shall present a copy of the bill certified by the Clerk of the Committee together with schedules of any amendments made by the Committee and any questions which the Committee was unable to resolve.

If a bill is reported with amendments or with questions which the Main Committee had been unable to resolve, a future time shall be appointed for taking the report into consideration and the schedules of amendments or unresolved questions shall in the meantime be printed: Provided that, if copies of the schedules have been circulated among Members, the report may be considered forthwith.

On consideration of a report from the Main Committee on a bill with amendments or unresolved questions, separate questions shall be proposed, on motion being made, on each of the unresolved questions which shall be open to debate or amendment. A single question shall then be proposed, if necessary, "That the amendments made by the Main Committee be agreed to", no debate or amendment to this question being allowed. No new amendments may be moved except as necessary as a consequence of the resolution by the House of any question on which the Committee had reported it could not agree. Finally the question "That the bill (or the bill as amended) be agreed to" shall be proposed, no debate or amendment being allowed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Bill reported without amendment or unresolved questions

SPEECH.PARA: 236A. If a bill is reported from the Main Committee without amendment or unresolved questions the question shall be proposed, at once or at a time to be appointed, "That the bill be agreed to", no debate or amendment being allowed.
236B. At any time before the moving of the third reading a bill, on motion without notice by any Member, may be reconsidered in detail, in whole or in part, by the House.

PARA.TAB: When a bill has been finally agreed to, the Speaker shall notify the House and a future day shall be fixed, on motion, for the third reading.
On the order of the day being read for the third reading of a bill, on motion being made, the question shall be proposed "That this bill be now read a third time".
The only amendment which may be moved to such question is by omitting "now" and adding "this day 6 months", which, if carried, shall finally dispose of the bill.
After the third reading no further question shall be put, and the bill shall have passed the House.
Amendments of a verbal or formal nature may be made, and clerical or typographical errors may be corrected, in any part of the bill by the Clerk acting with the authority of the Deputy Speaker.

When a bill originated in the House has been passed, the Clerk shall certify at the top of the first page "This bill originated in the House of Representatives; and, having this day passed, is now ready for presentation to the Senate for its concurrence".

(8)Standing order 245 (how disposed of):

(11)Standing order 262 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: Whenever the Senate returns to the House any bill which the Senate may not amend, requesting, by message, the omission or amendment of any items or provisions therein, the House shall thereupon, or at a later time to be fixed, consider the requested amendments, and the subsequent proceedings shall be as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)The House may make any of such omissions or amendments, with or without modifications.

(b)The omissions or amendments (if any) as agreed to by the House shall be made by the Clerk in the bill, which shall be returned to the Senate with a message, stating the manner in which the omissions or amendments requested by the Senate have been dealt with by the House, and desiring the concurrence of the Senate in the bill.
(12)Omit standing orders 270 to 290 (chapter XVII) and substitute the following standing orders:

PARA.TAB: A Main Committee is established to which:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)bills may be referred for consideration; and
(b)orders of the day for the resumption of debate on motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports may be referred for debate.

All proceedings on such bills as are referred to it, from the calling on of a bill and the moving of a motion "That this bill be now read a second time" to the completion of consideration in detail, shall be conducted in the Main Committee:

Provided that a bill may be returned to the House for consideration at any time during its consideration in the Main Committee by agreement to a motion which may be moved without notice by any Member "That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House" which motion shall be determined without amendment or debate. If the Committee is unable to resolve this question the bill shall be returned to the House for further consideration. The House shall continue consideration at the point which had been reached in the Committee and shall resolve any other matters which the Committee reports in relation to the bill.

PARA.TAB: All Members shall be members of the Main Committee.
The quorum of the Main Committee shall be 3 Members comprising the occupant of the Chair and one government Member and one non-government Member.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Deputy Speaker fixes meeting times, takes Chair

PARA.TAB: Subject to standing order 274, the Deputy Speaker shall fix the meeting times of the Main Committee which shall be notified to all Members and shall take the Chair of the Committee.
The Main Committee may meet at any time during a sitting of the House and the following provisions shall apply:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the Committee need not adjourn between items of business;
(b)proceedings in the Committee shall be suspended by the Chair to enable Members to attend any division in the House;
(c)a sitting of the Committee may be adjourned on motion moved by any Member without notice;
(d)upon the adjournment of the House the Chair shall interrupt the business before the Committee and forthwith adjourn the Committee; and
(e)the Committee shall stand adjourned upon completion of consideration of all bills referred to it by the House.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Committee to consider only matters referred

PARA.TAB: The Main Committee shall consider only such matters as have been referred to it by the House.

Every question in the Committee shall be decided on the voices and if any Member dissents from the result announced by the Chair, the question shall be recorded in the minutes as unresolved and included in a schedule attached to the report of the Committee to the House on the bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Committee may continue regardless of unresolved questions

PARA.TAB: The Main Committee may continue proceedings on a bill regardless of unresolved questions unless agreement to an unresolved question is necessary to enable further questions to be considered in which case the Committee shall return the bill to the House for further consideration.
A motion contradictory of a previous decision of the Main Committee in relation to the same bill shall not be entertained.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minutes to be recorded by Clerk of Committee
