PARA.TAB: All proceedings of the Main Committee shall be recorded by the Clerk of the Committee and such records shall constitute the Minutes of Proceedings of the Committee and shall form part of the Votes and Proceedings of the House for that sitting.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Rules for proceedings and order in debate

PARA.TAB: Except as provided by these standing orders, the same rules relating to the proceedings on bills and for regulating the conduct of business shall be observed in the Main Committee as in the House itself, the Chair being invested with the same authority as the Speaker for the preservation of order; but disorder in the Committee may be censured by the House only on receiving a report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chair to suspend sitting when disorder arises

PARA.TAB: If any sudden disorder arises in the Main Committee the Chair may, or on motion without notice by any Member shall, forthwith suspend the sitting and shall report the disorder to the House.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Chair to suspend proceedings when quorum not present

PARA.TAB: If at any time the Chair takes note that a quorum is not present he or she shall immediately suspend proceedings until a stated time or adjourn the Committee to the day of the next sitting of the House.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Resumption of proceedings after suspension or adjournment

PARA.TAB: The Main Committee may resume proceedings at the point at which they were interrupted following any suspension or adjournment of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: (13)Standing order 294 be amended to read:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Message announced by Speaker or Chair

PARA.TAB: A message from the Governor-General shall be announced to the House or the Main Committee by the Speaker or the Chair, as the case may be, but not during a debate, or so as to interrupt a Member speaking.

SPEECH.PARA: (14)Standing order 300 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: No instruction can be given to a committee to do that which it is already empowered to do, or, in the case of a bill referred to a select committee, to deal with a question beyond the scope of the bill as read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: (15)Standing order 301 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: An instruction to the Main Committee in relation to a bill requires notice, and can only be moved before the Committee has met to consider the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: (16)Standing orders 303 and 304 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: If any Member has—

SPEECH.PARA: (a)persistently and wilfully obstructed the business of the House; or
(b)been guilty of disorderly conduct; or
(c)used objectionable words, which he or she has refused to withdraw; or
(d)persistently and wilfully refused to conform to any standing order; or
(e)persistently and wilfully disregarded the authority of the Chair—
the Member may be named by the Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Following the naming of a Member, the Speaker shall forthwith put the question, on a motion being made, no amendment, adjournment, or debate being allowed, "That the Member be suspended from the service of the House".

SPEECH.PARA: (17)New standing order 304A be inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Speaker may order disorderly Member to withdraw

PARA.TAB: If the Speaker considers the conduct of a Member is disorderly, the Speaker, instead of calling on the provisions of standing order 303 or 306, may order the Member to withdraw from the House for one hour, which order shall not be open to debate or dissent.

SPEECH.PARA: If a Member fails to leave the Chamber immediately when ordered to do so by the Speaker, the Speaker may name the Member and shall forthwith put the question, on a motion being moved, no amendment, adjournment or debate being allowed, "That the Member be suspended from the service of the House".
(18)Standing orders 305, 306 and 307 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: If any Member is named and suspended under standing order 304 or 304A, the period of suspension on the first occasion shall be for 24 hours; on the second occasion during the same calendar year for 3 consecutive sittings excluding the day of suspension; and on the third or any subsequent occasion during the same calendar year for 7 consecutive sittings excluding the day of suspension. For the purposes of this standing order, any suspension in a previous session or any order to withdraw pursuant to standing order 304A shall be disregarded.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Speaker may order grossly disorderly Member to withdraw

PARA.TAB: When the conduct of a Member is of such a grossly disorderly nature that the procedure provided in standing order 304 or 304A would be inadequate to ensure the urgent protection of the dignity of the House, the Speaker shall order the Member to withdraw immediately from the Chamber and the Serjeant-at-Arms shall act on any orders received from the Chair in pursuance of this standing order. When the Member has withdrawn, he or she shall forthwith be named by the Speaker and the proceedings shall then be as provided in standing orders 304 and 305, except that the question for the suspension of the Member shall be put by the Speaker without a motion being necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: If the question for the suspension of the Member is resolved in the negative, he or she may forthwith return to the Chamber.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Member suspended excluded from Chamber and room where Main Committee is meeting

PARA.TAB: A Member who has been suspended from the service of the House or ordered by the Speaker to withdraw from the House for one hour shall be excluded from the Chamber, all its galleries and any room where the Main Committee is meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: (19)Standing order 28D be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: (a) A Selection Committee, to consist of the Deputy Speaker, the Government Whip, the Opposition Whip, the Third Party Whip, 4 Government members, and 3 Opposition or other non-government members, shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament to arrange the timetable and order of business for private Members' business and committee and delegation reports on each sitting Monday pursuant to standing order 101.

SPEECH.PARA: (b)Private Members' business which is to be accorded priority, the order of consideration and the times allotted for debate on each item and the time limits allotted for each Member speaking shall be approved by a majority of the members present at a meeting of the committee and in accordance with general principles adopted by the House after report by the committee.

(c)The Selection Committee may determine the order of precedence and times allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business and shall report its determinations to the House in sufficient time for its decisions to be published on the Notice Paper of the sitting Wednesday prior to the Monday to which the determinations apply.
(d)Reports of the committee made pursuant to paragraph (c) shall be deemed adopted when laid upon the Table and shall be printed in Hansard.
(e)Five members of the committee shall constitute a quorum of the committee.
(f)For the purpose of private Members' business in this and any other standing order, a private Member is any Member of the House other than the Speaker or a Minister.
(20)Standing order 40 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: Unless otherwise ordered, the House shall meet for the despatch of business on each—

SPEECH.PARA: Monday, at 12.30 p.m.
Tuesday, at 12.30 p.m.
Wednesday, at 9.30 a.m.
Thursday, at 9.30 a.m.

From the termination of the last sitting in the second week of sittings, the House shall stand adjourned until 12.30 p.m. on the third Monday after the termination, unless the Speaker shall, by writing addressed to each Member of the House, fix an alternative day or hour of meeting. The 4-weekly cycle will then be repeated.
(21)Standing order 48A be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: At 5.30 p.m. on a sitting Thursday and at 7.30 p.m. on each other sitting day the Speaker shall propose the question—That the House do now adjourn—which question shall be open to debate. No amendment may be moved to this question:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that:
(a)if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, that division, and any division consequent upon that division, shall be completed and the result announced;
(b)if, on the question—That the House do now adjourn—being proposed, a Minister requires the question to be put forthwith without debate, the Speaker shall forthwith put the question;
(c)a motion for the adjournment of the House may be moved by a Minister at an earlier hour;
(d)any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of the adjournment shall be set down on the Notice Paper for the next sitting, and
(e)if the question—That the House do now adjourn—is negatived, the House shall resume the proceedings at the point at which they had been interrupted:

Provided further that, if at 6 p.m. on a sitting Thursday or at 8 p.m. on each other sitting day, the question before the House is—That the House do now adjourn—the Speaker shall interrupt the debate, at which time—

(f)a Minister may require that the debate be extended until 6.10 p.m. or 8.10 p.m., as appropriate, to enable Ministers to speak in reply to matters raised in the preceding adjournment debate; at 6.10 p.m. or 8.10 p.m., as appropriate, or upon the earlier cessation of the debate, the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting, or
(g)if no action is taken by a Minister under paragraph (f) the Speaker shall forthwith adjourn the House until the time of its next meeting.
(22)Standing orders 101 and 101A be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: The House shall proceed on the days indicated with its ordinary business in the following routine:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Presentation of, and statements on, reports from parliamentary committees and delegations. 2. Orders of the day for the resumption of debate on motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports (debate concluding no later than 1.15 p.m.). 3. Private Members' business (commencing no later than 1.15 p.m., debate concluding no later than 2.45 p.m.). 4. Members' statements (at approximately 2.45 p.m.). 5. Questions without notice (at 3 p.m.). 6. Presentation of petitions. 7. Grievance debate (debate concluding no later than 5.15 p.m.). 8. Notices and orders of the day.

1. Notices and orders of the day. 2. Questions without notice (at 3 p.m.). 3. Presentation of papers. 4. Ministerial statements, by leave. 5. Matter of public importance. 6. Notices and orders of the day.

PARA.TAB: At 3 p.m. on each sitting day the Speaker shall interrupt the business before the House in order that questions without notice can be called on.:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that:
(a)if a division is in progress at the time fixed for interruption, the division shall be completed and the result announced; and
(b)the Speaker shall fix the time for the resumption of the debate on any business under discussion and not disposed of at the time of interruption.
(23)Standing order 102A be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: Following Prayers each sitting Monday, parliamentary committee and delegation reports may be presented in the order determined by the Selection Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: (24)Standing order 102C (precedence to motions regarding committee and delegation reports):
Omit "11 a.m." and substitute "1.15 p.m.".
(25)Standing order 103 (new business):
Omit "11 p.m." and substitute "8 p.m.".
(26)Standing orders 104, 104A and 104B be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: Government business shall, on each day of sitting, have precedence of private Members' business except that, on each sitting Monday, private Members' business shall have precedence of government business from the conclusion of committee and delegation reports but commencing no later than 1.15 p.m. and debate concluding no later than 2.45 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: At the conclusion of consideration of private Members' business, the Speaker shall put forthwith and successively, without further debate or amendment, any questions on which a division had been called for earlier in the day, and which had been deferred pursuant to standing order 193.

PARA.TAB: In the period during which private Members' business is accorded precedence pursuant to standing order 104, notices and orders of the day relating to private Members' business shall be called on by the Clerk in the order in which they appear on the Notice Paper. When the time allotted by standing order 102C or 104, or by the Selection Committee, for an item of business has expired, consideration shall be interrupted by the Chair and the question before the Chair shall be put:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, where the Selection Committee has determined that consideration of a matter should continue on a future day, at the time fixed for interruption, the Chair shall interrupt proceedings and shall fix the next sitting Monday for the further consideration of the matter.

Notices by private Members of their intention to present bills shall stand referred to the Selection Committee which shall give priority to them over other notices and orders of the day and determine the order in which they are to be presented. Upon the respective notice being called on by the Clerk, the Member in whose name the notice stands shall present the bill and may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes in support thereof. The bill shall then be read a first time and the next sitting Monday shall be appointed for the Member to move "That this bill be now read a second time".

If the motion for the second reading of any private Member's bill is agreed to by the House, further consideration shall be accorded precedence of other private Members' business and the Selection Committee may allot times for consideration of the remaining stages of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Any private Members' business not called on, or any private Members' business the consideration of which has been interrupted pursuant to standing order 104A and not re-accorded priority by the Selection Committee on any of the next 8 sitting Mondays, shall be removed from the Notice Paper by the Clerk.

SPEECH.PARA: (27)Standing order 106 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding standing order 105, the first order of the day, government business, on each sitting Monday following the presentation of petitions shall be a question to be proposed by the Speaker, "That grievances be noted" to which question any Member may address the House or move any amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: If consideration of the question has not been concluded at 5.15 p.m., the debate thereon shall be interrupted and the Speaker shall put any questions then before the House, and after resolution of those questions, shall forthwith call on the next order of the day, government business.
(28)Standing order 106A (statements by Members):
Omit "2 p.m." and substitute "3 p.m.".
(29)Standing order 112 be amended to read:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Petition to be lodged with Clerk

PARA.TAB: Every petition shall be lodged with the Clerk by 12 noon on the Friday previous to the Monday at which it is proposed that it be presented.

SPEECH.PARA: (30)Standing order 193 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: A division shall not be proceeded with unless more than one Member has called for a division. If one Member only calls for a division, that Member may inform the Speaker that he or she wishes his or her dissent to be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and in Hansard and the Member's dissent shall be so recorded:

SPEECH.PARA: Provided that, on sitting Mondays, any division called for in the House during the consideration of private Members' business on a question, other than a motion moved by a Minister, shall stand deferred until 5.30 p.m.
(31)Omit standing order 46.

PARA.EMPHASIS: When vacancy in Speakership, Deputy Speaker to fix time of meeting

PARA.TAB: When a vacancy has occurred in the office of Speaker during any adjournment following which the date and hour of the next meeting is to be, or may be, fixed by the Speaker, the date and hour of the next meeting shall be fixed by the Deputy Speaker.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Want of quorum, all Members to be counted and to remain in Chamber

PARA.TAB: When the attention of the Speaker has been called to the fact that there is not a quorum of Members present, any Member who is within the physical limits of the Chamber shall be counted to determine whether a quorum is present and no Member shall leave the Chamber until a quorum is present or 4 minutes have elapsed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Doors unlocked and bells rung when House counted

PARA.TAB: The doors of the House shall be unlocked whenever the Speaker is engaged in counting the House and the bells shall be rung as in a division.

PARA.EMPHASIS: House adjourns only by resolution with exceptions

PARA.TAB: The House can only be adjourned by its own resolution, except in the cases mentioned in standing orders 41, 44, 45 and 308, when the Speaker adjourns the House without putting a question.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Order maintained by Speaker, or in Main Committee by Chair

PARA.TAB: Order shall be maintained in the House by the Speaker, and in the Main Committee by the Chair; but disorder in the Committee can be censured by the House only on receiving a report.
No Member may speak twice to a question except in explanation or reply or during consideration in detail of a bill.
In all cases the reply of the mover of the original question closes the debate except during consideration in detail of a bill.

The Speaker, or the Chair, after having called the attention of the House, or of the Main Committee, to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition either of his or her own arguments, or of the arguments used by other Members in debate, may direct the Member to discontinue his or her speech: Provided that the Member shall have the right to require that the question whether he or she be further heard be put, and thereupon the question shall be put without debate.
The following matters are not open to debate, shall be moved without argument or opinion offered, and shall be forthwith put from the Chair without amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)Question that a Member "be now heard" or "do now speak" (standing order 61);
(b)Question that a Member be further heard (standing order 85);
(c)Motion for adjournment of debate (standing order 87);
(d)Motion for extension of time (standing order 91);
(e)Question put following declaration of urgency (standing order 92);
(f)Motion that the question be now put (standing order 93);
(g)Motion that a Member be not further heard (standing order 94);
(h)Motion that the business of the day be called on (standing order 107);
(i)Question that a bill be reported to the House (standing order 234);
(j)Question for the second reading or any second reading amendment to the second or subsequent bill in a group of cognate bills (standing order 217C);
(k)Question that the amendments made by the Main Committee be agreed to (standing order 236);
(l)Question proposed in relation to a bill reported from the Main Committee that the bill be agreed to (standing orders 236 and 236A);
(m)Motion that further proceedings on a bill be conducted in the House (standing order 270);
(n)Motion that a Member be suspended (standing order 304), and
(o)Motion that strangers be ordered to withdraw (standing order 314).

Should any of these questions be negatived, no similar proposal shall be received if the Speaker or the Chair is of opinion that it is an abuse of the orders or forms of the House, or is moved for the purpose of obstructing business.

PARA.TAB: (a)On the reading of a message from the Governor-General recommending an appropriation in connection with any bill, on the calling on of a motion for leave to introduce a bill or a notice of presentation, on the consideration of any motion preliminary to the introduction of a bill, at any stage of a bill, or on the consideration of Senate amendments or requests for amendments to a bill, a Minister may declare in the House that the bill is an urgent bill, and on such declaration, the question "That the bill be considered an urgent bill" shall be put forthwith—no debate or amendment being allowed—and on such question being agreed to, a Minister may forthwith, or at any time during any sitting of the House, but not so as to interrupt a Member who is addressing the House, move a motion or motions specifying the time which shall be allotted to all or any of the following:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)The initial stages of the bill (including any motion preliminary to the introduction of the bill) up to, but not inclusive of, the second reading of the bill;
(ii)The second reading of the bill;
(iii)The consideration in detail of the bill;
(iv)The remaining stages of the bill;
(v)The consideration of Senate amendments or requests for amendments to the bill;

and the order with regard to the time allotted to the consideration in detail of the bill may, out of the time allotted, apportion a certain time or times to a particular clause or clauses, or to any particular part or parts of the bill.

(b)When a proposed resolution for customs or excise tariff is being considered, a Minister may at any time declare that the proposed resolution is of an urgent nature, and, on such declaration, the question "That the proposed resolution be considered of an urgent nature" shall be put forthwith—no debate or amendment being allowed—and on such question being agreed to, a Minister may forthwith, or at any time during the consideration of the proposed resolution, but not so as to interrupt a Member who is speaking, move a motion specifying the time or times which shall be allotted to any portion or portions of the proposed resolution.

(c)When any motion of any kind whatsoever has been moved, a Minister may at any time declare that the motion is an urgent motion, and, on such declaration, the question "That the motion be considered an urgent motion" shall be put forthwith—no debate or amendment being allowed—and on such question being agreed to, a Minister may forthwith move a motion specifying the time which shall be allotted to the motion.

(d)Upon such motion or motions with regard to the allotment of time being moved, no debate thereon shall be allowed for more than 20 minutes, and in speaking thereon no Member may exceed 5 minutes. If the debate is not concluded sooner, then forthwith upon the expiration of that time the Speaker shall put any questions on any amendment or motion already proposed from the Chair.

(e)For the purpose of bringing to a conclusion any proceedings which are to be brought to a conclusion on the expiration of the time allotted under any motion passed under any of the preceding paragraphs of this standing order, the Speaker or the Chair shall, at the time appointed under the motion for the conclusion of those proceedings, first put forthwith any question already proposed from the Chair and then any other question requisite to dispose of the business before the House or the Main Committee, including, when considering any bill in detail or any Senate amendments or Senate requests for amendments to a bill, any amendments, new clauses and schedules, and modifications, copies of which have been circulated by the Government among Members 2 hours at least before the expiration of the allotted time. No other amendments, new clauses or schedules, or modifications may be proposed.

(f)Where any time has been specified for the commencement of any proceedings in connection with any business under this standing order, when the time so specified has been reached the business, whatsoever its nature, then before the House or the Main Committee shall be postponed forthwith, and the first-mentioned business shall be proceeded with, and all steps necessary to enable this to be done shall be taken accordingly.
(g)Standing order 93 shall not apply to any proceedings in respect of which time has been allotted in pursuance of this standing order.

PARA.TAB: After any question has been proposed from the Chair, either in the House or in the Main Committee, a motion may be made by any Member, rising in his or her place, and without notice, and whether any other Member is addressing the Chair or not, "That the question be now put", and such motion shall be put forthwith without amendment or debate.

Any Member may rise at any time to speak upon a matter of privilege suddenly arising, and he or she shall be prepared to move, without notice, a motion declaring that a contempt or breach of privilege has been committed, or referring the matter to the Committee of Privileges; but if a matter related to the proceedings of the Main Committee is raised in the Main Committee, the Chair shall suspend the proceedings and report to the House at the first opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: 107. A Member may propose to the Speaker that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion. The Member proposing the matter shall present to the Speaker not later than 12 noon on each sitting day on which a matter may be discussed a written statement of the matter proposed to be discussed; and if the Speaker determines that it is in order, the Speaker shall read it to the House. The proposed discussion must be supported by 8 Members, including the proposer, rising in their places as indicating approval. The Speaker shall then call upon the Member who had proposed the matter to speak.

At any time during the discussion, a motion may be made by any Member "That the business of the day be called on" and such motion shall be put forthwith and decided without amendment or debate, and, if agreed to, the business of the day shall be proceeded with immediately. A motion under standing order 87 or standing order 93 will not be in order.

In the event of more than one matter being presented for the same day, priority shall be given to the matter which, in the opinion of the Speaker, is the most urgent and important, and no other proposed matter shall be read to the House that day.

PARA.TAB: The House or the Main Committee may order a complicated question to be divided.

Subject to the provisions of standing order 233, the Speaker or the Chair may, in his or her discretion, disallow any motion or amendment which is the same in substance as any question, which, during the same session, has been resolved in the affirmative or negative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Decision on point of order during division

PARA.TAB: Should a point of order arise during a division it shall be decided by the Speaker.
Lists of divisions in the House shall be recorded by the Clerk in the Votes and Proceedings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Arrest of strangers in House, Main Committee or gallery

PARA.TAB: The Serjeant-at-Arms shall take or deliver into custody any stranger who causes a disturbance in any part of the Chamber or the room in which the Main Committee is meeting or any gallery of those places, or who does not withdraw when strangers are directed to withdraw, while the House or the Main Committee is sitting.

If at any sitting of the House, or the Main Committee, any Member takes notice that strangers are present, the Speaker or the Chair, as the case may be, shall forthwith put the question "That strangers be ordered to withdraw", which shall be decided without debate: Provided that the Speaker or the Chair may, whenever he or she thinks fit, order the withdrawal of strangers from any part of the Chamber or the room in which the Main Committee is meeting.

PARA.EMPHASIS: No stranger admitted into Chamber or Main Committee

PARA.TAB: While the House or the Main Committee is sitting, no Member may bring any stranger into any part of the Chamber or that part of the room where the Main Committee is meeting which is reserved for Members.
Except with his or her consent, the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker or the Second Deputy Speaker shall not be chosen to serve on a select committee.

Witnesses, not being Members, shall be ordered to attend before the House by summons under the hand of the Clerk of the House, or before a select committee, by summons under the hand of the Clerk attending the committee.
When the attendance of a Member is ordered by the House for examination by the House, he or she shall be summoned by the Speaker to attend in his or her place.
A witness before the House shall be examined at the Bar unless the House otherwise orders.

PARA.EMPHASIS: During consideration in detail by any Member

PARA.TAB: During consideration in detail of a bill in the House, any Member may put questions directly to a witness.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Messages to be signed by Speaker or a Deputy Speaker

PARA.TAB: Every message from the House to the Senate shall be signed by the Speaker or the Deputy Speaker and delivered by the Serjeant-at-Arms.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a motion to amend standing orders. It deals principally with handling legislation and structuring the proposal for a main committee. It deals with some matters relating to disorder, some matters relating to the sitting program and program of business, and some matters relating to the election of a deputy speaker. I will move two other motions later in the day—one will change sessional orders in relation to question time and the other will set in place a procedure to permit you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, to continue in office as Deputy Speaker without a fresh election being required. I intend to speak only to the motion which I have moved. I will briefly speak to the other motions during the afternoon and evening as they come forward for consideration.

PARA.TAB: I suggest—Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you would be happy with this procedure, as I think any of the other presiding officers would be—that, whereas there is only one motion before the House, if honourable members making a contribution wish to canvass all three, that certainly would be acceptable to the government. A number of people want to speak on these matters and it will not be possible to have them circulating again after each resolution has been considered.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—On that point, my understanding is that, with the cooperation and agreement of the Manager of Opposition Business, that is a sensible course of action. I will ensure that other Deputy Speakers are aware of that course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Firstly, because I might forget in the hurly-burly of discussion, I want to thank the clerks, particularly Mr Barlin, for the enormous work they have done in preparing what is a virtual total restructuring of standing orders in order to be able to cope with the very substantial changes, particularly those that are associated with establishing a main committee. It may be that, in the course of their consideration of this, the government's consideration and, ultimately, the House's consideration of it, we will find that there are some errors or some unworkable elements to it. If that is the case, of course, it will always be open to us to deal with that when the occasion arises and it becomes obvious to us that changes are needed. But I can attest to the fact that every care has been exercised in getting these standing orders together in a way that will make that main committee workable. I congratulate the clerks on their diligent work in doing that.

PARA.TAB: These are changes to standing orders and, therefore, they will sit in standing orders until the government at some time in the future and a House at some time in the future decides to change them. Other changes to standing orders or sessional orders will last only for the period of the experiment, as far as question time is concerned; that is, to the middle of this year when the matter will be considered again by the government.

There are a number of matters entailed in this first motion, which I have referred to. The first is the appointment of a deputy speaker and a second deputy speaker. The second deputy speaker will be drawn from the ranks of the non-government members of the chamber. I think this is an important step. It has been a matter of some debate over time—not by the committee that considered these proposals—that there ought to be, in the processes of election of Speaker, more bipartisanship than there has been hitherto, and perhaps even that an independent Speaker ought to be elected.

There are many arguments for and against that particular proposition. But I certainly believe that the effect of the election of a second deputy speaker under these terms and its enshrining in standing orders will create a situation where there will be more of a sense—even more than is simply provided for by the bipartisan nature of the appointment of temporary chairpersons—of the essentially independent or bipartisan nature of the person who is the presiding officer. I think that over time we will find that what seems like quite a small advance in fact becomes quite a major advance in the handling of business in this House.

In this motion there are also matters dealing with hours of sitting. Those hours of sitting are virtually the same as were handed forth by Dr Blewett's committee—not entirely the same but virtually the same. They still permit party meetings, which people are anxious to sustain, for Mondays and Tuesdays. But the main feature of them that was noteworthy to all is that they have us rising on three days at 8.00 p.m. and on the fourth day at 6.00 p.m., the view being that this will lead to more civilised hours for members.

I am not an optimist in that regard, I have to say. I suspect that these evenings will be filled very quickly and that we will have committees meeting in that time and being able to meet in that way at some leisure, unpressed by quorums and divisions. Once committee chairmen discover that, they will be even more ambitious for the evening meeting. Some of them will be throttled by their colleagues. I am aware of the fact that this has been an extremely popular reform on both sides of the House. There has been a great deal of concern on both sides of the House about the absurd hours that we keep—not as absurd a set of hours as we used to keep; as I recollect, when I came here it was a bit more frequently the case that the 11 o'clock rule was suspended—and certainly not the absurd hours as are sat in state parliaments. But if it sustains members' health and good commonsense in the course of debate, then I think that will be all to the good.

There is also a provision here for changes to processes on disorder, again recommended by the Blewett committee, which allows the Speaker the capacity to discipline recalcitrant members of the parliament by sin-binning them for a period of one hour, and then there is a series of consequent changes in regard to other penalties. If all these changes add up to a situation where some of the sense of the parliamentary tradition of the place is effectively restored, then that will be all to the good, too.

I must confess—I am not laying blame on the opposition in this regard; the government must share an element of blame itself—that this parliament operates a long way from the jealous guardian of traditions which existed in the parliament when I first came here and which existed prior to that in the time my father was a member of parliament. Those two periods are the only periods of which I have either direct knowledge or pretty good vicarious knowledge of how proceedings went. I think we saw an example of it here today when what were pretty tough-minded standing orders and parliamentary practices of hundreds of years standing—we took them from the Westminster system and they related to the way in which House committee proceedings have been regarded as sacrosanct and not for discussion in the House until the committee has reported; it was done for convenience, and I think it was convenient in order to encourage debate to proceed—were effectively just simply stood aside. In the conduct of question time it has been necessary for other processes to be set aside, including the quite strict standing orders relating to the nature of questions—whether or not they canvass information and all the other standing orders relating to them—and the nature of answers in relation to relevance.

There has been a substantial step back from a strict observance of the way in which standing orders operate. We do not have to get fixated with rules and we do not have to make gods of rules, but in a chamber which is supposed to be as dignified as well as robust as this one is, those are time honoured traditions of debate. It would be very useful if the Speakers and presiding officers got themselves into a position where they felt they were readily able to enforce the traditions of the place more effectively than has been the capacity of presiding officers of late. This might help that. I am not sure whether it will, but it might.

These standing orders contain a proposition dealing with the routine of business associated with the changed timetables. The most noteworthy feature of the routine of business is the shifting of the opportunity to deal with private members business from Thursday mornings to a substantial proportion of the Monday sitting. That is noteworthy only in the sense that, instead of its being concluded by question time, it will be broken by question time, given the change to the time at which question time is held to 3 o'clock.

The hope of the government in shifting question time to 3 o'clock is that it will enable, over the period of the lunch hour, much more business to be transacted by members of parliament without the pressure of immediately having to meet at 2 o'clock. Much business is transacted by members of parliament during the lunch hour. For example, committee meetings are held at this time. An enormous amount of entertainment activity occurs, with constituents entertaining members and with persons providing information essential to the effective activities of members of parliament. In the tasks that they have before them, ministers frequently have a need for entertainment at lunchtime, usually business lunches. The 3 o'clock start for question time will remove some of the pressure that is imposed on them by a 2 o'clock start.

Over the years, question time has been bumped all over the place. It has been held in the morning, at 2.15 p.m. and at 2 p.m. This is just yet another change of the time at which question time is held to 3 o'clock. We will see whether it is any better than the experiences that have been had with question time in the past.

The bulk of the material here deals with the main committee, which is highly experimental and will be difficult to organise. The standing orders make it as simple as possible, with a quorum effectively requiring in place only a chairperson, one government member and one non-government member. The use of that description is deliberate. There is not an anticipation, necessarily, that there will be ministers or frontbenchers in the main committee. There is an assumption, of course, that this would usually be the case, but it is not necessarily maintained that it inevitably be.

One matter we are going to have to look at is the whipping arrangements. It will be necessary for us to expand the number of whips, both on the government side and on the opposition side. Effectively, the main committee is going to have to be a whips-run chamber to a very large extent. There will be a requirement for more whips, from both sides of the House, to effectively perform that task.

If the main committee is to work as envisaged by the Blewett committee and by the government, it ought to have before it legislation which is effectively non-controversial but which does require a bit of detailed attention from the House, in the spirit of bipartisan cooperation. One would hope that simply because legislation would be being considered on a non-controversial basis it would not necessarily be the case that it would not be amended. There should be opportunities for members on both sides of the House to put forward amendments. If they become matters of disagreement, the suggestion is that that disagreement has to be reported to the House, to the main chamber, where consideration will then be given by the main chamber in the form of a vote on those particular matters.

It is also intended that this informal mode of operation should not extend to ready tolerance of disorder. The standing orders are devised in such a way that any of the people in the main committee, but particularly the Presiding Officer, can shut the main committee down and take the matter back to the chamber for that disorder to be resolved. Hopefully, that is not a situation which will ever be required.

The change that all these new arrangements impose on our normal operations will require an earlier tabling of explanatory memoranda. An explanatory memorandum will have to come forward at the first reading of a bill—not at its second reading, the time at which that normally happens—when that bill is headed off to the main committee.

This is an important series of changes. Having looked at the comments made by members on both sides of the House, I know that the motion I have moved is largely uncontroversial and I hope that it can be dispatched relatively speedily. It would be my intention to try to finish debating this motion at about 6.00 p.m. and then to move the motion relating to changes to question time so that debate on that can continue after the suspension for dinner. As was indicated, and I am sure you heard this, Mr Deputy Speaker, there was a willingness to tolerate a pretty broad ranging discussion on all of these matters for the convenience of members to have a chance to have a go at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you and your colleagues in the chair for your indication that you will allow a wide ranging debate on the three motions which are to be presented to the House. The House will already be aware of the broad nature of the opposition's attitude to these changes. We have very serious reservations about the changes that are proposed to question time, and the major reasons for that opposition have already been explained. They relate to the reduced accountability of ministers, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis).

PARA.TAB: We see the changes as being tailor-made to suit the political convenience of the Prime Minister. We regard anything that breaks a 93-year tradition of the Australian parliament of ministers—including of Prime Minister and Treasurer—being answerable to the parliament on every day that the parliament sits as being a serious reduction in the authority of this parliament. Our basic principle is that changes made to parliamentary procedures should enhance the power of the legislature over the executive, not the power of the executive over the legislature. If we extract the Prime Minister and the Treasurer from the daily sittings of a parliament that meets, on average, 60 or 70 days a year and cut that in half, there can be no argument—stripping all sophistry aside—that we are in fact reducing the power of the legislature over the executive. That is alien to our system of government and is, I think, very regrettable.

Interestingly enough, the valedictory session that we had earlier this afternoon provided some valuable insights to the issue that we are now debating. The honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) made a particularly valuable contribution to that debate when he spoke of the need—as did the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar)—for attitudinal changes by people in this parliament.

A lot of people on both sides of this parliament have a great respect for this institution. Some are less enthusiastic about it, but a lot care about it a great deal. I am certainly one of those people, and I know that my friend and colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is one also, as you are, Mr Deputy Speaker. There are many such people on the other side of the House, including the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and, in his own way, the Prime Minister. I am genuinely worried about the decline in public esteem for the parliament. All of us share some of the blame for that. We take our share of the blame. The government must take its share of the blame. A lot has to do with the attitude of two people, one of whom is the Prime Minister of the day.

I cite two instances, one that occurred in the early 1960s when the former Prime Minister Mr Menzies required the then Attorney-General, who later became a Speaker, to withdraw a misleading remark he had made about a flag in another country. An incident that I recall happening—I do not mention it to embarrass anybody in the chamber at the present time—was when the former Prime Minister Mr Hawke required a member of his ministry, who is no longer in the ministry, to withdraw a remark about a member of the opposition frontbench which he clearly regarded as being offensive.

I think a great deal lies within the capacity of the Prime Minister of the day. Whoever is in power is the dominant political personality. When Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister of this country he dominated question time. When Menzies was Prime Minister he dominated question time. I was here for 18 months while Whitlam was Prime Minister, and he dominated question time for most of the period, despite the parlous political bleeding of his government at that moment in Australian history. Of course, the present Prime Minister dominates question time. It is the nature of the beast—the beast being question time, not the individual Prime Minister. A lot lies within the capacity and the influence of the Prime Minister of the day.

Whatever comes out of these changes, I earnestly hope that there is a desire by the present Prime Minister and those behind him to recognise that the ideal to which the Australian public probably aspires is a question time which is vigorous and is characteristically Australian. We cannot hope to have a question time in Australia which is like question time in the House of Commons, because we are different people. We may have the same Westminster system, but we have our own version of it. It is a bit like saying that we both speak English but we speak it with an Australian accent and use Australian idioms. The same thing applies for our parliamentary institution.

There are some Australian characteristics of parliamentary exchanges that I would hate to see disappear. I would hate to see a sombre, unenthusiastic question time lacking vigour, lacking colour and, on occasions, lacking very vigorous language. Basically, I think people are now saying that it has gone a bit too far in the other direction and we have to try to get the pendulum back into the middle. By all means, let us have some robust exchanges, but they should not go on for too long, they should not be trivial and they should not be stupid. By working together we could do that without changing the rules. It would be very easy. We could do more to clean up question time and raise its repute in the eyes of the Australian community if the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) agreed that we were going to alter the way in which we conduct ourselves. Regrettably, the nature of adversarial politics in Australia has precluded that.

It has to be said that there has been a steady deterioration in the quality of question time. Fewer questions are asked now than were asked 10 years ago when Mr Hawke was Prime Minister. Fewer questions were asked during the Hawke period than were asked during the Fraser period. Fewer questions were asked during the Fraser period than were asked during earlier periods. A lot of these things are our own responsibility, and they lie within our own capacity to change.

We have said that we are very unhappy with the proposed changes to question time, and I repeat it today. Obviously we will oppose those changes, but because of the government's numbers they will come into effect. I hope the government is serious about reviewing the operation of question time. I am glad to see the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) nodding to indicate that the government is serious about it.

Although we are not opposed to the idea of more rational sitting hours, I wonder about the sense of the House getting up at 8 o'clock on Monday and Tuesday nights. I can see the sense of the House getting up at 8 o'clock on Wednesday night, and I can certainly see what is behind it getting up at 6 o'clock on Thursday night. But on Monday and Tuesday nights we could well have resolved to sit from 2 o'clock in the afternoon to 10 o'clock or 11 o'clock at night. This is what the opposition wanted. We put it to the honourable member for Bonython but, unfortunately, the government decided that it wants to start at 12.30 p.m. I think that in practice it will prove to be inconvenient for both the cabinet and the opposition executive. The idea that we can get through a party meeting and get ready for the resumption of parliament at 12.30 p.m. rather than at 2 o'clock might turn out to be rather misplaced. I hope the government retains an open mind about that matter, but I accept that it has taken that decision.

I have long held the view that this parliament should sit more frequently. I think many of the problems that have arisen and many of the differences that we have about such things as the rostering of ministers would be solved if we sat more frequently. I am not arguing that we should sit as frequently as the House of Commons, because it deals with a whole range of domestic and international political matters in Britain, whereas this country is a federation and we do not deal with matters that are within the purview of state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We probably do.

—My friend the right honourable member for New England reminds me that we probably do. I am grateful for his correction. If we sat somewhere closer to 100 days a year, we might not have an argument about rostering and we probably would have a better system.

PARA.TAB: I think the government's changes to the sessional sitting times are quite praiseworthy. It is sensible to start at the beginning of February rather than halfway through February. I have always thought that the Christmas recess was a bit too long. If we understood that, on occasion, while parliament was sitting it would be permissible and acceptable for people to be overseas more extensively than they are now, we might lose our reluctance to have the parliament sit for a longer period. I have no problem with starting in February. I think we could even improve the sessional sitting times a bit more.

The other items that are under consideration relate to the establishment of a second chamber. Our attitude is basically to give it a go. It might work; it might not. We have some reservations about the detail. My colleague the right honourable member for New England will canvass some of those in the debate. I understand that the main committee will be in the House of Representatives committee room No. 2, which disturbs me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely ridiculous.

—That is what I have been advised by the Deputy Opposition Whip. I have never known him to be wrong on matters as important as this; I have always found him to be absolutely reliable. Whilst we are prepared to give the idea of a second chamber a go and we will not adopt a difficult attitude, we wonder whether it really ought to be in committee room 2R2. I think it would demean the debating of legislation. Judging by the rising level of fury behind me, I think some of my colleagues will further develop this issue during the debate.

PARA.TAB: About nine months ago the soon-to-be retired honourable member for Bonython came to see me and said, `Can't we reach some agreement on some bipartisan changes to the procedures?'. I said, `Yes'. We talked about the fact that we do not have supplementary questions. He talked about a roster that would have allowed us to require the attendance of a minister specifically for questioning on a day on which he or she was not rostered. We did not get that; we got a full-blooded roster system. We talked about having a genuine guarantee of an extended question time. The government's guarantee is really not worth the paper it is printed on.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a guarantee.

—It is not a guarantee. The government is saying, `We'll guarantee you 14', but there is nothing in these changes about it. When I asked the Leader of the House about that, he said, `It's too hard'. The rest of it is not too hard. It is not too hard to have a second chamber but it is too hard to give us a guarantee of a miserable 14 questions, which is two fewer than the average of the Fraser years and two fewer than what Hawke was giving us at the beginning of his period of government.

PARA.TAB: When we consider that we now have 148 members in the House and we had only 75 in the late 1940s, we see how question time has continued to decline in significance. I am very disappointed about that. At no stage has the government taken our views into account. I accept that the honourable member for Bonython may have wanted to do so, but he suffered the same fate as Mr Speaker—a kick up the backside from the Prime Minister, who has found that some of his ideas do not suit his political convenience.

So in a sense, I finish where I started. It all gets back ultimately to those who control this place—the government of the day. The person who controls the government, certainly this government, is the Prime Minister, because he keeps telling us how he has got everybody in his pocket and how he runs everything to suit his own convenience. If we really want to improve the repute of this parliament in the community, I think there has to be a cultural change, particularly on his part. If it were to occur, I can, on behalf of the opposition, assure honourable members that it would be very warmly reciprocated.

Some of the more detailed concerns that my colleagues have about the standing orders will be developed during the debate. I just want to make it clear that whilst we are prepared to give the committee a go, we remain very profoundly opposed to the changes relating to question time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate—
—Shame!

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—The honourable member for Moreton does not need the assistance of the honourable member for Moncrieff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly do not. I will be in dire straits if I ever have to call on the support of the honourable member for Moncrieff, as wonderful a person as she is.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to participate in this debate and follow the very reasonable comments made by the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Howard) in his contribution to the debate. I acknowledge some of the points he made in his contribution. I would like to talk about a few things that I think are important in this discussion.

Generally, I would like to make the comment that all of the changes we are putting in are basically on trial. Although we are making changes to the standing orders in some places and introducing sessional orders in other places, I do not think by any stretch of the imagination that, if the things we are changing in the standing orders are totally unworkable or fail to achieve what they set out to achieve, they are locked in concrete and will not be able to be changed.

The government recognises that these new measures are quite a radical change to the format of this place. They seek to address some of the more fundamental questions that have been raised not just by opposition members most vociferously, but also by government members about the procedures in this place and the opportunities for honourable members, particularly backbenchers, to participate fully in the processes and the workings of this parliament.

One should enter this debate with the clear knowledge that, although the government has accepted some of the major points in the very excellent report of the procedure committee chaired by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), all of the changes that are being put into place will be very much on trial. If things do not work—particularly the change regarding the main committee, which is quite a radical change—we will need to look at them. I believe we should give all the changes a go. They are very much a positive change for the future.

With that in mind, I would like to comment on the changes to question time. The majority report of the procedure committee recommended that question time be at 3.30 p.m. At the time this report was tabled, a number of opposition members raised some concerns because, with question time being at 3.30 p.m. and the MPI following that, it was going to impact on the capacity to have question time and the MPI debate featured on the main news that night. The government has responded to that concern and has amended that recommendation and put question time in its proposed program at 3 o'clock, which I think takes account of the concerns expressed by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it, Garrie.
—Throughout the contribution of the Manager of Opposition Business in this debate no-one from the government side interjected. I believe that it is reasonable that I receive the same treatment.
—Well, I am just going to be unreasonable.

—The point that the honourable member for Moreton made was relevant. There is a whole list of speakers for this debate. If the honourable member for Moore wants to make a contribution, he should make it during his speaking time. I will be much stricter on interjections from now on.

—The other question that was raised by the Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Bennelong, referred to the setting of a minimum number of questions. The government has said that it will seek to introduce, not in the standing orders, a minimum number of 14 questions. The opposition is saying, `But it is not in the standing orders. There is no guarantee in the standing orders that we get a minimum number of questions'. We need to have a look at the other side of the coin.

PARA.TAB: I sat here in question time on Tuesday, I think, and measured the amount of time that the opposition actually wasted in question time by taking frivolous points of order and by point scoring. There were some 7 1/2 minutes wasted during question time by the taking of points of order, which is a deliberate tactic to disrupt ministers and break up the flow of question time. If opposition members want to make sure they get their minimum number of questions in question time, then they need also to look at themselves and at the amount of time they waste.

I agree that in the last session of parliament answers to questions went on for too long. We were not getting sufficient questions asked and answers given in question time because some ministers spoke for too long. The current Speaker has tried to ensure that answers are not too lengthy, and there has been a considerable improvement in the length of ministers' answers. If we could now get a reduction in the frivolous points of order and point scoring from the opposition during question time, we may well be able to achieve the minimum of 14, 16 or even—heaven forbid—18 questions in question time. The continual interjecting, point scoring and points of order in question time all waste time.

Opposition members cannot have it both ways. If they want to have questions asked and answers given in question time, then they should not waste so much of question time with their antics. We, as government members, need to make sure that ministers are not taking too long with their answers and opposition members also need to look at their performance in question time. Then maybe we will achieve that magic figure that everyone seems to be hanging out for of 16 questions per question time.

As a backbencher, I am particularly interested in the improved opportunities that I believe will exist in this process for backbenchers to contribute more in this place. I take my role as a member of parliament very seriously indeed. I believe I have a responsibility in this place not just to be a member of the government, not just to represent the Labor Party, but to effectively represent my constituents. I can only do that by getting opportunities to participate in debates on legislation, private members business and on reports that are tabled by committees of this place, government authorities, departments or semi-government authorities—which are very important matters that we spend so little time on in this place.

One of the very important changes that are being introduced relates to the creation of a second chamber. That will give backbenchers a much greater opportunity to participate in debates and to put forward the concerns of their constituents. The new hours that will apply in this chamber mean a reduced amount of time to discuss committee reports. However, new standing order 270, which refers to the main committee, says:

SPEECH.PARA: (b)orders of the day for the resumption of debate on motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports may be referred for debate.

I will be urging the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) to ensure that sufficient time is given each day in the program of the main committee for debates on committee reports, delegation reports and departmental annual reports, et cetera. I believe an important part of the work of this parliament is to scrutinise the work of government departments and semi-government authorities and to consider in detail the recommendations of parliamentary committees. I look forward to the increased opportunity that backbenchers will have, through the operations of the second chamber—the main committee—to participate in that.

PARA.TAB: The second and most crucial thing that I hope will come out of the formation of the main committee is that it will lead to the virtual end of the guillotine process. The operation of a second chamber will enable us to free up government business in this chamber for those important issues and pieces of legislation about which there is some difference of opinion or controversy and about which many people will wish to express their points of view for or against.

I have seen non-controversial legislation appear on the Notice Paper. Thankfully, I have not had to talk on legislation such as the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Deer Velvet Levy Bill. I do not think legislation like that raises a lot of heat or angst in this chamber. It would be valuable to have those debates shifted to the second chamber so that legislation dealing with issues of major national importance, such as native title rights, social security, pensions or things affecting our veterans, can be debated without time pressures. When we have to get many bills passed in a short time and the guillotine is imposed, we get only an hour or two hours to debate major bills as we also have to debate all the other minor bills. Freeing this chamber of the minor bills will allow those honourable members who have something important to contribute to those debates—even if they are not controversial—to get the time to do so in the second chamber. Much more time will then be available in this chamber to allow us to talk about the really significant matters of national importance.

I am very hopeful that the operation of the second chamber or main committee will lead to our not having a crush of bills at the end of session nor the need for the guillotine to be imposed, with the frustration that that provides for not only the opposition but also government backbenchers, who get frustrated at the fact that they have very limited scope to talk about issues that may be of great importance to them or their electorates. I believe that that is a major and significant achievement that will flow from the formation of the main committee, or second chamber. It is something that we should all be pleased about.

Another important matter that we have been discussing in relation to the main committee is the election of a second Deputy Speaker. That recommendation, contained in the report entitled About time, has been adopted by the government. It reinforces the principle that the positions of the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker are supposed to be independent. Having two deputy speakers, one from the government side and one from the opposition side, reinforces that independence. That is also something to be commended.

Another matter that I would like to talk about briefly is question time. There has been some disagreement and argument about the rostering of ministers. I am absolutely amazed at the opposition's allegation that somehow the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is seeking to run away from question time and avoid scrutiny by rostering himself on for only two days a week. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Prime Minister is certainly not seeking to avoid being scrutinised by the opposition.

By any objective measure, and as the Manager of Opposition Business said, the Prime Minister totally dominates question time. By this process, we are not seeking to avoid scrutiny but to improve the scrutiny of the government in question time. The rostering process, whereby only half the ministers will be available each day, will expand the consideration of the performance of many other ministers and their portfolios.

I do not have all the figures here—I think they are in the report—concerning the number of times the Prime Minister, the Treasurer or the Minister for Finance have been asked questions. They have totally dominated question time. Some ministers in this place have probably not even been asked a question, although most of them seek to get at least one from someone on the government side. A number of ministers in this chamber have never been asked a question by the opposition.

A major improvement that will flow from the question time changes is that the opposition will start to broaden its perspective as far as analysing the performance of all ministers in this place is concerned. I hope that it will lead to a greater scrutiny of the government and provide a greater opportunity for backbenchers on both sides to participate in a more worthwhile manner in question time.

I believe that the government's amendments to the standing orders and its proposed sessional orders are a worthwhile change. They will massively improve the flow of business and the efficiency of this chamber. I recognise that there may be some concerns about some elements of these changes, but I believe the opposition should give them a chance and that we should be happy to proceed with them. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, there is little doubt that so much of how this place functions depends on the person who is in the position that you now occupy. As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said, it is true that, above all, two people determine the nature and character of the parliament: the Speaker, or the person who sits in the chair; and the Prime Minister. More than anything else, the effectiveness and, I guess, ability of people to be able to express a point of view and engage in rational debate depends upon their behaviour and the way in which they interpret the standing orders.

PARA.TAB: The report of a committee into parliamentary procedure, chaired by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), was laid before this place. Unless the government is prepared to deal with the feeling that there is a need for reform, these reforms and any others will falter. I commend the honourable member for Bonython and the other members of that committee for the work that they put into the consideration of how we can make this parliament function better. In particular, I thank the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), who I think made a notable contribution in the reservations they expressed in the minority report.

As I have commented, a number of reports analysing the way in which the parliament operates have been produced. This is not the first report. None of the procedures will work—not even the changes to the existing standing orders as recommended in the About time report—unless the person who occupies the chair and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) are prepared to comply with them. I want to deal in general with a number of aspects of the whole debate. I will do so briefly before I go into the details.

My second point is that it is very important that people within this place understand that, to enable parliament to function, prime significance has to be given to what goes on in the parliament and not to the other ancillary activities in which we are all engaged. A very good example is this debate at the moment. A number of honourable members are interested in the subject. However, committee meetings are going on. We have all sorts of other commitments: some are with constituents; some are with policy formulation; and some are spent in various ways around this place.

To my mind, in order to make parliament function, we have to elevate the importance of this chamber. There are a couple of aspects to that. It is not just about the attendance of members; it is very much about the degree to which ministers treat debate in this place. I am appalled that virtually no minister of this present government attends during the committee and second reading stages of bills, and certainly no minister sums up debate. Of course ministers cannot be here all the time, but the prime duty of a minister in charge of legislation is not to get a parliamentary secretary or somebody else to attend at those times; it is to be here to listen to the views of members of both sides, to take note of them and to respond. I do not believe that that is being done adequately. There is no proposed change to the standing orders in that respect, and I regret that.

There are also problems in terms of the overall way in which this place functions. I have said before, and I repeat, that I would like the House to be more of a debating chamber. I would like to see this bar table narrowed. I would like to see the two sides of the House brought closer together. For all that the geography, or whatever we call it, of the House of Commons is different from ours—
Mr Punch interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I like being able to eyeball the honourable member for Barton. I think it would be great for us to speak so that we feel like we are actually having a reasonable discussion. I do not think we do that here. Having sat for a while up there with the gods, I can tell the House that a person feels remote from everything that happens in the chamber.
—Like the bleachers of the old Sydney stadium.
—The honourable member for Bennelong is so right—like the bleachers of the Sydney stadium.

PARA.TAB: Mr Leo McLeay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be prepared to take the honourable member on any day, even on his bicycle. It is important for us to think about the geography and how we can make the place function better. I commend this idea to the House: I have wondered whether it might be better if we spoke not from a dispatch box here, but from the other end of the table.
—From the heart.
—The honourable member talks about speaking from the heart. Some honourable members might find difficulty locating just what part of his anatomy he speaks from.

PARA.TAB: Mr Leo McLeay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they found mine, which was quite an achievement. I think this is an important point. If we spoke from the middle of the table, at least we would be speaking almost in a theatre of the round. I know that where we speak from at the moment is traditional, but there is a difficulty. The point I am making is that this ought to be a debating chamber. I do not think it is succeeding in being one. Regrettably, I do not think these changes will achieve it.

PARA.TAB: But enough of the philosophy. There is too little time left and I have a lot of things that I want to say about the details. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) spoke about these changes being only temporary. If that were so, I do not believe that there would be changes now being introduced to standing orders. Over the years that I was Leader of the House, if we changed anything—as we did frequently—we tried to introduce it by way of a sessional order, which allows for consideration, adaptation and then adoption into standing orders on the next occasion that the parliament meets. I would far prefer that to be so. I disagree with the proposed amendments to the standing orders. I believe they should all be sessional orders.

Secondly, I was horrified to hear from the honourable member for Moore the idea that these main committee meetings are not to take place in the No. 1 committee room of this parliament. As far as I am concerned, that means the whole of this proposed change is being treated in a totally light-hearted fashion. I do not believe it is appropriate. I believe they should be in the main committee room of this building. From my point of view, I will be doing everything to ensure that that is so. If 2R2 is to be the forum, then that is totally inappropriate.

I want to address the detail of these changes in several ways. I turn first to the matter of questions without notice. The honourable member for Bennelong and I spent a little time dealing with that matter the other day. It is not the matter of the Prime Minister being asked 18 per cent, or whatever it is, of questions; it is very much a question of the availability of the government to answer all matters within its responsibility, the whole field of its responsibility, on any day when this House sits. We know that individual ministers have a responsibility only to answer questions within their particular bailiwick. If the Prime Minister or the Treasurer (Mr Willis) are not here, it will be extraordinarily difficult. Let us take, for example, a day when the balance of payments figures go through the roof and the Treasurer is not in the House. We cannot pursue the matter. I think there are any number of reasons why every minister should be available. That has been the tradition here.

I do not know why every one of the Australian traditions have to be thrown on their ear. In this chamber we want to see the preservation of those elements which are good for democracy. As far as I am concerned, the accountability of government and the exercise of responsibility by ministers are fundamental. These changes to question time do not achieve either of those dictums. For that reason I am totally opposed to them and I regret the fact that the sessional order is being put forward in that form. I think it is a sessional order with respect to questions without notice but I might be wrong; it might be a standing order, too.

There are other detailed matters that I want to address. With respect to the quorum of the main committee, I believe that three is insufficient. If we are going to make the committee work, we need more than three members. I thoroughly approve of it being required to be at least some from either side of the chamber, but I do not think three is sufficient. It is no good having two or three people in the chamber and believing that we will have a sensible debate. I think the numbers should be somewhat higher than that. For my money, I would like to see it somewhere not less than 20, but perhaps that is too many.

In the detail there are a number of other matters that I wanted to pursue. The first concerns change 17, new standing order 304A. I do not believe that it is acceptable to have this sin-bin concept introduced and the member being suspended without a vote of the members of this chamber. As far as I am concerned, I am prepared to go along with the idea of having a one-hour suspension. But it is totally inappropriate for a person, who demonstrably is still a member of the governing party of the place, to be in a position to suspend members for one hour, or any other period, without a vote of this chamber. This is not a place where arbitrary judgment can be exercised, other than in extremis. I understand that there are provisions for dealing with gross disorder. But that is different. We are not talking about 304, 304A or 306. I am talking about circumstances where members are to be temporarily suspended. It is not satisfactory that that be exercised without a division or without an opportunity for this parliament to decide that that person should be so suspended.

There is then the question of the sitting hours. I was interested in the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong. I am one of the very few members of this place who has had a home in Canberra. As many members would know, my first wife had a brain tumour and at that stage we just had to come from where I live to Canberra. But people do not understand the sort of life that members live. Like many of my colleagues, I travel more than 1,000 kilometres every weekend. I frequently travel home from functions at 2.00 a.m., get home at about half past three or four and start work the next morning at about six. To say that it is ridiculous for us to work until 10.30 at night when we are here is just balderdash.

What these hours will do is to ensure that the committees, to which so much is being referred, will have to meet while the House is sitting or sit at night. This idea of us all going home is just not what is going to happen. I do not agree that rising on a Monday and Tuesday night under these standing orders is going to achieve anything. I like the idea of rising early on Thursday night at 6.00 p.m., but, let us face it, many members will not be able to get home. I am one of them and I do not live that far from Canberra. It will not be possible for many members to return to their own homes that night. People need to understand that very few members live in Canberra. If we want to go home, then we want to go home to our wives and to our families but we do not do that in Canberra. I do not see how all these high-minded ideas would work.

On the other hand, I am entirely in favour of an absolute law which says that this House should not rise later than 11.00 p.m. That is not being inserted in here. I would far prefer that there be an arbitrary requirement that there be no suspension of standing orders which would require this chamber to sit at any hour after 11.00 p.m. Let us not be beguiled into thinking that, because we have some new sitting roster, we are not going to get a rush of legislation and that, at the end of the session, we are not going to have reasons to sit longer. I would far prefer, at least on Monday and Tuesday nights, that we sit until 11.00 p.m. and that on every night that this House sits there be an arbitrary requirement that we do not sit after 11.00 p.m.

I am also concerned about some detail of standing order 101 and the routine of business. I believe that on a Monday there should be provision for a discussion of a matter of public importance. I do not support having question time at 3.00 p.m. I think that is too late. I like the idea of question time at 2 o'clock, although I accept that there are difficulties for some. So 2.30 p.m. would have been a compromise. I am also a bit apprehensive that 12.30 p.m. is too early to commence on Monday and Tuesday, given that we have shadow cabinet and party meetings.
