I do not think we will be able to get the business done. The sitting hours worry me; I do not think they are as they should be.

A couple of matters have arisen today. One is the question of evidence from committees of this place and the other is the question of privilege. There is no reference to it here in the changes. However, I was interested in the ruling given by the Deputy Speaker with respect to the matter of public importance discussed today. We do need to look at a number of matters which are not now being considered. If there is going to be change and reform, the sort of ruling given by the Deputy Speaker is a matter that could well have been introduced by way of a sessional order; it was not.

Matters relating to sitting within this chamber also concern me. I have spoken about this on other occasions. I notice from new sessional order 315 that strangers will not be allowed into any part of the chamber or any part of the room where the main committee is meeting. That means that if the committee is meeting in 2R2 nobody will be allowed in, which is rubbish. It is essential, therefore, that we at least sit in the main committee room where there is an opportunity for people outside to come in. We do not want to sit in privacy.

As far as I am concerned, television—which I am all in favour of, although I question the degree to which it intrudes into our lives and the way in which it has changed the character of the place—is not the same as allowing the public to sit in. There has to be room for the public to sit in. As I have said on a number of occasions, I would like to see a special visitors gallery at the back of this chamber, as there is in the Senate.

My final point relates to the limitation of debate in urgency motions. Since amendments circulated by the government are allowed to be included in the Hansard, amendments circulated with two hours notice by the opposition should also be included.

There is an advantage in amending our sessional orders but I regret that it is being done by way of changes to the standing orders. I am very apprehensive about the consequences of the change to questions without notice, but I am quite prepared to give the idea of a main committee a go, subject to the remarks I have made. As I said, I trust the government will rethink the question of where it meets. Any venue other than the main committee room will be regarded as unsatisfactory. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on proposals which will bring about the most substantial reform in parliamentary procedure for many years. The proposals include many of the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure in its report About time: bills, questions and working hours. The committee was chaired by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett). It is a pleasant irony that the last day of the existing procedures in this House should be the last day of sitting for him, as he resigns tomorrow for an important assignment overseas—one of the worst kept secrets in modern times.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Bonython made a tremendous contribution in his decade as a minister, and he leaves many achievements behind him—the establishment of Medicare; the introduction of what are probably the world's most effective measures against AIDS; in the area of trade, work that went towards the reform of GATT and pursuit of the interests of the Cairns Group; and significant social security measures. He gave us more than 16 years of his life. We shall miss him, his intellectual penetration and incisive wit. But his last achievement, his work on the reform of parliamentary procedures, will be of permanent benefit to this place and to the cause of parliamentary democracy.

Following the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Tuesday, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) moved almost 27 pages of amendments to standing orders to bring the recommended changes into effect. They are actually more radical than those proposed in the report. Essentially, there are three major reforms. The first relates to changes in sitting hours. The House is to sit four days per week on a pattern of two weeks on and two weeks off, rising at 8.00 p.m. on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and at 6.00 p.m. on Thursdays, enabling most MPs to be home that night. Meal breaks are to be eliminated. As I said, the sitting pattern will be two weeks on and two weeks off. The total sitting time is slightly more than at present.

The second reform is the creation of a main committee or second chamber, which will increase the amount of time available for debating legislation and which will, I hope, reduce government application of the gag or guillotine. The third reform relates to question time, making it less gladiatorial and giving greater opportunity for genuinely seeking or providing information.

I welcome the changes in sitting hours. My only concern is that, if MPs simply disappear at 8.00 p.m. or 7.30 p.m., when the adjournment debate begins, it may make the committee system unworkable, as many committee meetings now take place at night. I hope that will not be the case.

The second chamber reform is the most important, but has been barely commented on in public debate. It creates a parallel rather than a linear or sequential model for debate. Traditionally, the time given to a particular bill is determined by several factors: its political importance both to government and opposition; the ticking of the clock; and a spatial factor—the requirement that our legislative process be carried out in a particular place, this chamber, and nowhere else.

When Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister in 1978-79, there was an experiment in having debates elsewhere for the committee stage of bills. This was abandoned because the then government felt that the system unduly benefited the opposition and because ministers felt very exposed. Nevertheless, this system has worked very well in the House of Commons. For example, if there is a bill reforming the law of bankruptcy, those MPs with expert interest in the subject should be able to devote time to a long and detailed debate without feeling that they are slowing up the process of legislation of broader significance, such as the budget.

The government proposes that the second chamber have no quorum provision, except for the requirement that there be a presiding officer, a member from the opposition and a member from the government. Typically, the second chamber will debate non-controversial bills and there will be no divisions. I agree with the honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) that visitors to the main committee must be permitted.

We need to promote attitudinal change and changes in our political culture, and that means radically improving the quality of debate, which tends to be soporific, if not catatonic. Typically, when question time ends, the chamber is deserted. Members do not stay around for debates. Typically, speakers arrive in the chamber only a minute or two before the time the previous member's speech is due to end. Also typically, it is rare for a government MP to comment on, or analyse, the remarks of an opposition MP or vice versa. Our debates are anything but that. I can recall very few memorable debates in this place. The Native Title Bill was one; the debate on the Gulf War was another.

We should dispense with whips' lists. We should give priority to ministers and shadow ministers to set the parameters of the debate, but then the call should be given to MPs who are in the House following the debate and who jump as soon as the last MP sits down. If they do not jump, they do not get the call. If we could change the culture to make debates interesting, oppositions might not need to call quorums.

It is surprising that the opposition, in its criticism of the government's proposals, has concentrated on question time to the virtual exclusion of the others—especially the fact that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) will answer questions on only two of the four sitting days, Monday and Thursday, with other ministers to be rostered for particular days. That is in line with House of Commons practice, except that the British Prime Minister appears only once each week for 30 minutes.

Under our proposed changes, the opposition could, if it wished, ask every one of its questions of the Prime Minister each Monday and Thursday. I find any suggestion that the Prime Minister will be absent from two question times because he fears the withering onslaught of the opposition questions grotesque. If anyone has anything to fear in question time, when the Prime Minister is in full flight, it is the opposition itself, which rarely shows grace under pressure.

However, there are good reasons for changing the nature of question time. It will get away from the idea of a gladiatorial contest day after day, with blood on the axminster, and to make it a genuine request for, and provision of, information. This may sound naive, but we have to work on both sides to raise the public reputation of the House, especially at question time, which is the only time each day when the House itself, the press gallery and the public galleries are packed. This means fewer dorothy dixers, as the Prime Minister said, and no more questions or answers which are personally abusive.

I welcome the changes to question time because they will involve a range of the culture if they are going to work. The range of questions asked is far too narrow at present. Ministers and shadow ministers should be put on their mettle. About half of the members of the crowded opposition front bench rarely have an opportunity to ask a question, and opposition questions tend to be concentrated on a handful of ministers, and they are excessively concentrated on a particular minister if he or she is singled out.

To follow on from the comments made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), I would be deeply concerned if I thought the changes would increase the power of the executive over the legislature. I do not believe that the changes to question time are intended to do that—I hope not, anyway. I suspect that it will not change the balance much, but if it does, the opportunity will be the opposition's.

I regret that the government did not accept the recommendations of the Blewett committee on supplementary questions—that is, the right of a questioner to ask one more question if the answer to the original question is thought inadequate. It works well in the House of Commons. Of course, it must not be abused. But the House of Commons forms an astute judgment on that. If ministers cannot handle supplementaries, or alternatively, if members are abusing the system because the question has been adequately answered and they just want to double up, it reflects against the member who attempts to ask the supplementary. So I think the process is self-correcting. I hope that the new system will change the culture of question time: it will only work if it does. The change is long overdue and will improve the professionalism of the House of Representatives.

The Prime Minister said that there will continue to be room for theatre, but that the time has come for the emphasis to be reweighted in favour of substance. I agree. The theatrical aspect is important, but we could do with less theatre of the absurd or, in some cases, Grand Guignol. I have often complained that this parliament is really more like a national repertory theatre than a legislature, with the press gallery essentially drama critics looking each day for trials of strength, muggings and pratfalls. The nation deserves better than this.

I believe that with the range of proposals we have put up we have an opportunity to re-examine the way in which we operate this parliament. It is the understanding of the government that the changes are not necessarily thought to be immutable and that we have to give them a try over the next session or two to see how they work. If it is thought that there should be areas of improvement, my understanding is that the Leader of the House would be sympathetic to making further amendments.

So the proposals are not set in concrete. I believe that the proposals deserve our full support. We have the potential to make a much more effective and appropriate parliament for Australia in the 21st century, and as we face up to the challenges of the end of the first century of Federation. I congratulate the government on taking up the recommendations and I commend the proposals to the House.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following amendments to the standing orders be adopted for the remainder of the session with effect from 21 February 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Standing order 150 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: The reply to a question on notice shall be given by delivering it to the Clerk. A copy of the reply shall be supplied to the Member who has asked the question, and the question and reply shall be printed in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: If after the expiration of 90 days of a question first appearing on the Notice Paper a reply has not been delivered to the Clerk, the Member who asked the question may rise in his or her place at the conclusion of the question period and request the Speaker to write to the Minister concerned, seeking reasons for the delay in answering.
(2)New standing order 151A be inserted:

151A. Questions without notice shall be asked only of those Ministers who are rostered to attend the question period on that day. The roster shall be prepared by the Leader of the House in consultation with the Manager of Opposition Business, and shall be presented to the House.
(3)Standing order 152 be amended to read:

PARA.TAB: At the conclusion of the question period, questions without notice may be put to the Speaker relating to any matter of administration for which he or she is responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members would be aware, we are effectively debating these three motions across-the-board throughout the evening. As you, Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, are well aware, members will not be called to order when they decide that they will speak on times of sittings and all that sort of stuff while we have question time propositions before us. In my opening remarks in an earlier speech today, I did not speak to the issue of question time knowing that I was going to move this motion. There are one or two things I need to place on the record in order that we can be held to them in the course of consideration of these matters over the next few months and when they come up for reconsideration by the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I have been very interested to watch bits and pieces of the debate so far. A couple of very good ideas have come up from both sides of the House which I think at the end of this debate we are going to have to sit down and think through. I think one of the good things that we have got into over the last few years is a mode of changing standing orders, not necessarily how everybody wants them changed, but at least we have been doing it. They have been sacrosanct for so long. To get into a mode of changing them we might as well start picking up good suggestions when we see them, be they from the procedure committee or anywhere else.

This motion does a couple of things, and it has been very little noted that this is the case. Firstly, it imposes a level of discipline on the answering of questions on notice that hitherto has not existed in standing orders. Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, you are a noted placer of questions on notice, some of which, we suspect, are drafted by people who have been even more prominent Australians than you. You will no doubt welcome this particular change, which means that ministers will have to get a leg on. A member will be able to rise after 90 days and ask the Speaker why a minister has not answered a question on notice and the minister will be obliged to write a reason to the Speaker as to why that has happened.

The second element of the motion concerns the rostering of ministers. The change is quite simple; everybody knows what that procedure means. Effectively, half the cabinet will appear each day. What is not in standing orders is what is, nevertheless, the undertaking of the government, and that is that there shall be 14 questions each day in the 45-minute period that is set for question time. If they are not answered in the 45-minute period which is set for question time, then question time will proceed until they are answered.

The point has been made that prior to this government we got through many more questions in question time. The average now is around 10 questions in that 45-minute period. We will no doubt get the argument that in Malcolm Fraser's time it averaged about 15. The difference was very much the way in which questions were asked as well as the way in which questions were answered. It was a source of some joy to me when I was a junior member of this place, and in opposition, having just been elected in 1980, that on one day of the week it was the view of our party whips and leaders that all of us backbenchers would have a go in question time, unfettered by the demands of the frontbench. We were all obliged to go away, invent our questions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen questions were asked each day, each week.

—Quite a lot of questions were asked on those particular days; I acknowledge that it was 15 questions a day. It was also a different opposition. We gave our backbenchers a go. When we gave the backbenchers a go we found that, of course, the ministers do not answer the backbenchers' questions at great length. Often the ministers are only vaguely aware of the materials that the backbenchers bring before them because the backbenchers tend to have a whole variety of interests that do not actually appear on the front pages of the newspapers every day. In those circumstances ministers have a working knowledge but not a pejorative knowledge of the materials to hand. So the idea that one would serve up five or 10 minutes on the subjects is not there.

PARA.TAB: On one of the other two days, at least, only half the questions were asked by the frontbench. This could be interrupted when there was a bit of a thing running but by and large that was the case. We had many more questions, much shorter answers, fewer dorothy dixers from the government side of the House and fewer prepared questions by the coordinating committee from the opposition side of the House. Members other than the Leader of the Opposition had a go and this parliament actually exercised some scrutiny. That has disappeared. The intention is that this should bring it back. Whether it does or not will be open to a great deal of questioning, and we will find out over the next few months. The opposition is unhappy with it. That is disappointing but it is not necessarily a bad thing.

The allegation is made that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) seeks to evade scrutiny. Those outside this chamber and those on this side of the chamber respond to that accusation with a huge horse laugh. It is well known that the Prime Minister relishes the opportunity of question time. This is an exercise of some self-sacrifice on his part, but the chamber will be the better place for it. It is in the spirit of trying to make question time better, in the same way as it was in the spirit of trying to make this House a more effective place, that we supported in the first instance the motions we have just passed—the suggestions of the Blewett committee. In this instance, we have not gone along with them but we have made some changes, some of them partially influenced by the directions in which the Blewett committee suggested we should go. We will see whether these changes work. It is our intention that they operate only until the middle of the year and we will make any necessary adjustments after that point. But I hope they will work. I hope they will make question time better. I think the public would like that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a saying that you can be too clever by half, and I think the debate that has taken place here and in the papers during the last few days is a good illustration of the government being too clever by half. I was deputy chairman of the Standing Committee on Procedure, which brought down the report About time, from which some of the changes we are talking about today were derived.

PARA.TAB: Before the report was released there was a lot of anonymous backgrounding of the press by government members. That was a breach of the privilege of parliament. It can never be proven, but we always know who these people are; their fingerprints are all over the newspaper reports. The changes were reported as reforms. The reports said, `Here is a great reform of parliament which is going to loosen it up', and they got away with it. Then the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) got too clever by half. He decided that he was going to put forward to this parliament a proposal whereby he would come to question time only once a week.

I reiterate the committee's original suggestion: the House was to sit eight days each fortnight instead of seven. We agreed that on the Monday of each of those sitting weeks we would have a limited roster with the opposition having a right of veto over that roster. The only person whose absence could not be vetoed on those two days per eight was the Prime Minister. So the Prime Minister could be excused on two days per eight days. But he had no excuse on six days out of eight and, if the opposition so required, no other minister could be excused on any of the eight days.

The Prime Minister got too clever by half. He took a proposal to cabinet that he should come only once a week; the very different rostering system being put forward here now has only the slightest, most accidental resemblance—

TALK.START.PARA: —Fleeting.

—`Fleeting'—as the honourable member for Moore says—resemblance to what the committee put forward. As it happens, he now has to be here twice a week. The reason he has to be here twice a week instead of once a week is that his own backbench revolted.

PARA.TAB: I referred to being too clever by half. The press swallowed all this last December. They used the term `reform', which I will not use. It is incorrect language; it insinuates a value judgment of changes. They are not reforms; a reform is something that is better. They are changes in which some wee little details are better. If we do not have an answer from the minister to a question on notice after 90 days we can get up and say, `Mr Speaker, the minister has not answered my question'. It is not clear whether stamping your foot at the same time, raising your voice or really whingeing will get you thrown in the sin-bin under this brand new, untried standing order but there is a chance that it will. Come on! What sort of a reform is that? The committee knew it was not much of a reform; it said it was a start.

I was a member of the committee, and I put on the record that the only government member of the committee with the gall to speak about this dog's breakfast of a version of what the committee recommended was the chairman, who does not have to be here after today to answer for a single word he has said. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) is not speaking, nor is the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) or the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). They are not on the speakers list, which is not a great omission, but they were all here last December yabbering away about what a wonderful report this was. They were very keen then to talk to the press, on and off the record, but they are not too keen today to get on the record and talk about the actual changes being discussed now.

I have nothing against the new honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick); he is a pleasant chap. I have told him that, if he does as well as his Liberal predecessor, he will be doing very well indeed. But he has been here less than 12 months and he is going to get up and tell us how good these changes are; how much better it is going to be than it has been for the last 20 years. I am a bit disappointed with the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). He is supposed to have a photographic memory. He read to us a speech which made references to things apparently in the report that were not in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not debating the report.
—But you did say that these references came substantially from the report About time.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—If we are talking about procedure, we will address our remarks through the chair and will not debate across the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated, the honourable member for Lalor did say, as every government utterance has indicated, that these references came substantially from the report. That is balderdash! Let me take this a little further because government members really need to be a bit more educated. They have clearly stopped reading the report, looking at it and thinking about it; they are reading only their own government's propaganda.

PARA.TAB: I refer now to the main committee. A little more will be said about that. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and I put in a dissenting report about the main committee because we had a very uncomfortable feeling about it. We put down on paper what we thought was wrong with it. But we felt that the shuffling off of a whole lot of legislation to some other room was a further part of the general denigration of this parliament which we see day in and day out in a variety of ways, including non-attendance of ministers through debates and the way things are conducted at question time. Page 8 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Main Committee would meet in the main committee room and would meet during sittings of the House.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not breaching privilege at all when I say that the reason it was called `the main committee' was that the committee's entire discussion was in terms of the committee meeting in the main committee room. The report states that that is where the committee would meet.

PARA.TAB: I know the committee cannot govern this, but the suggestion came from government members and it was promoted by government members. I see a couple of members of the committee have put their names on the speakers list. Whacko! They are right down at the end; it will be interesting to see whether they get time to speak. The suggestion was always promoted in those terms. I know that government members could not guarantee it but it was their idea. They promoted it at length and came forward with all the details. Something as basic as whether committee meetings could be held in the main committee room was surely something they could have chatted to someone about. You would think that a former Speaker, the honourable member for Watson—a great advocate of the main committee—would have known that we could not always use the main committee room because the Senate also has access to it. It is not a House of Representatives room; it is not one that the Speaker can decide this chamber will have sittings in. I think the sneaking suspicion that the honourable member for Moore and I had that we were all being dudded—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hoodwinked.

—Yes, hoodwinked, as the honourable member says, was very well founded. Today we were told that the committee is now going to meet in 2R2. We are going to make second reading speeches around a committee table.
—No-one has told you that; you've made that up.
—Yes, we have been told that.
—Order! We will not have debates across the chamber.

—I am not going to have the honourable member for Watson wasting time, but I did not make it up. He is telling an untruth again. I am going to defend myself when I choose to. He would have known that we could not have gone into the main committee room but he only ever talked about the main committee room.
—Rubbish!
—Order! The honourable member for Watson should not provoke the honourable member for Moncrieff.

—The government got too clever by half and the newspapers have woken up—at least temporarily. I say this to the press: I come from a state where we had a royal commission on behalf of the state government into widespread corruption. There were a number of reasons for the royal commission, not least of which was that a scandal would blow up, the journalists would write their stories and the newspapers would print them. But the Premier would act as though nothing had happened, as though the scandal did not exist. At press conferences the Premier would talk about something else the whole time. But blow me down, within three days it did not exist. That happened year in and year out.

PARA.TAB: It was only when a particular journalist, Phil Dickie, put hours, days, weeks and months into doing his homework, and documented the scandal chapter and verse, and then Four Corners put it into everyone's living room that anything happened. There was nothing new in the scandals; they were known, but the press had allowed them to go away.

I say to the press: it has been great to see editorials in the press about question time. It has been wonderful to see P. P. McGuinness using words that we are sometimes not allowed to use in this chamber about the Prime Minister in question time and what it is really all about. I want to see what happens in three days time. If the press is fair dinkum, they will keep on reviewing what has actually happened here when these changes come in.

The government is being too clever by half. It assumes, `Well, if we can weather it this week, we have a week's recess coming up. The press gallery will go away, and this matter will go away. They will just come back and start reporting on our media conferences and so on. It will all be okay'. We are not going to let it go away, and we will see just how real the concerns are.

Mr Deputy Speaker, do you know what I suspect this rostering is about now that it has all come out? As I have sat here this last week and heard this unlikely word `reform' tripping off the Prime Minister's tongue, I thought about what the Prime Minister's version of the committee's recommendation on rostering would be like. I thought we would have some ministers getting up—all these ministers of whom nobody wants to ask a question. Apparently, ministers cannot even get their own backbenchers to ask dorothy dixers. The honourable member for Lalor would know a bit about that from when he was minister for science.

The penny dropped. We had a debate here once and the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) put on the record why we do not have ministerial statements anymore—because the Senate wants to debate them. So ministers in the Senate are the only ministers who make statements anymore. How dare that unrepresentative swill want to debate government statements! So now we get ministerial statements in question time instead. Under these new arrangements, we will have nothing but minor ministers—whose actions are not newsworthy and therefore do not get asked questions—making wall-to-wall ministerial statements. That is what question time will be like—ministerial statements from the juniors.

If the government is fair dinkum it will extend the activities of the main committee—it will make it function in a real way—to include debate on ministerial statements and reports. We have only talked about legislation in the main committee, but reports come in here that never get a word said about them. It is said that we need the extra time because in the non-controversial areas people need to say things that are relative to their electorates.

There are speeches relevant to members' electorates deriving from reports—just as relevant as anything that goes into legislation. I see that the honourable member for Lalor is nodding his head in agreement. The same goes for ministerial statements. These do not have to be items of controversy—not at all. But it is just as important for members to get those speeches on the record in parliament. We will see how fair dinkum the government is. It should use the main committee for debate of non-controversial ministerial statements and for debate on non-controversial reports—really let it be a forum for members.

In response to the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who said that these changes are not set in concrete, that they are on trial and can be changed: why has it taken so many years to change them? What is there in the standing orders versus the sessional orders? Standing orders do not come up every session; sessional orders do. Once they are in the standing orders they might as well be set in concrete because all the previous standing orders on this subject have taken 20 years to get through. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure has presented lots of reports on question time but nothing has ever happened. But the minister saw an opening and he was in in a flash. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: WET TROPICS OF QUEENSLAND WORLD HERITAGE AREA CONSERVATION BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill is to implement the terms of an agreement between the Premier of Queensland and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 16 November 1990, which provides for a regime of cooperative management of this sensitive and unique environment. The bill is intended to complement the Queensland Wet Tropics World Heritage Protection and Management Act 1993 which was passed by the Queensland government on 30 September 1993. These two pieces of legislation together will bring into effect permanent management arrangements to implement Australia's international obligations for the wet tropics of Queensland world heritage property under the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage—the world heritage convention.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth legislation will be an acknowledgment of the Commonwealth's ongoing commitment to protect, conserve, present and transmit to future generations the wet tropics of Queensland world heritage property, in accordance with Australia's obligations under the world heritage convention.

The government recognises the processes established under the very comprehensive Queensland legislation. Day-to-day management of the world heritage property will be carried out by the Queensland government in accordance with management plans proclaimed under Queensland's Wet Tropics World Heritage Protection and Management Act 1993. The Queensland legislation provides for extensive consultation with key interest groups including government departments, public authorities, land-holders, local authorities, Aboriginal people concerned with land in the region, interested groups and persons, and members of the public in the preparation of management plans.

The Queensland legislation provides for the submission of the final management plan to the Joint Commonwealth-State Ministerial Council, established under an agreement between the Prime Minister and the Premier of Queensland, for recommendation to and subsequent approval by the Governor of Queensland in council.

The bill empowers the minister to act on behalf of the Commonwealth to nominate two directors to the board of the Wet Tropics Management Authority for the purposes of 14(b) of the Queensland Act. The board will consist of six persons: one person appointed on the nomination of the ministerial council, two persons appointed on the nomination of the Commonwealth, two persons appointed on the nomination of the state and the executive director of the management authority.

The bill makes obligatory the tabling of the annual reports of the Wet Tropics Management Authority in both houses of this parliament and provides for the secondment of Commonwealth officers to the authority. In addition, arrangements have been made by ministerial agreement with Queensland, whereby the Commonwealth will have a very significant input into the selection of the executive director and members of the Wet Tropics Management Authority who will be appointed under the Queensland legislation.

The bill was passed by the upper house on 8 February 1994 and it incorporates a preamble and amendments which were proposed by the Australian Democrats and to which the government has given its full support. These amendments encapsulate the spirit of the Mabo legislation, passed after this bill was introduced in the Senate in December 1993, by ensuring that in future all Commonwealth governments will involve Aboriginal representatives formally in the management of the wet tropics world heritage area. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the House.
