DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with a great deal of pleasure that I introduce the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: This bill is for an act to amend the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990. These amendments have become necessary to allow competitors, tested under proposed complimentary state or territory anti-doping legislation, to have access to the same appeal provisions as those available to competitors tested under the ASDA act.

Honourable members are no doubt aware that Australia is at the leading edge in the fight against drugs in sport. The government has made it quite clear through its legislation, and through the policies adopted by the Australian Sports Drug Agency and the Australian Sports Commission, that it is determined to ensure that athletes who cheat on their fellow competitors, their sport and themselves are not able to escape the sanctions they justly deserve. However, the ASDA act only allows the selection of national level competitors to undertake drug tests. The testing of competitors below this level requires the enactment of state and territory legislation.

All states and territories have agreed that such legislation is desirable and have provided a commitment to its introduction. However, in order to ensure that there is a coordinated national approach, extensive discussions have been undertaken on the need for the states and territories to introduce anti-doping legislation which is complementary to existing Commonwealth legislation.

The ASDA act was amended in July last year to include provision for the states and territories to confer broader powers on ASDA to undertake testing of state and territory level competitors under complementary anti-doping legislation. The states and territories are now able to introduce legislation allowing ASDA to test competitors defined in state and territory legislation.

It is important that legislation introduced by the states and territories is complementary to, and consistent with, the existing Commonwealth anti-doping legislation in all major respects. It is particularly important that there is consistency in the protection of the rights of the competitors.

A major element of the ASDA legislation relates to the protection of the rights of competitors who have been selected to provide a sample. The ASDA act includes appeal provisions for all competitors who have failed to provide a sample or who have returned a positive test result. It is important that all competitors are treated equally and have equal access to such appeal provisions.

This bill makes provision for the states and territories to confer jurisdiction for review of decisions by ASDA following a positive test result, or failure by a competitor to comply with a request by ASDA to provide a sample for testing, on the Commonwealth Administrative Appeals Tribunal or federal court. This will enable the states and territories to include in their complementary legislation provisions for access by competitors tested under state or territory legislation to the same appeal provisions as are currently available to competitors tested under Commonwealth anti-doping legislation. This should ensure that a consistent uniform appeal mechanism is available to all competitors tested under any anti-doping legislation in Australia.

Under current arrangements competitors tested under Commonwealth legislation may be listed on the register of notifiable events. The bill includes provision for the names of competitors tested directly under state or territory legislation, who have returned a positive test or who have failed without reasonable cause to provide a sample for testing, to be included on the register of notifiable events. The bill also includes provision for the removal of names of competitors tested under state or territory legislation from the register of notifiable events. These amendments provide for the same procedures to apply to competitors tested under state or territory anti-doping legislation as currently apply under the ASDA act. The Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and Victoria have each developed complementary anti-doping legislation and I understand that, as soon as the provisions in this bill come into force, they will be seeking to introduce their legislation.

In order to avoid variations in the drafting of anti-doping legislation in the states and territories, and to ensure that all legislation is consistent, the Commonwealth has written to the states and territories proposing that the drafting of the legislation be referred to the parliamentary counsels committee. This committee consists of heads of Commonwealth, state and territory offices of parliamentary counsel and will assist in the development of model complementary anti-doping legislation consistent with existing Commonwealth legislation.

The model legislation can be adopted by each state and territory and should avoid unnecessary variations in drafting between the ASDA Act and complementary legislation. The development of model legislation should also simplify and encourage the early introduction of consistent anti-doping legislation in each state and territory.

The successful introduction of complementary legislation in each state and territory will enable ASDA to carry out tests on a considerably greater number of athletes. This will make it increasingly difficult for competitors who choose to use drugs to avoid detection. The introduction of this legislation will mean that Australia has one of the most stringent anti-doping policies of any country in the world and will send a clear message to the sporting community throughout the world that Australia will not tolerate the use of drugs in sport. I am sure that this will be taken into account by overseas athletes proposing to train and compete in Australia, particularly in the period leading up to and during the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000.

There will be no additional financial obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by this bill. Additional testing by ASDA under state or territory legislation, including the costs of the tests, will be the subject of agreements between ASDA and the respective states and territories. All additional costs will be met by the states and territories. I commend this bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to it.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like all members, welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate and to convey my thoughts on the recently announced changes to the arrangements concerning procedures of the House, which include new sitting times. I have listened with great interest to the views of the long-term honourable members opposite. I was especially interested in the views of the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who seems to equate longevity in this place with wisdom. If that were the case, why are those opposite still on the opposition benches after 11 years?

PARA.TAB: As a newcomer, having been a member for only 11 months, I think my views are not as blinkered as the views of those opposite. As a father, whenever my two young daughters, Sarah and Hannah, were troubled, anxious and unable to relax and go to sleep, I used to tell them fairytales. This eventually would relax them and they were soon worry free and asleep. With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to recount one such fairytale tonight to honourable members, with a view to allaying their fears and concerns about these proposals.

Once upon a time, in a land far to the south in a country called Australis, there were murmurings of discontent coming from the people's palace. Australis once consisted of warring tribes that continually fought over their boundaries and the trade that flowed across them. Some 113 years after the initial invasion and settlement of this great land, the wise elders from the warring tribes decided that enough was enough. They decided that for future security and prosperity the tribes must come together in one alliance and form one country. A people's palace was set up in which the chosen members, from villages scattered across this vast land, came together to settle disputes and determine how the country should best be run. These chosen ones met on a regular basis throughout the year and spoke long into the night and early morning on issues of importance to the country.

It came to pass that two main groups emerged in this people's palace: those of the red shield and those of the blue shield. In the people's palace those who supported either group faced each other across a large table. Members of the red and blue shields chose from among their ranks knights and ladies to be their leaders, their decision makers and to be responsible for the good government of the country. This being a civilised country, all disputes were settled in one big battle held at least every three years. But this battle, important though it was, was not one of death and destruction, like those in other countries. This was a battle of words and the winning of hearts and minds. Those of the red shield had won the last five battles and had really gained the ascendancy in the people's palace.

The leader of the red shields, Prince Paul the Fair, had a very strong team of knights and ladies to assist him in the ruling of the country. Prince Paul and his court set in train a series of measures to change the rules governing conduct in the people's palace. He chose a former member of his court, Prince Neal, to come up with a series of well thought out measures. Those of the blue shield were furious over these proposed changes for, having lost the last five battles, their influence amongst the villagers was on the wane. They were desperate for a new leader, someone who could lead them to victory. Their current leader, Prince John, was nervously watching other knights on his frontbench—Prince Little John, Prince Peter, Prince Andrew, Prince Alexander, and a fair woman named Lady Bronwyn—as rumour had it that they wanted to replace Prince John as their leader.

There were also some murmurings to these proposed changes from those of the red shield. One named Daryl expressed concern that, without Prince Paul to lead them daily, those of the blue shield may be more advantaged. Prince Paul allayed these fears, saying that these changes would allow his fellow knights and ladies to toughen and ready themselves for any future battles and would enable members of both shields to work more effectively and constructively for the villagers they represented.

As honourable members would realise, I am relating this fairytale to illustrate a point. Our parliament is close to its centenary. Its rules and regulations were framed long ago when travel and communications were in their infancy. We, as members, are now expected to be abreast of a multitude of portfolios in order to be able to represent effectively the needs and aspirations of all our constituents. I appreciate the many traditions that have been established in this parliament and feel honoured to be standing here representing the people of Franklin. But, as the needs and requirements of our parliament change, we must do the same when it comes to the procedures of this august House. Surely this place is about growth and renewal.

We have a vast array of standing orders to govern the way we act. As a newcomer, however, viewing their effectiveness over the last 11 months, I have no doubt that changes must be made. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said to the House the other day in relation to these arrangements, if we want to preserve the institutions of our democracy, if we want them to work more effectively, we must be prepared to change them where necessary—and, of course, there have been great changes since many of these institutions and procedures were first introduced.

The trial period for these changes—radical changes in the view of many of those opposite—will surely allow us to judge their value and effectiveness. While I admire the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who is here at the moment, and respect his views about the workings of this place, as a new member I heartily support the proposed changes. They are long overdue, and only a reformist party would have the courage to introduce them into this parliament. I humbly congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) for his zeal in persevering in his desire to change the way in which this House works. I commend the proposal to the House and urge all honourable members to wholeheartedly get behind these changes, to let them go through their trial period and to work constructively to see that they are implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the analogy of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) of princely kingdoms and courts because we have suspected for some time that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is starting to get imperial delusions. The honourable member for Franklin has half confirmed that by using what was, in the end, not a very clever analogy to demonstrate his views.

PARA.TAB: I am a member of the Standing Committee on Procedure. About Time was the product of our deliberations over the matters of bills, questions and working hours. As co-signatory to the dissenting report that was prepared by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and me, I must say that many of our suspicions have proved to be well-founded. In the first instance, when the Prime Minister talks about reforming parliament to make it work more efficiently and to provide the opposition with a better forum within which to present its views, we have to be a little bit suspicious. Why would a government with a comfortable majority make things easier for the opposition? It is highly unlikely. It does not fit in with the logical sequence of events that occur in here. Many of the things that have occurred have borne out my view and the view of the honourable member for Moncrieff that the whole alleged bipartisan approach to reforming the various aspects of our work was, in the end, a push by the government to introduce changes that make it more convenient for the government to run the House of Representatives in the manner in which it sees fit.

I turn to a problem that has arisen in relation to the main committee. I was very sceptical about the main committee. I have some doubts as to whether it will provide the sorts of opportunities that the government and the majority report alleges a main or alternative committee debating forum will provide for members. It was recommended that we were to have the debates of the main committee in the main committee room. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know as well as I that it is very difficult to transpose the atmosphere, the dignity—although sometimes that is not quite as pronounced as at other times—of this chamber to another chamber. In other words, we are concerned that the actual debates that will occur will do so in an atmosphere of perhaps lesser dignity, lesser importance, and that those bills that are sent to the main committee for the second reading debate will become second-class as far as those members who are participating in the debates are concerned. We are still unsure—at last news—as to whether or not the main committee room will be available to us to participate in main committee debates. A couple of hours ago there was a rumour that we may be going to one of the smaller committee rooms, which is a matter of great concern.

In the procedure committee's discussions, and as outlined in the dissenting report, we were concerned that transferring debates to the main committee would end up demeaning the standard or the standing of those debates. If that committee is going to meet in a small—dare I say—dogbox committee room, that will certainly bear out our suspicions. One could argue that it would virtually become a Potemkin parliament. I do not see how it will come to pass that debates held in small committee rooms will have the same standing as debates held in this chamber.

I suppose the rationale for the main committee was to provide extra debating time on non-contentious bills, but it was not designed to consign those debates to a lesser standing. Some members represent constituents who feel very strongly about the less exciting pieces of legislation, such as that dealing with the pig slaughter levy. I imagine that if they were standing in a small committee room debating legislation, they would feel that the importance of it had been devalued quite considerably.

The majority report, to which the honourable member for Moncrieff and I dissented, recommended a 3.30 p.m. question time. Much has been said about the problems that would be caused for the reporting of parliament's activities as a result of moving question time to 3.30 p.m. or, as is the case in the Prime Minister's statement and in the amendments to standing orders, to 3.00 p.m. The 3.00 p.m. proposal would still cause problems for what are the best opportunities for the community, the Australian people, to have their government—the people who are administering their tax money—scrutinised by the opposition.

We all know that question time is the focal point of the day's activities. It is a very important part of the parliamentary day. Likewise, so are the matters of public importance and the censure motions that generally occur immediately following question time. Members of the media expressed some concern about the time available to them to prepare edited commentary on what occurs at question time and then during MPIs and censure motions. Having question time commence at 3 o'clock will still cause a fair amount of unnecessary problems for those who are involved in the preparation of news material, particularly for television.

There is no doubt that things have changed since the parliament has been televised. People are probably much more aware of some of this so-called theatre that the Prime Minister talked about in his speech, some of which appears to have been plagiarised. We are looking at a situation where the MPIs and the censure motions are being pushed off the edge of the reportable day of parliament's proceedings and therefore there is less opportunity for the opposition to scrutinise those ministers who are administering taxpayers' money on behalf of the Australian community.

Tonight on television we saw a very skilful melange of question time and MPIs put together as part of the news reporting so that people were able to get as full a picture as possible in a 30-second or one-minute report of what has gone on today. It is very important that we see the danger in moving question time to 3.00 p.m.

The honourable member for Moncrieff and I opposed the movement of question time to 3.30. I suppose 3.00 p.m. was seen as a bit of a compromise. It has still gone too far; we should really be ensuring that question time and the ensuing debates, MPIs and censure motions are held at such times that allow the electronic media in particular to provide the Australian community with as full a report as possible. The Prime Minister said in his address:
If we want to preserve the institutions of our democracy, and if we want them to work more effectively, we have to be prepared to change them where necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: That is fair enough; that is true. But one has to ask: why the changes? Why are we going to be changing some of the ways in which we do our work in this building? There is no doubt that there is a need to change the sitting hours. I for one would not be prepared to accept the responsibility for those who have perhaps become ill as a result of the hours and the extraordinary pressure under which we work in the House of Representatives. That goes not only for members of the House of Representatives, but it also goes for those people who work here, whether they are in the reporting staff, the support staff, the clerk's office or elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: There has been a consistent series of attacks on the institutions that underpin our system of parliamentary democracy. These attacks are part of a consistent program to provide changes to undermine and to break down the resistance to changes which would bring about the type of society which many on the other side would like to see in Australia—a society that is quite alien to the mainstream of Australian people. They, too, are wary at times, and ought to be more wary, of those social engineers, those people who say that they know better than they how to run their lives or how to run the system of government under which they live. In particular, the flag has been mentioned. I will not dwell on the flag other than to say that it represents something that is an obstacle to change.

The Speaker's chair is an interesting part of the symbolism of our chamber. Mr Deputy Speaker, we know that the simple chair in which you sit is the result of a conscious decision of the government to make a change from the Speaker's chair in the old Parliament House, which would have been seen as a link to the past and to the constitutional origins and British parliamentary traditions that have underpinned our system.

There has been a decline and a breakdown in the standards of ministerial behaviour and responsibility. I do not have to dwell on that; it is in the minds of many people around the country right at this very moment as they witness the embarrassing and absolutely indefensible situation in which the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) finds herself as a result of the sports rorts scandal, which has grown out of all proportion to the origins of the program and has become probably one of the most dangerous scandals facing the Keating government.

We also have changes in the symbolism in our armed forces and changes in and attacks on the judiciary. As I said, these are seen as obstacles to the type of society that many of those opposite would like to see inflicted on the Australian people. So why does the House of Representatives need to be changed? First of all the Prime Minister says, `Question time doesn't work'. I agree with that. He then says, `There is too much legislation for too little sitting hours'. I agree with that. One of the things that the Prime Minister did not say, of course, is that ministers take far too long to answer questions on notice. I certainly agree with that.

There is no doubt that many in the community lament the type of behaviour that goes on in this chamber at question time. They look at the disorder that sometimes occurs and wonder what on earth their members of parliament are doing. The pressure and heat that are generated in question time are often a result of the intense frustration felt by members of the opposition as they watch ministers fail to answer questions and take an inordinate amount of time to give answers.

Over recent years we have seen the frequency of questions decline to an extraordinary number. This has been particularly more pronounced in the last couple of years. We have heard the Prime Minister say that he will guarantee 14 questions a day. Of course, there is no such guarantee in the amendments to the standing orders that are proposed in the Notice Paper today. If we look at the other commitments that have been given by the Prime Minister in the past, we see that this one would have to be consigned to the dustbin as one which no-one in his or her right mind would possibly believe.

The other matter to be discussed is the use of answers as non-respondable debating points. As the Prime Minister quite rightly pointed out, question time has ceased to be an interrogation. It has become a point scoring exercise, principally because ministers are using the opportunity to debate the answers to the questions or elements associated with them and use those to bludgeon us because we have to remain in silence. We are unable to do anything other than ask a brief question.

I came into this parliament, probably a bit innocently, thinking that there was such a thing as bipartisanship. I have since discovered that that is a myth; there is no such thing. The government sucks in our contributions and then spits them out whenever it sees fit. As we saw with the report on the broadcasting of televised parliamentary sittings, when the Prime Minister does not want something to take place, he cuts it off; when he wants to do something, he does it, ignoring the views of some members of the committee, including recommendations of the majority of the committee. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fear there is a touch of deja vu this evening. When we debated the tabling of the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure, About time, I spoke after the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was in the chamber. I remember an exchange on theatricality in the House. I find myself once again engaged in the debate.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to speak on this matter, briefly—although I notice I have 15 minutes and not 10—because I think this is a very important issue. I was fascinated when my colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) referred to fairytales and then told us a fairytale. When I read the response of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and the MPI put forward by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) on this matter, I honestly had to wonder whether I was reading a fairytale because of some of the arguments that were put forward.

In relation to these suggested changes, we can go back to the tabling speech of the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) on 28 October last year. I pay tribute to the honourable member for Bonython, not only for an illustrious parliamentary career but also for bringing into the House this evening the report and the various matters that have come to these trial changes. It needs to be emphasised that this is a trial. He made the point in his speech that essentially we seek to make a series of evolutionary changes. If one thing clarifies the difference between ourselves and the opposition, it is that we are prepared to respond and adapt to changing circumstances.

The honourable member for Bennelong referred to 93 years of tradition, and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) talked about 20 years of tradition. I was quite disappointed by the contribution of the honourable member for Moncrieff, who appeared to be implying that members who are fairly new to this House should not have a say on this matter. That is very disappointing. I note that other colleagues who are on the committee with the honourable member for Moncrieff and the honourable member for Moore will be speaking later in the debate.

If the Liberal Party were looking for a new name—and I gather there was some discussion about a new name—perhaps it could be called the Party for Looking Backwards. Would it be too strong to suggest the Troglodyte Party? That might be too strong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very droll.

—We could try the Droll Party. I think it is disappointing to not see a degree of bipartisanship, because this is a consultative change. Perhaps the committee's report has not been fully adopted. There was obviously a range of debating positions within caucus, and there are probably many views on the other side of the House. What has been suggested is a trial of some new procedures to see how we get on. Apart from the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), I do not think people have too many problems with the sitting times. I think it is a very useful change. I do not see a problem with moving some of the debate into a smaller chamber. It would appear a bit ludicrous for half a dozen people, and sometimes less, to sit in this beautiful chamber when a great deal of business could be conducted in smaller rooms, as we conduct parliamentary committee work.

PARA.TAB: The changes to question time seem to be exercising the minds of most people. I agree with what the Leader of the Opposition said in his speech on 8 February: question time is absolutely fundamental to our democratic process. But the comments of those opposite suggest that there is a major hijacking of question time, and we hear all this talk of imperialism. We on this side of the House are not the imperialists; we are the republicans. I feel that this is where the fairy story is going off the rails.

The Prime Minister strongly dominates the parliament and confidently deals with the opposition. This is not simply because he gets so few questions from the Leader of the Opposition; when he does get them, he deals with them very confidently. What he is saying is that he also has confidence in his ministers to be able to operate under increased scrutiny. If he did not have confidence in his ministers, he would be suggesting that he has to be here each day to protect them.

This is a very positive move and, as the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) indicated, it is very important that the executive be placed under scrutiny not only by the government but by the parliamentary caucus because, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) said in his address, we are also backbenchers. There is a very important opportunity being made available to provide further scrutiny of our ministers. I would have thought that this would have been welcomed by the opposition but it seems that this is not something that it is looking for.

The honourable member for Moore spoke about the timing of question time and the problems the electronic media are having. I believe parliament must make the decisions about the timing of our operations and, if that requires the media to make some alterations to their timetable, then that is the way it should be done. I believe there is far too much focus on assisting the media with their operations. This is one of the difficulties that have resulted in the need to look at these changes because, in a sense, one could argue that the media's appetite—as I think I argued in my speech on 17 December—is fairly voracious. The stories have become quite skewed because the media pick up grabs for the 6 o'clock news. As the Prime Minister said in his speech, form has become more important than substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hates that, doesn't he?
—I do not think he does.
—I am sure he does.

—There is no doubt that there is a great deal of ability on both sides of this House to provide the theatrical flourish, but I think it is important to get some substance in the stories. It is true that the electronic media generally have a bias to form over substance; that is one of the major problems, I believe, in any intellectual debate in this country. It is very hard to get a rational, reasonable argument on the electronic media.

PARA.TAB: It would be fair to say that, while we all read the papers, in terms of intellectual discussion, everyone has moved to the 30-second grab in the news. An example would be a recent episode of Real Life where the issue of the widows pension was raised. It was fascinating the way that particular broadcast completely gave a reasoned, rational approach to the argument. I was invited to do an interview but, because my interview did not fit the angle that that particular program wanted to take, it was not put on. I think that we are all aware of this sort of issue.
Mr Connolly interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I do not know what the honourable member for Bradfield is saying. It must have been something that I will be very sorry to have missed.
—Can't you get on the ABC?
—All the time; I do not have a problem getting on the ABC.
—They are opposed to a reasonable, rational approach.
—Oh! They are opposed to a reasonable, rational approach. I am disappointed because I believe it is important.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister probably did not hear that either. It is good to see a bit of mirth because I think one of the problems that we have had in the debates in the House is a lack of a degree of humour. I think that a little more eloquence and a little more humour would serve us very well. I think the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is very helpful in this aspect. I was absolutely fascinated today when he spoke about Senator Bishop. The opposition was spellbound. The uproar at the other end of the chamber was caused by one of the National Party colleagues suggesting we extend the leader's time. It got a wonderful response.
—I think it was laboured humour.

—We have to have humour of all sorts. However, I believe these changes are going to be very helpful. As I pointed out earlier in my speech, the major difference between the two sides of the House is the backward and the forward looking. It is very important that we respond to change. I note the honourable member for Moore trotted out the issue of the flag and the honourable member for Bennelong trotted out the issue of the flag and of trampling all over our constitution. These arguments from the honourable member for Bennelong are amazing and, indeed, chronically conservative, I might say.
—Do you like the trade unions?

—They are part of the wonderful institution that is our country, but they are moving, changing, developing and responding to change and that is why, with the accord and this government, we have held the agenda on this issue. It sounds like a red herring to me.
—I tell you what, you responded to it.

—It is all part of the cut and thrust. I was fascinated by the points of order that the honourable member for Bennelong thrust onto the Deputy Speaker earlier. I find it amazing that our opponents on the other side of the House cannot see the big picture, cannot get into the big issues. After being disillusioned by many years in opposition, which I can understand, honourable members opposite must deal with the petty issues. In relation to some of these changes that are being proposed it would be useful if we all said, `Well, look, let's give them a try'. There should be a commitment to review those operations. We might find that change is helpful.
—I think a change of government would be very helpful.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Order! The millions of listeners we have may not be able to hear the interjections of the honourable member for Bennelong. I suggest that he allow the honourable member for Capricornia to finish her speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I dare say, if the honourable member for Bennelong really wants to make a point, he might have to get up and take a point of order.
—I wouldn't be so ungracious to do that to you.
—It is wonderful to finally see graciousness coming from the opposition.
—Come on. Don't be so uncharitable.
—I hope the honourable member for Bennelong is not going to lecture me. We are dealing with the fact that, once again, these backward-looking people who have been here all these years, probably feel—
—You are talking about the government again.

—I have not been here as long as the right honourable member for New England has been here. Here we see the importance of people working together with new ideas, and evolving change. There is nothing that should not be looked at or should not be reviewed. Even our constitution—I gather the visiting member of the royal household endorsed those debates during his visit—should be open to changes and we should try these changes. I hope that we will come back and have a full and frank debate about them. We may find that some members of the opposition will think that they have in fact worked quite well.

PARA.TAB: I believe the scrutiny of all our ministers will be helpful. I believe we can provide a more positive response in question time and have real debate on the issues. I certainly hope, as I said in my previous speech on this matter, that our ministers will demonstrate some discipline in their answers to questions so that more—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give me a chance and I will.

—Indeed, I should compliment the Minister for Development Cooperation for his excellent response to a question today. I hope that he noted that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), and I were wearing very relevant badges about the issue that he was referring to—the violence against women in the former Yugoslavia. I commend him for his response to that question. I would hope that we would all work together to foster positive changes instead of the crippling level of debate that we have had on this issue, particularly from the opposition.

—Announcing yesterday his changes to the sitting hours pattern, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) again saw the need to camouflage his reasons, this time by referring to the report of a committee chaired by the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett). The fact that the actual recommendations of that committee, along with some of its observations, have been largely ignored should come as no surprise, given the increasing disdain of the parliament as an institution displayed by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Many of our institutions have been the target of the Prime Minister's vituperation. However, his performance yesterday was notable for what he did not say and what he did not give as his reasons. Not surprisingly, this time he resorted to the refuge of scoundrels and claimed that the announced changes are reforms. The word `reform' replaces `patriotism' as the last refuge of scoundrels under this government.

Another issue is the way the proposals came before the House, pronounced as they were by the Prime Minister himself. Why did they not come from the Speaker? After all, the Speaker is charged with the responsibility of running this place. Perhaps he could not bring himself to do it because either he is not in favour of what is now intended or he is not prepared to be left open to humiliation by the Prime Minister of the kind that was savagely handed out concerning the broadcasting of House proceedings. Either way, we can understand the Speaker's reluctance to chance his arm again, even though that would otherwise have been appropriate.

Failing that, why not have the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) do the deed? No. The head honcho himself has done the honours—no less a person than the Prime Minister. The Speaker and the Leader of the House, though much more responsible than anyone else for the day-to-day running of this place, did not get the nod. This announcement has come from a Prime Minister who will not come into the House to debate matters of great national import, despite the repeated invitations and challenges from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Why should the man who would be king by any other name bother to debate any issue while proceedings in the House and question time are reported time and again in the media as debate?

The Prime Minister's reputation as a parliamentary debater can never be put to the test in question time. But it suits him to allow the myth to be perpetuated and at the same time to escape real debate and argument. Given the Prime Minister's propensity to substitute longwinded answers to questions for traditional debate, it is possible to conclude that he does have unstated reasons for what is now proposed. Historically, even relatively minor alterations to sitting patterns have been the product of a relevant committee. That is not so this time. This time, a committee report has been used by the Prime Minister as no more than a catalyst to do things his way.

Previously, major changes were championed by the Leader of the House or the chair. That is not so this time. Until now, more often than not such proposals were likely to be the subject of a free vote. That is not so this time. The Prime Minister has deliberately locked his sheep into his grand plan, the central feature of which is to make life easier for himself. This matter is essentially about mollycoddling a precious Prime Minister not noted for his physical or intellectual stamina.

The practical effect of pre-empting a free vote on such fundamental changes is to stifle debate on the details. That is predictable from a Prime Minister and a government that in each parliament and each year for 11 years have engineered the increasing irrelevance of this chamber. Over the period we have seen question time degenerate into a farce. The use of dorothy dixers from the government's back bench is virtually the absolute rule. Responses to government questions are, in the minds of media viewers and readers, almost universally regarded as debate, so much so that the Prime Minister seems to believe it. The number of answers attempted has fallen away abysmally. More frequently than not, the greater part of responses to questions without notice are mostly or totally irrelevant. It is an embarrassment to have to attend question time. It has become an insult.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that.

—The honourable member for Gilmore is an insult to the place. Question time has become an insult to those who have elected us. It is, and always has been, within the domain of the Prime Minister and his ministers generally to prevent the sad spectacle that is now question time.

PARA.TAB: By its own good example, the government could, and still can if of a mind to, create a more decorous atmosphere in this place. No changes to standing orders can achieve that. The example set by the ministry—and it alone—stands in the way of seemly conduct during question time. Regrettably, again, such leadership from the Prime Minister does not seem to be in prospect.

These proposed changes, as one of three criteria, are predicated on `the need to free up chamber time for the proper consideration of legislation'. The obvious way to do that is to have the parliament sit on more days; it is as simple as that. Ministers with direct responsibility might then attend the chamber during debate on legislation which they have the responsibility of administering.
The experiment with a second and ancillary chamber would not be necessary if the parliament were to sit for, for example, another 40 days each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my point exactly.

—The honourable member for Bennelong made the point very well earlier. After all, the place is now empty for 305 days each year, or 306 in a leap year if one wants to get technical. If we sit another 40 days a year, it will still be stone motherless empty for 265 days a year.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit like what happens with departments of state under this government. How often has a regulatory or revenue raising department gone to a Labor minister to be given more power and law when what was there was perfectly adequate and the call for more became the alibi for poor and inadequate administration? The same principles apply here.

The Prime Minister's justification for a second chamber is that we need to free up this chamber for the proper consideration of legislation. The chamber is uninhabited—empty—for 305 days of the cotton-pickin' year, yet we have to have another chamber with all the cost that that entails.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I thank the minister at the table, the Minister for Development Cooperation. I appreciate his support. He should talk to his Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Extra space is not needed; members of parliament in the parliament doing their jobs are needed. If ministers with responsibility for the proposed law attended debates and answered criticisms at the conclusion of second reading debates and in the committee stage, who would be in a position to judge in advance, as the Prime Minister does now, whether a bill is routine or uncontroversial? All government legislation is potentially controversial, and so it should be. More sitting days is the obvious remedy for many of the real shortcomings which undeniably exist.

But, as often proves to be the case, the obvious and simple answer is the one unlikely to be adopted. Sitting on more days would also help to settle sitting hours more satisfactorily. Instead of cramming more hours into a sitting year of up to 60 days, fewer daily hours would be possible without sacrificing—dare I say it—productivity and the material we can get through in this place.

I believe that these proposed hours are a recipe for health problems for honourable members and their staff rather than the opposite, as has been claimed. I would have welcomed the opinion of health care professionals, and I would have welcomed the Prime Minister having sought such information. Many honourable members, in common with the rest of Australia, prefer to take recreational exercise during daylight hours. The minister at the table is no doubt under instructions to walk during the day. When will he get a chance to do so with the threat of a division hanging over him? The proposed hours will make that impossible, particularly during winter in Canberra. A number of our colleagues, including the minister at the table I think, are already under doctors' orders to take a brisk walk every day at the very least. When will they get that chance with the new hours in place?

Generally, however, my resistance to what is now in the offing is that it does not accord with the reasons offered. The procedure committee's logic, although some of it was arguable, was in evidence, but the ultimate version, the Prime Minister's, lacks the committee report's credibility. What is left to discuss is merely a hotchpotch, its only justification being this Prime Minister's and this government's need for greater convenience. It promises little by way of improvement and a lot by way of executive imperialism. It is a gigantic move away from the ultimate supremacy of the House over the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to add my congratulations to the Standing Committee on Procedure, which produced the report on which these reforms are based. I think it has done a very industrious job and has come up with some pretty good, basic, commonsense ideas. We can all be grateful to the committee for its report. If I can just digress for one minute, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) on his parliamentary career.

PARA.TAB: In the last two months or so, it has been quite a strange experience for me, being a relatively new member, to be here seeing so many members of many years standing resigning, including no fewer than three former ministers for health—the honourable member for Bonython; the former honourable member for Mackellar, who has already resigned; and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar). They were all former ministers for health at times when I actually worked for that department. It has been a rather odd experience for me to be here and see all those people disappear. Certainly, the honourable member for Bonython has made a great contribution to the Australian Labor Party and to public life, and no better example of that exists than Medicare.

I turn to the motion and the amendments that are contained in it. First I mention a fairly simple one but one which is so sensible that I am amazed it has not been thought of in the past; that is, to have four sitting days in a week instead of three. I am a bit astonished by the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). Judging by what he was saying, he thinks that we should sit for 365 days a year.

Obviously there are many aspects to parliamentary life and one of them is coming here, as we are elected to do. But it is also pretty important for us to be seen occasionally in our electorates, to serve the people that we represent and to be available to them. We have to come here and pass legislation. As a matter of fact, I enjoy coming here but only for a certain amount of time. If we have to come here for a certain number of weeks, then it makes obvious sense to maximise the time that we are here and be as productive as possible. I would have thought that four days is a minimum that is sensible for a sitting week. As I said, I do not understand why it has taken so long for the parliament to realise that four days is sensible.

I think that the two weeks on, two weeks off pattern is a must. I know that the current situation of two weeks on and one week off is only happening in this case; it should not happen again. I think we should come for two weeks, or eight sitting days, and then have two weeks back in our electorates as a minimum. As I said before, it is important that members of parliament are accessible to their constituents and to their party rank and file—from whichever party it might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of us work in our electorates.

—That is right. We need to be seen and, in reality, to be actually doing things to further the interests of our constituents. So two weeks on, two weeks off is a pretty good compromise—if we can call it that—for a sitting pattern.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the hours of sitting. I must say that, of all the things we have to get used to when we change our lifestyle as a member of parliament, what I have found the toughest has been the long nights of sitting. I suppose that I have come off lightly compared with people in the past who have regularly been here until 5 o'clock in the morning. But last year I did find that it was fairly tough. Not only do we have to be here until 11 or 12 o'clock but often, because the adrenaline has been going and our minds have been active, it is fairly difficult to go straight to bed. We find that we may have to spend an hour or two unwinding and then go to bed. However, we then have to get up the next morning and come in to start all over again at 8 o'clock for one committee or another. I found that one of the more difficult things to adjust to.

I think the latest possible sitting time of 8 o'clock in the evening is a much better idea for all the obvious health reasons. Also, I believe that it will ensure better productivity and better performance on both sides of the House, dare I say it, if we have four days a week and if we have sensible hours, finishing at 8 o'clock. That way we can have our dinner, perhaps have an earlier night, and then come in and be a bit fresher in the morning than sometimes we have been.

The changes to question time are, I suppose, the most controversial of the changes, judging by the reactions of opposition members in particular. I must admit that there were concerns on our side about the decision to reduce the appearances of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in question time to only twice a week. But they were political concerns in that we thought the Prime Minister was being a bit generous to the opposition by only coming two days a week. We were a bit worried that he might be letting them off a bit lightly. In fact, I think he is doing the opposition a favour.

It is incredible that the opposition, in its self-righteous indignation, opposed this change and complained about it because I think that, if anything, it would be better for the opposition to have the Prime Minister here only twice a week to clean them up, as he usually does, rather than having him here every day. Having said that, despite the reservations that have been expressed by some of my colleagues, I think it would be a very good arrangement because it will give other ministers the opportunity to answer more questions and to develop their skills. It will also give members on both sides of the House—if it is possible for some members of the opposition—the opportunity to develop their skills by asking more questions. Despite the reservations that some people have on both sides of the House, the new question time format with the rostering system is, on balance, a sensible idea. I am looking forward to seeing how it works.

I have talked about the opposition. If the Prime Minister or anyone on this side came in here and moved a motion that the sky was blue, the opposition would find a way of opposing it. That is what this opposition does. It has no policies; it has nothing to offer the Australian people. I notice that the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) suggested that they should change their name to `the party for looking backwards'. I cannot think readily of anything to top that in terms of a suggested name change. The opposition really is a party of the past. The performance of those opposite shows it. They have nothing to hang their hat on and so they oppose at every opportunity.

Those opposite have also been the main contributors to unruly behaviour that parliament gets a reputation for. There has been a lot of concern expressed by people during this debate about the image the parliament has in the community; the image that we get on the 6 o'clock news every night where we have a few seconds of grabs from question time, of some of the more robust comments made by both ministers and the opposition. That does not go down too well in the electorate. Of course, it is the opposition that causes that, by and large, because it is in its interests to.

I can remember when I was on Campbelltown City Council as a Labor alderman. In the first four years that I was there Labor did not have an absolute majority but, with the support of a couple of Independents, we were seen as being the ruling party, if you like, on Campbelltown council. We had the mayor as a result of that. What our opponents did, this motley collection of Liberals and so-called Independents who were to the right of Genghis Khan, was to seek to make council unworkable by moving points of order, rescission motions and just causing general unruly behaviour. It had the effect, which was certainly the aim of it, of giving council a bad name. We were getting headlines in the local papers that `council is unworkable' and there were fights and brawls going on. Of course, any publicity of that nature in a chamber—whether it be a local government or a parliament—always reflects badly on the incumbent government, which is why opposition parties do that sort of thing. They cause the disruption; they cause the chaos. It reflects badly on the government. That is the way the public perceives it because that is the way it is covered in the media.

One can almost understand the opposition's attitude in this debate. It is based on self-interest, but that does not make it right. Members of the opposition come in here and say that the Labor government has no respect for the principles, traditions and status of this House—

TALK.START.PARA: —The conventions.

—That is right. They say that we have no respect for the conventions and the institutions of democracy. Back in 1975 the coalition parties conspired with the then Governor-General, the Chief Justice of the High Court, the CIA and God knows who else to bring down a democratically elected government. They were not too worried about following convention or constitutional requirements in those days. They were just out for power.

PARA.TAB: When the High Court brought down its Mabo decision, the coalition parties were not too worried about railing against the High Court decision. They support law and order when it suits them, but not when its affects their born to rule status in the community. That is what it amounts to. As I said earlier today, these people on the opposition benches grew up in an era when their parents obviously taught them that they were born to rule; that they would inherit power because they were the pillars of middle class and the establishment; and that it was all theirs just for the taking. But it has not worked out that way.

In 1972 the Labor Party was elected to office. We had a rude interruption in 1975 due to events I have already described. Since 1983 we have had a Labor government which has tackled social justice and reform at all different levels of society. The opposition does not like having some of its cherished symbols of the past challenged. Someone has only to mention the thought of having a new flag, a head of state who does not live overseas or, dare I even suggest this, a republic or maybe even changing the constitution a little bit. We need to do most of those things. As soon as anyone mentions or wants to debate these issues, the opposition is outraged. How dare we challenge the constitution, the status quo and the established order in this country!

Those opposite accuse us of being Labor ruffians as well as calling us other names. That is because they have been in opposition for 11 years and they have lost five elections in a row. They are frustrated beyond belief. They just do not like it. In a way, I do not blame them. But they also have to remember that they represent constituents and that they have a responsibility in this parliament to observe true democratic traditions and to work in the interests of Australia. I know other people want to speak in this debate. I will end my thoughts there and commend the changes to the House.

The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Before I call the next member, I would like to observe from the chair that, although this is a wide-ranging debate and the occupants of this chair have taken it as such, I believe that members should relate their remarks to the matter before the House and not roam too widely or they may be brought into disregard by the chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be appropriate for me to open my remarks by congratulating the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett)—who is soon to leave this chamber to represent Australia in the United Kingdom—for the work he and his colleagues on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure have done in producing their report About time: bills, questions and working hours, which has resulted in some significant proposals for changes to the standing orders of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: After listening to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), I must say that he seems to have completely supported my basic contention, which is that the proposals to change question time have not been based on idealism, as he would suggest; rather they have been based on the ALP's pragmatic judgment that the image of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is damaging the status of the party. This point came out very clearly yesterday when I had a bus load of constituents up here for question time. At the end of the procedures, I went to say goodbye to them. I was met by a number of ashen-faced people who asked, `Is he always like that?'. Another one said, `That's exactly what he looks like on television'. I said, `Yes, he's like that almost every day of the week'. It is not unlikely, therefore, that the Labor Party has decided that there is a lot of sense in taking its baseball bat out of the chamber for three days out of five. For that reason, the Prime Minister will be appearing in our midst for only two days of the week. It is also significant that the Prime Minister, in his efforts to appear as statesman in this particular subject, in his opening remarks to the House on 8 February, said:
If we want to preserve the institutions of our democracy, and if we want them to work more effectively, we have to be prepared to change them where necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it, that would appear to be a perfectly reasonable statement. It is one which most people, without necessary knowledge of the subject, would be prepared to accept. But when we analyse the statistics of how this

parliament has performed over recent decades, we can only come to the conclusion that, while there is perhaps a need to make some changes, equally some of the other changes proposed have been effectively forced on us because for too long every effort seems to have been made to prostitute the standing orders of the parliament in such a way as to achieve a position where it is now claimed that the parliament is virtually unworkable. I took out some statistics on this matter. I have already sought the permission of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous), who is at the table, to have them incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard the first table of these statistics.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first statistics relate to questions without notice. The period under review is from 1970 to 1993, so it is a reasonable spread. It goes back to the Gortonian period of the coalition. It goes through the Whitlam period, the Fraser period and the Hawke and Keating period. It demonstrates that, since 1970, the maximum number of questions were asked between 1976 and 1979, during the Fraser government. Over that four-year period, the number of questions asked ranged between 1,447 and 1,021.

PARA.TAB: Any other similar period between 1970 and 1994 under a Labor government demonstrates a hopeless comparison. For example, in 1993 the number of questions asked fell to 429. In 1991 it was 861, which is double that figure. But at no stage over the last 11 years did the total number of questions asked in any one year remotely approach the statistics between 1976 and 1979. There are a number of reasons for that. One is that the average time taken to answer a question has gone up significantly in recent years. Let me give some examples of that.

In 1970, the average time taken for a question and answer combined was 2.6 minutes. In 1992 it was 5.8 minutes. In 1993 it was 4.7 minutes. The evidence is clear: the trend has been inexorably upwards. Therefore, the content of question time, in terms of the number of questions asked, clearly goes in the opposite direction; it has fallen significantly. In 1970 the average number of questions asked per day was 16.7. During the Fraser years, that figure rose to 19.3. But, under Labor, over the last 11 years, it has been at best 13.7 and at worst 11 questions per day.

Regardless of whether we consider time or the number of questions asked during question time, the evidence is absolutely conclusive. One of the reasons why question time has failed over recent years is that the government of the day has wanted it to fail. If we relate that again to the number of sitting days, we again find a very significant trend. In 1970 the House sat for 73 days. From 1970 through to the end of that decade, the lowest number of days in which the House was in session was 60 and the average was around 68 to 75. But over the last 11 years it has fallen as low as 38 days in 1990 and 46 days in 1993. Yet we are told that we must reform the system because question time does not work.

I would be among those who take the view—and I think many members on both sides do—that we share concern about the public perceptions of parliament. For better or worse, the introduction of the televising of parliament, and of question time in particular, has undoubtedly confirmed in the eyes of the viewers their very worst expectations of parliament and of some people in parliament, including the Prime Minister.

But is the response to that problem—and I acknowledge that it is real—to simply take the Prime Minister out of the chamber, so he only comes in here for two days a week? Or is the response to look at the more fundamental problems: why ministers spend so much time burbling on answering questions; why the number of ministerial statements has fallen; why more ministers now use question time as a mechanism for effectively making statements and why the ultimate outcome of all that must be that fewer questions are asked and, sadly, that too many questions are asked of too few people? The bias in question time in recent years has definitely seen—and I use the language of other speakers—a gladiatorial context. Many questions are from the leaders of the opposition to the Prime Minister or to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and so forth.

I would also take the view that it is better that there be a more even spread of questions, especially across the entire frontbench. And, yes, I would like to see members on both sides of the chamber have the freedom to stand up in their places and ask free ranging questions. I do not want to see the whip on the government side, as I did today, come into the chamber with a handful of papers and all his meek, mild mannered little backbenchers lining up to be force-fed their pieces of paper so that they can take their places and ask their set piece dorothy dixers.

That is not the basis of the so-called Westminster system, which is meant to be a free ranging system by which backbenchers can represent their constituents and also ensure that the ministers and the government of the day are kept on their mettle. Mistakes are made on all sides in this, but the biggest error must lie with the government because it is the government which has the executive responsibility to make parliament work and to make it work well.

We get told, when it is convenient for the government to say so, that we are following the Westminster system in terms of question time. That may be so to a point, but the important thing is that Westminster sits significantly longer per year than we do. While it is true that the prime minister appears only twice a week in Westminster, the facts are that there are more weeks of sitting and therefore the prime minister is in the chamber for a longer period. The significance of this, therefore, is that we must be on our guard to make sure that when reforms are put forward they are reforms which are going to be useful and which are going to make parliament work in a more efficient and effective manner.

I turn to the question of the second chamber. I believe that the second chamber as a concept is worth a go. I am prepared to take that view and I do so in the context of knowing that these are but trial procedures and let us see how they work. There has been some argument and some concern about which size chamber should be used, whether it should be the main committee room of parliament—which I should point out to the House is a shared committee room; we share it with the Senate, and that could create some difficulties—or whether there should be a room specifically set aside for the purpose.

I am one of those rare members of this House who actually recall when we were last in government, some years ago. An attempt was made to have estimates committees in the House of Representatives. At that time we had a committee set aside and it was quite well attended by members who were interested in the range of estimates which were under review. I remain to be convinced as to how many members will actually turn up for these secondary debates or, as it was described by one of my colleagues, for this `second-class legislation'. I hope that is not the case because no legislation is second-class.

The sad thing about our adversarial system is the presumption of the public that we fight about everything. The public is generally unaware of the fact that something like 80 per cent of the legislation which goes through this chamber does so without any major division. We could perhaps get through much more legislation by having the two chambers working parallel. Some of that 80 per cent of legislation which is not subject to party controversy would be able to go through the second chamber. It is often legislation of a technical nature and, therefore, members may be able to ask more questions.

I also put on record my belief that the second chamber should also be used for ministerial statements, or at least opportunities should be taken for more ministerial statements in both chambers. An attempt should be made to introduce a greater debating procedure and more time for debating ministerial statements and the annual reports of departments, which are regularly tabled in this chamber and which then disappear into oblivion. They are never subject to review within the parliament, yet the whole purpose of those reports to the parliament is so that members have the opportunity to comment on them if they so wish. The truth is that the structure as it currently works does not give us the opportunity to comment. I hope the introduction of the second chamber will enable that opportunity to be created.

I refer again to the matter of question time. The Prime Minister made the observation yesterday, I think it was, `Oh, well, if you can't get questions up, put them on notice'. I am one of those who uses the process of questions on notice rather lavishly. I could not help but smile wryly when I heard him make that remark because I put a question on notice only quite recently, question No. 829. On 1 February I asked the Prime Minister upon notice:

SPEECH.PARA: Will he supply all information deleted on grounds of irrelevance from documents supplied in response to my Freedom of Information request of 6 September 1993.
Guess what the answer to the honourable member's question was? It was no.

PARA.TAB: That is the response we get from the Prime Minister, who tells us that we should put more questions on notice. We may well do so, but there is certainly no guarantee that we will get an answer from a man whose arrogance is now supreme and who has now decided not to come into the chamber for most of the week and who will now deign be present in our midst for only two days a week.

It has been suggested that, by introducing an additional day of sitting, all these problems will somehow or other be overcome. I do not believe that will be the case. As I said, unless there is a clear provision in standing orders, which there is not, that answers must be short and that they must be pertinent to the quest-ion, we are going to make very little progress

SPEECH.PARA: in real terms in trying to reinstitute into this chamber a sensible and effective system of questioning of ministers in question time.

PARA.TAB: A number of other issues were raised in the address by the Prime Minister: the handling of legislation, parliamentary questions and the question of how long we sit. I have endeavoured to cover that last matter in my opening remarks. We simply sit for far too short a time in terms of the volume of legislation which is now expected to come before the House.
I seek leave to incorporate the second table of those statistics.
Leave granted.
