TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of bills declared urgent between 1980 and 1993, under Labor since 1985 there has been significant growth in the number of bills which have been guillotined and the number of bills which have been declared urgent. In 1992 it was 132 bills and in previous years it was the same sort of number. This demonstrates the problem we face. (Time expired)

—I do not intend to use my full time tonight because, as is clear from the Notice Paper and list of speakers, there are many honourable members who wish to comment on this report. One thing we can say about this report is that there is not a lot of agreement on it. The only thing we can all agree on is that the current system does need to be looked at, but we all have our views on what changes should occur. Another thing we can be sure of is that change does not come easy. The parliament of this nation, throughout which we now expect people to confront workplace reform and productivity, should be looking to confront the issues. The Liberal Party talks about it; we have done it. If it is good enough for the factory floor to confront those issues, it is good enough for this parliament.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion we are talking about a trial period. It is very much a situation of, `Let us see how it works, and if changes need to be made we can do that at the appropriate time'. We will not find out whether those changes will work until we actually try them. I believe the sitting time changes will assist the sanity and good health of all members and staff of Parliament House. The overall total number of hours remains, which ensures that there is still sufficient time for debate. I certainly will be glad to get home on a Thursday night. I have a young family whom I love very much, and I also have a very busy electorate office.

I noted the comments earlier tonight of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) regarding the fact that we can sit for another 40 or 50 days per year. Maybe all the honourable member for Curtin does is sit in this House. This House is an important part of my job as a member of parliament but so is my electorate. I spend a lot of time in my electorate whenever I can. It is a large and growing electorate and it has people there with problems. They are regularly in touch with me and I with them to ensure that I can assist them. It is a lot harder to assist them when we are stuck in Canberra for most of the year. Do members of the opposition not like their electorates? Are they scared of going out in to their communities? Would they rather just stay up here and hide from them?

In relation to the second chamber, I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). It is worth trialing. It should help speed up the time taken to consider legislation while at the same time actually allowing more time for the consideration of all legislation. By having the two chambers that will be able to occur. Having the two chambers may be of great assistance to the Liberal Party. I guess it could probably put half of its frontbench in one chamber and half in the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they would fit.
—They would fit and there would be room for more expansion depending on who next criticises the present leader.
—There is hope for us all.

—Even for the honourable member for Fisher. I believe the new system being proposed for question time will widen the scrutiny of government. It should allow more questions, as the honourable member for Bradfield noted earlier, compared with the recent experience, and it should effectively allow greater exposure of ministers other than the Prime Minister or the Treasurer, who tend to dominate in terms of questions asked.

PARA.TAB: Why is question time not working at the moment? A number of speakers have mentioned that and gone through some of the reasons. Certainly the length of answers is a problem and the previous speaker raised a number of statistics on that issue. There are some other statistics which I managed to get together this afternoon from Hansard which I think also point to some of the problems with question time.

In 1993, the period I have been here, several things occurred. During question time 208 points of order were raised—178 from the opposition, or 85.6 per cent. We heard 39 points of order from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer); 31 from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey); 25 from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard); and 12 from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who is in the chamber now. They make up the ton, with a total of 107 points of order.

There was a total of 50 warnings by the Speaker concerning unruly behaviour—49 for the opposition, or 98 per cent. Again the honourable member for Mayo figures prominently, with 11, as do the honourable member for O'Connor again, with 10, and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), with a recent burst, with five. They make up over half the total.

The total number of interjections for this period was 517. The opposition made 388—75 per cent of the interjections. It really shows that when we are talking about the length of answers we have also to take into account the points of order, the warnings necessary by the Speaker and the interjections. They all take up time. As can be shown, the opposition has done its best to take up as much time as possible.

One funny thing happened today in the parliament during question time. A question was directed to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), and he waxed lyrical about the senator who is soon to arrive here—probably—as the new member for Mackellar. A funny thing happened; for once there were no interjections. The opposition was quiet, listening intently except for the honourable member from the National Party, whose name escapes me, who made a comment about extending the time of the Leader of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are 146 members who your name escapes.
—That may be so. There are still more members on my side than there are on your side, fella.
—You're a oncer.

—Speaking of interjections, the total for the honourable member for Mayo has now gone to 12. That change to question time is something we have to trial. It has been said by some members of the opposition that this is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) running scared, but they do not ask him questions. If he is running scared from the opposition, I would hate to see him when he is going full bore.

PARA.TAB: Earlier tonight the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) asked why we would change the rules to assist the opposition when we have a comfortable majority. The simple reason is that we have a comfortable majority and do not feel threatened by the opposition, and I am very confident that I will not be a oncer.

The changes may not be perfect, they may require adjustment and change at the conclusion of the trial period, but I am very confident that I will be sitting on this side of the chamber after the next election and the honourable member for Mayo will prove to be a oncer as shadow Treasurer.

I worry that the opposition is once again showing a lack of flexibility and an inability to look to the future. If it continues to look backwards to its halcyon days under Fraser and Menzies, it can hardly expect to be taken seriously at the time of future elections.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! Before I call the next speaker, I point out that an interjection is only an interjection when it is acknowledged by the person being interjected on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin) was kind enough to pick up many of the interjections that we made from this side of the House. This side of the House, of course, is very concerned about a number of the changes being made by the government in the proposal before us.

PARA.TAB: I was somewhat heartened by a number of the comments made by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), a person I greatly respect. I must say that as a child I remained glued to the television set watching his exploits on the BP Pick-a-Box program. I was particularly interested to hear his comments that the changes before the House should alter the culture of question time. He—and I agree with him—expressed the hope that the changes will improve the professionalism of this House. He also said that what we are debating should not be considered to be something which cannot be altered in the future but something which we are trialing over the next session or so. He expressed the earnest hope that the alterations before the House have the potential to make a much more efficient and much more appropriate parliament.

I hope that the honourable member for Lalor is correct. I am not convinced that he is because the government, if it were serious about introducing all of these changes as trial changes, would have introduced sessional orders and not made permanent changes to the standing orders.

At this stage I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) on his committee report. It is sad that the government did not pick up all aspects of the committee's report and, indeed, of the minority dissenting report of members of the opposition. I take this opportunity to wish the honourable member well in his new appointment as High Commissioner to London.

The changes recommended in his report are wide ranging and there are many alterations. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in his contribution stressed that we will have to gauge how these alterations do or do not work in practice. The government must be fairly certain of a permanent status for a number of changes because, as I said before, the government altered the standing orders and did not merely introduce sessional orders.

Some of the suggested alterations are supported by the opposition. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has indicated that we are taking a quite reasonable approach. We do not believe that all of the standing orders of the House, all of the practices of the House, should remain immutable. We accept that as Australia goes on, as the years go on, we must, as a parliament, remain relevant to the Australian people.

I think it is a sad indictment of this place that parliament is held in total contempt by the ordinary people of Australia. People are disillusioned, they do not accept that there is fair debate in this chamber, they are cynical about the abuse which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) heaps on the opposition, and they believe that we act like a whole lot of schoolboys and schoolgirls. Clearly the system, as we understand it, has not been working in this House. That is why I was particularly pleased when the committee, chaired by the honourable member for Bonython, took this very important issue on board. I must say I was hopeful of substantial changes which would have improved the working of this place.

We are elected to this parliament to represent the people of Australia. This parliament and this House are greater than each and every one of us. I think it is a sad indictment of the government that question time has been allowed to descend into the shambles that we have seen since the election in March 1993 and certainly during the tenure of the former Speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay).

A number of the changes are not entirely controversial. It is clear that we cannot keep on sitting the hours that we have been sitting. It is absolutely crazy that the House of Representatives should sit until 11 o'clock at night, as has been the case during the time that I have been in the parliament. At times, of course, the government suspends the 11 o'clock rule and we are here until 1 o'clock, 2 o'clock or 3 o'clock. This is in a parliament which sits not many more than 60 days a year. Some years it has sat more and some years it has sat less. But it is not a place where the representatives of the people are given adequate time for debate.

We do not object to the proposal for the Speaker to have the opportunity to sin-bin offenders who have not incurred the wrath of the chair by being sent out for a longer period. We think that is important. We are worried about the proposal for a main committee. This could mean a further reduction of the importance of the role of the House of Representatives in the government of this country.

I was heartened by the remarks of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). He, like the honourable member for Lalor, suggested that the changes we are debating today are not necessarily changes that will stay in place forever. I certainly hope that the government will come back into this place after the sessional orders relating to question time expire in the middle of the year and say that we will have a reasonable question time.

The main objection that we in the opposition have is to the absolute travesty to which this government will be reducing question time. This parliament sits for not many more than 60 days a year. At present, the Prime Minister and the entire ministry must come in here and accept the questions that we ask—although, as we have seen through the sports rorts affair, ministers do not even try to answer the questions. They filibuster, avoid answering the questions and heap abuse on the opposition but, at the very least, they must be here. We are able to ask them questions. They do not endeavour to answer the questions, but the press are able, if they wish, to expose weak ministers—ministers who have done the wrong thing by not answering the questions that we, as representatives of the Australian people, ask at question time—in the media the next day.

I was somewhat amused by the remarks of the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) when he said that the Prime Minister will be making a sacrifice by not coming into question time every day. The people of Australia will certainly be pleased that the abuse we hear from the Prime Minister every day will not continue. But, with a parliament sitting only 60-odd days, it is important that the Prime Minister be here to be held accountable for the actions of his ministry, his government—the government of Australia—during all of those 60 days.

It is perfectly true that a rostering system of ministers applies in the House of Commons. But it has to be realised that the House of Commons sits for some 120 days a year. I understand that the Prime Minister in the United Kingdom parliament is available for about half of those days—about 60 days a year. This Prime Minister is proposing to be available for about 30 days a year. So the Prime Minister of Australia will be in the parliament of Australia one in 11 days out of 365 days a year to be held accountable for his actions. I do not think that is acceptable. It indicates that the Prime Minister is afraid to front the parliament.

When we look at the sports rorts affair and the $30 million of taxpayers' money which was spent largely in government electorates, we can see why the government is running scared. The only reason the Prime Minister will come in for half the time on Mondays and Thursdays is the backbench revolt by the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) and other members. If the Prime Minister had had his way, we would have seen him for a mere 15 days out of 365 days a year.

Every cloud has a silver lining, though, and one minor plus in having a rostering system is that when the Prime Minister is not here our frontbenchers and backbenchers will be able to target other weak ministers. Let us face it, the government's performance has been pretty tacky, ordinary and iffy. So, if the Prime Minister and Treasurer are not here, we will find that the other ministers on the front bench, many of whom ought not to be ministers, will be able to be subjected to scrutiny.

I am also concerned that we are guaranteed only about 14 questions. I gather the Canadian parliament has on average about 40 questions. From the time of Prime Minister Fraser to the time of Prime Minister Hawke, there has been a reduction in the number of questions asked per sitting day. After the present Prime Minister stabbed former Prime Minister Hawke in the back, fewer questions have been asked every day this parliament has sat. Consequently, major changes are being made to the standing orders and sessional orders of the House of Representatives.

The coalition comprises very reasonable people. We are prepared to take government at the next election. We hope to receive the support of the Australian people at the next election. I am quite confident that we will have the numbers to move on to the other side following the next election. Some of these changes are acceptable; some are disastrous. Honourable members ought to look at our program outlined by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) prior to the last election. We wanted to make this place work. We suggested that there should be an independent Speaker so that the Speaker, not as now, would be able to exercise free and open discretion without fear of being disciplined by his own party. We believe that is a very important step, and we hope that we will be able to implement it after the next election.

Sadly, some of these changes are disastrous. We think there are some reasonable people on the government benches. I believe that, if the Leader of the House had had his way, he would have brought in a more reasonable package than we are debating tonight. I hope that, when what we are saying about these disastrous changes comes to fruition, the government will reconsider its position, taking into account what we and the honourable member for Bennelong have said, so that the matters we are discussing tonight, which some members opposite say are on trial, are changed.

Quite frankly, members of all parties in this place owe it to the Australian people to make the House of Representatives work. We are supposed to be the representative house of this nation. When it is run, as it is, as a sausage machine, a sham, a place where democracy does not exist, where the opposition does not get a fair go and where ministers refuse to be accountable, we are bringing the entire House of Representatives, the entire parliament of this country, into disrepute. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you and the government to look at what we are saying with a view to bringing in worthwhile and genuine reform to improve the very flawed package which the minister has brought before the House today.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I pay tribute to the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), for leading the committee, of which I was delighted to be a part, in the production of its report, About time: bills, questions and working hours, proposing a range of procedural reforms to the parliament. It is very gratifying to see the contribution of the honourable member for Bonython over a long period in this parliament culminating in the major effort involved in the production of the procedure committee report that has been so roundly adopted in many aspects and which will be a testament to his parliamentary career in Australia long after he has left the chamber.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased that the government has taken up so many of the recommendations contained in the procedure committee report. The reforms are trial measures at this stage, but they will ensure the ongoing dynamic relevance of this parliament as the fundamental democratic institution of the people of Australia. The important question that we should ask is: how do we ensure that the parliament continues to be the fulcrum for democratic process in this nation? I think these reforms are sensible and constructive in the way they ensure the management of legislation and in the way accountability of the executive to the House is retained.

I am particularly pleased with the recommendations on the main committee. The other change that has not been talked about too much in the course of the debate is the enlarged role for standing committees in some of the legislative processes that will be part of the new parliamentary standing orders. I note, in particular, the new arrangements for second reading debates. In many cases, there will be scope for standing committees to give advisory reports on legislation in a short period after the second reading. Hopefully, these suggestions and contributions will help to ensure that the value of that legislation is enhanced, thereby enlarging further the parliamentary committee process which has developed in the House of Representatives in a substantial fashion in the last few years.

We then turn to the question of the main committee itself. Many speakers have said it is a shame that there is not more recognition of the fact that there is, in relation to much of the legislation on significant issues, not a great amount of division between government and opposition. This second chamber provides a mechanism for a broadening of the scope, particularly for backbench members of parliament, to make a substantial contribution in areas of policy. These may not be the ones that create high temperature debate but they are nevertheless important to large elements of the Australian community. The second chamber will be a place where they can be fully debated and scrutinised and where suggestions can be brought forward by members of parliament. I think they are very constructive changes.

The reform of sitting hours has been spoken about by many speakers. I think change is long overdue. Those who talk about the hours of parliament that have operated `since I was a boy listening to parliament' will say that there are historical arrangements for travel to Canberra and will give a host of other reasons. I think it is time to recognise the range of pressures which exist in this building on parliamentary sitting days and to try and ensure that we make all aspects of the parliament building as productive as we possibly can when parliament is in session. I am sure the reforms to the hours are a recognition of that. They are also a recognition of the pressures that apply to members' families and I think the changes will be welcome from that point of view as well.

As part of the changes, we will be sitting both Mondays in each two weeks of sittings rather than only on the second Monday, as has been the case in recent years. That extra day will provide time for private members' business and give individuals adequate opportunity to raise issues pertinent to their electorates. At the same time, it will provide scope for the broadening of the processes relating to question time.

I believe the reform of question time will prove to be very substantial and constructive for the parliament. I watched the proceedings in the House of Commons and tried to get a feel for the difference in their approach. It is certainly my view that the change recommended and enlarged by the government in its response to the report is very significant and will be seen as very worth while. It really will mean a return to the sorts of question times I listened to on radio when I was younger. There will be a far more lively and better atmosphere about question time because the scope of questions, the diversity of answers and the flexibility that will provide will be very helpful not only to the procedures of the parliament but also to the community's perception. I think the accountability process will be enhanced into the bargain.

It is very clear that over recent years question time has become a matter for one or two policy or perhaps personality issues and for one or two of the leading players on either side of the chamber. That is not the sort of question time we will get when we have the roster arrangement as has been outlined. My observation of the House of Commons and the way it operates was that that is certainly true. I do not think any loss of accountability occurred as a result of that. I can see only good coming in terms of the breadth of policy issues that members will be able to raise in question time. For all those reasons, I think these are very positive changes indeed.

I have no doubt that the adversarial aspects of question time will remain. That is a fundamental part of our democracy and I do not think we should be wanting to walk away from that—and we are not. There will definitely be scope for members to cover a whole range of issues which are of great interest to the people of Australia, not necessarily just the few headline items of the media in Canberra with the sort of herd mentality much of its agenda has. Certainly the televising of parliament and the capacity of members to ask questions that may be on the minds of many in the community outside Canberra, in the cities and regions of Australia, will provide a much more productive atmosphere and improve the way parliament is viewed across the country.

The types of reforms outlined are very welcome. No doubt there are always arguments about length of answers to questions and the nature of many of the questions. I certainly think it is often the short, sharp, succinct answers to questions that are the most effective. I am sure the change in our approach to question time with the rostering system will be much more conducive to the whole community feeling that, if there are matters of particular importance on their minds, members can actually come in here and raise those issues with relevant ministers, be they matters relating to telecommunications, veterans' affairs or whatever. Matters relating to social security entitlements and so on can be just as pertinent to many citizens of Australia as the one or two issues that might be the priorities of a tactics committee or a particular agenda that might be pursued at a given point in time. For those sorts of reasons, I think the changes to question time will enhance the democratic institution we are part of.

As others have said, we certainly should take the privilege of being here very seriously indeed. I do not believe these reforms do anything other than maintain the continuing vitality that is important to treating that privilege rightfully. I am sure that is what these reforms will lead to. In any event, the important issue is that they will be tried. They are the first major and substantial reforms of House of Representatives procedure in a long time. I think they are worth trying and giving full effect to and I look forward to their success.

Achieving a common approach and the sort of response that we hoped would be forthcoming with some bipartisanship proved quite difficult for the Procedure Committee. I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) is in the chamber and I pay tribute to him for his efforts in support of much of those discussions.

We really do want to ensure that our constituents genuinely feel that their respective member of parliament has the capacity at the peak times of the day, when interest is highest, such as at question time, to raise issues of pertinence and relevance to them. Unless that can be done, I think question time will just proceed to be a sort of gladiatorial contest. That might be good for theatre—I am not going to suggest that it does not help to shape many of our attitudes within this chamber—but one of the things we notice quite clearly when we get back to the electorates and talk to people at schools—

TALK.START.PARA: —Parramatta Marist?

—Even at Parramatta Marist, as the minister has rightly interjected. We would like to see the issues on our agenda debated a little more, which is not happening very often. Question time is so highly structured and geared that the opportunity is not there for interventions which are meaningful to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the honourable member for Bonython. He has made a great contribution throughout his parliamentary career and has ensured that this item is on the agenda. I am very pleased to pay tribute to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) who has had the foresight to bring this matter on for debate. It is a comprehensive response to the report of the Procedure Committee. I am also very pleased he has arrived in the chamber at this time. I look forward to the continuation of the discussion.
Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)at the time of commencement of operation of standing orders relating to the appointment of the Deputy Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker, the occupant of the office of Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees immediately before that time of commencement shall be appointed Deputy Speaker; and
(2)the provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing and sessional orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing and sessional orders.

Very briefly, this motion confirms the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) continuing as Deputy Speaker, otherwise there would be a nasty hiatus in his salary between now and when we would have a chance to elect him. He will be pleased to know that this will not occur upon passage of this motion. It will effectively ensure that the honourable member for Scullin is, on the arrangements, the first Deputy Speaker. That will leave a vacancy in second Deputy Speaker, which will be filled when the opposition wants to fill it, after it has gone through its party room processes. As you would be aware, Mr Speaker, there is agreement that debate should be able to continue over the content of all three motions while debate on this motion continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) for looking after me. He looks after everybody on this side of the House. I am privileged to have the opportunity to speak about this report. As a member of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I was involved in the preparation of this report, About Time. I am not going to repeat all of the things that have been said by honourable members on both sides of the House about the details of the report. Suffice it to say that this must be pretty much of a record for getting a government response, because the 1986 report of the Procedure Committee is still waiting on a response from the government; perhaps it has been superseded by this report.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), not only for his parliamentary service over so many years but also for the vision that he had for reforming this parliament. He managed to enthuse all other members of the Procedure Committee with that same vision to reform the parliament. There is no denying that the parliament is in need of reform. Another speaker made reference to visitors to this place. I find that when a group of schoolchildren come in here to see question time they say, `Mr Nehl, we would not be allowed to act like that at school'. I try to explain the drama and the theatre that is involved, the reason for that being that if one sits there like a dummy when so many lies are being told across the floor, the whole of Australia sees them and hears them on television and they therefore become truth, so one has to react. Question time will always have that degree of rowdiness, if you like, but it does stand in need of reform. At every meeting of the Procedure Committee as we were working to develop this report, the honourable member for Bonython said that we had to have a situation where there was give and take, where we would end up with a package which we hoped would be acceptable to the executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —You give and I'll take.

—The honourable member says, `You give and I'll take'. Unfortunately, that does seem to be part of the result that we have had. While I endorse almost every single recommendation in this report, I do not endorse what has been presented to us today in the new sessional orders and the new standing orders, the new arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will recall that a minority report was put in by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). I did not join with them in signing that minority report for two reasons. Firstly, I believe that it was an absolute act of futility because there was no way that a minority or dissenting report was going to have any chance of influencing the executive. Secondly, I believed, along with the honourable member for Bonython, that we stood the best chance of having the package adopted if we could present it in a thoroughly bipartisan manner with support from both sides of the House. We worked up a compromise. There was a lot of genuine give and take within the committee. The compromise is this report, About Time. But I am afraid that this report bears very little resemblance to what is before us today. It is quite sad that on the honourable member for Bonython's last day, what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has done is insulting to the committee and, quite frankly, is like a slap in the face with a wet Kimbie for the honourable member for Bonython. Again we have seen the Prime Minister's arrogance at work, with him saying what he wants and to hell with what the parliament wants.

I am not going to go on further, except to say that this is a good report. It was a compromise report. It did satisfy the vision of the honourable member for Bonython, and it was a sound vision. Had we ended up with what the report said, it would not have satisfied me, it would not have satisfied people on both sides of the House, but it would have been a darned sight better than the arrogant response of the Prime Minister which has emasculated this report. As I said, it has been like a slap in the face with a wet Kimbie for the honourable member for Bonython.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) uses wet or dry Kimbies. I certainly do not share that particular view. As a member of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I want to make a few comments. I congratulate the honourable member for Bonython and the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) on their outstanding valedictory speeches. It is a pity that those speeches were made before this debate because no doubt the honourable member for Bonython, as the chairman of the committee, would have liked to participate in this debate.

PARA.TAB: I would like to respond very much in spirit to the remarks made by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who was a member of the committee. I agree with him that, under the leadership of the honourable member for Bonython, members of the committee took very seriously the task of reforming the standing orders and sessional orders of the parliament to make it more relevant, more responsible and more accountable.

There are various interpretations of the treatment of the report. I have said on a number of occasions—and, by and large, most members would agree—that the report was a good one. It is also fair to say that members of the committee were very concerned that we had to tread warily, that ultimately the decisions about this report would not be our own. We had to take our mind's eye to the position of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the cabinet and their likely attitude to the proposals as much as we necessarily had to take into account the views of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the opposition leadership team.

Originally, some time ago, I looked upon the proposition of rostering with a great deal of suspicion. But for quite some time now I have been very much a keen advocate of giving it a go. It is fair to say that the committee recognised some of the resistance to rostering and therefore wanted to offer a limited experiment of rostering. The argument is that we have not had a limited experiment, we have had a full-blown implementation of rostering of question time and that this is somehow outrageous and arrogant. I do not think so. I cannot say that I am dreadfully disappointed that we have gone from a limited experiment of rostering to a full-blown trial.

The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has indicated that not only will we put the standing and sessional orders into practice but by mid-year we will want to review them to see how they have worked. Whilst we will not be able to reduce the hurly-burly of question time, opening up question time for the opportunity to question a wider range of members and—as some have dared say—actually allowing backbench members to ask their own questions can only be good for the institution of parliament.

I can well remember coming here as a new member and rushing up to Mick Young, the then Leader of the House, with some proposed questions. The response was invariably the same: `Look, they're great questions, Roger, but I don't think we'll ask them at this time'. In fact, I never got to ask any of them at any time.

If I have one regret about the contribution of honourable members—maybe even on both sides of the House—it is that we still seem to be coming at this from a party political point of view, a partisan point of view, rather than standing up as members of parliament who are really interested in the institution of parliament and not in the dominance of whichever executive we happen to be affiliated with. An example is the contribution of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). I thought he was going to go on to say that this change to sessional and standing orders would lead to a breakdown in family life, to more crime and to an increase in unemployment, and that it would worsen the trade deficit and drive down the dollar—so extreme were his views of the impact of the changes. Of course, they will not be anything like that.

I regret that I was not able to hear all the contributions in the debate, but I particularly want to respond to a point raised by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It is a view which is consistently expressed by the opposition. Maybe oppositions always express this point of view. It is that we should sit more frequently. We have to understand that, as much as members of this House really enjoy being here and get a sense that they are part of an institution when they come to parliament itself, ordinary members of parliament win their elections not in this place but back in the electorates. As the techniques of campaigning have become more refined and more sophisticated, it is the party apparatus and members' self-survival instincts that dictate that they need to maximise the amount of time they spend in their electorates. I would happily embrace the thought of more frequent sittings, but I suspect that it is impossible, given the demands of our electorates and given the demands of campaigning techniques.

Reservations have been raised by opposition members about the second chamber. Perhaps I can understand and respect those points of view, but I think it is worth while giving it a go. Let us see how it works. With a bit of goodwill on both sides of this House—and I know that there is a lot—I think that it has every prospect of success. It is also arguably a matter for increased micro-economic reform. We will be sitting for the same amount of time and hopefully getting more legislation through. I have said previously that, whilst the Senate rejects the mechanism of delegated legislation, it will always be the case that a lot of legislation needs to go through.

Perhaps for me the most disappointing issue as to the way the government took up the recommendations was in the time for and the number of questions. I remain unapologetic for saying that I think the suggestion of 16 questions was a good idea. The way the committee had linked the time for questions and the number of questions was such that we wanted to put pressure on ministers to restrict their answers and make them more relevant. How? If the answers were longwinded and irrelevant, I am sure the Prime Minister would very quickly get frustrated sitting in this place for an hour and 15 minutes or an hour and a half listening to those answers. It would be a matter of self-discipline.

I was aghast when the Senate put a time limit of four minutes on the answers of ministers. I thought limiting the answers of ministers was an outrageous proposition, but experience has shown that it has worked well. Parliamentarians on both sides of the chamber may need to address either a limitation or the original mechanism proposed in the report. I strongly endorse these changes. I think it is to the credit of the honourable member for Bonython that this report, unlike so many other reports, has not languished without a response but has been hastily implemented. I compliment my colleagues on the other side, as well as on my own, who served on the committee and served the parliament well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity this evening to read into the record a letter that I received yesterday from a local solicitor. I raised the matter informally a moment ago with the responsible minister. In part, the letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I have some clients that have instructed me to raise with you the current discrimination against them. In essence the situation is this: my client Jilau Parker is an Aboriginal woman. She married a white Australian. My client resided on her homelands at Kintore in the Northern Territory. Being both public minded and committed to free enterprise, they established a local community store and they had goods transported from various parts of Australia to the store for sale to the local community. The store was trading successfully. There has been no allegation of profiteering.

PARA.TAB: The Central Land Council has decided that the local community should establish a store in their own right. My clients have no objection to that, as they recognise that the principle of free enterprise requires competition. Without due cause or justification, without fair notice to either my clients or the other members of the community, the Central Land Council called a meeting, allegedly at which a decision was reached that my client was not allowed to continue to reside at Kintore. Furthermore, the store was to be closed.

Section 19 of the Northern Territory Lands Act 1967, on my interpretation on the specific words used in it, makes provision for an Aboriginal person to be able to apply to the Central Land Council for a lease from which they intend to conduct a business.

SPEECH.PARA: My clients and I have without fail consistently and continually asked for the normal commercial negotiating process to commence with advice from the Central Land Council as to what terms and conditions they would require my clients to comply with for the purpose of them granting a lease to my clients to conduct a business from. The Central Land Council has consistently refused to do so and in its most recent letter says that I have misinterpreted section 19. This really is a political hot cake because it combines those elements of discrimination and restrictive trade practices that are no longer tolerated by community opinion.

This evening in this chamber I have spoken informally to the responsible minister. I hope he will take the matters up when he can. I look forward to some resolution of what seems to me to be a totally anomalous situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay a brief tribute to the Australian film producer and director K. G. Hall, who died in Sydney on 8 February, only a fortnight before his 93rd birthday. Kenneth George Hall was born in Sydney in February 1901. He started as a reporter and then moved to publicity and advertising. He worked for Union Theatres in the days of silent movies, when Australia had one of the highest proportions in the world of cinema seats to population. In the transition to talkies, he ran Cinesound—Greater Union's newsreel outlet and the rival of Twentieth Century Fox—from 1931 to 1956.

PARA.TAB: Kenneth Hall was then appointed by Sir Frank Packer as the first chief executive of Channel 9 and stayed there for a decade, from 1957 to 1966. But he will be remembered as the producer-director of no fewer than 18 feature films, the first of which was produced in the silent era in 1927. Most of his films were made in the early period of talking films, at a time when nobody other than Charles and Elsa Chauvel were making features here. The films were straightforward, crude but forceful, with clearly delineated characters. But they stood up then—most of them were profitable—and they still look good. They also provide a priceless glimpse of the old traditional, monocultural Australia. Hall had an eye for talent. Gough Whitlam made his film debut—admittedly in a minor part—in Broken Melody, which appeared in 1938.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about you?

—I will come to that in a minute. His last film, Smithy, which was the story of Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith and starred Ron Randell, featured Billy Hughes, still the member for West Sydney, in a cameo role. Perhaps his best-remembered work was the series based on Steele Rudd's Dad and Dave, with Bert Bailey as Dad, beginning in 1932 with On Our Selection and ending with Dad Rudd, MP, so we can see there was a definite move upward.

PARA.TAB: The Silence of Dean Maitland, a 1934 movie which was a remake of a Raymond Longford silent movie, was a lurid success. Hall aimed at a popular market and he generally hit the target. He despised what he regarded as the pretentiousness of the art film. In 1943, he produced a newsreel shot in New Guinea by Damien Parer—a relative of Senator Warwick Parer—called Kokoda Front Line. It won an academy award, the first for an Australian production.

In his later years as a television executive, Hall poured large buckets on those brave souls who were attempting to revive—exhume might be the word—the Australian feature film industry. It was hard enough after television began here in 1956 to even keep a significant level of local feature production. At one stage, Hector Crawford produced more programs than did all the other Australian producers combined.

In his book, Directed by Ken G. Hall, which was published in 1976, Hall attacked the Australian Film Development Corporation and the Australian Film and Television School. He reserved particular contempt for Phillip Adams and your humble servant, Mr Speaker, for trying to create, or revive, an Australian film culture aimed at helping Australians understand the new world they were living in and communicating that view of themselves to the world. I think we were right; he was convinced we were wrong. Nevertheless, I had and still have great respect for what he achieved, almost single-handedly, for about 15 years in film production: keeping some tradition alive. There was no humbug about him; you knew where you stood. He was awarded an OBE in 1973 and, at the age of 85, an AO in 1986. He loved Australia and he gave it all he had. Regardless of whether he was friend or foe, we are diminished by his passing.

Since this is a day for commemoration, I point out that this is the anniversary of the death of the great Aleksander Pushkin in a duel in 1837. As a mark of respect, I will refrain from reciting his poem The Raven—`Voren' in the original Russian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you might recall that on 3 October last year, a major disaster in the form of a flood occurred in north-east Victoria. At the time of the flood, it was described by officers of the State Emergency Service as the worst major disaster since Ash Wednesday. On the day of the flood—and every day after, it seems—I have been in touch with the government; with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and ministers, seeking assistance for the victims of the floods. Assistance has been given in a large number of areas by the state government and in some areas by the federal government. I want to place on record my appreciation to those governments for their assistance.

PARA.TAB: However, consistently since the floods, I have raised a number of grave anomalies that exist with respect to major disaster policies and laws. For example, because—thank goodness—no-one was killed or injured in these floods, although major widespread disastrous damage was done, the federal legislation enabling declaration of a major disaster was not triggered. Had there been a death or an injury, it would have been—that is beyond doubt.

The government—and I thank it for this—has now advised me that it has accepted my submissions that the law is wrong and inflexible. I understand that the government proposes to bring amendments in, during this session as I understand it, to remove that restriction and allow a declaration of a major disaster to be made, even when there is no death or injury, provided there is widespread and substantial damage. I welcome that, and I only wish it had been made on the day of the disaster.

But there are a large number of people who still have not recovered from the damage caused to their lives and property, such as small business people, families, individuals and farmers. I make a plea to the government that, in preparation of the legislation—which I hope will come in very quickly—it will see fit to declare the major disaster legislation to be made effective from 3 October last year. This will enable those people who need extra assistance to receive the benefit of the extra assistance that is available for a major disaster declaration, such as was made with respect to the bushfires in New South Wales. I support the government's announcement to virtually triple major disaster relief payments: up to $2,000 for couples and about $200 per child.

In Benalla, for example, the maximum amount of assistance received for flood damage was $600. In many cases, these families have sustained greater damage and have no insurance at all—because insurance is not available for flood damage but it is for fire damage—yet they received only about $600 assistance. So there is a grave anomaly existing in this area with respect to the treatment of Australians affected by a major disaster.

I requested this help from day one. Therefore, I am not asking for retrospective legislation as such, because my request has been a continual one since the disaster. The government has responded and said it will bring in the change to the law, so the case is made out. I hope I will be able to get the support of all honourable members of the House—that is why I am raising this issue tonight before we adjourn—that, between now and a fortnight's time when discussions take place in respect of this legislation, the legislation will be backdated to 3 October last year. I have not got a costing for it but I can assure honourable members that my request is a responsible one. I believe that the extra amount payable by the Commonwealth, if the flood is retrospectively declared a disaster, will be relatively small and certainly nowhere near the amount required to be paid with respect to the bushfires in New South Wales.

However, I am prepared to assist the government to do its research and to come up with figures if necessary to assist in the costing of that. I make a plea before we adjourn tonight that government members support me and do what they can to bring this legislation in from 3 October last year. I can tell the House that all Australians, wherever they are, would support the government. The important thing is that, when there is a major disaster in Australia, we are all Australians together; we all stick together and we do want to see all Australians treated equally. There has been only 100-odd days since the floods. Honourable members should remember that I started to ask for assistance on the day of the floods, and I have continually asked for it since then. Regrettably, it has taken all this time for the government to decide that the law is wrong and that it will change the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions in this place we have had some very serious debates about social security matters and, in particular, the impact of certain measures that the government has taken to target benefits. I want to raise this evening a concern that I have with regard to the social security system which impacts on every recipient of social security.

PARA.TAB: One of my constituents, Mr Les Watts, an active community member who works very closely with aged people and veterans, has raised with me his concern about the correspondence process that the Department of Social Security engages in when it is seeking information from its clients—the people who receive pensions, the unemployment benefit or other forms of income support from the government. Mr Watts has raised this with me because one of the people whom he has helped, and continues to help, is Mrs Mary Cleary, who is almost 80 years old, has considerable vision difficulties and is suffering from dementia. She is an age pension recipient.

Recently, she received a letter from the Department of Social Security's client services section demanding that she complete a client information update within 14 days or face the risk of losing her pension. Several days after Mrs Cleary received this letter, her family read it and immediately approached Mr Watts to express some concern at the possibility of Mrs Cleary losing her pension because she did not complete this form and send it in straightaway. This is a problem with the processes of the Department of Social Security in its correspondence with clients.

When I sought some advice from the office of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) about the schedule of correspondence that comes out from the department, I ascertained that annually the Department of Social Security sends out 80 million pieces of correspondence to its recipients. Some of those letters are several pages long and require quite extensive reading and understanding in order for the client to get to the end of the letter and work out what he or she has to do. It is an issue that I have some concern about.

I believe that the Department of Social Security needs to undertake a major review of the contents of its letters and the way in which it seeks information. I find totally unsatisfactory the process which demands that people respond within 14 days or lose their pension. The fact that we are sending out so many pieces of correspondence to recipients is a bit over the top. We need to review the amount and content of correspondence that we are sending to social security recipients.

Sending out all this information costs the taxpayer a lot of money, and the information is irrelevant for very many constituents. It is also a demeaning process, particularly for people suffering from literacy or vision difficulties or those in nursing homes or hostels who are having trouble coping with their responsibilities in terms of their personal financial affairs. In those situations, they have to rely on the advice and support of others to deal with those basic things. That is not something that many people like to do. We need to have a major review.

This is an issue that I have raised also with the Aboriginal community. Last year when our committee was collecting evidence in our access and equity inquiry, we found that the same correspondence is going out to remote Aboriginal communities. The department is demanding that Aboriginal people who live in, for example, Meekatharra or other very isolated places tell them about their shares and investments. It asks them for information updates on how their investment portfolios are going. It is a ridiculous situation. The department is not making any real assessments about the practicality of its correspondence.

I request the Minister for Social Security to undertake a major review of the correspondence and ensure that people like Mrs Cleary are not troubled again by such threatening correspondence. In that way, the matter will be dealt with in a more fair and rational manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the call of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) for a review of the Department of Social Security's excessive correspondence. I do so on behalf of not only social security recipients but also those in the area of employment.

PARA.TAB: One of my constituents is a seasonal employer of casual employees. He spends most of his waking hours at his business, filling out forms related to social security payments for former employees. As he has pointed out to me, he spends a lot of his time doing bureaucratic work for the Department of Social Security, a burden which he carries himself.

The honourable member for Moreton was also helpful in relation to the debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure, About time, when he talked about the excessive use of the guillotine. I appreciated hearing his comments, because he was quite emphatic that he felt the guillotine was being overused. I have to agree with that.

The guillotining of bills is a fairly recent phenomenon. In 1986, 40 bills were guillotined. In 1992, that had increased to 130 bills out of 284 bills that were introduced into the House. As my colleague has rightly pointed out, it is quite clear that the badly programmed legislation that is brought into the House is triggering the excessive use of the guillotine. An enormous amount of individual legislation is coming into this place. The United Kingdom parliament has 50 to 60 bills per annum. The Australian average is about 215.

I made comments earlier today about the role of the main committee and some of my concerns about the principles behind the establishment of that committee. The quite clear conclusion that can be drawn from the excessive amount of legislation that is being pushed through this House is that we need to sit more often. Quite clearly, we need to sit more often. We sit around a half to a third of the time of the United Kingdom parliament and certainly half as many days as the Canadian parliament.

In the circumstances of this enormous amount of legislation, I might add that, in the first decade of federation, we had 23 acts per annum, which amounted to debating time of something like 25 hours per act per member. In 1992, 264 acts were considered, meaning two hours per act per member debating time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Productivity.
—That facetious comment is typical of those on the government side. They are not interested in real debate about legislation.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that you are here this evening, Mr Speaker, because you may recall that I asked you a question without notice about questions on notice. You will recall that I have had some concerns about this matter. Those members of the committee would know that I had sufficient concerns to have the matter raised as part of our deliberations leading to the report, About time.
My view is that questions on notice are an important part of the process of responsible government and accountability. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) invoked Malcolm Fraser when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . members who genuinely wanted information, as opposed to publicity, should place their questions on notice for a written answer.
All we asked in our report was for this paragraph to be added to standing order 150:

If after the expiration of 90 days of a question first appearing on the Notice Paper a reply has not been delivered to the Clerk, the Member who asked the question may rise in his or her place . . . and request the Speaker to write to the Minister concerned, seeking reasons for the delay in answering.

This is an old recommendation from a previous report of the Standing Committee on Procedure, yet we still have not had the standing orders amended to provide for a more swift answering process to questions placed on notice. If after all this we are going to be told that if we genuinely want answers we should put questions on the Notice Paper, and we have to wait three, five, six, nine or 12 months for an answer, I ask: how on earth can the government claim to be in any way accountable to the people of Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the United States joined the growing number of states that have recognised Macedonia. Australia is rapidly running out of excuses for not recognising Macedonia. First, we said that we were waiting for the European Community to do so. Now, all the European Community states have granted recognition to Macedonia. When they did this, we then said that we were waiting for the United States. Yesterday, the United States recognised Macedonia. Now what is our excuse? We timidly do not want to upset various groups in this country.

PARA.TAB: With the recognition by the United States, all members of the United Nations Security Council have recognised Macedonia, as indeed has the United Nations itself. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) knows, as does the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, that Macedonia meets all the requirements for recognition under international law. It is particularly offensive that the Macedonian people in Australia are not even permitted an office here that could carry out consular facilities. I know that you are aware of this, Mr Speaker.

Indeed, we Australians have made it as difficult as possible for law-abiding Australians of Macedonian descent to obtain even a visa. They cannot obtain a visa in this country to visit Macedonia. They cannot settle the legal claims that have arisen in that country, including property rights. We have done everything we can to frustrate the Macedonian community. One must ask why. Macedonia is a threat to no-one. It is a small country that has valiantly sought international recognition and now most countries in the world, with the regrettable exception of Australia, have recognised it.

Not for the first time I urge the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs to immediately recognise the sovereign and independent state of Macedonia under the name Macedonia. Mr Speaker, you, coming from the Illawarra as I do, would know that thousands of Macedonians have made their home in Australia and in particular in our own region. In fact, you and I perhaps represent more Macedonians in our electorates than any other electorate in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Queanbeyan.

—I recognise that there are many Macedonians in Queanbeyan so ably represented by my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. Indeed, the electorate of Moore also has a large Macedonian community. Mr Speaker, I am sure you would agree with me that those Australians of Macedonian decent have proved to be excellent citizens and have contributed greatly to our society. We owe it to them to recognise Macedonia immediately, under the name `Macedonia'. I again appeal to the Prime Minister and the foreign minister to do this. We owe them nothing less.

—Over the Christmas period I spent some time in Asia looking at the development of industry in that area and comparing it with industry in this country. I would have to say that many opportunities exist in Asia for Australian companies. It concerns me that, as a country, we really have not developed the links with Asia in the way we should have done.

PARA.TAB: There has been a lot of rhetoric with respect to development in those areas. Certainly that development has been occurring in some areas with larger companies but there are also many opportunities for smaller companies to develop links in Asia and to expand their manufacturing bases. One of the things that is very difficult for manufacturers in this country is to amortise the costs of their equipment across their production runs in Australia, because we have relatively small production runs compared with those that are available to manufacturers in the South-East Asian and Asian regions.

If companies are able to buy new equipment and then, after they have used the equipment in the Australian area, pass it to companies in which they are joint venture partners in Asia, those companies are able to get a longer life out of the equipment and therefore amortise the costs of it over a longer period of time. This will give them opportunities firstly to move the equipment down the line—something the Japanese have been able to do for many years and which we have not quite picked up the skills of yet—and, secondly, to give them access to markets for products of higher technology that they develop in this country.

I would say at this stage that some effort really needs to be put in within the government on this area to ensure that these companies, who have worked very hard to develop technologies, do in fact make use of those technologies outside this country. There are two elements to this: firstly, it allows them to provide newer technologies in this country to compete with imports on the local front; and, secondly, by passing those technologies down the line it allows them the opportunity to compete in international markets, which is something that we as a country certainly need to develop.

There are a number of problem areas that companies have in being able to compete in Australia. The overheads that companies actually have control of never cease to amaze me. It is in the order of 25 per cent. The rest of the overheads are set by some form of statute whether it be by the taxing system that we have in the country, by the regulated wage systems that we have, or by the cost of transport, communications and whatever. Within that 25 per cent of overheads over which they have flexibility, it is very difficult for many of them to be able to be competitive in this country.

That is why I am eager to see some of the micro-economic reforms, about which we see a lot of rhetoric from the government, but very little action, develop. Earlier this week a number of our members indicated that one of the real problems we have is that, whilst the government continually talks about micro-economic reform that we are achieving—I acknowledge that we are achieving micro-economic reform—that micro-economic reform is not keeping pace with the micro-economic reform that is occurring amongst our competitors. We really do need to address that problem and recognise that we must at least keep pace so that we do not fall behind in the way that many of the industries, particularly the manufacturing industry, are at the moment.

I recognise that in some areas of industry, such as in agriculture and in mining, we are in fact ahead and that is shown by our results. However, we are having many difficulties in the area of real manufacturing products. It is important for us to look at these areas and give opportunities to some of the smaller businesses in this country. There are some 800,000 small businesses in this country. If we could give them confidence and provide one extra place of employment in each of those businesses, the unemployment that we have in this country today would be almost non-existent.

I hope that we can undertake a bipartisan exercise in this area. Certainly we on this side of the House would be happy to support the government in trying to improve the opportunities for small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the dying moments of this adjournment debate I thought I would resurrect the great issue of the day in this House which is, I suppose, the great symbol of this government's decline in terms of its ability to be accountable to the people of Australia. That issue, of course, is Kellygate, or the sports rorts affair. It was Lord Grey who said, `The lamps are going out all over Europe' and Lord Acton who said, `Power tends to corrupt and absolute power corrupts absolutely'. The problem is that, as the government has had five successive election victories—
—You learnt that from the bagman in the west, didn't you?
—Order! The parliamentary secretary need not prompt the honourable member for Moore.

—I do not need any prompting, Mr Speaker. I must say that the whole theme of this particular scandal, and it has now evolved into scandalous proportions—last night's revelations about the whiteboard will become part of Australian political history and, in fact, probably would rank alongside some of the all-time greats from the past.
—Tell us some of those.
—I was just trying to think of a few all-time greats. I was going to say the Rex Connor affair—
—Leave the dead alone.

—No, we are talking about history. It is sometimes very hard when we are talking about history because obviously we will be dealing with people who have passed on. I am just saying that in this case the Kellygate affair will become part of Australian political history. It will be a milestone. In years to come the great grandchildren of those opposite will say to them, `Great Grandad, what were you doing when this sports rorts affair was going on?' They will be able to tell them. They will say, `I built sports buildings'.
—They will want to know whether you had a whiteboard.
—They will say, `Did you have a whiteboard Grandpa? What did the whiteboard in your office say?'
—And was it electronic?

—Quite so. As the shadow minister asks, was it electronic, did it print out? I must say that, of all the things that I have heard during this sports rorts affair—and it is now of historical proportions—there was a terrific cartoon in the Canberra Times, I think it was. This cartoon showed a little group of young chaps aged 10 or 11 all in their football gear. The minister came along and said to them, `And which electorate do you play for?' I thought that was one of the best little cartoons about the whole affair.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned during the 90-second statements, in my state it can be seen quite clearly in the two seats that the Labor government needed to hold, Canning and Swan, that bribes—that is all they are—were offered to those swinging voters in those electorates of 1,844—

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on record my personal appreciation of the efforts of the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett). Having come into this place as a marginal member, I particularly appreciated the honourable member for Bonython coming to my electorate over the years to help me with the difficult things, especially in the days of health reform, which he did for many people. He is held in high regard on both sides of the House and I do not think one could walk away from this parliament with a better reputation than that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, you would appreciate that, in what is called the tapestry of politics, there is always a tale or two to tell. I remember a specific instance at the time of the 1990 election campaign, when we were not as popular with the pharmacists as we might have been. The honourable member for Bonython came to my electorate on a Sunday afternoon. He had a terrible cold. He had been on a plane for hours and he needed a box of tissues. The only place in which he could buy them was a pharmacy in Melton, which is in my electorate.

There were two pharmacies next door to each other, and both of them were open. The honourable member for Bonython looked at the names and said, `An old mate I went to school with owns that pharmacy. We'll go in there because at least I'll get a decent reception'. So we went in to buy a box of tissues and he asked the person who served him, `By the way, where's Frank?'. Frank had passed on six months earlier and the person who had since taken over the pharmacy was not in the least impressed with the honourable member for Bonython being in the shop. He was prepared to sell him the box of tissues, but he gave us a little piece of his mind on the way out again.
The honourable member for Bonython did all of those things. He goes with our best wishes. On behalf of many of my colleagues who have worked with him at the grassroots

SPEECH.PARA: level as well as at the policy level within the government, we wish him well and we look forward to meeting him in the future.
